HEADLINE: Koch Outlines 'Painful' Plan To Close Deficit

BYLINE: By RICHARD LEVINE

 BODY:
Declaring that ''bad news can't wait,'' Mayor Edward I. Koch yesterday presented a program of spending cuts, fee increases and other measures to close a $530 million budget deficit this year and reduce an even larger one that had been expected next year.
Mr. Koch said the cuts were painful but necessary. The Mayor, however, will not be in office long enough to carry many of them out, and he acknowledged that his successor might choose to change or halt his program.
But at a City Hall news conference at which he outlined the fiscal problems facing the city, Mr. Koch warned, ''The law charges the mayor, whoever that individual is, to have a balanced budget.'' 
Asked about the Koch plan later in the day, David N. Dinkins, the Manhattan Borough President and Democratic mayoral nominee, said he wanted ''time and opportunity'' to examine Mr. Koch's recommendations agency by agency, adding that he would do it as quickly as he could. $201 Million in Spending Cuts His Republican and Liberal Party opponent, Rudolph W. Giuliani, said that he supported the Mayor's ''forthright response.'' ''I am pleased that he chose not to raise taxes,'' Mr. Giuliani said, ''and instead made his difficult decisions in terms of budget cuts.''
The spending reductions in the Koch plan, which total $201 million out of the $27 billion budget for the fiscal year that ends in June, would affect virtually every city agency. There would be no layoffs, but the municipal payroll would be reduced by 3,182 workers through attrition.
The plan to hire 3,220 police officers, which would result in 2,000 additional officers, would go ahead, but the department would lose 457 civilian employees.
The city would save $162 million by refinancing municipal bonds and $40 million by reducing contributions to city worker pension funds. Under the plan, the city would eliminate its subsidy to the Water and Sewer Authority, which would save $102 million but would result in higher water and sewer rates, increasing the average homeowner's bill by $28 a year. The remaining $25 million in the deficit would be taken from the general reserve fund.
The Mayor said he preferred a property tax increase to the water and sewer charges, since the former is deductible on Federal tax returns and the latter are not. But he said he did not believe the City Council, which must enact a property tax increase, would do so.
Council leaders said they were not consulted about the Mayor's plan and expressed irritation that Mr. Koch sought to cut many of the programs the Council and the Board of Estimate added during budget adoption talks in the spring. They said they might wait until a new mayor is elected and negotiate with him. They also indicated that a property tax increase was a dead issue.
While the Council and Board of Estimate technically must approve that part of the Mayor's plan that constitutes a budget modification, Mr. Koch said yesterday that he has the power to put virtually all of it in place, since he has the authority not to spend funds even if they have been included in the budget.
Late in the afternoon, Paul Dickstein, the city budget director, said he was already moving ahead on the water and sewer fees. The bond refinancing is to take place in November.
 
Savings Depend on Attrition
The spending cuts, however, largely depend on attrition. And although the city has had a hiring freeze for a month, the bulk of the vacancies seem likely to occur after Mr. Koch leaves office on Dec. 31. The new mayor would be free to replace any workers who left, and could also roll back the water and sewer fees.
Even so, Mr. Dickstein said that Mr. Koch's successor will have to produce a financial plan to close next year's budget deficit of nearly $400 million - and find money to pay for most of the wage increases city workers are likely to receive - just two or three weeks after inauguration day.
The budget director said he believed that if anything, the next mayor would be under pressure to make even more cuts. ''The intent,'' he said of the Mayor's plan, ''was to make it easier for the next guy.''
In recent days fiscal issues have become more prominent in the mayoral campaign, with Mr. Dinkins suggesting that spending by city agencies other than the Police Department could be cut by 1 percent. Mr. Giuliani, criticizing Mr. Dinkins's approach as irresponsible, suggested several of the steps that the Mayor called for, including the refinancing of bonds.
 
Koch Criticizes Dinkins's Plan
In his comments yesterday, Mr. Koch also took issue with Mr. Dinkins's across-the-board approach to spending cuts. ''In the real world,'' the Mayor said, ''some services are more essential than others, and therefore have to be treated better than others.''
Administration officials also noted that the Mayor's plan envisioned more cuts than Mr. Dinkins would realize through his plan for a 1 percent reduction in the agencies whose spending can be controlled by the city.
While Mr. Giuliani was generally supportive of the Koch plan, he said in his statement he had ''concern'' about reductions in the Police Department's civilian staff and in day care.
For Mr. Koch, yesterday was most likely the last chance to display a characteristically tough-minded fiscal approach that many believe will be his legacy. ''I have previously said that the city's budget would not be 'out of whack' on January 1,'' the Mayor said in his news conference, quoting himself. ''The plan I am announcing today insures that it will be balanced.''
 
Clean Team Is Hit Hard
Among the agencies hardest hit is the Sanitation Department. Its Clean Team, which had been cut from 1,400 workers to 505 workers in recent years, would decline to 354 workers. Spending for parks, libraries, cultural institutions and foster would also be reduced.
There were three main reasons why the Koch Administration felt forced to act. One was a slowdown in the rate of growth of the city's economy, which led to tax collections that lagged behind expectations. Another was unanticipated spending, mostly for health care.
The third factor was the administration's assumption that the sale of New York Coliseum site to Boston Properties would not be concluded during the fiscal year because the developer's plans to build an office and apartment complex with twin towers are being challenged in court. A $247 million payment the city expected was pushed back into next year's budget.
Mr. Koch said he was also acting now ''to address the uncertainty inevitably associated with a change in administration'' and to reassure the financial institutions that rate city bonds. He noted that Moody's Investors Service had confirmed its A rating for general-obligation bonds.
The managing director of Standard & Poor's, Hy Grossman, listened to the Mayor's presentation yesterday in the Blue Room and said afterwards that he did not ''see anything in the near term'' to change his company's rating of A-.

HEADLINE: EDUCATION;
Lessons

BYLINE: By Edward B. Fiske

 BODY:
Ever since tuitions at private colleges began soaring in the early 1980's, college officials have been bracing for a revolt.
The only question was when parents and students would conclude that designer label diplomas from Old Ivy - or even Potted Ivy - had become so costly that they were not worth the loans, second mortgages and deferred vactions they required.
The much-anticipated counterattack has now begun, but not from the direction colleges expected. Instead of facing economic resistance from potential students, colleges are under political assault from the Federal Government. 
An investigation announced in August by the United States Department of Justice into how colleges set tuitions, allocate financial aid and determine salaries and whether these activities violate antitrust laws has sent shivers through the higher education establishment.
For public universities, tuition-setting has always been a political process because the decisions are made by legislatures. But in the independent sector things get complicated.
One theory holds that selective colleges compete with each other by selling high quality, not low cost, and that tuitions are pegged to what the market will bear. Sticker prices are high, but plenty of discounts (scholarships) are offered to families who cannot afford full price.
William G. Bowen, the former president of Princeton University who now heads the Mellon Foundation, said colleges may act this way when it comes to fund-raising - raising as much as they can and spending it on quality programs - but that tuition-setting involves a delicate balancing of economic and educational objectives. ''High tuitions affect the composition of your student body -and thus the educational process,'' he said. ''You deliberately hold tuition as low as you can.''
Robert Zemsky, director of the Institute for Research on Higher Education at the University of Pennsylvania, said colleges practice ''cost-plus'' pricing - taking current expenses, adding enough to cover inflation and new programs and pegging tuition at a level that will generate the needed revenue. Since tuitions are the end-product of these calculations rather than a basis for them, he said, this approach ''provides few incentives to trim costs.''
The Justice Department has now come up with its own possible explanation: collusion among colleges and universities. By September, it had asked at least 30 of them for explanations of how they set tuitions.
Whatever the method, the results are troubling. A study published by the College Board in August showed that between the 1980-81 and 1988-89 academic years, disposable personal income per capita in the United States rose 66.8 percent. By contrast, the cost of attending college rose 118.1 percent at private universities and 82.2 percent at public ones.
With the perceived economic value of college degrees - especially prestigious ones - well acknowledged, families have little muscle to resist soaring tuitions. And colleges, caught in their own cycle of competition, are loathe to break the pattern. Now the Justice Department is doing what neither party could on its own.
The changing political tide was signaled by William J. Bennett, the former Secretary of Education, who waged a public relations war against high tuitions. ''At first I dismissed Bennett's attacks because I didn't think the great public was listening,'' said David Breneman, the former president of Kalamazoo College in Michigan, now a visiting fellow at the Brookings Institution. ''But I'm reassessing my view.''
The investigation seems to have friends in high places. Ten college presidents who met with President-elect Bush in December were reportedly treated to a lecture on high tuitions from John Sununu, the White House chief of staff.
Some scholars compare the situation to the public pressure that has developed against soaring health-care costs. ''The public will not - and should not - accept the inviolability of large tuition increases in the cause of 'educational excellence' any more than it has accepted, or will accept, ever-increasing charges to obtain high-quality medical care,'' said Arnold R. Weber, president of Northwestern University.
Mr. Weber argues that colleges should begin to think in terms of ''comparative advantage'' - specializing in certain activities rather than going for across-the-board prestige. Too many presidents, he said, agree with the adage of Mae West that ''too much of a good thing is wonderful.''
Mr. Zemsky suggests that by deciding tuition rates at the beginning of the budget-making process, colleges can become more productive. ''The public is deciding what is a fair price for higher education and telling colleges and universities, 'Don't step beyond that line without fear of enormous discomfort,' '' he said.
The Justice Department may or may not find evidence of price-fixing, but it has already altered the climate in which tuitions are set.
Caveat vendor.

HEADLINE: EDUCATION;
The Mainstreaming of Marxism in U.S. Colleges

BYLINE: By FELICITY BARRINGER

 BODY:
As Karl Marx's ideological heirs in Communist nations struggle to transform his political legacy, his intellectual heirs on American campuses have virtually completed their own transformation from brash, beleaguered outsiders to assimilated academic insiders.
It could be considered a success story for the students of class struggle, who were once regarded as subversives. But some scholars say that as Marxists have adapted, their ties to the 19th-century German philosopher have fragmented into a loosely knit collection of theories with little in common. And in the past decade, while the prosperity of Western economies has made Marxism irrelevant to many, new rival radical theories have arisen to challenge the Marxists themselves. 
''A Marxist revolutionary is hard to find,'' said Loren Graham, a historian at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology. ''Marx has become relativized. He's no longer a battle cry -just a great figure in economics and history, along with a number of other great figures.''
 
An Uneasy Relationship
Even though today's Marxists may be establishmentarian, they are still not at ease.
''For a long time Marxists were virtually excluded,'' said Eugene D. Genovese, whose growing array of prestigious academic titles - Sunderland Fellow at the University of Michigan Law School, Distinguished Professor of Arts and Sciences at the University of Rochester - bear witness to the mainstreaming of Marxists since the blacklists in the 1950's.
''Then for a long time it was fashionable to be a Marxist,'' he continued. ''Now it's getting unfashionable again, and many are retreating. There are a lot of people who don't want to call themselves Marxist or anything else.''
Indeed, non-Marxist scholars are asking whether Marxism is assimilating itself out of existence.
''It's been diluted to the point where it's a very thin gruel,'' said the Princeton historian Lawrence Stone. ''Some of my young colleagues call themselves neo-Marxists. I can't see much difference between their views and mine, and I call myself a liberal Democrat.''
 
Upheaval in Eastern Bloc
Recent interviews with a dozen historians, sociologists, literary critics, economists and legal scholars show that the upheaval in Poland, Hungary and other Eastern bloc nations has lent a new sense of excitement to discussions of class analysis and debates about whether capitalism will give way to socialism or whether socialism will rediscover capitalism.
But several scholars say the excitement has not brought increased enrollment in courses that focus on Marxist analysis, although it has made Soviet and Eastern European studies popular. Where Marxism is thriving, these scholars say, is less in social science courses, where there is a possibility of practical application, than in the abstract world of literary criticism.
It is also in this field that new radicals - from feminists who say class analysis leaves women out, to deconstructionists who say historical truth does not exist - have posed the sharpest challenge to those who back Marx's theories of class struggle.
''Marxism and feminism, Marxism and deconstruction, Marxism and race - this is where the exciting debates are,'' said Jonathan M. Wiener, a professor of history at the University of California at Irvine.
 
Omissions in History
In response to feminists' claims that all the categories of Marxism are organized around male concerns and experience, Professor Wiener said, ''To understand women's history you need a completely different set of analytic categories.'' A new group of Marxist feminist historians is now trying to reconcile the differences, he added.
But deconstructionists deny that one can understand any experience of the past because the evidence for any conclusion comes from people's observations, most of which appear in a text. Deconstructionists maintain that texts are only stories told by people who leave out what they deem unimportant, and that such omissions keep written history from being reliable evidence about reality.
This philosophy is ''very upsetting to people who think there is one historical truth and there is one way to discover it,'' Mr. Wiener said, adding, ''Marxism believes there is a real world and it's really possible to understand it.''
Some scholars try to incorporate the cacophonous pluralism of radical theories into their work.
Asserting that ''relieving anxiety is not the object of academic work,'' Gayatri Spivak, a literary critic who is the Andrew W. Mellon Professor of English at the University of Pittsburgh, uses elements of deconstructionist theory, Marxist theory and feminist theory in her work.
''The three are not married in my use of them,'' she said. ''They are always bringing each other to crisis.''
 
A Matter for Analysis
Whatever anxiety may spring from the theoretical wars, Marxist scholars greet the apparently robust vitality of capitalism with equanimity. For Mr. Wiener, this is a matter for analysis, not anxiety.
''Marxism needs to account for the continuing vitality of capitalism as capitalism embraces more and more of the world,'' he said. ''That doesn't mean there aren't capitalists and there aren't workers and this class relation doesn't provide a key to what's going on. We need to look more at how the ideology of consumerism has overpowered class consciousness.''
Far from producing anxiety, the transformation of the Communist landscape delights American socialists, who said decades ago that the Stalinist system was a perversion of Marxism, and now join conservatives in applauding the economic and political changes taking place in Poland, Hungary and the Soviet Union.
''These things show that a fundamentally Marxist mind is capable of creativity and change,'' said Mark Mancall, a history professor at Stanford University.
 
The Salvation of Socialism
John Roemer, an economics professor at the University of California at Davis, said: ''I'm very happy with what's happening in these countries. I think it's going to save socialism, rather than kill it.''
And diversity is now the signature of once-monolithic Marxism. Professor Spivak calls herself a Marxist feminist, Professor Roemer designs Marxist market-driven economies, and Erik Olin Wright, a sociology professor at the University of Wisconsin, calls himself an analytic Marxist, seeking to break Marx's grand theories down into their components.
Like many contemporary Marxists, Professor Wright is a bit uncomfortable with his establishment credentials.
''It makes me nervous,'' he said. ''I feel it shouldn't have been as easy for me in a big university as it has been. I don't see myself as having compromised my beliefs, but I'm not so naive as to believe that I'm more immune from the pressures of an institution than anyone else.''

COMPANIES
 
UAL's stock rebounded after plunging $33 early in the day and closed down $8.375, at $170. The recovery was spurred in part by rumors of stock purchases by two large investors. [Page D1.] The proposed takeover of United Airlines is a certain nominee for Wall Street's worst deal of the year. [A1.] 
 
Officials of the Transportation and Treasury Departments told a House subcommittee that proposed legislation to restrict airline takeovers would not be good for the industry or the economy. [D8.]
 
The trust that owns the majority of Manville's stock is exploring whether to put the company up for sale. [D1.]
 
A.T.& T. and Sun Microsystems are on the verge of winning the race to establish a new software standard. [D1.] I.B.M. introduced an array of products for computerized manufacturing. [D4.]
 
Sears, Roebuck's profits fell 15.6 percent in the third quarter, relecting a sharp drop in retailing income and a rash of hurricane claims against Allstate Insurance. [D1.] Shell, Mobil and Chevron reported that profits were down slightly; Texaco reported higher total profits but a decline on a per-share basis. [D7.]
 
A $2.25 billion offer for Public Service of New Hampshire is expected from shareholders and Northeast Utilities. [D4.]
 
Salomon's earnings more than doubled in the third quarter, to $177 million, or $1.28 a share. [D7.] Times Mirror's earnings fell 13.4 percent; Knight-Ridder's net jumped 18.2 percent, while The Washington Post Company's profits were up 17.7 percent. [D22.]
 
Mercedes-Benz introduced a high-performance roadster embodying new safety technology. [D5.]
 
TECHNOLOGY
 
The marketing of ''degradable'' plastic products is raising concerns that consumers worried about the environment are being lulled into an unwarranted sense of security. [Page A1.]
 
Are plastic or paper bags a better choice for shoppers concerned about the environment? [D9.]
 
MARKETS
 
The stock market gyrated wildly on heavy volume. The Dow Jones industrial average plunged 85 points in the first hour of trading but recovered to close 3.69 points lower, at 2,659.22. [D1.] Stock index futures prices also fluctuated wildly. [D18.]
 
The S.E.C.'s chairman, Richard C. Breeden, sent reassuring signals to the markets in a wide-ranging interview. [D1.]
 
Prices of Treasury securities continued to climb and yields declined. [D17.] Yields were mixed on C.D.'s and money market accounts for the week ended yesterday. [D17.]
 
The dollar finished lower against most leading currencies, depressed by the volatility of stock prices. [D18.]
 
Shares sold short and not yet covered rose 6 percent in over-the-counter trading in the four weeks ended Oct. 13. [D28.]
 
INTERNATIONAL
 
The Bush Administration put forward a plan for knocking down trade barriers in services. [D5.]
 
THE ECONOMY
 
Sales of U.S.-built cars plunged 19 percent in mid-October and sales of domestic light trucks dropped 22.8 percent. [D5.]
 
Orders for durable goods edged down 0.1 percent in September despite the second-biggest increase in military orders. [D2.]

HEADLINE: Rumors Lift UAL After $33 Plunge

BYLINE: By AGIS SALPUKAS

 BODY:
Rumors of stock purchases by two major investors and of a revival of the original buyout offer helped the stock of the UAL Corporation recover strongly yesterday after it plunged by $33 a share earlier in the day.
After falling as low as $145 a share, the stock of the parent of United Airlines closed at $170, down $8.375 from Monday's close, After a block of more than 800,000 shares was traded this morning. rumors began circulating that Donald J. Trump, the New York developer, or Coniston Partners, an investment group that already holds many UAL shares, might be buying large amounts of stock.
A spokesman for Mr. Trump said he would have no comment. A partner at Coniston did not return a phone call seeking comment.
 
Quarter of Stock Traded
More than 4.9 million shares - almost a quarter of UAL's common shares outstanding - were traded in one of the most active days for a stock that has been extremely volatile for months, rising from around $120 in June to a high of $294 in early September, after the announcement of a $300-a-share buyout offer led by UAL's management and the airline's pilots' union. 
The stock has plunged since Oct. 13, when it became clear that sufficient financing for the deal could not be arranged.
''This deal may not be dead,'' said one Wall street arbitrager who did not want to be identified, voicing a hope of many UAL investors who had gambled that the $300-a-share proposal would be completed.
On Monday, UAL's 12 independent directors agreed in a five-hour meeting in Chicago to direct management and employees to concentrate on running their airline and to wait to see whether another bid emerged or the original deal could be salvaged.
 
Pivotal Roles for Directors
Three people familiar with the UAL board said that as it wrestled with what to do next, pivotal roles could be played by three directors who have tended to be outspoken leaders on the board and another three who have known each other a long time and see things from a similar perspective.
These people said that Andrew F. Brimmer, a financial consultant; Neil A. Armstrong, the former astronaut who now heads his own computer systems company, and Frank A. Olson, the chairman and chief executive of the Hertz Corporation, who presided over the last reorganization at UAL, tend to be the most outspoken on what should be done next.
The three directors who are old friends and in the past have been allies are John F. McGillicuddy, the chairman and chief executive of the Manufacturers Hanover Corporation and the Manufacturers Hanover Trust Company; E. Mandell de Windt, the retired chairman and chief executive of the Eaton Corporation, a diversified maker of electronic equipment, and James J. O'Connor, the chairman and chief executive of the Commonwealth Edison Company of Chicago.
''They may end up the core group,'' said one person familiar with the board and its members. ''They pal around, they have the same outlook on life. You see them congregate during cocktail time.''
While Mr. McGillicuddy has often been outspoken, he may stay in the background during this round. His bank decided against lending money for the deal, placing him in an awkward position.
On the other hand, there was also agreement on the board that the major reason for the collapse of the financing attempts was the way the lead bank, Citibank, a Citicorp unit, had handled the financing arrangements for the buyout and thus the role of Mr. McGillicuddy, as a banker, could increase.
 
Seeker of Consensus
Richard P. Cooley, the chairman and chief executive of the Seafirst Corporation, a Seattle banking company, presides over the board's deliberations. The people familiar with the board said Mr. Cooley, the senior member of the board, would listen and then seek a consensus.
When the 12 directors met on Monday it quickly became apparent that they wanted time for the dust to settle before taking any action, said a participant in the meeting who did not want to be identified.
That person said that contrary to suggestions on Monday by a Wall Street executive, the board had set no conditions for any possible bidder. The person added that Stephen M. Wolf, UAL's chairman, president and chief executive, and John C. Pope, a senior vice president and the chief financial officer, had not been asked to take themselves out of the buyout group. And he said that contrary to a previous report, Mr. Wolf and Mr. Pope had not pulled out of the buyout effort to focus exclusively on running the company.
Both executives are under pressure to leave the board from some major stockholders and some arbitragers who have taken big losses since the stock plunged. Their critics argue that they were too tough and aloof in their dealings with the banks during negotiations for the financing.
A large investor who sought this week to organize a vote to oust Mr. Wolf and Mr. Pope said that although there were some investors who wanted to join an effort to remove them, ''nobody wants to lead.''
 
Experienced on Difficulties
Among the board members who have played important roles in the past is Mr. Brimmer, an economist who was on the Federal Reserve Board from 1966 to 1974 and now heads a financial consulting firm in Washington. He has much experience with companies in difficulty and is a member of the boards of the BankAmerica Corporation and the Navistar International Corporation, formerly International Harvester. Both companies have been on the way to recovery after hard times.
Mr. Armstrong, the former astronaut and chairman of Computing Technologies for Aviation Inc., played a significant role in the last restructuring of UAL. In June 1987 the board removed Richard J. Ferris as chairman and decided to sell off major divisions of the company, including Hertz, now a unit of the Park Ridge Corporation, and two hotel chains, distributing the proceeds to stockholders.
Mr. Olson, of Hertz, has been a UAL director since 1985, when Hertz was acquired by UAL. He took over as chief executive after Mr. Ferris was ousted. Mr. Olson guided the company through the divestiture of Hertz and the hotel chains.
Other board members are expected to play more low-key roles. They include Juanita M. Kreps, an economist and a former Secretary of Commerce; Fujio Matsuda, executive director of the Research Corporation at the University of Hawaii; Nicholas R. Petry, the president of the Petry Company of Denver, an investment firm that specializes in energy companies; William M. Jenkins, the retired chairman of Seafirst, and Harry Mullikin, chairman emeritus of the Westin Hotel Company.
Of the board as a whole, the person at Monday's meeting said that ''they are a pretty close group and they have been together a long time.''
Mr. Wolf and Mr. Pope did not participate in the meeting because they are part of the buyout effort and they are considered inside directors. The 15th board member, Ralph Strangis, a partner in the law firm of Kaplan, Strangis and Kaplan in Minneapolis, is Mr. Wolf's attorney and was put on the board at his request. He also worked on the buyout proposal and is considered an ''inside'' member.

HEADLINE: Dow Ends 3.69 Lower In Wild Day

BYLINE: By PHILLIP H. WIGGINS

 BODY:
The stock market fluctuated wildly yesterday on heavy volume. The Dow Jones industrial average plunged 85 points in the first hour of trading but recovered in the late afternoon to close only 3.69 points lower, at 2,659.22.
The early plunge, with investors' emotions still fragile after the 190-point tumble on Oct. 13, spurred speculation that the market had not returned to normal and prompted widespread selling. Declines on the New York Stock Exchange, at 1,222, outpaced the 382 advances by a ratio of more than 3 to 1. 
Also, in the broader markets, the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index slipped 1.13, to 343.70, while in over-the-counter trading, the Nasdaq composite index dropped 5.52, to 461.70.
Volume on the Big Board soared to an exceptionally strong 238 million shares from a slow 135.9 million on Monday.
Traders said the initial impetus for yesterday's decline was a 33-point plunge in the price of UAL, parent of United Airlines. UAL's board announced on Monday after the close of trading that it wanted to keep the company independent.
UAL's slide pushed other airlines down too, and the Dow transportation average fell nearly 80 points in early trading. The indicator finished 25.96 points lower, at 1,210.70, while UAL rebounded to close off 8 3/8, at 170, after rumors circulated that Donald J. Trump, the developer, was accumulating shares. Other airlines also closed above the day's lows. AMR fell 1 3/4, to 68 7/8; Delta 1 1/2, to 66; USAir 2 3/8, to 40 1/8, and Pan Am 1/8, to 3 1/2.
Computer programs that send out trading sell signals based on how various futures and options stand in relation to stocks were also a factor in early selling yesterday as the S.&P. 500 futures and the S.&P. 500 cash index both tumbled. Shortly afterward, the stock market began to rally, bolstered by buy programs. Stocks remained stable through midafternoon before short covering pushed stocks up in the last half-hour.
Hectic, heavy trading of stock index futures, with wild price gyrattions, contributed greatly to huge swings in stock prices. [Page D18.] ''Since Oct. 13, the market has been dramatically futures driven, obviously affecting the big stocks in the Dow and S.&P. 500,'' said David D. Bostian Jr., managing director and chief investment strategist at Jesup & Lamont in New York. ''There are two forces at work here. In terms of the bigger picture, there is a growing recognition that we may be headed for a recession and lower corporate profits than had been expected. On the other hand, it appears that one of the reasons we had the rally in the afternoon is that there is also a growing hope that the Fed might make a more overt move to lower interest rates.''
Kenneth S. Hackel, president of Systematic Financial Management Inc. in Fort Lee, N.J., said, ''I think program trading is turning off the public at large from the small investor to professional portfolio manager,'' adding that program traders had ''beaten the market down to undervalued levels, especially in light of current bond yields.''
 
Recession Fears a Factor
Recession fears also came into play early in the day. Durable goods orders were reported down one-tenth of 1 percent for September, well above the 1.8 percent drop expected by most economists. There was cause for concern, however, because, excluding the often-volatile military sector, orders fell 3.9 percent.
About 9:50 A.M. yesterday, the Dow was off only 15 points. By 10:10, however, the Dow was off 25 points, and 25 minutes later it was down 68. It then slipped to an 80-point drop before it began to recover. By 11:30, it had snapped back to a decline of only 44 points.
About 2:30, the Dow began to falter again, falling to a 60-point-plus loss before beginning another recovery. About 3:20 P.M., a wave of program buying in blue-chip stocks and stocks showing good earnings fundamentals pushed the Dow from a 35-point decline to a 3-point gain. Selling resurfaced almost immediately, however, and stocks fell about 15 points in the next five minutes.
 
Merger Stocks Down
Merger-related stocks outside the airlines that were hit yesterday included Ramada, off 1/2, to 10 3/4; Kollmorgen 5/8, to 12 3/4; MGM/UA 3/8, to 17 1/2; Hilton 2 3/4, to 93 1/4; McGraw-Hill 1 1/4, to 65 7/8; Paramount Communications 1, to 57 3/4; Woolworth 5/8, to 57 5/8; Time Warner 1 1/8, to 137 1/2; Rorer Group 7/8, to 41 3/4; Upjohn 5/8, to 37 7/8, and Telerate 3/8, to 19 1/4.
Among active blue chips, Philip Morris rose 5/8, to 44 1/2; Phillips Petroleum gained 1/2, to 23 5/8; Chase Manhattan slipped 7/8, to 38 7/8; McDonald's was up 1 3/8, to 32 3/4; Bristol-Myers slipped 1/8, to 52 1/4; A.T.&T. added 1/8, to 43 1/8, and BankAmerica dropped 1 1/4, to 29 1/2.
Security Pacific was the most active stock, slipping 7/8, to 44 1/2, on a volume of 14.8 million shares, in an apparent dividend capture play. The stock, which has an annual yield of 5.02 percent, goes ex dividend today.
Dow Jones jumped 5 3/4, to 41. The company's management said that it knew of no reason for a rise in the stock.
While down sharply, the secondary averages did not come back nearly as much as the Dow. On the American Stock Exchange, the market-value index dropped 3.10, to 376.36, while in over-the-counter trading, the Nasdaq composite index fell 5.52, to 461.70.

HEADLINE: New S.E.C. Chief Defines Goals

BYLINE: By NATHANIEL C. NASH, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 24

 BODY:
In his first public discussion of the future policy of the Securities and Exchange Commission since he took office as chairman two weeks ago, Richard C. Breeden sent reassuring signals to the markets today, saying that his agency would not press Congress to grant the commission power to close the nation's securities markets in times of crisis.
''Circuit breakers'' put in place after the stock market crash of 1987, which require temporary trading halts if the market drops a certain amount, had diminished the need for the S.E.C. to be given summary authority to close down trading, he said.
''Moreover, my personal view is that a decision of that economic consequence should not be made by the commission alone,'' Mr. Breeden said. ''It should ultimately be a decision the President makes.''
 
Would Support Registration
In a broad-ranging interview about how he plans to conduct the business of the agency that regulates Wall Street, Mr. Breeden outlined an agenda that could both increase the agency's reach in some areas while checking its influence in others. 
Reflecting the thinking of his mentor, President Bush, he said: ''We want to be a fair cop. But we also want to be a tough cop.''
For example, he said he would strongly support any initiatives that require banks and savings and loan associations that issue stock and other securities to the public to register with the S.E.C., a measure that would bring thousands of financial institutions under the regulation of the commission. The issue has been debated in Congress, but there has been no legislation.
But at the same time, he said he was not prepared to continue the fight of his predecessor, David S. Ruder, to wrest regulation of stock-index futures from the Commodities Futures Trading Commission.
And, in addressing the recent volatility in the market - stock prices gyrated wildly today alone - and fears raised in Congress and in the investment community about the proliferation of leveraged buyouts and corporate takeovers, he declined to take a strong position.
 
A Difficult First Day
''I don't know what the right level is,'' he said, referring to takeover activity. ''The marketplace should decide those questions.''
For the 39-year-old former assistant to the President for issues analysis in the Bush White House and main architect of the savings and loan bailout, Mr. Breeden's first two weeks on the job have been a period of intensive training. Sworn in on Oct. 11, his first day at work was Oct. 12, but a security guard at first refused to let him into his office because he did not have a pass.
The next day, Oct. 13, Mr. Breeden did not have any trouble getting into his office, but the stock market tumbled, with the Dow Jones industrial average falling nearly 200 points. The day was chaotic, he said, because he was unfamiliar with the telephone system and did not have a computer terminal in his office. ''People had to run out and run back in to give me stock quotes.'' he said.
But in general, he expressed confidence that the market systems put into place since the Dow plunged 508 points on Oct. 19, 1987, had worked well so that orders were not backed up and investors got accurate price information.
 
Few Changes Outlined
''There is a perception that there were no changes, and that is erroneous,'' he said. ''A great deal was done.''
Indeed, Mr. Breeden outlined plans for very few changes in the market beyond those that the agency has already submitted to Congress, such as requiring brokerage firms to report large trades by their major customers and permitting the S.E.C. to get information on the financial condition of affiliates of broker dealers.
He said even though the commission had requested authority from Congress last January to shut down the securities markets without the President's intervention, the consensus of current commissioners was that such a dramatic new level of power was not needed and that effort would be abandoned.
But Mr. Breeden is not expected to tread lightly when it comes to advocating new policy initiatives that he feels are needed.
 
Savings and Loan Losses
He said today that he would strongly support any effort to force banks and savings institutions to register their securities with the S.E.C., adding that if savings and loan associations had been forced to use generally accepted accounting principles in the 1980's, the huge losses at the savings institutions would have been discovered much sooner and at a lower cost to the taxpayer.
And he said that he would strongly support dramatic changes in Federal laws that currently prohibit banks from owning securities firms and vice versa to make United States firms competitive with European financial institutions.
Though Mr. Breeden did not seem to be overly concerned about the market's ability to deal with wide swings in prices because of computerized trading, he said he was worried about the confidence of the small investor.
He said that even though the level of volatility in the market had greatly increased, stock prices in general had risen strongly in recent years.
 
Concern for Small Investor
Pulling out a chart he had asked his staff to prepare for testimony he is scheduled to give on Wednesday to a House subcommittee, he noted that if an investor had bought the 30 stocks in the Dow Jones industrial average in January 1987, the value of those holdings as of Monday would be up more than 40 percent, despite the market's volatility over those 34 months.
''While people focus on the volatility that exists in some of the short-term trading,'' he said, ''I would not like to have a situation in which people who are saving for college education or for retirement read about volatility in the markets and get scared away.''
He acknowledged that a key to maintaining small-investor confidence in the markets was to insure that the public perceived the S.E.C. as effectively enforcing the securities laws.
While promising to be a ''tough cop,'' Mr. Breeden refrained from outlining a specific enforcement agenda, saying he would present an outline of his thinking at a later date. ''The commission's record is generally a good one and I want to see it stay that way,'' he said.
 
Salaries Not Competitive
But he said that the agency does have an Achilles' heel - insufficient staffing levels and pay scales so low that it has had problems keeping talented lawyers.
''I've already got problems trying to compete for graduates of law schools,'' he said, because the S.E.C. can only offer ''$27,000 versus $82,000 by a Wall Street law firm.''
And he acknowledged that the savings and loan bailout law, which he had a big hand in devising, has only made that problem worse.
Under that law, all Goverment banking agencies, including the Federal Reserve Board, Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation to the Office of Thrift Supervision and the National Credit Union Administration are exempt from Government pay caps and can begin to offer competitive salaries. But the S.E.C. and C.F.T.C., he said, were still under the salary restrictions, which has led to the agency losing as many as a third of its lawyers in a single year and experiencing a turnover rate double that of the other agencies.
''I think that over the long run we will have a very significant problem in maintaining the traditional excellence of the commission staff if we are not able to be competitive even with other Government agencies, much less the private sector,'' he said.
''It can really effect litigation if you end up having to change your lawyers on the case every 18 months.''

HEADLINE: Economic Scene;
Unleashing Ma Bell

BYLINE: By Peter Passell

 BODY:
COULD A.T.&T.'s rivals in long-distance phone service survive no-holds-barred competition? Since the breakup of the telephone monopoly in 1984, the Federal Communications Commission has kept A.T.&T. on a short leash to prevent the giant company from chewing up the ''small fry.''
But now two of those small fry have grown into profitable multibillion-dollar corporations, and A.T.&T. is asking the regulators for the freedom to fight for market share. If the F.C.C. agrees - a crucial decision could come as early as tomorrow - high-volume telephone users are likely to reap a bonanza from lower prices.
When the Bell System was dismembered, analysts generally agreed that rivals would need a lot of help from Washington to gain a secure foothold in the long-distance market dominated by the ultimate name-brand company. The analysts were right: After A.T.&T.'s competitors lost their discounts on regulated charges for hookups to local telephone exchanges, all of them took a financial bath and some went broke. 
But in the ensuing consolidation, a few companies emerged with both the technical capacity to match A.T.&T.'s service and the marketing savvy to sell themselves to once-skeptical consumers.
MCI Communications now has 12 percent of the long-distance market and in the last year has grown four times as fast as A.T.&T. U S Sprint Communications, with its much-ballyhooed all-fiber-optic system, has an 8 percent share and is the principal carrier for 117 of America's 800 largest companies. Joel Gross, a communications analyst at Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette, believes a fourth network, assembled from a half-dozen smaller companies, will soon emerge.
One reason A.T.&T.'s rivals have managed to do so well in the last few years is continuing regulatory discrimination. Last summer, the F.C.C. switched A.T.&T. from traditional fair-rate-of-return regulation to a more flexible ''price-cap'' system that gives the company discretion to adjust individual rates within a narrow price band.
But neither the old price regulations nor the new ones apply to MCI, U S Sprint and other smaller long-distance companies. And they have taken advantage of A.T.&T.'s inability to cut prices, offering volume discounts where A.T.&T. is most vulnerable to customer defections.
A.T.&T. has fought back, convincing the F.C.C. to allow it fast-track approval for rate concessions needed to hang onto its biggest customers. And it is now asking the commission for broad discretion to cut rates by more than the 5 percent permitted under the price-cap rule. If the F.C.C. agrees, it is a sure bet that A.T.&T. will price aggressively, accepting sharp reductions in its fat profit margins to check its loss of market share.
It is obvious why MCI and U S Sprint are unhappy at the prospect of an A.T.&T. unleashed. But it is not so easy to see how the public would lose from the ensuing donnybrook.
One worry is that A.T.&T. would slash prices by enough to drive rivals out of business, and then be free to price-gouge. But as Peter Pitsch, a former F.C.C. staff member who now consults for A.T.&T., points out, such ''predatory'' pricing is only a plausible option if the predator can hope to make up the inevitable short-term losses with long-term monopoly gains. And two considerations make such a calculation unlikely.
Once the cables have been laid and the switches installed, it costs very little to operate a long-distance phone system. Thus even if A.T.&T. were able to drive MCI and U S Sprint into bankruptcy, their creditors would find it advantageous to continue to sell long-distance services. And if A.T.&T. somehow did manage to shut down its rivals, the F.C.C. would hardly be likely to reward it with permission to charge monopoly prices.
Another concern is that price-cutting would make long-distance service unprofitable for all, discouraging further investment. That, however, might not be such a bad thing. Losses are capitalism's way of telling businesses to slow down: There is enormous overcapacity in long-distance communications and more investment anytime soon is unlikely to be productive.
Does all this mean the commission will hang tough and permit A.T.&T. to flex its competitive muscles? A year ago, when the F.C.C. was dominated by Reagan-appointed free marketers, the answer would have been easy.
Today, with a Bush-appointed majority led by a chairman, Alfred Sikes, of less certain ideological bent, it is hard to say. MCI and U S Sprint have managed to squeeze a lot of regulatory mileage out of their underdog status, and certainly will not give up the privileges that go along without a fight.

HEADLINE: Durables Orders Down In September

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 24

 BODY:
Orders for ''big ticket'' durable goods edged down one-tenth of 1 percent in September, but the drop would have been more pronounced if not for the second-biggest increase in military orders on record.
Analysts attributed the big jump in military demand to a rush by the Pentagon to place orders in September, the last month of the Government's budget year. They said the weakness in the nonmilitary categories provided fresh evidence that the nation's manufacturing sector was headed into a slowdown. 
Over all, orders for durable goods, items expected to last three or more years, dropped by $147 million last month, to a seasonally adjusted $126.68 billion, after a 3.9 percent rise in August, the Commerce Department said today. The drop of one-tenth of 1 percent was the first decline since a 2.5 percent drop in July.
 
Biggest Drop Since May
Without the huge 56.3 percent surge in military orders, orders would have fallen 3.9 percent, the biggest decline in civilian demand since May.
''This is a weak report showing that the industrial sector has lost momentum,'' said Bruce Steinberg, an economist at Merrill Lynch. ''The only thing that held orders up in September was defense, and that category is volatile and not indicative of underlying economic trends.''
In September, manufacturing employment had its biggest drop in seven years, and many economists predicted that the weak orders report would lead to more layoffs in coming months.
''This report points to a sharp slowdown in industrial activity during the final quarter,'' said Gordon Richards, senior economist at the National Association of Manufacturers.
 
Particularly Ominous Sign
Many economists pointed to a big 5.6 percent drop in demand for nonmilitary capital goods in September as a particularly ominous sign, especially since it followed an even larger 10.3 percent August decline. This area, which reflects business investment plans, has been one of the key sources of strength over the last year.
In September, orders in the transportation category fell by 4.7 percent, to $34.78 billion, after a 7.3 percent August rise. The September weakness was attributed to a $3 billion decline in orders for new cars as manufacturers cut back on production plans in the face of sluggish sales.

HEADLINE: End Sought to Trade Barriers in Some Services

BYLINE: By CLYDE H. FARNSWORTH, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 24

 BODY:
The Bush Administration put forward a blueprint today for ending trade barriers in a large number of services that account for more than a quarter of the world's $2 trillion of annual trade.
The proposal, affecting areas ranging from financial and communication services to construction and tourism, opens a new phase in global trade talks in Geneva. It is the first comprehensive effort to establish rules for services similar to those that apply to manufactured goods under the 42-year-old General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade.
The initiative is likely to spark lively debate and opposition, and its prospects are uncertain. The European Community and other developed nations are expected to support the plan's general points while seeking some modifications, but third world nations are likely to object to attempts to strip their nascent services industries of protection. 
 
Question of Labor Exports
Brahm Dutt, commercial and financial counselor at the Indian Embassy here, said his country wanted the liberalization to include the export of semiskilled labor, such as carpenters and blacksmiths, to foreign construction sites. But such exporting of labor is not covered by the American proposal.
India and other developing countries are also seeking greater flexibility to adjust to competition from service industries of the developed countries, such as banks, insurance and travel companies.
The Bush plan would set up a legal framework to assure that foreign services are treated on a nondiscriminatory basis.
The new arrangement, for example, would provide for openness in promulgating laws and regulations affecting services. It would also give service providers the right to establish an office in a host country and would ban subsidies that cause injury to foreign service providers.
Further, guidelines would be established to limit restrictions that countries impose on payments in service transactions.
 
Fast-Growing Sector
Much as trade in manufactured goods expanded sharply after the establishment of the GATT, so Washington's hope now is to further the expansion of trade in services, which is already the fastest growing sector of activity in the United States and in many other countries.
In the United States, services employ about three-quarters of the work force and account for two-thirds of the gross national product and a quarter of total exports. Exports of services last year yielded a positive trade balance of $20 billion.
Allied with the United States in negotiating objectives are most of the developed countries. Yet publication of the American proposal shows some subtle differences between the United States and the European Community. The Europeans are pressing for a somewhat less sweeping accord.
The American services plan and previously reported parallel efforts to get rid of trade barriers and market distortions in agriculture were formally announced here at a news conference by the United States trade representative, Carla A. Hills, and the Secretary of Agriculture, Clayton K. Yeutter.
''These proposals are a microcosm of our broad goal in the round - to eliminate the hundreds of ways governments distort trade and restrict fair competition,'' Mrs. Hills said.
Domestic companies that provide services strongly backed the American draft plan.
''This is a very powerful document and should have an important catalytic function,'' said Gordon J. Cloney, president of the International Insurance Council, which represents the domestic insurance companies on international trade matters.
Harry L. Freeman, executive vice president of the American Express Company, said he believes compromises will be struck with developing countries. With so many of them developing service industries, there is an increasing convergence of interests, he said.
 
Phase-Out of Farm Subsidies
The agriculture plan calls for a substantial reduction in trade barriers and the phasing out of export subsidies.
It would also phase out internal support or subsidy measures that have the most distorting effect on trade. It also calls for the harmonization of health and sanitary measures, which many countries use to unfairly restrict trade.

HEADLINE: Car Sales Are Down 19 Percent

BYLINE: By DORON P. LEVIN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: DETROIT, Oct. 24

 BODY:
Sales of United States-built cars plunged 19 percent in mid-October and sales of domestic light trucks dropped 22.8 percent as auto makers continued to feel the effects of earlier aggressive discounting.
The drop was not surprising to Big Three auto companies or to analysts, who said they had expected a sales ''payback'' from the summer months of the third quarter, when buying was stronger than normal.
''Anyone who didn't buy in the third quarter and decides to buy in the fourth must be desperate to be the first one on the block with a 1990 model,'' said Ron Glantz, an analyst for Montgomery Securities Inc. 
Harvey Heinbach of Merrill Lynch pointed out that retail car and truck dealers now have relatively few 1989 models left on their lots. Although manufacturers have put rebates on 1990 models, too, the deepest discounts tend to be for 1989 models.
 
Estimates on '89 Sales
Mr. Heinbach said slower-than-normal sales could continue for the rest of the fourth quarter unless auto makers unleashed another wave of deep discounts.
He estimates that about 10.1 million domestic and imported cars will be sold in the United States in 1989, compared with 1988 sales of 10.6 million. And he expects sales next year to drop further to 9.4 million because of a softening economy.
The eight domestic manufacturers, which consist of the Big Three and five Japanese automotive companies, sold 158,863 cars in the period from Oct. 11 to 20, compared with 196,196 sold in the comparable period last year.
The General Motors Corporation posted a 24.8 percent decline, selling 69,980 cars, compared with 93,086 cars a year ago. The Ford Motor Company posted sales of 46,995 cars, a 21.2 percent decline from last year's 59,613. The Chrysler Corporation sold 22,336 cars in the latest period, down 23.7 percent from a year ago.
 
Japan Surpasses Chrysler
Results were mixed for the five Japanese companies, but their combined sales of cars made in this country were substantially ahead of a year ago, mostly reflecting increased production at the Toyota Motor Corporation's new assembly plant in Georgetown, Ky., and the Mitsubishi Motor Corporation's joint venture assembly plant with Chrysler in Normal, Ill.
Significantly, combined United States car production by the Japanese auto makers now surpasses Chrysler's total car production. In the mid-1980's production of the so-called Japanese transplants was far smaller.
Sales of domestic light trucks, which include mini-vans and utility vehicles and double as personal transportation for a growing number of Americans, were 94,543 for the mid-October period, down from 122,468 a year ago.
Ford sold 31,143 light trucks, down 24.2 percent from last year's 41,097. G.M. sold 37,860 trucks, down 25.6 percent from last year's 51,134, and Chrysler sold 22,925 trucks, down from 27,795 a year ago. The Nissan Motor Corporation managed a slight gain, pushing truck sales to 2,615, from 2,442 last year.

HEADLINE: Market Place Added Volatility Expected in 'Junk'

BYLINE: By Anise C. Wallace

 BODY:
AFTER going their separate ways most of this year, the ''junk bond'' and stock markets now seem to share anxieties. When the Dow Jones industrial average plunged almost 86 points yesterday morning, prices of some high-risk, high-yield bonds fell sharply as well. Then when stock prices later recovered, junk bonds rose slightly.
''When the stock market gets strong, we get strong; when the stock market gets weak, we get weak,'' said David M. Feinman, a junk bond trader at Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc. in Beverly Hills, Calif. 
For much of 1989, the junk market and the stock market moved apart, with the stock market rising despite signs of stress in the junk market.
As volatility in both markets increases, many investors expect the junk market's disarray to continue indefinitely. ''There are going to be continued fluctuations because there's a lot of confusion,'' said Kingman D. Penniman, head of junk bond research at McCarthy Crisanti Maffei, a bond research firm in Montpelier, Vt.
This volatility and skittishness in turn are making it difficult for underwriters to place some of the new offerings being marketed, investors say. Indeed, the amount of new offerings could be cut to $5 billion from the planned $11 billion, said Peter F. Karches, managing director and head of junk bond securities at Morgan Stanley & Company.
Yesterday morning after the Dow plunged, arbitragers who had lost money in the UAL Corporation and who needed to raise cash began selling bonds of RJR Holdings, traders said, and that selling spilled over into the rest of the junk bond market. Traders in the secondary market reacted by selling bonds like RJR, Harcourt Brace Jovanovich and Duracell. Prices of some RJR bonds, considered to be a source of trading liquidity for investors who need to raise cash quickly, fell 3 points, or $30 for every $1,000 face amount. They recovered slightly, ending down 2 1/2 points for the day. The bellwether RJR bond is yielding around 13 percent.
''To me, it's clear the whole junk market was affected by the UAL situation,'' Mr. Feinman said.
At the same time, junk bond investors continue to be extremely selective about providing credit to new issuers. Companies that have a demonstrated cash flow record, like Imo Industries, an electronics concern, are finding buyers willing to spend some cash they have in their portfolios. On Monday, Morgan Stanley successfully sold $150 million of Imo bonds, which had a 12 percent coupon.
However, other companies trying to raise cash from junk bond lenders could face a tougher time. Several investors said yesterday that a scheduled $1.6 billion bond offering by the West Point Acquisition Company, needed to help finance the acquisition of West Point Pepperrell by Farley Industries, would be difficult under these market conditions.
Yesterday a spokesman for Drexel, Farley's investment banker, said the firm planned a ''road show'' for the West Point offering but had not yet selected the dates for these meetings with portfolio managers and analysts around the country.
Investors also said that the $1.1 billion offering of bonds of TW Services could be hard to sell. Investors are nervous about companies where cash flow is closely tied to the overall health of the economy, like housing and retailing. As a result, some money managers said they were unlikely to buy bonds of TW, a food service company whose operations include Denny's, a restaurant chain.
To help pay off its debts, TW may have to sell some of the assets, a practice that was once tolerated by the credit markets but that has suddenly become suspect. ''TW needs to do a lot of things that the market doesn't want to see,'' Mr. Penniman said. A spokesman for the Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette Securities Corporation, the underwriter, declined to comment.
In this market climate, portfolio managers are becoming more demanding. Investment bankers at Shearson Lehman Hutton Inc., who are trying to sell $150 million of junk bonds for the R.P. Scherer Company, are finding that investors are trying to force them to include equity in the deal, as well as better ''call'' protection. A banker at the firm said yesterday that the Scherer deal had not yet been structured and that he did not know whether it would be offered this week as originally planned.
 
Paine Webber to the Rescue
Stock and stock index futures traders say trading by Paine Webber brokers helped stem the stock market's rout yesterday morning.
The firm's trades - executed for a large institutional client engaged in a ''tactical asset allocation'' shift between stocks and bonds - were behind some of the big moves in the futures contracts yesterday, market sources said.
The buying of stock-index futures contracts began when the Dow was down about 80 points. That buying attracted futures traders in Chicago and helped turn around a plunging market. Paine Webber officials declined to comment.

HEADLINE: FUTURES/OPTIONS;
Index-Contract Gyrations Buffet Underlying Stocks

BYLINE: By KENNETH N. GILPIN

 BODY:
Stock index futures prices gyrated wildly in hectic, heavy trading yesterday, contributing greatly to huge swings in stock prices on Wall Street.
A heavy burst of selling, much of it inspired by speculators in UAL Corporation stock seeking to hedge their positions, pushed the nearby December Standard & Poor's 500-stock index futures contract down its 12-point limit by 9:33 A.M., Central daylight time.
Further sell orders would have led to a 30-minute suspension of trading because the 12-point decline triggered the Chicago Mercantile Exchange's circuit-breaking mechanism. But buy orders, reportedly from Paine Webber, emerged as the S.&P. futures index hit its intraday low of 335.95, and within minutes the contract had regained half of the 12 points it had lost. 
The abrupt turnaround did not immediately lead to a rebound in stock prices, however. Shortly after the S.&P. contract hit its downside limit, the Dow Jones industrial average went into a near free fall and was down more than 85 points at one point.
 
'Panic in the Stock Market'
''When we went lock-limit down in futures, there was some panic in the stock market,'' said Jeffrey Tabak, a partner at Miller Tabak Hirsch & Company in New York. ''But as soon as a buyer in the futures markets emerged, the market began to jump back.''
Jack Barbanel, president of First Global Management Inc. in Princeton, N.J., said: ''Arbitrage-related program trading is exacerbating the up and down movements in stock prices. But everything we have seen since Oct. 13 is being driven by fundamentals. The stock market is in the process of adjusting to lower-than-expected corporate earnings, weak economic news and continued problems in the 'junk bond' market.''
Compared with the market's early gyrations, the next few hours in the stock index futures pits were fairly stable. But additional buying emerged later in the day when, contrary to earlier rumors, problems in the high-yield ''junk bond'' market did not emerge.
 
Trump Rumors Spur Prices
Rumors that Donald J. Trump, the developer, might be preparing a bid for either United Airlines or American Airlines also helped to push index futures prices higher. The rumors, along with the movement in the futures markets, helped underlying stocks. By the end of the session, the Dow index had lost just 3.69 points for a close of 2,659.22.
''This is a completely spastic market,'' said Richard L. Sandor, an executive vice president at Drexel Burnham Lambert. ''The market is incredibly sensitive to rumors. I haven't seen it like this in years.''
Helped by the late burst of buying, the nearby December S.&P. 500 futures contract closed at 346.50, down 1.45 on the day. Meanwhile, the underlying index of the 500 stocks that make up the Standard & Poor's cash index closed at 343.70, down 1.13.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Ends Day Lower; Sales Spurred by Stock Dip

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar finished lower against most leading currencies yesterday, depressed by the volatility of stock prices and by expectations of lower United States interest rates.
A steep morning plunge of more than 80 points in the Dow Jones industrial average touched off a heavy but brief flurry of dollar sales. Those subsided once the stock market started to recover.
David Jaques, a vice president at Barclays Bank P.L.C. in New York, said the dollar did not manage to recover all of the ground it lost during the temporary stock market selloff. The Dow industrials closed at 2,659.22, a loss of 3.69 points.
Mr. Jaques said currency dealings were lethargic in the early going, with traders lacking a compelling reason to buy or sell. News of a decline of one-tenth of 1 percent in September orders for American durable goods created barely a ripple in the currency markets because the figure virtually matched previous estimates.
In New York, the dollar was quoted at 141.50 yen, down from 141.90 yen. A pound cost $1.6075, compared with $1.6030 on Monday.
Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with the quotes of late Monday, included: 1.8358 West German marks, down from 1.8470; 1.6095 Swiss francs, down from 1.6190 Swiss francs; 6.2370 French francs, down from 6.2740; 1.1713 Canadian dollars, up from 1.1704, and 1,345.75 Italian lire, down from 1,356.00.
Gold prices rose. On the Commodity Exchange in New York, gold for current delivery settled at $370.20 an ounce, up $3.20 from Monday. The Republic National Bank of New York quoted a gold bid of $368.70 an ounce at 4 P.M., compared with Monday's late bid of $366.25.

HEADLINE: Real Estate;
2 Hotels Build For Business Travelers

BYLINE: By Shawn G. Kennedy

 BODY:
BUSINESS travelers have long been the bread and butter of the hotel industry in Manhattan, but competition for this segment of the traveling public is heating up as the city's overall hotel occupancy rate drops and more hotels go up.
One way some operators are staking their claim to a bigger share of the Manhattan hotel market is by providing larger and more sophisticated meeting spaces. Two of the most ambitious projects are nearing completion in midtown.
The New York Hilton and Towers Hotel, the largest convention hotel in New York, with 2,121 guest rooms and just under 100,000 square feet of ballroom, meeting and banquet space, will open a 36,000-square-foot expansion of its three-level convention area next month. The new space will be on the second and third floors of an office building under construction just west of the hotel. 
In the other project, the developer Harry Macklowe is putting a 100,000-square-foot conference center in the mixed-use hotel and office building that his company is constructing on the block between 44th and 45th Streets near Broadway in the Times Square area. The hotel and conference center are to open in April.
Industry analysts expect the number of first-class transient rooms in Manhattan to grow by 10 percent by 1991. The current count is 45,000 rooms. Occupancy rates now are running at about 75 percent, a slippage from 78.7 percent two years ago.
Hotel industry analysts say the Hilton and Macklowe projects illustrate not only an increased demand for meeting space in Manhattan but the changing nature of the hotel industry as well. According to Thomas McConnell, a manager of the hotel industry group of Laventhol & Horwath, an accounting and consulting firm, most hotels view these meeting space components as drawing cards rather than profit centers.
''On a per-square-foot basis,'' Mr. McConnell said, ''the cost of building guest rooms or meeting or conference space comes out to be about the same - around $400 to $415 a foot in the city. The extra expense comes in the operation of these facilities.''
Stephen W. Brener, a Manhattan-based hotel consultant, said two factors were behind the lower occupancy rates: rooms added in recent years and budgetary belt-tightening in the corporate world.
''The individual business traveler is still the most valuable customer for most hotels at the upper end,'' he said. ''They represent the largest segment of the market and they pay the highest rates. But the business traveler is harder to get now because companies are economizing by cutting back on travel expenses.''
John F. Power, general manager of the Hilton hotel, said: ''This addition will significantly increase our ability to host groups that we could not accommodate before. Not only will it give us more room, but the new space will have state-of-the-art technology that will allow both those gathering for meetings as well as exhibitors maximum flexibility and advanced audio-visual capabilities.''
The Hilton's new space, which the hotel is calling Americas Hall, is in the 35-story office building being built next door by Edward J. Minskoff and A. Alfred Taubman. They bought the site a few years ago from Hilton Hotels and the Prudential Insurance Company after Hilton decided not to go forward with a plan to build an addition. As part of the deal, the developers agreed to provide specially built space with high ceilings and reinforced floors for the hotel's convention space expansion.
A glass-enclosed bridge will link the new convention halls with the existing meeting and ballroom space on the hotel's second and third floors. Each floor has 18,000 square feet of open space that has been fitted with power lines, 132 telephone jacks, 10 cable televison outlets and the technology needed for satellite or in-house video transmissions. Mr. Power said the new space could accommodate up to four different groups at one time.
With its new venture, the Macklowe organization is seeking to attract a different segment of the meeting market. Rather than trade shows and large conventions, the developer hopes the conference center will appeal to corporate clients that want to hold small meetings but do not want to leave town to do it.
The Macklowe Conference Center will occupy five floors in the 638-room hotel and will incorporate the adjacent Hudson Theater, a landmark auditorium that Mr. Macklowe bought for the air rights that allowed him to raise his new building to 52 stories. The 1,100-seat theater, built in 1904, will be be restored by the developer and will serve as an auditorium for the conference center. It will also be rented for independent events.
The main entrance to the conference center will be on 45th Street, while the lobby for the hotel will be on the 44th Street side of the building. The conference space will include 33 meeting rooms featuring video and rear-screen projection equipment.
