LENGTH: 1558 words

HEADLINE: An Ohio Fair Where Big (and Orange) Is Beautiful

BYLINE: By JENNIFER STOFFEL

DATELINE: CIRCLEVILLE, Ohio

 BODY:
AS the time approached to set his entry on the scales for the city's 83d Pumpkin Show weigh-in, David Mangione, an agricultural extension agent in nearby Chillicothe, shook his head.
''It just hasn't been a good year for pumpkins,'' he said. ''It rained so much, and the fruit didn't set on until August. We probably lost a good 45 days off the growing season.''
It was Mr. Mangione's first time in the competition and he wanted to appear casual about it. His was the first of the 10 giant hybrid pumpkins that had been brought to the town square for the Oct. 18 weigh-in and judging, the unofficial opening of Circleville's four-day pumpkin festival. 
Four men slid Mr. Mangione's giant faded-orange entry onto a blanket, then lifted it off the back of a pickup truck onto the scales. It stood more than 2 feet tall and 4 feet wide. There was silence from the crowd. Mr. Mangione's mottled and slightly lopsided squash came in at 274 pounds. He smiled.
Pumpkins and Circleville have been synonymous since the turn of the century, when farmers began planting pumpkins among their corn to supply local canneries. The show began as a produce sale set up along Main Street in 1903, and has been held every year since except for three years in World War II. These days the festival is nothing less than a pumpkin extravaganza, even though the popularity of freezing forced the last of the canneries to close many years ago. Nowadays the crop goes to farm stands and to out-of-state canneries. The four-day Pumpkin Show, one of the oldest of Ohio's agricultural fairs, inundates this county seat of 14,000 people with more than 300,000 visitors. Whole families from southern Ohio and West Virginia are drawn, some coming back year after year. Many show up dressed in orange.
Aside from the estimated 100,000 pounds of pumpkins on display here, a visitor this year could take in seven parades, beginning with the Oct. 18 parade of the Little Miss Pumpkins and culminating with the Oct. 21 Parade of Queens, when farm festival queens from across the state were invited, among them the Sweet Corn Queen from Millersport and the Apple Festival Queen from Jackson.
In between, awards were handed out for everything pumpkin: pumpkin pie eating, pumpkin face decorating, pumpkin fashions and pumpkin floral arrangements. On the unseasonably cool opening day this year, another crowd gathered at noon outside the Pumpkin Show Building to await the judges' choices among the dozens of baked-goods entries.
The prize for best pumpkin recipe went to Pat Young for her pumpkin drop cookies. The best pumpkin layer cake was Marion Jones's. The champion pie was submitted by Dorothy Norman. The winners in the pumpkin categories are all from Circleville.
But in Circleville pumpkin is not reserved merely for pies, cakes, breads and cookies. At the Pumpkin Show, churches and other local organizations sell pumpkin ice cream, pumpkin fudge, pumpkin waffles, pumpkin soup and even pumpkin sloppy joes. Considering the nutritional merits of pumpkin - it is rich in vitamin A, phosphorus, calcium and iron - this is not a bad thing.
Linda Ballou, a local dog breeder, has been a judge in the baking contests for 10 years. She said she eats pumpkin only this one time.
For Circleville the show is not only the biggest entertainment event of the year, but also a tremendous economic opportunity. Schools close; exhibits and carnival rides are set up in front of the courthouse; the city's five hotels are quickly filled.
A 1984 survey by Pumpkin Show officials found that the show added more than $6 million to the local economy. While the event is promoted as the Greatest Free Show on Earth, Ned Hardin, the owner of the Chevrolet dealership here who has been the event's publicity director for 49 years, said, ''We give them every opportunity to spend their money while they're here.''
He said people keep coming because they get ''bitten by the pumpkin.'' Many former residents choose this time of year to come back the way other families gather for major holidays. ''It's kind of a reunion,'' Mr. Hardin said. ''About every home in town is full of visitors. I myself have 14 people in from out of town.''
The pumpkin weigh-in remains the most important event. It has had its share of controversy through the years. The real giants, including one earlier this decade that set a Circleville record at 510 pounds, are not technically pumpkins, but rather have been crossbred with squash.
To qualify as a true pumpkin, an entry at Circleville must have a hard, five-sided stem, a standard set by Ohio State University. Squash have round, soft stems. Separate weigh-ins are held for pure pumpkins and for hybrids to please both factions of competitors, and separate awards are given. The largest pumpkin this year was 45 pounds, entered by Burness Scarbro. The Circleville record was a 134 1/2-pounder in 1964. But the real crowd pleasers in Circleville are the truly huge entries, even if their breeding is suspect.
Growing the vegetable to such proportions is not easy. These giant hybrids are extraordinarily sensitive. Too much heat or too much rain, conditions growers have had to deal with in succession in the past two years, have kept the weights way below the records. The hybrids are also highly susceptible to fungus that can damage them overnight.
Exact cultivating methods, closely guarded secrets among competitors, include a combination of special fertilizers, near continuous watering and patience. Nick Wohrer, a grower from nearby Lancaster who hauled in a 189-pound entry this year, said he spent at least 30 minutes a day all summer tending his great pumpkin and nipping new blossoms off its vine; he said he even went so far as to talk to it. Other growers spoke of their fear of vandalism and would not reveal the locations of their patches.
Good seeds are also considered among the keys to success. The winner here not only takes home a prize of $1 a pound, but can also make twice as much as that by selling the thick, thumbnail-sized seeds.
It was clear that these vegetables are not judged on shape, color or tenderness. Many were only slightly orange, leaning toward gray with more than a hint of green, conceding their squash relations. And sure enough, this year's champion, a 280-pounder entered by Latta Shaeffer, was mostly green and yellow, and severely flattened across the bottom.
Accepting his loss, Mr. Mangione said, ''There's always next year.'' With that he was off to help lift Mr. Shaeffer's champion onto the truck where it was displayed until the end of the Pumpkin Show.
 
Pumpkin Pie
(Adapted from 1989 Winner, Best Pumpkin Pie, Dorothy Norman, Circleville, Ohio)
Preparation time: 25 minutes
Cooking time: 60 minutes
 
4 eggs
2 cups canned pumpkin or fresh pumpkin puree (see box)
1 cup granulated sugar
 1 teaspoon salt
1 teaspoon allspice
1 teaspoon pumpkin pie spice (a commercial mixture of ginger, cinnamon, cloves and nutmeg)
1 1/2 teaspoons ginger
1 tablespoon cinnamon
 1/2 teaspoon cloves
4 tablespoons butter, melted
3 cups evaporated milk
1 teaspoon vanilla
2 pastry pie shells (9 inches).
1.Preheat oven to 450 degrees.
2.Beat eggs together, lightly.
3.Add each ingredient in order listed and mix well after each addition.
4.Pour into the pie shells.
5.Bake 10 minutes; reduce heat to 350 degrees and bake 50 minutes. Let cool before serving.
Yield: 18 servings.
 
Pumpkin Drop Cookies
(Adapted from 1989 Winner, Best of Pumpkin Show, Pat Young, Circleville, Ohio)
Preparation time: 25 minutes
Cooking time: 10 minutes
 
2 cups flour
1 teaspoon baking powder
1 teaspoon cinnamon
 1/2 teaspoon baking soda
 1/2 teaspoon nutmeg
1 cup butter, plus butter for greasing cookie sheets
1 cup brown sugar, packed
1 egg
1 cup canned pumpkin or fresh pumpkin puree (see box)
1 teaspoon vanilla
1 teaspoon grated orange peel
 1/4 cup currants
 1/4 cup chopped walnuts
 1/4 cup confectioners' sugar, approximately
2 tablespoons milk, approximately
36 pecan halves.
1.Preheat oven to 375 degrees.
2.Stir together first five ingredients and put aside.
3.Beat 1/2 cup butter for 30 seconds, then add brown sugar, beating until fluffy.
4.Add egg, pumpkin, vanilla and orange peel to butter mixture and beat well.
5.Combine dry ingredients with butter mixture.
6.Mix in currants and walnuts.
7.Drop by teaspoons on greased cookie sheet, two inches apart.
8.Bake 8 to 10 minutes.
9.To prepare icing, heat remaining butter quickly over high heat until it darkens, being careful not to burn. Remove from heat and add confectioners' sugar and milk alternately, just enough to thicken.
10.Spread icing on top of cooked and cooled cookies, decorating each with a pecan half.
Yield: 3 dozen cookies.
 
Look, No Cans!
TO make pureed fresh pumpkin cut pumpkin in half and remove seeds and stringy portion. Peel and cut into one-inch pieces. Cook, covered, in one inch of boiling salted water for 25 to 35 minutes, or until tender. Drain and mash. Drain again and puree in a blender or food processor. In selecting pumpkin for cooking, look for one that is bright orange, firm, unblemished and with its stem firmly attached. It should be stored in a cool, dry place, away from the danger of frost.

HEADLINE: Gorbachev, in Finland, Disavows Any Right of Regional Intervention

BYLINE: By BILL KELLER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: HELSINKI, Finland, Oct. 25

 BODY:
President Mikhail S. Gorbachev declared today that the Soviet Union has no moral or political right to interfere in the affairs of its East European neighbors, and held up neutral Finland as a model of stability in stormy Europe.
His spokesman embroidered the theme jokingly, saying that Moscow had adopted ''the Sinatra doctrine'' in Eastern Europe. ''You know the Frank Sinatra song, 'I Did It My Way?' '' said Gennadi I. Gerasimov to reporters. ''Hungary and Poland are doing it their way.''
''I think the Brezhnev doctrine is dead,'' he added, using the Western term for the previous Soviet policy of armed intervention to prevent changes in the Communist governments of the Warsaw Pact, In talks with Finland's President, Mauno Koivisto, at the beginning of a three-day state visit, Mr. Gorbachev was reported to have said that the current political upheavals in the East bloc must be allowed to run their course. 
 
Of Regional Interest
Mr. Gorbachev has repeatedly pledged a policy of noninterference, but his emphasis on the point - and his lauding of the Finnish example - were striking in a week when Hungary was joining Poland in a retreat from orthodox Communist rule, and East Germany was boiling with demands for political liberty.
''The events that are now taking place in the countries of Eastern Europe concern the countries and people of that region,'' the Soviet leader told the Finnish President, according to Mr. Gerasimov, whose formal position is that of spokesman for the Soviet Foreign Ministry. ''We have no right, moral or political right, to interfere in events happening there. We assume others will not interfere either.''
Finland, once an autonomous part of czarist Russia, gained its independence in 1917. It was invaded by the Soviet Union late in 1939, after the formal outbreak of World War II, and was forced to cede some territory to the Russians. The Karelian Autonomous Republic, which borders on Finland, is largely populated by Finnish-speakers.
Today, as Mr. Gorbachev moved through largely friendly crowds, there were some cries of ''Give us back Karelia,'' but no indication that he heard them.
Mr. Gerasimov, who served for many years as a correspondent for the Soviet news-feature agency Novosti in New York, has used the ''Sinatra doctrine'' expression before to explain the willingness of the Soviet Union to allow its allies to follow different political lines.
 
A Deft Response
Mr. Gerasimov declined a direct answer when asked how Moscow would respond if its allies wanted to move toward neutrality. He noted that Hungary and Poland still have obligations as members of military and economic alliances with the Soviet Union.
''We may witness a change of government in Warsaw or Budapest, but international obligations do not necessarily go away with a change of government,'' Mr. Gerasimov said.
He added that Moscow has long proposed a mutual breakup of both the North Atlantic Treaty Organization and the Warsaw Pact, but he did not say how the Kremlin would react if the Warsaw Pact showed signs of breaking up on its own.
Still, Mr. Gorbachev's remarks today seemed to suggest that Moscow is open to more fundamental changes in its relations with East bloc allies.
Both Poland and Hungary have said they do not plan to leave the alliance, but some officials in both countries favor drastic military changes, including withdrawal of Soviet forces now based on their soil.
In recent months, Finland - with a largely free-market economy but reliant on Soviet trade, formally neutral but always attentive to Soviet security concerns - has loomed large in the minds of East bloc countries. Hungary has sent several delegations to study Finland's economy, its laws and its relations with Moscow.
Asked during a brief walk in downtown Helsinki this evening whether he considered Finland a model for countries in Eastern Europe, Mr. Gorbachev replied, ''To me, Finland is a model of relations between a big country and a small country, a model of relations between states with different social systems, a model of relations between neighbors.''
As if to underscore the advantages of good-neighborly relations, Soviet officials this week are to sign an agreement to sharply reduce sulfur emissions that have been poisoning Finland's forests.
Kaj Barlund, the Finnish Minister of the Environment, said in an interview today that it was ''the most radical'' anti-pollution agreement ever signed between a Communist and a non-Communist country, but he conceded that the Soviets would probably require costly technological help from the Finns to live up to their end of the deal.
The treaty calls for reducing the two countries' 1.4 million tons a year of sulfur-dioxide emissions by half before 1995. The largest share of the noxious emissions comes from two Soviet nickel smelters a few miles east of the Finnish border.
Mr. Gorbachev also made a significant concession to Finland's pride tonight when he said at a banquet speech, ''I want to greet neutral Finland.''
It was the first time that a Soviet leader had given full weight to this country's policy of neutrality in world politics. Moscow's reluctance to directly acknowledge that Finland is neutral has long been resented here as an implication that Finland owes special deference to the Kremlin.
 
A Finely Tuned Ear
In turn, Mr. Koivisto, the Finnish President, demonstrated the kind of sensitivity to the Soviet Union that the Kremlin prizes in this relationship. He included in his banquet speech an implicit but unmistakable message of non-support for separatist movements in Soviet Lithuania, Latvia and Estonia, across the Baltic Sea from Finland.
Mr. Koivisto said that although tensions are now erupting in the Soviet Union, ''underneath the surface, there is every reason for confidence in the ability of this community of peoples to solve its problems in a way that enables the distinctiveness of the parts to be increased while strengthening the whole.''
Finland and Estonia, which face each other across the Gulf of Finland, have longstanding ties that are now expanding. Direct air connections and a new, second ferry line across the gulf are due to open this winter, adding to an already fast-growing business and tourist traffic. Finnish bankers and businessmen say they see promising investment opportunities if Estonia gets greater economic independence from Moscow.
 
Russian Praises Baker
MOSCOW, Oct. 25 (Reuters) - The Soviet Union today welcomed what it said was a new American approach to security relations outlined by Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d, and said Washington's view was close to its own.
A Foreign ministry spokesman Vadim P. Perfiliyev, said that recent speeches by Mr. Baker in New York and San Francisco ''clearly demonstrate a new U.S. approach to relations with the Soviet Union.''
After a wait-and-see attitude in Washington during the Bush Administration's early months, the Secretary of State said that American interests lay in the success of Mr. Gorbachev's program of political and economic change.
''The stated principle of stability and predictability in strategic relations completely coincides with our own views,'' Mr. Perfiliyev said, alluding to Secretary Baker's speeches.
But Mr. Perfiliyev also said that his Government could not accept all of Mr. Baker's propositions without qualification. He said Moscow rejected the idea that continued development of cruise missiles and strategic bombers could serve as stabilizing factors because of their slow speed.

HEADLINE: BONN GIVING POLES AID OF $1 BILLION

BYLINE: By FERDINAND PROTZMAN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BONN, Oct. 25

 BODY:
Chancellor Helmut Kohl's trip to Poland, delayed by a dispute over the amount of economic aid he will offer, is to begin Nov. 9. Mr. Kohl will arrive in Warsaw with more than $1 billion in aid to help rebuild a devastated economy, according to West German officials.
The money, in the form of a package of credits, is meant to buy breathing room for the Solidarity-led Government's economic and political changes. Bonn is also heralding the visit as the beginning of a new era in West German-Polish relations. The trip was originally planned to coincide with the 50th anniversary of the invasion of Poland by Nazi Germany, on Sept. 1, 1939, which began World War II. 
 
Substantially More Offered
The size of the aid package, the largest by a Western nation since Solidarity in August formed Poland's first non-Communist Government of the postwar era, also signals what West German officials said was a special obligation toward Poland rooted in the history of turbulent relations between the two nations.
Mr. Kohl postponed his visit in July after Poland rejected West Germany's original aid offer as insufficient. Although Bonn is withholding details of the new aid package until they are officially announced in Warsaw during Mr. Kohl's stay, West German officials said it was substantially larger than the amount Warsaw rejected.
A three-year French aid package announced today totals $642 million, weakenening West Germany's contention that other Western nations are not providing their share of aid for Poland's program of political and economic change.
Mr. Kohl's center-right coalition Government strongly supports the idea that Western industrialized nations must provide financial support for Eastern European nations, like Poland and Hungary, willing to undertake political and economic changes, West German officials say.
The Bush Administration asked Congress for $455 million in aid for Poland and Hungary over three years. The House of Representatives voted last week to provide $837.5 million to the two countries over three years. The Senate is expected to take up a $989 million, three-year package soon.
The new West German credit package was designed to deflect domestic criticism that the generosity toward Poland, which already has a huge foreign debt burden, is excessive.
West German officials and economists said that the amount of aid has been raised substantially and that the new package will total between $1 billion and $1.5 billion. But rather than provide large new lines of open credit, Bonn will instead guarantee bank loans to help finance specific foreign-exchange-earning projects, officials said. It will also encourage joint ventures between West German companies and Polish concerns.
Poland has given West Germany a list of industrial and agricultural projects that total more than $1.5 billion. While it is highly unlikely that all of them will come to fruition, West German officials said a substantial number could be approved.
 
'A Lot of Verbal Support'
These officials are also mildly critical of the reluctance shown by the United States, Britain and other industrialized nations to provide as much financial aid to Poland as Bonn is offering. ''There has been a lot of verbal support from the Western industrial nations, but not much money,'' an official said. ''With winter approaching, economic aid is vital.''
Volker Ruhe, a member of Parliament and secretary general of Mr. Kohl's party, the Christian Democratic Union, expanded on that view. ''One of the reasons we can't wait with aid for Poland is that if we fail to support the reform movement this time, what hopes are left for Poland?'' he said ''It's the same with Hungary. If we want democracy to succeed, they also need goulash.''
When German and Polish officials failed to reach agreement on an aid package in July and Mr. Kohl was forced to delay his visit, Bonn blamed turmoil in the Polish Government and differences over tying West German economic aid to better treatment of the German minority in Poland. Polish officials said the aid package was simply not enough.
Mr. Kohl's policy toward Poland has drawn sharp criticism from right-wing politicians in West Germany. They have raised the issue of German territory lost to Poland after World War II, and played to resentments among lower-middle-class West Germans of the number of ethnic Polish immigrants, asylum seekers and black-market laborers.
Bonn last gave its backing to loans for Poland in 1986, but the credit line was rapidly closed when Poland failed to keep up with payments on its $39 billion in foreign debt.
 
French to Give $642 Million
PARIS, Oct. 25 (Special to The New York Times) - Three days after Lech Walesa criticized France for not doing enough to aid Poland, the French Government announced today that it would provide $642 million in emergency assistance to Poland over the next three years.
France made the announcement hours before President Francois Mitterrand gave a speech to the European Parliament calling on the nations of Western European to coordinate their aid programs for Eastern Europe.
Mr. Mitterrand also urged that Western European nations form an investment bank to provide loans to help Poland modernize its economy.
Under the plan announced today, Paris would provide $145 million in investment credits to Poland, and $320 million in trade credits.
On Sunday, Mr. Walesa said France's tardiness in providing aid to Poland was ''scandalous.''

HEADLINE: Mary McCarthy, 77, Is Dead; Novelist, Memoirist and Critic

BYLINE: By MICHIKO KAKUTANI

 BODY:
Mary McCarthy, one of America's pre-eminent women of letters, died of cancer yesterday at New York Hospital. She was 77 years old and lived in Castine, Me., and Paris.
In her long and prolific career as a novelist, memoirist, journalist and critic, Miss McCarthy earned recognition for her cool, analytic intelligence and her exacting literary voice - a voice capable of moving from the frivolously feminine to the willfully cerebral, from girlish insouciance to bare-knuckled fury.
In 1984, she was awarded both the Edward MacDowell Medal for outstanding contributions to literature and the National Medal for Literature.
 
'A Subversive Soul'
''If there were any real ancestor among American women for Mary McCarthy it might be Margaret Fuller,'' the critic Elizabeth Hardwick, a friend, once observed, referring to the 19th-century American editor, essayist, poet, teacher and translator. ''Both women have will power, confidence and a subversive soul sustained by exceptional energy.'' 
Miss McCarthy's accounts of sexual shenanigans in ''The Man in the Brooks Brothers Shirt'' in 1941 and ''The Group'' in 1963 created something of an uproar when they first appeared. But her notoriety in literary circles stemmed less from the scandal quotient of her fiction than from her adversarial literary and political stands. She had celebrated public skirmishes with Philip Rahv, Diana Trilling and Lillian Hellman; issued vitriolic pronouncements on Watergate and the Vietnam War, and became known for the ferocity of her book and theater reviews.
 
Perverse Opinions
At their worst, those reviews pointed up Miss McCarthy's weakness for catchy one-liners and her taste for willfully perverse opinions. Of Tennessee Williams's ''Streetcar Named Desire'' she wrote, ''His work reeks of literary ambition as the apartment reeks of cheap perfume,'' and of Eugene O'Neill and ''The Iceman Cometh'' she declared, ''He is probably the only man in the world who is still laughing at the Iceman joke or pondering its implications.''
Yet at her best (as in ''The Stones of Florence'') Miss McCarthy was an erudite cultural historian, using her familiarity with history, politics and the arts - and the application of some plain old-fashioned common sense -to draw surprising connections and to make her readers reconsider their preconceptions.
''A career of candor and dissent is not an easy one for a woman; the license is jarring and the dare often forbidding,'' Ms. Hardwick said. ''Such a person needs more than confidence and indignation. A great measure of personal attractiveness and a high degree of romantic singularity are necessary to step free of the mundane, the governessy, the threat of earnestness and dryness. Moderating influences are essential.''
In the case of Miss McCarthy, she said, ''the purity of style and the liniment of her wit, her gay summoning of the funny facts of everyday life, soften the scandal of the action or the courage of the opinion.''
To Robert Lowell, Miss McCarthy was ''our Diana, rash to awkwardness,'' blurting ''ice clear'' sentences above the ''mundane gossip and still more mundane virtue'' of her colleagues. To Alfred Kazin, she was the owner of ''a wholly destructive critical mind,'' a critic with an ''unerring ability to spot the hidden weakness or inconsistency in any literary effort and every person.'' And to Norman Mailer, she was ''our First Lady of Letters'' -''our saint, our umpire, our lit arbiter, our broadsword, our Barrymore (Ethel), our Dame (dowager), our mistress (Head), our Joan of Arc.''
 
Heroines Were Self-Portraits
The most tireless mythologizer of her life, however, remained Miss McCarthy herself. There were her memoirs: ''Memories of a Catholic Girlhood'' (1957), the beautifully observed portrait of her painful youth, and the later, more workmanlike ''How I Grew,'' published in 1987. In addition, the heroines in Miss McCarthy's fiction form a sort of continuing portrait of the author: Meg in ''The Company She Keeps'' (1942), the clever Vassar girl, ''a princess among the trolls''; Martha, ''the bohemian lady'' in ''A Charmed Life'' (1955), whose need to ''tell the truth'' continually gets her into trouble; Kay, the skeptical iconoclast in ''The Group'' (1963), and Rosamund, the esthetic mother figure in ''Birds of America'' (1971).
These novels also included sharp-edged portraits of many of Miss McCarthy's friends and lovers: her second husband, the critic Edmund Wilson, was portrayed as a loud, unappealing intellectual in ''A Charmed Life''; and Rahv, her roommate and mentor as editor of The Partisan Review, turned up in ''The Oasis'' (1949).
Yet if Miss McCarthy's novels often read like thinly disguised exercises in autobiography, they also attempted to provide an idiosyncratic chronicle of American life - at least within her own intellectual set - as it changed over some five decades. Sexual freedom in the 1930's, radicalism in the 40's and 50's, Vietnam and the social upheavals of the 60's, Watergate and terrorism in the 70's - these are the larger issues that flicker in the background of the novels.
 
Fiction Was Difficult
There is a certain didacticism to these books, a feeling of willed creation, and Miss McCarthy herself acknowledged that she found it considerably more difficult to write fiction than essays or reviews.
Each novel, she once said, had its genesis with an idea. ''Birds of America,'' which chronicled the coming of age of a teen-age ornithologist, was meant to be ''a novel about the idea of equality and its relation to nature''. ''The Groves of Academe'' (1952), a satiric portrait of a scheming scholar and his colleagues, was intended to address the question ''Where is the justice for an impossible person?'' ''The Group,'' a chatty gossip sheet about the lives of eight Vassar women, was conceived as a study of the illusory idea of social and political progress that captivated so many young people in the 1930's.
That last novel, which brought Miss McCarthy both a popular audience and a movie sale, enhanced her almost legendary reputation for enraging old friends and acquaintances who thought they saw themselves as the thinly disguised and gleefully skewered characters in her fiction.
 
A Painful Childhood
Throughout her career, Miss McCarthy seemed preoccupied with two themes: what she called ''the idea of justice'' and the idea of self-reliance. Both impulses originated in her painful childhood, and both, in a sense, led to her later attempts to invent an identity true to her platonic conception of herself.
Mary Therese McCarthy was born on June 21, 1912, in Seattle, the daughter of Roy Winfield McCarthy, a member of a prominent Roman Catholic family in Minneapolis, and the former Therese Preston, whose father, a transplanted New Englander, was one of Seattle's most successful lawyers. She had three brothers, Kevin, Preston and Sheridan.
The early years of Miss McCarthy's life seem to have been a romantic idyll; she would later portray them as a lovely succession of parties and holidays, with May baskets and valentines.
''Both my parents were handsome, winning and romantic,'' she wrote. ''Their marriage was opposed by both families, partly for religious reasons, and partly because my father was an invalid, with an invalid's febrile vitality. He had a bad heart, and it was prophesied, from the first, that he would die young and leave his wife with a pack of children.''
 
'Dickensian Cruelty'
In fact, both he and his wife died in the great flu epidemic of 1918, and the 6-year-old Mary and her three brothers were sent to live with their great-aunt Margaret and her husband in Minneapolis. There, they experienced what she once called ''circumstances of almost Dickensian cruelty and squalor.'' The children were made to stand outdoors for three hours at a time in the snow, and they were regularly thrashed with a razor strop; Miss McCarthy recalled being beaten in one instance for receiving a school prize, lest she become ''stuck up.''
Miss McCarthy's bitter recollection continued: ''Two blocks away, my McCarthy grandparents, dwelling in sumptuous middle-class style, instilled in us the contrast between wealth and penury by occasional treats and vacations; it was thought beneficial that we should know we were orphans and fitted for a different destiny than our well-tended cousins.
''Today, some of my relations allege my literary successes and my brother Kevin's career as an actor as proof that the harsh formula followed in our upbringing produced results; nevertheless, I cannot feel grateful. Nor do I believe that artistic talent flowers necessarily from a wounding of the stem on which it grows.''
When she was 11, Miss McCarthy was rescued from her misery in Minneapolis by her maternal grandfather, Harold Preston, who took her to Seattle and gave her a fine education at the Forest Ridge Convent and the Annie Wright Seminary.
 
Puritanism vs. Romance
As ''Memories of a Catholic Girlhood'' and ''How I Grew'' indicate, the twists and turns of Miss McCarthy's melodramatic childhood would develop two distinct sides to her personality: on one hand, the puritanical student who wants to win prizes for her scholarship and dreams of becoming a nun; on the other, the die-hard romantic who writes moody stories about suicide and prostitution and dreams of becoming an actress. In fact, before she left for college in 1929, Miss McCarthy took some acting classes at the Cornish Drama School in Seattle, where she met the actor Harold Cooper Johnsrud, whom she married a week after her graduation from Vassar. She would divorce him three years later.
By the time Miss McCarthy left Vassar in 1933, she said, she had become ''a wayward modern girl,'' determined, in the words of her colleague William Barrett, ''to hold her own with men - both intellectually and sexually.'' Her finely observed collection of interconnected stories, ''The Company She Keeps,'' would chronicle - in slightly disguised fashion - many of her adventures in these early post-college years, including the breakup of her first marriage, her desultory love affairs and her dabbling in Trotskyite politics.
Writing of that time, Mr. Barrett described the girlishly pretty writer as ''a Valkyrie maiden, riding her steed into the circle, amid thunder and lightning, and out again, bearing the body of some dead hero across her saddle.''
Two influential men of letters, Rahv and Wilson, would play important roles in the shaping of Miss McCarthy's career. Rahv, with whom she lived during the 1930's, helped her to get her first literary job - writing theater reviews for the magazine; Wilson, whom she married in 1938, persuaded her to try writing fiction. He put her in a room, she recalled, and told her to stay there until she finished a story. Their tempestuous marriage produced one son, Reuel, and ended in divorce in 1946. Later that year she married Bowden Broadwater, a writer and teacher.
 
Satiric Wit
With a clinical eye and an apparently total gift for recall, Miss McCarthy used her satiric wit to illuminate the pretensions and prejudices of her fellow intellectuals. Much of her writing was devoted to exposing what she regarded as the ignorance, bigotry, dishonest sentimentality and affectation that cluttered the intellectual marketplace.
She defended Hannah Arendt and William Burroughs when it was fashionable to assail them, and attacked J. D. Salinger, Kenneth Tynan and Arthur Miller when others were singing their praises.
The litigious Lillian Hellman was so incensed, in 1980, by Miss McCarthy's description of her in a television interview as a ''dishonest writer'' that she instituted a $2.25 million defamation suit.
Hellman's death in 1984 placed the lawsuit in limbo, making Miss McCarthy feel somewhat put out. ''I still feel disgusted by the amount of lying that didn't stop,'' she said in an interview in 1987. ''I wanted it to go to trial, so I was disappointed when she died.''
 
Busy Despite Health Problems
Miss McCarthy married James Raymond West, a former director of information for the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development, in 1961. They divided their time between an apartment in Paris and their house in Maine.
In addition to her husband and son, Miss McCarthy is survived by two stepsons, Daniel West of Los Angeles and Jonathan West of Lodz, Poland; a stepdaughter, Alison West of Manhattan; two brothers, Kevin, of Sherman Oaks, Calif., and Preston, of Millsboro, Del., and two grandchildren.
In recent years, Miss McCarthy had several operations for hydrocephalus (water on the brain), but maintained a hectic schedule, working on another volume of memoirs, contemplating a study of Gothic architecture, teaching literature at Bard College and learning German. She recalled telling a friend some two decades ago that she ''never woke up in the morning without a feeling of intense repentance and a resolve to be better.''
''I don't do that anymore - or almost never,'' she said in a recent interview. ''But I do have this idea of improvement, if not in one's powers, at least in one's vision, in one's understanding. I suppose it's all tied up with the American belief in progress. Not that I have that as an idea, but I certainly have it in my personal life. I couldn't live without feeling I know more than I did yesterday.''

HEADLINE: MEDICARE CUTBACK EXPECTED TO ADD TO PRIVATE RATES

BYLINE: By MARTIN TOLCHIN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 25

 BODY:
Insurance experts and members of Congress say millions of older Americans will face higher health insurance costs if Congress repeals or cuts back the Medicare program that pays for the catastrophically high costs of a major illness.
The higher expected costs would come in the form of higher premiums on policies offered by many private insurers to cover the difference between the total cost of an illness and what the Government pays under Medicare.
The planned Medigap increases were not unexpected by the health insurance experts. Private insurers had said earlier this year that they were holding down increases because many benefits had been picked up by the Federal program. The proposed increases are subject to approval by individual state insurance regulators. 
 
Increases Up to 43%
Industry officials and members of Congress said in interviews over the past two days that private insurers have proposed or plan to propose increases in premiums ranging from 10 percent to 43 percent to compensate for an anticipated increase in coverage if Congress, as expected, repeals or sharply curtails the program to pay for major illness.
The officials said they could not precisely estimate the number of older Americans who would face higher payments, but they noted that 25 million of the 33 million Medicare recipients carry the additional insurance.
Congress passed the Medicare Catastrophic Coverage Act in June 1988 to help the elderly avoid financial ruin from the cost of a major illness after President Ronald Reagan proposed the plan. But Congressional curtailment is near because of strong protests from elderly taxpayers opposed to the income tax surcharge that helps finances the program.
 
Sullivan Opposes Repeal
President Bush has not taken a position on the issue. But Dr. Louis W. Sullivan, Secretary of Health and Human Services, opposes repeal.
Some companies are awaiting final Congressional action before proposing the amount of their increases. The legislation is now before a Senate-House conference committee. The House voted to repeal the program that places a ceiling on elderly patients' payments for hospital and doctor bills and would pay much of the cost of prescription drugs. The Senate voted to retain only the hospital benefits.
Premiums for Medigap policies range from about $200 to about $1,300 a year. The Blue Cross/Blue Shield Association estimates that repeal or cutback of the Medicare program to pay for major illness will increase monthly premiums in its policies by an average of 43 percent, or $21, in the North; 26 percent, or $14.22, in the West; 26 percent, or $12.38, in the East; 21 percent, or $11.40, in the South, and 15 percent, or $8, in the Midwest.
These increases would be in addition to increases that Blue Cross says would be to cover the cost of inflation in health care of 33 percent in the North; 14 percent in the West; 5 percent in the East and 10 percent in both the South and Midwest.
Under the Medicare program to pay for major illness, an elderly American who earns more than $15,000 annually pays the mininmum surtax, which is $22.50 for every $150 of income taxes paid, while an elderly citizen with an income of more than $35,000 pays the maximum of $800. The program is also financed by a $4 monthly premium deducted from the Social Security checks of all Medicare beneficiaries.
Many of those who pay the surtax said they resented paying to finance a program that duplicates the private coverage they have as retirement benefits.
Congressional authorities estimate that about 20 million elderly taxpayers with incomes below $15,000 would receive the benefits under the program without paying the surtax. This group is among those who now face the prospect of going without Medigap policies or having to pay for benefits they would have received under the Government program at little cost.
 
Very Poor Are Unaffected
Insurance industry officials said that repeal or curtailment of the program is unlikely to affect the very poor, whose health benefits are covered by Medicaid.
''The people who are mostly going to be hurt by this are the 20 million who wouldn't have paid any surtax,'' said Representative Pete Stark, Democrat of California, the chairman of the Health Subcommittee of the Ways and Means Committee and a co-sponsor of the program. Mr. Stark said he did not believe the prospect of premium increases would cause Congress to preserve the program, because those who would be hurt most were the least influential politically.
Mr. Stark said, ''These companies all told us this year that they raised their premiums less than they would have otherwise because the government's catastrophic coverage plan had taken over some of the exposure that their plans had covered.''
The proposed rate increases for private insurance have stirred renewed controversy on Capitol Hill about the lobbying campaign waged by those who sought to repeal the surtax and ended up nearly destroying the program, which was passed with bipartisan support. The program pays for hospital costs above $560. Beginning Jan. 1 it would pay doctor bills of more than $1,370 and beginning in 1991 it would pay for half the cost of prescription drugs of more than $600.
The Health Insurance Association of America, which represents the health industry, estimates that supplemental insurance is held by more than 25 million people, or 78 percent of the 33 million Medicare beneficiaries, of whom 30 million are 65 and over and 3 million are disabled.
A majority of those with such insurance pay for it themselves. Three out of 10 older Americans receive some Medigap insurance as a retirement benefit, but many of them purchase additional Medigap insurance from private companies, according to the Employee Benefit Research Institute.
 
Empire Blue Cross Waiting
Albert A. Cardone, chairman and chief executive officer of Empire Blue Cross and Blue Shield, which covers New York City and suburbs, said, ''If the Federal government covers less and we have to cover more, it would make sense to have a premium increase.'' He said that his organization would await final Congressional action on the program before applying for a rate increase.
Officials of the American Association of Retired Persons said that the policy that the organization offers through the Prudential Insurance company will probably seek an increase 25 percent above inflation if the Medicare Catastrophic Coverage Act was repealed and 15 percent if the program is drastically curtailed.
Representative Brian J. Donnelly, Democrat of Massachussetts, and a sponsor of the House bill that would repeal the program, was asked about the rate increases sought by his home state and elsewhere, and said, ''These are only rate requests.''
''These companies always go to the high mark,'' Mr. Donnelly said. ''We're going to keep a close eye on these people to make sure that they don't gouge the seniors. I hope these insurers don't think they can take advantage of the elderly.''

PUB-DATE: October 26, 1989

SECTION: Section A; Page 1, Column 1; Metropolitan Desk

LENGTH: 2764 words

HEADLINE: H.U.D. Economist Says Bosses Pressed Him to Approve Grants

BYLINE: By MICHAEL WINERIP

 BODY:
The economist for the Department of Housing and Urban Development in New York says two former regional administrators improperly pressured him and other subordinates several times to support favored grant applicants. Two examples that he cited as the worst involved projects with ties to Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato.
The two regional administrators, Joseph Monticciolo and Geraldine McGann, are longtime associates of the Senator. Both were sponsored for their H.U.D. jobs by Mr. D'Amato. All three have denied any impropriety.
The H.U.D. regional economist, David Burns, spoke in a recent interview. He is the first high-ranking New York H.U.D. official to talk extensively in an interview about how the troubled office was run. 
In 1987, Mr. Burns said, Mr. Monticciolo ordered him to approve a project site proposed for the Lower East Side of Manhattan that Mr. Burns was going to reject.
''He said, 'Look, David, you're going to have to change your recommendation,' '' Mr. Burns recalled.
 
'Caved In'
Mr. Burns, in his own words, ''caved in.'' Within months, a Long Island-based construction company, Jobco, was chosen general contractor for the Lower East Side project. Jobco is a major campaign contributor to Mr. D'Amato, and it employs the Senator's brother as a lawyer.
Mr. Burns's account contradicts sworn testimony Mr. Monticciolo gave before Congress last summer, when he said he had never pressured his technical staff members to change their recommendations.
Mr. Monticciolo's lawyer, Robert Hill Schwartz, who is handling all questions for him, did not reply to a list of questions submitted in a telephone call by a reporter. Mr. Schwartz did not return frequent follow-up calls.
In 1988, Mr. Burns recalled, Mrs. McGann pressured him to approve a senior-citizen housing project at 105th Street and First Avenue in Manhattan that Mr. Burns had planned to reject because he thought the area already had too much subsidized housing. Again, Mr. Burns says, he gave in, and the project was approved for a nonprofit group whose board includes the Senator's mother and a former aide to Mr. D'Amato.
Mr. Burns, who has held his post for 15 years, said the two projects were ''the worst sites I'm aware of that were approved'' by the H.U.D. office in recent years. He described the neighborhoods as already filled with subsidized housing and abandoned buildings, and he called them dangerous for the elderly.
Zenia Mucha, a spokeswoman for the Senator, said that neither Mr. D'Amato nor his staff had spoken to H.U.D. officials about the Lower East Side project. ''We had absolutely no knowledge who the developer was going to be,'' Ms. Mucha said.
A lawsuit by a neighborhood group has prevented construction on the Lower East Side project.
Mr. D'Amato, a New York Republican, has said that while his staff has given ''technical'' aid to the nonprofit group sponsoring the 105th Street project, the New York Foundation for Senior Citizens, he never pressured H.U.D. on its behalf. Reports of Pressure Are Denied Asked by members of a House Government Operations subcommittee who were investigating political favoritism at H.U.D. if he ever pressured his technical specialists to change their decisions for ''your own justifiable or unjustifiable reasons,'' Mr. Monticciolo testified, ''I've never tried to change the outcome.''
In an interview, Mrs. McGann said the New York Foundation for Senior Citizens was chosen on its merits, and it ''didn't make a difference'' who was on the board. Representatives of Jobco and the foundation also said they were chosen on merit and knew of no pressure applied on their behalf.
Mr. Burns's assertions, taken along with recent Congressional testimony by another former high-ranking New York administrator, Alexander Naclerio, portray an office where H.U.D. regulations were often bent, broken or waived to justify and mask political or personal favoritism.
Mr. Burns recalled being sent to work on a H.U.D. project in Seabrook, N.J., and being told by Mr. Monticciolo: ''Don't do anything improper. These are not my people.''
In September, Mr. Naclerio testified that Mr. D'Amato's influence was so extensive that Mr. Monticciolo made sure ''things were cleared with Senator D'Amato,'' and that his H.U.D. phone had a rapid-dial button to the Senator.
Mr. Monticciolo and Mr. Naclerio were recently subpoenaed to appear before a Federal grand jury in Brooklyn investigating H.U.D.'s New York office.
This month, the Housing Secretary, Jack F. Kemp, disciplined Mrs. McGann, moving her from New York to the Washington office, after an internal investigation concluded that she had violated ethics rules in connection with a program in her hometown of Island Park, L.I., in which her son and a cousin of Mr. D'Amato were among those awarded subsidized houses.
The regional economist is one of the top 20 staff members in H.U.D.'s New York office, which includes 950 employees. He evaluates potential housing sites, determines the feasability of projects and sets rents for the government to charge.
Mr. Monticciolo was the fourth regional director that Mr. Burns worked for as economist, and Mr. Burns said he had never been pressured this way before. He said he felt the pressure was improper because he was being asked to issue a false recommendation. Mr. Burns said the interference occurred most frequently on Section 202, a program for building senior-citizen housing. Both the Lower East Side and the New York Foundation projects are under Section 202. Winning Applicants Had D'Amato Ties There were other indications of problems and favoritism with the 202 program. In 1985, H.U.D. officials in Washington were so displeased with the projects chosen for grants by the New York office, they revised the list, something that had never happened in H.U.D.'s nine other regional offices.
An examination of H.U.D.'s New York records indicated that about two-thirds of the successful applicants for Section 202 grants during 1986-88 had at least one major participant who was a D'Amato contributor. Several of those contributors said in interviews last summer that they gave because they believed Senator D'Amato had major influence in the office.
One project knocked off the list by H.U.D. officials in Washington in 1985 was sponsored by the senior-citizens foundation. The Senator's mother, Ann, and his former aide, Deborah Smith Bernstein, joined the foundation's 29-member unpaid board that year. The next year, New York again approved the project, and this time it won a $5.7 million grant.
In an interview last summer, Senator D'Amato said his staff might have gone ''to extra lengths to help a great, great group, and it's one I'd continue to help because they do great work.'' He said his staff had given similar ''technical'' assistance to other worthy groups seeking Section 202 grants.
Each applicant for a senior-citizen project was supposed to be ranked by H.U.D. on a rating system, which gave points for quality of the site, management team and architectural and engineering plans. Typically, 100 nonprofit groups vied for 15 grants each year in New York and its suburbs.
Mr. Monticciolo told Congress that everything was done by the book, that he followed his specialists' recommendations.
'Take Another Look At the Site'
Representative Donald Lukens, an Ohio Republican, asked, ''Do you remember at any time ever pressuring any staffer who contributed to the merit system in terms of changing their rating?''
Mr. Monticciolo said he sometimes asked, ''Why did you give these points?'' ''Or in some cases,'' he continued, ''sites were turned down, and then we would get them to go back and take another look at the site or send the superior out to look at a site to determine whether or not it was acceptable.''
''You might have once or twice attempted to change the outcome for your own justifiable or unjustifiable reasons?'' Mr. Lukens asked.
''I've never tried to change the outcome,'' Mr. Monticciolo replied.
Mr. Burns called Mr. Monticciolo's testimony ''misleading and untruthful.''
As economist, Mr. Burns had the power to reject a site if the area was ''unduly concentrated'' with subsidized housing. ''You don't want another Yonkers,'' he said, ''with all the subsidized housing loaded in one area.'' He said he only rejected a site if it was ''a complete disaster.''
In 1987, Mr. Burns intended to reject a site in Manhattan, at Ninth Street and Avenue C, proposed by the Lower East Side Coalition Housing Development. His rejection would almost certainly have killed the project, he said, because there are few available sites that meet H.U.D. criteria in the area where the coalition wished to build.
''It was a low-income area with an overriding concentration of assisted housing,'' at least 60 percent, he said. ''Putting it there was almost a policy of segregation. This is exactly what the law didn't want to happen.''
First, he said, he was asked to change his decision by two of ''Monticciolo's lieutenants in the housing department.'' Then, he said, he was called in by Mr. Monticciolo's assistant at the time, Mrs. McGann, who showed him a memo supporting the site.
To make sure he wasn't being unreasonable, Mr. Burns said, he asked several colleagues to evaluate the site, including John Kemp, the H.U.D. economist for New Jersey, who is not related to the current Housing Secretary. In an interview, John Kemp said he, too, thought the site should be rejected.
''Then Monticciolo told me we were going to take a ride and look at the site, and took along McGann and Jerry Blue,'' Mr. Burns said. Mr. Blue was a special H.U.D. assistant whom Mr. Monticciolo had hired from Senator D'Amato's office.
A Car Ride Changes a Rating ''They really wanted this project for whatever reason,'' Mr. Burns recalled. ''We hadn't left the garage, when Gerri McGann said to me, 'David, try to be objective.' I said, 'You try to be objective.' Monticciolo told me to shut up.
''We got near the project, and Monticciolo said, 'This doesn't seem bad.' And then there was block after block of devastation. He got very quiet. All of a sudden he wasn't talking. Almost glum.''
''I went into his office afterward. I said: 'Joe, I'd like to get along with you, I'd like to be a loyal employee. But it would make a farce of everything I do to change my recommendation. It would make my job meaningless.' He said, 'We'll see.'
''Two weeks later, Monticciolo saw me. He said, 'Look, David, you're going to have to change your recommendation.' ''
Mr. Burns gave it a passing rating. ''When you're in any organization, you want to belong and not just be considered an outcast,'' he explained. ''And I hate to admit it, the bonus system was a factor. You're rewarded for getting along with the boss.''
Mr. Burns said there is nothing wrong with the administrator overriding a technician, if he takes responsibility for the decision. ''But Monticciolo would have had to provide something in the record, and Washington would be able to look at it. He'd rather have his technicians lie for him.''
The Lower East Side project was financed from Secretary Samuel Pierce's discretionary list, which was often used to satisfy political requests. A H.U.D. spokesman in Washington said no documents could be found indicating whether the project had a particular political advocate.
Representatives of the Lower East Side housing coalition said they knew of no elected official who pressured H.U.D. on their behalf. Ms. Mucha, Mr. D'Amato's aide, said that the Senator's staff gave the project no ''technical or special help,'' but that they may have written the type of form letter that the Senator routinely sends for groups seeking his support.
Mrs. McGann said she recalled no involvement by the Senator's office. She said there had been an honest disagreement among staff members, and the car ride was made to discuss the site. Asked why they didn't just overrule Mr. Burns, she said, ''You'd have to speak to Mr. Monticciolo.''
On Aug. 26, 1987, Mr. Monticciolo informed the Lower East Side Coalition of the approval, and a few months later the group selected Jobco of Great Neck, L.I., as general contractor. No bidding is required by H.U.D. in such selections.
Favoritism Charged In Hiring Jobco According to Federal election records, Jobco's owners have given $9,600 to Mr. D'Amato's campaigns and were the hosts of a fund raiser for his 1986 campaign. Armand D'Amato, the Senator's brother, has done legal work for Jobco for years.
At the Congressional hearings last summer, committee members questioned whether Mr. Monticciolo had shown favoritism in picking Jobco for a White Plains housing project. Though Jobco was the third and last choice of White Plains officials and was not the low bidder, H.U.D.'s New York office intervened and Jobco was picked.
Mr. Monticciolo told the panel he had followed his specialists' advice. But when Mr. Naclerio, who supervised the specialists, testified last month, he said Mr. Monticciolo ''urged and told me he wanted Jobco.''
The former director of the Lower East Side group, Luis Nieves, said three companies had responded to requests for proposals. He said Jobco was selected by his board based on its 40 years in the construction business. ''I had no discussions'' about Jobco, Mr. Nieves said. ''No one asked me to call them, to pick them.''
The president of Jobco, Robert Pascucci, said no one from H.U.D. or the Senator's office had aided Jobco in getting the Lower East Side job. He pointed out that Jobco had been doing Federal housing work for a decade before Mr. D'Amato became Senator. He said Jobco withdrew from the project last month because studies of the site showed ''bad subsoil'' conditions that would require expensive below-ground piles, so the project would not be profitable. He said Jobco had not received any compensation.
Paul Terry, a member of the group opposing the project, said the opponents had called Mr. D'Amato's office seeking help in stopping it but were told the Senator supported the project.
Mr. Terry recalled that while examining H.U.D.'s files, he found a letter of support from Mr. D'Amato and became ''really depressed.''
After 20 Years, A $2,000 Bonus In 1988, Mr. Burns said, when Mrs. McGann succeeded Mr. Monticciolo as regional administrator, she began pressuring him on three new projects.
''McGann's aide, Francine Kellman, said, 'Please, David, just look at these again,' '' he said. ''I knew what was happening. I knew it would be McGann next. I didn't want to drag the fight out again.''
He said he caved in quicker this time. That year on his evaluation, Mrs. McGann gave him the top rating, his first ''outstanding'' in 20 years at H.U.D. and his biggest bonus ever, worth nearly $2,000.
''She told me I was loyal,'' Mr. Burns said. ''It made me almost sad. I felt that I had to some extent prostituted myself, and I was getting a bonus.''
If Mr. Burns had rejected the senior-citizen foundation site, it would have killed the project. ''The area was 90 percent subsidized housing,'' he said. ''It wasn't a place for the elderly. I can tell you emphatically, we've got plenty of sites in the city much better.''
After the foundation received H.U.D. approval, the site was opposed by local residents. Ultimately, the nonprofit group decided to seek a location in another part of Manhattan. But because of H.U.D's 1988 approval, it is still eligible for the grant.
Linda Hoffman, director of the foundation, said she ''called the Senator's person in 1988 to find out when'' she would hear on funding for the project. ''I certainly never asked for anyone to pressure on the board's behalf.''
She said Mrs. D'Amato and Mrs. Bernstein had been named to the board because ''we're really looking for people who really care about what we're doing and people who can give their time and help.''
Mrs. McGann said she had never been pressured or exerted pressure on behalf of the foundation. Many sites for H.U.D. senior-citizen buildings in Manhattan are on city-donated land, which is usually not well located, she said, and compromises must be made if housing is to be built.
Asked whether she had sent her aide, Ms. Kellman, to question Mr. Burns's decisions, she said, ''I don't recall.''
Ms. Kellman said that she did not remember the specific project, but that hers is a ''go-fer'' job. She said that she regularly relays messages from the regional administrator asking staff members to reconsider projects, and that no pressure is intended when she does so.

HEADLINE: Rebels Step Up Killings in Peru to Disrupt Election

BYLINE: By JOSEPH B. TREASTER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LIMA, Peru, Oct. 25

 BODY:
A leftist rebel group is mounting the biggest terror campaign in its history in an effort to disrupt Peru's municipal and presidential elections.
With the municipal elections scheduled for Nov. 12, the guerrillas have assassinated 123 mayors and other local officials, political leaders and candidates this year.
It is estimated that more than 400 candidates have resigned in fear, and Government officials expect many more to withdraw before election day.
''This is the first stage in a political military campaign whose ultimate objective is the presidential elections next April,'' said Raul Gonzalez, a political scientist and one of the leading authorities on the Shining Path, a Maoist guerrilla movement known in Spanish as Sendero Luminoso. 
 
Terror More Widespread Now
The Shining Path, founded in 1970 by Abimael Guzman, a philosophy professor at the University of Huamanga in Ayacucho, began its violent effort to take power in Peru with an attack on a rural voting station in the elections in 1980 that brought a civilian President to office after 12 years of military rule.
''The Sendero terror campaign is more widespread now than in any previous year, and it is widespread throughout Peru,'' a United States official said.
About half of the country's 21 million people live in emergency zones where the army is given broad powers to combat the guerrillas. In recent opinion polls terrorism has ranked as the country's greatest concern, a few percentage points ahead of the economy, which declined by 20 percent last year. Narcotics trafficking, the greatest concern of the United States in Peru, was a distant third.
Six months ago, in a demonstration of Shining Path's growing strength, about one million people obeyed the group's demand for a three-day ''armed strike'' in the country's mining and farming heartland, cutting all supplies of food, electric power and export minerals from three Andean provinces to Lima on the Pacific coast.
 
Greater Protection Urged
''They have been getting stronger and stronger,'' said Senator Enrique Bernales, a Socialist. ''They are installing a network in the whole country. This is the most serious threat Peru has ever faced.''
Mario Vargas Llosa, the Peruvian novelist and front-running presidential candidate of the center-right Democratic Front coalition, called on the Government this week to provide more protection for candidates against ''those who want to destroy our democratic system.''
Though the Shining Path imposes an ascetic personal code on members that forbids the use of drugs, it is financing its revolution with earnings estimated at as high as $30 million a year from Peru's cocaine industry. Serving as broker to obtain better prices for growers, it extracts taxes from peasants and fees from traffickers for the use of airfields.
American and Peruvian officials say they do not believe that the Shining Path, with an estimated 4,000 armed members, is capable of blocking either of the coming elections. But its strategy, the officials believe, is to reduce the number of candidates and voters so that the validity of the elections is thrown into doubt, raising the possibility of a return to power for the military.
''The idea is to get the military to step in, with the expectation that the usual repression of a military government would improve the climate for the Senderos, push more people in their direction,'' a United States official said.
 
Military Accused of Abuses
International human rights oganizations have accused Peru's armed forces of widespread abuse of human rights in the name of maintaining order.
The Peruvian Senate's Committee on Violence and Pacification, the most widely relied upon source of statistics on violence here, says Shining Path terrorism is running at an all-time high.
So far this year 1,016 civilians and 293 soldiers and policemen have died in political violence, compared with 1,030 civilians and 289 soldiers and policemen for all of last year. The Shining Path has lost 1,026 dead this year, compared with 667 last year, the committee said.
As the elections approach, the tempo of violence has been picking up. Last month, the committee said, 155 people died in political violence, compared with more than 270 so far this month.
Today, Shining Path guerrillas shot to death an official of the Education Ministry and his nephew in the Andean village of Acobamba, 185 miles east of Lima, The Associated Press quoted the police as saying. In Lima, Reuters reported dynamite attacks today on the Soviet and Chinese Embassies. It said the police blamed the Shining Path in the attacks, which caused minor damage at the two embassies.
In 1984, as the army carried out a major campaign against the Shining Path, civilian deaths were higher than this year. But Western diplomats and some Peruvians say they believe that many of the civilians were killed by the army.
''Without question, this is the most violence we've seen from Sendero,'' an American official said.
The greatest disruptions in the November elections are expected in seven departments along Peru's Andean spine. One of them, Junin, is at the point where the main road from the mountains leads into Lima. Junin is also the location of the main hydroelectric plant for the capital and the source of much of its food.
''Fifty percent of the voters in those areas will probably not be able to vote,'' said Agustin Mantilla, the Minister of Interior, who oversees the nation's police.
Most of the slain mayors have been killed in towns with only a few hundred people, but fear has spread across the nation.
''They are killing some and giving others a time frame in which they will be killed if they don't resign,'' Senator Bernales said. ''Every day we are getting calls and letters from people saying they are resigning their candidacies.''
In Ayacucho, where Shining Path was founded, two of the three candidates for mayor have resigned and the third has moved into a hotel in Lima, 220 miles to the northwest.
''Outside the department capitals the candidates are doing very little campaigning,'' Senator Bernales said.

HEADLINE: Reagan Sees Virtue in Sale of Studio to Sony

BYLINE: By STEVEN R. WEISMAN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TOKYO, Oct. 25

 BODY:
Former President Ronald Reagan told Japanese audiences today that he welcomed Japanese investment in the United States and that Sony's recent takeover of a big motion picture studio might even ''bring back decency and good taste'' to American movies.
Speaking at midpoint in his nine-day visit to Japan, Mr. Reagan addressed one of the most delicate recent issues in Japan-American relations by saying it was hypocritical for Americans to invest in other countries around the world and then oppose Japanese investment at home.
''Some of those people don't know what they're talking about,'' the former President told an audience of corporate executives and other wealthy business people at a black-tie dinner this evening, referring to critics of the proposed takeover of Columbia Pictures by Sony, the Japanese electronics company.
''If America looks like a good investment, why, we should be pleased and proud of it,'' Mr. Reagan said. He added that the United States remained the largest global investor in other countries and then commented, ''Who are we to bellyache about somebody else wanting to do that?'' 
The former President made his comments in a speech and a television interview featuring some of his most freewheeling thoughts since leaving office in January. He appeared to be in a buoyant mood as a result of the affectionate greeting he has received since arriving here on Friday.
 
Grateful for Quake Aid
On several occasions, he told the Japanese how grateful he was as a Californian that $6.5 million had been raised privately so far to help victims of the northern California earthquake.
He also used his platform to challenge Japan to use its enormous economic resources to increase aid to Poland, something that the Government of Prime Minister Toshiki Kaifu is considering. The Government is said to be uncertain and divided over how much aid to give.
Addressing several other recent issues, Mr. Reagan defended President Bush's recent actions in Panama, saying Mr. Bush was correct in declining to use American troops stationed in Panama to back a military coup to oust Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega. ''I think we'd lose most of our friends in Latin America had we done it that way,'' Mr. Reagan said.
Mr. Reagan, as he has before, also criticized China for cracking down on protesters in June. But in an unusual aside, he also suggested that the students might have been partly to blame for pressing their own claims too fast and too far, undercutting those who favored progress in China.
''I love those young people, and I agree with what their feelings are, but did they handicap people who were quietly trying to do what they want?'' he asked in the television interview.
 
Cost of Trip Is $6 Million
Mr. Reagan arrived here on Friday as the guest of the Fujisankei Communications Group, a news media conglomerate whose owners are politically conservative supporters of the former President and his policies. The group is paying more than $6 million to bring Mr. Reagan and his wife, Nancy, to Japan, including a $2 million fee to Mr. Reagan himself.
Spokesmen for the Fujisankei group and for the Foreign Ministry have made no secret of their hope that Mr. Reagan would speak out against what Japanese fear is a growing protectionist sentiment in the United States. The former President stuck to generalities until now, but today he fulfilled the hopes of his Japanese hosts.
In the television interview for the Fuji network, owned by Fujisankei, he was asked about the negative reaction in the United States to the Sony deal. ''I don't feel there's anything wrong with that,'' Mr. Reagan interjected, adding that as a former actor ''I'm not too proud of Hollywood these days, with the immorality that is shown in pictures and the vulgarity.''
''I just have a feeling that maybe Hollywood needs some outsiders to bring back decency and good taste to some of the pictures that are being made,'' he added.

HEADLINE: Jordan Vote Stirs Fervor Where Fiat Is the Rule

BYLINE: By ALAN COWELL, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: SALT, Jordan, Oct. 19

 BODY:
Six months ago, many of the young men of this town were throwing rocks at the police in what they called their version of the Palestinian uprising in the Israeli-occupied lands across the Jordan River.
These days, those same young men are hoisting banners and streamers aloft in preparation for Jordan's first parliamentary general election in 22 years - a ballot called precisely because the rocks were thrown in an outpouring of rage and frustration over what many saw as the authorities' mismanagement of the nation and distance from the people.
The vote, set for Nov. 8, is laden with portents that go beyond the borders of this small, economically ailing kingdom of three million people that frequently figures in United States diplomacy, sandwiched between Arab dictatorships and the turmoil of the Israeli-occupied West Bank.
 
Expectations Are Raised
The ballot will choose a legislature empowered to reject and generate laws and force governments out of office. But its powers are severely limited by other rules that permit the King to dissolve it, as he has done in the past when deputies became too troublesome, or to invoke martial law and keep it in force for decades. 
Despite those frailties, the election has raised expectations and the question of whether it is possible to implant democratic tendrils in a region ruled more by force and coercion than by the ballot.
And it raises anew the uncertainties and frustrations of Jordanians of Palestinian stock, who represent the majority of the population. Some face a difficult problem: by voting in an election apparently aimed at supporting the Hashemite monarchy of King Hussein, they also dilute the argument that the Palestine Liberation Organization is their sole representative.
 
Maneuvering of British
It was in this town in 1920 that the British, embroiled in maneuvering with France for influence in areas that had once formed part of the Ottoman Empire, announced that the country should be given self-government, thereby rewarding the Arab nationalist they had enlisted on their side against the Turks allied to Imperial Germany in World War I. In 1921, the British installed the Emir Abdullah, King Hussein's grandfather, in Amman to found the Hashemite dynasty of a land then called Transjordania.
There are few here who argue that the King could avoid an election. ''The Government is in trouble, the regime is in trouble,'' said Kamel Abu Jaber, a political scientist from Jordan University. ''We have always had political crises. But we have never before had a political and an economic crisis together at the same time.''
 
'Share With the People'
''The King has come to the conclusion that he cannot control the country in the way he did in the 60's and 70's,'' Dr. Abu Jaber said. ''If he wants to maintain the continuity of the regime, he must share with the people.''
Despite those complexities, there is great fervor in Jordan's cities at the unaccustomed prospect of a vote. The newspapers are filled with advertisements placed by would-be legislators from a dizzying array of backgrounds that range from Muslim fundamentalists to Communists.
It is, some candidates say, a gamble for King Hussein that will determine whether he can buttress his regime against the region's and his own country's tensions, or confront new instability like the protests that seized parts of the country, including this town, last April. The King has ruled Jordan for the 37 years since he was enthroned at the age of 18. The vote presents a wider test, too, of Arab leaders' reluctance to countenance even limited loosening of control.
''The more democracy Hussein allows to take place, the less Syria, Iraq and Saudi Arabia will like it,'' a Western diplomat said, referring to the highly centralized and authoritarian governments on Jordan's borders and suggesting that a quasi-democratic example might stir passions in Jordan's neighbors.
Within the harsh conventions of Arab politics, few Jordanian analysts expect more than a gradual change, and an acknowledgment of popular sentiment. ''Sharing power is a very strong demand among the voters and the candidates,'' said former Foreign Minister Taher al-Masri, a Jordanian of Palestinian descent who is running for parliament. ''It will be very gradual, but the Parliament will change the concept of political life.''
''I don't think anybody is interested in making a change in the regime,'' said Laith Shubeilat, an Islamic candidate running as an independent.
 
Election and Coup in 1956
Jordanians last held a general election widely accepted as fair in 1956. A year later, an attempted coup by leftists provoked the King to bar political parties, dismiss Parliament and jail legislators. In 1967, Jordanians faced another election shortly before the Six-Day War with Israel, but that was widely held to be rigged and many voters boycotted it.
There has been no general election since then because the King argued that a vote was impossible while the West Bank of his kingdom was under Israeli occupation. In July 1988, however, the monarch severed Jordan's ties with the West Bank in response to the Palestinian uprising there. The action unnerved Jordanians of Palestinian descent, who are at least 60 percent of the population, and who increasingly voiced apprehension that they had become second-class citizens.
The decision coincided with other dynamics. King Hussein's land had slid into economic crisis with an $8 billion foreign debt. The monarchy and its chosen governments were perceived by many as aloof and uncaring. Some ministers were widely seen as corrupt.
 
A 'Shaken' Image
''Many things were exposed - corruption, debts, the abuse of authority, bad management and so on,'' said Jemal Shair, a Christian Jordanian campaigning in Salt on behalf of his small Union of Democratic Unity. He said the King's ''political image, even in the eyes of his friends in the West, was shaken.''
Then, last April, austerity measures imposed to meet the terms of an agreement with the International Monetary Fund ignited riots that spread from the southern town of Maan to Salt. Palestinian Jordanians generally steered clear of the protests, leaving the authorities with the conclusion that discontent had infected the East Bank Jordanians who had been seen as a bedrock of loyal support.
Prime Minister Zaid al-Rifai, a longtime associate of the King, was dismissed and new elections were promised.
Under a new electoral law, Parliament will be expanded from 60 to 80 seats and the West Bank Palestinians, who held 30 of the seats in the old legislature, will no longer be included or vote. The law, however, has drawn new electoral boundaries that weight the outcome of the election heavily in favor of the relatively conservative and loyalist countryside, against the more politicized and restive cities, particularly Amman, the capital, where the bulk of Jordan's Palestinians live.
 
Palestinian Registrations
''Palestinians are being asked to vote to show loyalty, but not be properly represented,'' said Ibrahim Abu Ayyash, a Jordanian of Palestinian descent who is a member of the Palestine National Council, which the P.L.O. calls a parliament in exile.
Up to 60 percent of Jordan's Palestinians did not register to vote, according to Mr. Abu Ayyash and others, though most of them hold Jordanian passports. ''The general attitude among people was that the elections will be rigged, so why bother?'' he said. ''The King's men will be everywhere, so why register?''
Another reason, Mr. Abu Ayyash said, was that ''since July 1988, Palestinians have been treated differently.'' ''There's discrimination against Palestinians,'' he continued.
The P.L.O. chairman, Yasir Arafat, is said by Western diplomats to have told King Hussein that he will not interfere in the vote. But a Western diplomats said the P.L.O. might well ''drop hints about the suitability of candidates.''
By many accounts, the King called the election in an effort to broaden the base of his regime, and thus its legitimacy, effectively surrendering some power to maintain control. But his motives remain inscrutable to most candidates and voters.
''In secret, people do not believe the King is sincere,'' said Yacoub Zayadeen, leader of Jordan's outlawed Communist Party.
''There's a lot of skepticism that the King will clamp down,'' said Dr. Abu Jaber, the political scientist. ''But what alternative do we have? This is a test. It is a test for the regime. It might give it new life or it might cause its death.''
