HEADLINE: Arlington Journal;
Prosperity Threatens Refugee Of Vietnam

BYLINE: By B. DRUMMOND AYRES Jr., Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: ARLINGTON, Va., Oct. 25

 BODY:
Kham Dinh Do is a survivor.
In 1949, he opened a jewelry store in the northern Vietnamese port of Haiphong, naming it Dat Hung, or ''Attaining Prosperity.'' It lived up to its name.
When the Communists took over the upper half of Vietnam in 1954, Mr. Do fled south to Saigon, opening a second Dat Hung store there. It too lived up to its name. 
Twenty years later, just four days before the Communists seized Saigon, Mr. Do fled once again, this time landing in this northern Virginia suburb just across the Potomac from Washington. Today he runs a third, prospering Dat Hung, one of the economic anchors of ''Little Saigon,'' a section of Arlington where Vietnamese refugees have established three dozen or so shops and restaurants over the past 15 years. Today 40,000 Vietnamese have settled in the Washington area, the largest concentration of Indochinese refugees on the East Coast.
But Mr. Do's struggle may not be over. He may be forced to flee still again, not from the Communists but from the wrecking ball.
It is a matter of economics. A subway station in Little Saigon, officially known as the Clarendon section of Arlington, has begun to draw upscale developers.
Back in the days when there was no subway and only struggling Vietnamese refugees were interested in Clarendon's run-down commercial properties, store space could be rented for as little as $5 a square foot. Today, it goes for upward of $25 a square foot in new buildings, and many of the old buildings are being emptied so that they can be demolished and replaced.
A number of businesses have already been forced to move, with several going to suburban shopping malls where other Vietnamese-operated stores are situated. The merchants who remain say that while business is still good, the disappearance of those stores and restaurants has cost Little Saigon some of its popularity as a major social gathering place for the Vietnamese.
''The streets here are not as crowded with Vietnamese at night or on weekends as they once were,'' said Emerson H. Lee, a former Saigon tax official. Mr. Lee, who like many refugees has Anglicized his name, Le Huu Em, now works as an accountant in Little Saigon, watching over the books of many of the section's merchants.
''Vietnamese refugees do not tend to live in specific neighborhoods,'' he added, ''but they tend to shop and gather in certain places, like Little Saigon. In most of these places, the Vietnamese businessmen have only small stores or offices, so they cannot pay big rents. Here in Little Saigon, we have formed a committee to work on the problem, and what we would like is for the local government officials to help us persuade developers to put up some buildings that small merchants can afford. We have been good for Arlington. We have struggled and made success.''
Mr. Lee was attending a tax seminar in Washington when Saigon fell. Rather than return, he found work as a bus driver and began studying accounting, finally passing the examination and setting up his own business in 1983.
Arlington officials say they do not want development to destroy Little Saigon. That is also the position of the Clarendon Alliance, a coalition of neighborhood developers, residents and business people.
''We would like for the Vietnamese to stay because they have helped make the neighborhood a place where people not only work but also live and shop,'' said Andrea Grenadier, the group's executive director. ''We don't want just a bunch of tall office buildings. We like the ethnic flavor. But keeping the right balance is a little tricky. We're working at it.''
Mr. Do, bent over his jeweler's bench, says he is optimistic that the coalition will achieve its goal and that Little Saigon will endure. But if not, he will not despair.
''Nothing stops me, nothing,'' Mr. Do said in clear English.
''I have moved before. I can do it again. I can survive.''

HEADLINE: WASHINGTON TALK;
Bush on Capital Gains: A Matter of Experience

BYLINE: By R. W. APPLE Jr., Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 25

 BODY:
Like other mortals, Presidents have only so much time and so much energy (although George Bush spent his vacation this year trying to disprove that self-evident proposition).
So from the dozens of issues that confront their Administrations, they all choose a few to concentrate on. And they all make the choices for one of two reasons, singling out either problems they care about in a visceral way or problems with potential electoral appeal.
President Bush, to the surprise of many people in Washington, seems to have settled on the reinstatement of a tax break on capital gains, eliminated as part of the tax law enacted in 1986, as one of the symbolic issues of his first year in the White House. 
He has been pushing the idea since early in the Presidential campaign last year, and he kept at it since then even though the smart money said he was wasting his time.
It will look like an increase in the budget deficit when we're supposed to be cutting it, the experts said. The Democrats will call it a rich man's perk, the experts said, and the Democrats did precisely that.
Yet the President managed, with the help of Southern Democrats, to maneuver the capital gains tax cut through the House, and he thinks he has the votes in the Senate. Even leading Democrats think he may ultimately get what he wants.
Mr. Bush called a group of Republican senators to the White House on Tuesday, then sent them out into the driveway to attack the Democratic leadership on Capitol Hill. Today he pressed a few Democratic senators who have expressed some interest in the subject to help him get an up-or-down vote on his idea - to no avail.
The President makes his pitch to anyone who happens along. He told an interviewer this week that the nation had given him a mandate for his capital gains proposal by voting for him last November after debates made it clear that ''Bush is for it; his opponent is against it.''
The Senate leadership, he insisted, has been ''frustrating the will of their own majority.'' Completing his pitch, he asked intently: ''Did you get all that down? It's very important.'' How come? For one thing, Mr. Bush shares the conventional Republican view that lower taxes on capital gains stimulate economic growth for all by putting more money into the hands of entrepreneurs who can invest it in new job-generating projects.
But quite apart from that, an old friend said, Mr. Bush's experiences as a young oil executive shaped his views.
''Ronald Reagan paid 91 percent income taxes during his peak years as an actor, and that made him a crusader for lower rates,'' the friend said. ''George Bush didn't take much salary out of his company down in Texas. He took stock, hoping for big capital gains, and he has believed passionately ever since that people who take chances to build things ought not to be penalized.''
Mr. Bush's already strong convictions, the friend said, were reinforced by those of former Representative William A. Steiger, a Wisconsin Republican who died in December 1978. Mr. Steiger, who served with Mr. Bush on the Ways and Means Committee and was his best friend in the House, pushed through the capital gains tax cut of 1978 almost by himself.
Seeking to make publicly palatable what the President instinctively favors, Treasury Secretary Nicholas F. Brady asserted recently that three-fourths of the benefits of a cut in the capital gains tax would flow to people with annual incomes under $50,000. But the nonpartisan staff of the Joint Congressional Committee on Taxation calculated that 80 percent of the benefits would go to those with incomes of more than $100,000 a year.
In political terms, it probably doesn't matter. Although Americans harbor a deep-rooted belief that their taxes are too high, they haven't focused sharply on this debate.
A poll of 1,000 adults taken early this month by Yankelovich Clancy Shulman for Time magazine and CNN, with a margin of sampling error of plus or minus three percentage points, showed that only 23 percent had paid a lot of attention to the capital gains issue, with 40 percent paying some attention and 35 perent paying none at all. And opinion was pretty much split - 45 percent for a tax cut, 37 percent against and 18 percent not sure.
Not much electoral oomph there.

HEADLINE: Uncle Scrooge

 BODY:
Washington sets the pace for contributions to international aid agencies, and once again it is dawdling. The International Development Association - the World Bank agency that lends to the world's neediest - needs another refill. But the Bush Administration can't seem to find $100 million in next year's budget to keep I.D.A. lending at current levels. Stalling in the face of starvation sets a sorry example. 
To be poor enough to qualify for an I.D.A. loan, a country's per capita income must be less than $790 a year. Can any country be that poor? Yes. Some 90 countries have qualified for almost $55 billion of I.D.A. assistance in the 28 years it has been in business. Among the 34 current contributors are two that once got I.D.A. aid themselves - South Korea and Colombia.
I.D.A. is restocked every three years. For the next three, it seeks $14.5 billion. While that's $2 billion more than the last replenishment, it would only maintain I.D.A.'s lending capacity in step with inflation. The United States used to provide one-quarter of I.D.A.'s funds, but the Reagan Administration allowed it to slip. The U.S. is still the largest donor, though, at $958 million a year. An increase of just $100 million a year for 1991-93 would keep the U.S. share from slipping further.
In five negotiating sessions so far, the other main donors have indicated they'll increase their donations proportionately if Washington comes up with the $100 million. But the U.S. delegation has still made no commitment. Another negotiation is scheduled for next week in Kyoto. If there is no agreement then, it is feared that the others will redirect their funds to agencies that directly serve their special interests - Western Europe's in Africa, and Japan's in Asia.
While Congress is usually tight with funds for foreign aid, the Administration can't use that excuse in I.D.A.'s case. In 1986, when President Reagan wouldn't contribute to a special I.D.A. fund for Africa, Congress voted $225 million anyhow. I.D.A. has special appeal to Congress's black caucus. And it's one agency whose loans can't be said to be ''bailing out the banks.'' Countries that borrow from I.D.A. are so poor that banks won't lend to them. These countries are desperate. For $100 million, the United States can show that it cares.

HEADLINE: In Capital, Jersey Rivals Behave Like Statesmen

BYLINE: By CLIFFORD D. MAY, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 25

 BODY:
During the months they have been vying for New Jersey's top office, James J. Florio and Jim Courter have appeared as likely adversaries if not natural enemies. But here in Washington, where both candidates for governor are members of the House of Representatives, they do not seem to be cut from very different cloths.
Both are lawyers raised in New Jersey and New York. Both project images as bright, dynamic, youthful Congressmen, though Mr. Florio comes off as rough-hewn and rather earthy, in contrast to Mr. Courter who appears polished and a bit aloof.
Each was elected to Congress just after his 37th birthday. Mr. Florio, at 52 years old, is four years older than Mr. Courter and preceded him on Capitol Hill by two terms. Both have been concerned about the crime, illicit drugs and soaring automobile-insurance premiums. 
 
Similar Political Traits
Mr. Courter serves on the Armed Services Committee, a fitting assignment for a no-nonsense, mainstream Republican. Mr. Florio serves on Energy and Commerce, equally appropriate to a no-nonsense, mainstream Democrat. Both sit on the Select Aging Committee. (Mr. Florio has a third seat on Veterans Affairs.) ''They have very similar political characteristics,'' said Ross K. Baker, a political scientist at Rutgers University and the author of ''House and Senate,'' just published by by W. W. Norton. ''Both are serious legislators. Neither is viewed as a lightweight. I've seen both debate on the House floor and they're both good at it.''
One more thing they have in common: Despite their statesmanlike demeanor on Capitol Hill, both have been willing to wage an unusually mean-spirited campaign against one another in New Jersey, one that has included sharp and sometimes loosely substantiated attacks on the honesty and integrity of the other.
''It's interesting and disturbing to me,'' said Richard V. Sinding, president of the Center for Analysis of Public Issues in Princeton. ''Florio and Courter have clearly worked hard to carve out reputations in Washington as gentlemen of some substance. And yet in this race they have gone at each other like a couple of party hacks.''
As members of Congress, the differences between Mr. Florio and Mr. Courter stem largely from divergent interests and priorities. In recent months, the pressures of the campaign have caused both to miss many debates and votes in the Capital.
But today, Mr. Florio - who has been endorsed by abortion-rights groups - did make a brief appearance in Washington to vote for an override of President Bush's veto of a bill expanding Federal payments for abortion in cases of rape and incest. The override effort fell short of the two-thirds majority needed. Mr. Courter, who has said he opposes abortion in most cases but would not ''impose my views on the people of the state,'' decided not to interrupt his campaign schedule to participate in the vote.
Mr. Florio's voting record wins the support of liberals and unions. He is widely regarded as a leading expert on the environment; most significantly, he receives primary credit for championing the establishment in 1980 of a Federal Superfund to pay for toxic-waste cleanups.
His ''community right to know'' law has for the first time required corporations to tell local residents and authorities precisely what potentially hazardous substances they are producing. Three years ago, Florio legislation established a system for removing asbestos from the nation's schools.
Transportation and consumer affairs have been other areas of concentration. Mr. Florio fought against cutbacks for Amtrak and for the upgrading of the passenger and freight rail system along the Eastern corridor.
He has also stood out as one of only a few Democratic Congressmen to push for legislation to reduce the influence that special interest groups wield through political action committees. But such bills have not passed. An articulate proponent of limited government, low taxes and free-market economics, Mr. Courter is also considered an expert on defense policy.
But unlike most Republicans who focus on the Pentagon, he has held the generals' feet to the fire on wasteful spending. In particular, legislation he wrote has sought to increase the percentage of military contracts awarded through competitive bidding.
Mr. Courter has also favored more money for military projects he considers worthwhile, like the Strategic Defense Initiative - also known as Star Wars - and he has argued for military aid to the contra rebels battling the Nicaraguan Government.
 
Some Failures by Both
''He's a smart guy and he's been a serious player on the Armed Services Committee,'' said Representative Les Aspin, the Wisconsin Democrat who is chairman of that committee. ''He's been a chief water carrier for the Administration on all the defense bills we've come out with in recent years.'
Occasionally, each man has made forays into the other's sphere. Last summer, for example, Mr. Courter pushed for a bill to ban oil exploration off the New Jersey coast for the next decade, and he has advocated stricter measures for controlling acid rain.
Mr. Florio was a co-author last year of an amendment to the Omnibus Trade bill authorizing the President to block any acquisition of a military supplier by a foreign company if it would jeopardize national security.
Both Congressmen have also suffered what might be interpreted as failures. For example, over the 14 years that Mr. Florio has represented Camden - where he is also the leading local political power - it has continued to decline and decay.
 
'They've Both Done Well'
Mr. Florio does not deny the deterioration, but he suggests that the onus belongs more with the Republican Administrations in Washington than with him, Congress or local officials.
''The cities of our state and nation have not fared well over the last eight years,'' he said. ''At a time when cities are in a state of disrepair, the Federal Government has bailed out on making efforts to rehabilitate them.''
As for Mr. Courter, even though he serves on the Military Installations and Facilities subcomittee, he failed to prevent Fort Dix, the nation's second-largest military training base, from being included among bases scheduled for scaling-down or closing.
''Overall, I think they've both done well in Washington,'' said Richard Roper, director of the Program for New Jersey Affairs at Princeton. But one important difference, he added, is that ''Florio's concerns have been much more home-based, and that's got to be an advantange for somebody running for governor.
Another factor working to Mr. Florio's benefit and Mr. Courter's detriment is that the Democrats have been the majority party in Congress throughout their tenure.
Neither Congressman maintains a presence in Washington as they do in New Jersey. Mr. Florio generally stays in the capital only three nights a week, he said. When he is in Washington, he lives in a one-room efficiency apartment above the International Liquor Store, a few blocks from his Capitol Hill office. Mr. Courter rents a one-bedroom apartment in a renovated town house in Arlington, Va.
Mr. Courter generally stays in Washington from Tuesday till Thursday, the days that the House is actually in session.
Both politicians explained their desire for wanting to exchange the House of Representatives for the State House by saying that they had experienced larger than anticipated frustrations trying to translate their ideas and arguments into policies and practice in Washington.
''As governor I think you could accomplish things in a way that's very difficult to do as a legislator, particularly one from the minority party,'' Mr. Courter said.
Mr. Florio echoed that thought: ''In Washington you're one among many, many Congressmen. As Governor, I think I could really make an impact.''

HEADLINE: Region and State at Odds Over Adirondack Park

BYLINE: By SARAH LYALL, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: SARANAC LAKE, N.Y., Oct. 25

 BODY:
Concerns about the environment and home rule run deep here in the heart of the Adirondack Park, a place that is both the year-round home of 130,000 people and the greatest surviving wilderness east of the Mississippi. On Tuesday its residents had a chance to speak their minds.
More than 1,000 people, some driving for hours to get here, crowded into a college gymnasium to present their views to a state panel charged with forming a plan to guide the Adirondack Park into the next century.
The panel, the Commission on the Adirondacks in the 21st Century, is to present its recommendations to Gov. Mario M. Cuomo on April 1. Its members are traveling around the state this month and next, asking people from Long Island to Buffalo what their hopes are for the park, which is now 40 percent state-owned. 
 
Checkerboard of 6 Million Acres
''The Adirondack people have been excellent stewards of this land for generations,'' John McIntyre, Supervisor of the small town of Westport, said at the hearing. ''This land is just as special to us, if not more so, than to those so-called visionary environmentalists out there.''
Arthur Potter, who lives in Washington, Conn., and owns land in the town of Long Lake, said: ''We're opposed to any additional acquisition of land by the state. We feel we're protecting our piece of the Adirondack Park better than any state agency could.''
The park is a six-million-acre checkerboard of state and privately held land, within a boundary known as the Blue Line. Since 1973, when the Adirondack Park Agency was set up to regulate land use and zoning within the Blue Line, residents have complained that they are losing control over their property. Policy in the park, which covers one-sixth of New York State and is about the size of Vermont, must answer to often-conflicting forces.
There are environmentalists who would have the state buy more land and leave it untouched; tourists who want both easy access to the park and a pristine setting when they get here; foresters who make their living from the park's trees; developers looking for quick money; sportsmen who balk at restrictions on hunting and fishing, and full-time residents, who juggle a complex set of feelings about the land and their place on it.
Many of the people who spoke at Tuesday's seven-hour hearing, said they resented being told what they can and cannot do on their property. ''Every time you turn around, you've got to fill out some paper work,'' said Daniel Reilly of Franklin Falls.
Bruce Phillips, a retired airline employee from Westport, said he and his parents had put most of their money into land, hoping to build on it and make a profit some day. But now, he said, he probably cannot. ''I wish they'd leave us alone,'' he said.
 
Concern Over Economy
At the same time, residents said, they want limits on large developments, which they associate with places that have been built out of control.
In a region where unemployment sometimes reaches 18 percent, people are worried about how they are going to survive economically under increased restrictions.
The residents said they want to encourage tourism because the region depends on it. But they bristle at tourists' attitudes that they have as much right to the land as year-round residents.
People here resent that only two of the commission's more than a dozen hearings were scheduled within the park.
Members of the commission point out that the state pays taxes on its 40 percent of the park's land. ''The park has been a park for the people of New York State for 25 years,'' said Peter A. A. Berle, chairman of the commission. ''We're all taxpayers, and there's a vested state interest.''
As the evening wore on, some residents charged that the state's mandate to keep state-owned land in the park ''forever wild'' was keeping the state from properly managing it. The trees grow so thick, they said, that animals die and the land is of no use to visitors.
''We hear the scenic vistas are going to be lost if we don't buy them up,'' said J. Vernon Lamb of Lake Placid. ''But if they're left forever wild, there won't be scenic vistas any more.''

HEADLINE: The California Quake;
From Homes to Hospitals, Dimension of Loss Emerges

BYLINE: By ANDREW POLLACK, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 25

 BODY:
As the dust continues to settle, public officials and the insurance industry are beginning to get a clearer picture of the vast toll of the earthquake that struck Northern California last week.
State officials say damage to private property has reached $6 billion. Several hundred to a thousand homes have been destroyed, more than 100,000 homes are damaged and about 14,000 people have been displaced. In addition, more than 1,000 businesses have been damaged or destroyed. 
Damage to public property increases the official state estimate of losses to $7 billion. Dozens of public buildings have been damaged, and six major highways have been rendered unusable for periods that are expected to last from a few days to a few years.
Virtually everyone agrees that the damage estimates are not exact or complete and that it is still too soon to get a clear picture.
''It seems everyone in the world has gone into the business of estimating dollar losses,'' said James A. Snyder, president of the Personal Insurance Federation of California, a trade association. ''Anything that's going to be available this soon is going to be a guess, an educated guess perhaps, but nevertheless a guess.''
He said a total damage estimate of $10 billion ''would be reasonable.''
Teams of insurance officials have moved in to estimate the losses, but have not yet announced their findings. In part, this is because many people are still too stunned to have filed claims.
Hugh Strawn, director of catastrophe services for the Property Loss Research Bureau in Schaumburg, Ill., an insurance trade association, said many people whose property was damaged or destroyed ''haven't really come to grips with their own personal lives.''
''Because of that,'' he said, ''they are simply not notifying the insurance companies that there may be a claim.''
 
Some Specific Estimates
Still, some fairly specific estimates are being compiled, including these:
* The State Transportation Department estimates that road and bridge repair will cost $700 million to $1 billion. The Nimitz Freeway in Oakland, whose collapse killed at least 39 people, will cost $50 million to $100 million to raze and replace. In addition, it will cost $200 million to $300 million for structural improvements to about 700 bridges and elevated highways throughout the state to make them more earthquake resistant, a job that had already begun before the tremor last week.
* In San Francisco, city officials estimate the damage to homes and businesses at $1.5 billion. Of those buildings inspected so far, about 250 were destroyed or have been declared unsafe, and 750 to 1,000 others are in need of major repairs.
* Damage to public property in San Francisco has been estimated at $500 million, although that figure could drop if two badly damaged public hospitals can be repaired instead of replaced. Nine public buildings have been declared unsafe. At San Francisco International Airport, a runway, the control tower and 20 percent of the gates were damaged. Repairs are expected to cost $7 million.
* In Santa Cruz County, which includes Santa Cruz and Watsonville, damage estimates have been put at $1.5 billion and continue to grow. In Watsonville, which has a population of 30,000, at least 195 homes have been destroyed and 235 sustained heavy damage. Elsewhere in the county, more than 400 homes have been destroyed or declared unsafe. Landslides caused by recent heavy rains have already destroyed 100 houses, and geologists warned today that more landslides are likely.
* In Santa Clara County, which includes San Jose and the high-technology area of Silicon Valley, officials estimated that 104,000 homes sustained structural damage. Total damage in the county was put at $670 million.
* In Alameda County and Oakland, officials estimated property damage at $1.5 billion, not including the Nimitz Freeway. More than 3,500 homes were damaged; three public buildings were destroyed and 22 were damaged. The Port of Oakland, the Bay Area's major shipping center, had more than $100 million in damage.
* Stanford University in Palo Alto estimated its damage at $160 million. Several dormitories remain unsafe for habitation, and Memorial Church, which was rebuilt after the 1906 earthquake, is again in need of major repairs.
 
Hurricane Damage Cited
Still, the damage from the earthquake was heavily concentrated only in certain areas.
''I spent time in Charleston before coming here,'' said Mr. Strawn, the catastrophe investigator, referring to the South Carolina city that was hit by Hurricane Hugo last month. ''The damage there was far more widespread than here.''
But he said that, in terms of economic interruption and damage to structures like highways and bridges, ''this may be more costly.''
One thing already clear is that much of the earthquake damage will not be covered by insurance. Industry officials say only about 20 percent of homeowners have earthquake insurance, and damage to public structures is usually not covered by insurance.
The State Farm Fire and Casualty Insurance Company, the largest home insurer in the Bay Area, estimates that its payments for the quake will be $300 million. The company insures 316,000 houses in the Bay Area, 83,000 of which have earthquake protection. It also has earthquake policies for 39,000 businesses in the area.
Analysts estimate that State Farm might have 18 percent of the market for homeowner's insurance. If its experience is typical, that could mean that total earthquake insurance payments would be about $1.5 billion for homes and small businesses.
Joseph Wahed, chief economist at the Wells Fargo Bank in San Francisco, said that if there is a bright side to the damage, it is that even $10 billion is small compared with the size of the area's economy.
''Within six months' time, the Bay Area economy will be off and running at full speed'' he said.

COMPANY: BAY AREA INSURANCE SERVICES (59%); PERSONAL INSURANCE FEDERATION OF CALIFORNIA (55%);

HEADLINE: HEALTH;
Personal Health

BYLINE: By Jane E. Brody

 BODY:
As the influenza season nears, doctors are issuing their annual warnings that people at risk of life-threatening complications should get flu shots. But the vaccinations can also be valuable for otherwise healthy people.
A common notion is that the shot is primarily for those who are old or already sick, because the potential benefits to the young and healthy are minimal and perhaps no greater than the risks. But doctors say there is no medical reason not to get the vaccine, even if you are young and healthy.
Although I am healthy, middle-aged and not in a high-risk category, I have already made an appointment for my shot this year. One reason is that I tend to get very sick when attacked by the influenza virus, and my illness typically lingers for two months. Past attacks have been complicated by secondary infections. In addition, like many people, I simply don't have time to be sick, especially for the lingering aftermath of an infection like influenza. 
The flu is usually debilitating and painful. The symptoms include a fever, coughs and muscle aches throughout the body, and may include gastrointestinal upset. Complications, like bronchitis and pneumonia, can be serious and sometimes fatal.
The illness is also debilitating on a wider basis. In an epidemic year, the flu can cost the nation more than $6 billion, about 20 percent of which is in direct medical costs, while the rest involves lost wages and production.
The Centers for Disease Control, the Federal agency responsible for containing communicable diseases, says those at high risk of complications include everybody 65 years of age and over, and people of all ages who have chronic lung or cardiovascular problems like asthma, emphysema, heart disease, kidney disease, diabetes or sickle-cell anemia.
The doctors also recommend the shots for children on long-term aspirin therapy for a problem like rheumatoid arthritis because a child taking aspirin after the flu can develop Reye's syndrome, an often-fatal swelling of the brain.
Anyone who, because of illness or medical treatment, has a poorly functioning immune system is also considered at high risk. And some flu experts recommend the vaccine for pregnant women, especially those who will be in their last three months of pregnancy in the winter. The experts say pregnant women face a greater risk of complications from the flu, and the risk of reactions to the shot are outweighed by potential benefits.
The vaccine is also recommended for people in jobs considered indispensable, like health care workers and police officers, as well as for others who are in close contact with high-risk people.
 
Vaccine and Its Effects
Dr. Edwin D. Kilbourne, a microbiologist at Mount Sinai Medical Center in New York and author of ''Influenza,'' which was published by Plenum Press in 1987, said the main reason for limiting the vaccine recommendation was a matter of availability.
''Manufacturers only produce about 20 million doses a year, and that's not even enough to cover the high-risk population,'' he said, adding that more than 50 million people are thought to be at risk. ''If millions of healthy people started demanding vaccine, there wouldn't be enough to go around. So public health authorities are reluctant to push universal immunization.''
But, he conceded, it is a Catch-22 situation. With the demand for vaccine low - only one-fourth of the people regarded as high risk get the shot each year - producers are reluctant to make more vaccine and take the risk of ending up with unsold vaccine at the end of the flu season.
Making the vaccine is no minor undertaking. Each summer a new vaccine must be devised to cover the strains of flu virus expected to predominate in the coming winter. This requires months of planning and the cooperation of thousands of chickens, since fertile eggs are needed in which to grow the flu viruses.
And since the natural viruses do not grow well in chick embryos, each year Dr. Kilbourne's laboratory genetically ''reassorts'' the viruses to infuse them with genes that foster efficient growth in the laboratory. The viruses grown in the chick embryos are then killed to produce a vaccine that can stimulate an immune response without actually causing influenza in those who receive it.
After the vaccine has been produced, usually by early fall, the companies disband their flu vaccine operations until the following year.
 
Selecting Viral Strains
If the flu watchers have guessed right in selecting viral strains for the vaccine, it will be 70 to 90 percent effective in preventing flu in those exposed to the infection in the next flu season. This immunity takes effect within 10 to 20 days and lasts about a year.
This year's vaccine was designed to protect against the three viral strains expected to cause illness in North America. They are two A strains, Shanghai '87 and Taiwan '86, and one B strain from Japan, Yamagata '88.
Many cities provide the shots free to elderly people and the chronically ill. For others, a shot usually costs $10 to $15, not including what the doctor charges for an office visit.
As vaccines go, the flu shot is considered very safe. Dr. Mark D. Denison of the Thomas Jefferson University in Philadelphia who is an expert on infectious disease, said side effects are minimal. About 25 percent of those who get the shot develop a localized ache where the vaccine was injected, and 1 to 2 percent develop a slight fever and a more severe ache in the arm that lasts a day or two.
But the vaccine can be dangerous for people who are highly allergic to eggs.
Although toxic reactions are more common in children under 2, the vaccine is recommended for those over 6 months who have lung or cardiovascular ailments. To help prevent side effects, children are usually given a vaccine made from a virus that has been disrupted to decrease toxicity.
To minimize adverse effects from the vaccine, doctors advise people who are already suffering from an infectious illness to wait until they recover to get a flu shot.
''The vaccine is not ideal,'' Dr. Kilbourne said. ''The hope is to get one that will produce a longer-lasting immunity. Currently, even if the prevailing viruses don't change from one flu season to the next, the immunity induced by the vaccine only lasts one year.''
A longer-lasting vaccine would make mass immunization much more practical and economical, he said.
Although the ''official'' flu season does not begin until mid-December, Dr. Kilbourne and other specialists say it is wise to be immunized before December. Thus, the push is on to get all who need it vaccinated in October and November.
But Dr. Kilbourne noted that even after a flu outbreak has begun in a community, it is not too late to administer the vaccine to high-risk people, many of whom will be protected within 10 days of the shot.
 
The Path of Illness
Children who have not been previously exposed to flu virus are the primary vectors of influenza, which spreads through virus-laden droplets, like from a sneeze or a cough.
In children, the disease is sometimes misdiagnosed at first. Unlike adults, children often develop gastrointestinal distress along with the more typical flu symptoms of fever, muscle aches and coughs. And children do not usually get as sick as adults do from this viral infection.
During the holiday season, when people tend to mingle in close quarters, the virus begins to take hold among adults. In January, when children return to school, the disease peaks among all age groups, as infected children bring it home to their parents, who in turn may expose co-workers and others before they realize they have the flu.
A prescription drug, amantadine, or its derivative, rimantadine, may help people who have not received the vaccine but who may have been exposed to type-A influenza virus. In people who already have the flu, the drugs can diminish the severity of the illness and reduce the risk of complications. But they work best in people who are not yet sick but who have been exposed to the virus or may be exposed before the vaccine can develop effective protection. Because of possible side effects, the drugs are not recommended for otherwise healthy people, nor are they recommended for pregnant women.

HEADLINE: Extra Innings for Some Veterans

BYLINE: By JEFF SCHMALZ, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: POMPANO BEACH, Fla., Oct. 22

 BODY:
Fourteen years after his finest moment, pitching a shutout for the Boston Red Sox in the opening game of the 1975 World Series, Luis Tiant found himself working for the Massachusetts State Lottery, uncomfortable in a business suit and unhappy that his life seemed to be behind him.
So when a letter came asking if he would be interested in playing professional baseball in a new league for players older than 35, the 48-year-old Tiant, who left the majors in 1982, jumped at the chance. And so did more than 200 other people, many of them former major league players, coaches and managers, including Vida Blue, Rollie Fingers, Graig Nettles and Earl Weaver.
Last week, on eight baseball fields in Florida, some of the big names in the game's history put on uniforms once again, uniforms with strange team labels like Tropics and Gold Coast Suns, but uniforms nonetheless.
 
'You Never Forget It'
Stretching and grunting and never taking off the caps that would reveal their bald spots and gray hair, they began to practice for a three-month, 72-game season that will begin Nov. 1, maybe even before the World Series ends. It will be a season that its sponsors hope marks the beginning of a longstanding league and that, coupled with major league spring training, will make baseball a Florida attraction throughout the winter tourist season. 
Some players showed up because they need the money. The salaries in the league, which is called the Senior Professional Baseball Association, range from $2,000 a month to $15,000. But many of the players came because they need the glory and the camaraderie even more than money. Their memories are no longer enough of a substitute for the real thing.
''You never forget it; there's nothing like the big league,'' said Tiant, who was wearing a rubber shirt to help him shed some pounds as he worked out for the Gold Coast Suns. ''And after it's over, it's hard to adjust.''
''I've been hunting and fishing and building a house in Tahoe,'' said Dave Kingman, 40, the former home-run hitter for the San Francisco Giants, the Mets, the Chicago Cubs and the Oakland Athletics, whose major league career ended three years ago. ''But after you played ball for 17 years, you miss it. It's good to see the guys and know the competition is still in me.''
Most of the players, coaches and managers said that for once in their lives, they were going to play baseball their way, free of the high-stakes pressures that took away from the fun of the game in the majors, free of interference by the big league bosses.
''Let me make clear that we're playing to win,'' said Dick Williams, the 60-year-old former manager of six major league teams, including Boston, Oakland and the San Diego Padres, who will manage the West Palm Beach Tropics. ''But now we can finally have some fun and not have to worry about baby-sitting the millionaires.''
 
A Goal Like the Big Leagues'
Make no mistake, this is not a charitable endeavor. The owners of the eight teams, mostly lawyers and businessmen in their 30's, are novices at professional baseball and awed by the stars they have attracted. But while they may give their managers a freer hand, their chief goal is the same as that of the owners in the majors: to make a profit.
They'll do that, they hope, through ticket sales to tourists and elderly retirees and through the sale of broadcast rights to cable television. Prime Network, which reaches 18 million homes nationwide, has agreed to carry 30 games a season for three years. In the New York City area, the games will be broadcast on the MSG cable station.
The state of Florida has its financial interests at play in the enterprise, too. Eighteen major league teams have their spring training camps in Florida in February and March, generating tourism that, by state estimates, brings in $16 million a year to each of the 18 local economies. If only a fraction of that is generated by the new seniors league, state officials say, it will be an appreciable boon to local businesses. And the combination of the seniors league and big league spring training, they hope, might generate enough momentum to win a major league team for Florida.
Much of the long-term success of the seniors league depends on its ability to go beyond nostalgia and produce serious baseball. Wiseacres in Florida are already talking about its being ''the linament league.'' But if the last week's practice sessions are any indication, that might turn out to be a misnomer.
 
Some Fairly Young Players
For one thing, some of the players are relatively young, about half of them in their late 30's, some fresh out of the majors. And not all have given up hope of returning to the majors. Some free agents, like the 36-year-old Paul Mirabella, who was on the Milwaukee Brewers' roster last season but didn't pitch because of shoulder surgery, said they wanted to use the seniors league to show scouts that they were back in form.
And the older players - most of them in their mid-40's -seem trim and in surprisingly good shape, although there's no question that there have been some cramps.
''I'm starting to feel better,'' Mickey Rivers, the 41-year-old former Yankee outfielder, who last played in the majors in 1985, said at the end of last week after practicing for the Palm Beach Tropics. ''But there's a lot of soreness. It's going to take some time.''
On the field, the action seems quick and enthusiastic. On the first day of practice for the Winter Haven Super Sox, there was one stolen base, a triple with a play at third and two double plays. On the first day of batting practice for the Bradenton Explorers, Willie Mays Aikens, 36, hit 11 consecutive balls over the fence.
After two weeks of practice, each team roster will be cut to 24 players.
 
'No Potbellies'
''I think a lot of people who are laughing now are going to be surprised,'' said Weaver, who in his years with the Baltimore Orioles was regarded as one of the best managers ever and who is now managing the Gold Coast Suns. ''The guys are in great shape. They've worked out, no potbellies. You wait: they're going to be drafting some of these players back into the majors.''
The spectators, as might be expected for the first days of practice, were sparse, fewer than a hundred at each park. Mostly they were old men who, like little kids, brought bats and balls to be autographed. They cheered not so much the plays as the sight of men triumphing over age.
''Go, Mickey, go!'' Joe De Vuono, a 63-year-old retired Pepsi Cola deliverer formerly of Long Island and now of Boynton Beach, Fla., shouted to Rivers as he made a base hit. ''Show Steinbrenner he was wrong. You're not too old!''
The idea for the league was that of Jim Morely, a 33-year-old real-estate developer and former outfielder for a San Francisco Giants farm team in Fresno, Calif. He said the idea came to him while he was lying on a beach in Australia reading about a Senior PGA Tour golf tournament.
Morely sent letters of inquiry to 1,250 ballplayers over the age of 35 - or, in the case of catchers, over the age of 32 - and 730 wrote back that they would be interested. These included former players in the majors and the minors, as well as some who had been in semipro ball.
 
Looking for 8 Stadiums
He then looked for stadiums in central and southern Florida, with the criteria that each seat at least 5,000 spectators and that they be near enough to each other that players would have to travel no more than two hours by bus to each game.
With all that in place, Morely solicited groups of private investors for seven teams (he backed the eighth team himself), and 72 individuals or partnerships applied. Each has had to put up about $1 million to buy into a franchise. League officials will not say how much they are getting for the cable-television deal. But the real money for the owners will come, if it comes, from the franchises' catching on and eventually expanding, perhaps to Arizona and southern California.
To protect the owners, total salaries for the three-month season are capped at $550,000 for each team. Ticket prices will run from $5 to about $10 a game.
Richard B. Horrow, a lawyer who is president of the league, said that in organizing each team, the original intent was to create ''a family-reunion atmosphere'' that would keep former members of the same team together, ideally in the same towns where they had practiced in the spring. To a limited degree, it has worked out that way.
 
Bill Lee Is Back
In Winter Haven, where the Boston Red Sox hold spring training, the team is called the Super Sox and has the former Red Sox pitchers Ferguson Jenkins, Jim Willoughby, Bill Lee and Rick Wise. In Bradenton, where the Pittsburgh Pirates train, the Bradenton Explorers lay claim to the former Pirates Al Oliver and Manny Sanguillen.
In Port St. Lucie, where the Mets train, the St. Lucie Legends at least include some former New Yorkers, among them Graig Nettles and Jerry Grote.
And in West Palm Beach, the Tropics are building a team around some former Oakland A's, including Rollie Fingers (still sporting his handlebar mustache), Kingman, Tom Underwood and Rodney Scott. But one of Oakland's biggest legends, Vida Blue, wound up elsewhere, in Port St. Lucie.
The Gold Coast Suns have taken on several Hispanic players in an effort to appeal to the large Hispanic population of southeastern Florida. The team, which will play in Pompano Beach and Miami, includes Tiant, Ed Figueroa and Cesar Cedeno.
But for the most part, the teams - the others are the Fort Myers Sun Sox, the Orlando Juice and the St. Petersburg Pelicans - are pretty much a hodgepodge of players from everwhere.
How the players and managers can interrupt their lives for three months to work in the league varies from man to man. Some, like Bert Campaneris of the Gold Coast Suns, have been playing in other countries, like Japan, and have been looking for something in the United States. Others, like Rivers, have been working with youth groups and can take time off.
 
Golf: 'Enough'
A few, like Fingers, who represents a sports-entertainment concern, can do their business by phone. Many, like Tom Underwood, an investment banker, live in south Florida and merely take an extended lunch hour to come to practice.
And then there are those who have all the time in the world, the retired stars.
''I love golf, but after you play 25 straight days, you say, 'Enough,' '' said Weaver, who joked about being ''close to 70'' but is listed as 59 years old in the Baseball Encyclopedia. ''So when this came along, I said: 'Why not? Why not one more time?' ''
A fan shouted down to him, asking if Weaver, who was ejected from 91 games in his major league career because of his raging against umpires, would be thrown out of games in the new league, too. Weaver turned around and winked at him.
''I'd be surprised if I wasn't,'' he said.

HEADLINE: Senators See Delay in Capital Gains Tax Cut

BYLINE: By SUSAN F. RASKY, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 25

 BODY:
Senate Democrats who generally favor reducing capital gains taxes warned President Bush today that his only realistic hope of achieving a lower rate was to include it in a broader budget compromise, one that might have to wait until next year.
Senator Christopher J. Dodd of Connecticut, one of eight Democrats invited to the White House to discuss the issue, said, ''We told him that if he expects Senate Democrats to walk away from the majority leader and violate the Senate rules to accommodate a capital gains tax cut, he was wasting his time and hurting the substance of the issue.''
The blunt assessment came as Senate Republicans expressed increasing apprehension about the political risks of tying a capital gains proposal to a bill raising the national debt limit, and began searching for other legislation to carry their cause.
In an unexpected move this evening, Senator Bob Packwood of Oregon, chief sponsor of a capital gains tax cut, offered his proposal -which would cut the tax for corporations as well as for individuals - as an amendment to pending legislation that would provide economic aid to Poland and Hungary. 
Mr. Packwood, the senior Republican on the Finance Committee, made it clear that he intended this as a test vote to demonstrate that a majority of senators support a gains-tax reduction even though the number might not reach the 60 votes needed to assure passage by breaking a threatened filibuster. A test vote could come as early as Thursday.
In order to get 60 votes, Senate Republicans need to draw support from a pool of 10 to 20 Democrats who generally favor reducing capital gains taxes. But the President's meeting today, along with a similar one yesterday with 10 other Democrats, suggested that expected Democratic support for Senator Packwood's proposal was not forthcoming.
Without a timely increase in the debt limit, the Government would not be able to make Social Security payments on Nov. 3, and Republicans were clearly worried about the political implications of linking the two issues.
''We don't want to be placed in a political box of holding up Social Security checks for one issue,'' said Senator John McCain, an Arizona Republican. ''It's not that cutting the capital gains tax isn't a major issue, it's a question of what gets impeded in the process.''
In addition, some key Republicans on the Senate Finance Committee are deeply concerned about the wisdom of pursuing capital gains tax reduction at all this year, when there do not appear to be the 60 votes needed to assure Senate passage.
 
Not Just a Tax Issue
''Most of the Republicans on the Senate Finance Committee favor capital gains reduction, but almost none of us agreed with the President to do it this year,'' said Senator Dave Durenberger, a Minnesota Republican on the panel. ''When the President was up here earlier this month, we told him, 'You're going to get capital gains, but you may not get it this year.' ''
Mr. Durenberger said the White House response was that cutting the capital gains tax was not just a tax issue, but a political issue that could be used to make the Democrats a minority party by dividing them.
''We're in two different ball games here,'' Senator Durenberger said. ''We're trying to make tax policy, and John Sununu is trying to make the Democrats a minority party.'' Mr. Durenberger was referring to the President's chief of staff, who along with the budget director, Richard G. Darman, and the Treasury Secretary, Nicholas F. Brady, have been involved in planning political strategy on the capital gains issue.
 
Packwood's I.R.A. Plan
Senator Packwood said he still favors an attempt to attach the proposal to the debt-limit bill, but said he was waiting for the President and the Senate Republican leader, Bob Dole, to make a decision. Mr. Packwood said he thought he would win a majority of Senate votes, and that such a vote would strengthen the Senate's bargaining hand with the House, which has approved a temporary reduction in the capital gains tax.
The Packwood proposal includes a plan to permit tax-free withdrawals from individual retirement accounts once their owners reach the age of 59 1/2.
Senator David Boren of Oklahoma, the chief Democratic supporter of a capital gains tax cut, calculated the odds for passage this year as 1 in 3, with the odds improving next year to 2 in 3.
 
Robb Cites Deficit
Senator George Mitchell of Maine, the Senate majority leader, persuaded Mr. Boren not to offer a gains tax cut of his own and not to sign on as a co-sponsor of Mr. Packwood's plan. He also won a pledge from Senator David Pryor, an Arkansas Democrat who generally favors capital gains tax reduction, that he would vote against attaching such a tax cut to the debt-limit bill.
Senator Charles Robb, a Virginia Democrat whom the White House has considered as a possible supporter for a capital gains tax cut, said deficit reduction had to be the first priority. ''There are a number of us who don't want to address this until we do something about deficit reduction,'' he said.
The difficulty for Republicans in deciding whether to make their stand on the debt-limit bill is compounded by the legislative logjam that has developed as the House and Senate try to sort out other differences over deficit reduction plans.

HEADLINE: Alaska Spill Jolts Chevron, Too

BYLINE: By THOMAS C. HAYES, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: SAN FRANCISCO

 BODY:
Public outrage over the 11 million gallons of crude oil that the Exxon Valdez spilled into Alaska's Prince William Sound in March has lashed the industry in many ways. But perhaps no company, Exxon included, has been jolted as badly as the Chevron Corporation.
The troubles at the nation's No. 3 oil company have spurred speculation about possible asset sales or even a takeover. This talk has helped the stock. Chevron's shares, which had fared badly in recent years, have been trading heavily in the last three weeks. It had reached a record high of $66.875 a week after the market plunge on Oct. 13. [The stock, the fourth most active on the New York Stock Exchange Wednesday, closed at $66.625, up $1.75.] Profits, which have seesawed in the last four years, are down. The company said recently that it earned $1.1 billion in the nine months ended in September, a 31.3 percent drop from $1.6 billion in the comparable period last year. In the third quarter, profits fell slightly, to $417 million, or $1.22 a share, from $420 million, or $1.23 a share, a year ago. Sales rose to $8 billion in the quarter from $7.2 billion in the period a year earlier. 
 
Reserves Blocked
Basically, the company's problem is that it has spent a lot for oil reserves, but a backlash of protest after the Exxon spill has kept it from getting at the oil still in the ground.
Two months ago, regulators in California revoked Chevron's permit to begin shipping oil 100 miles by tanker to Los Angeles from a gleaming new processing plant near the Point Arguello field west of Santa Barbara, Calif. The plant, completed and idle for two years, was designed to process enough crude for refining to fuel two million cars a day on the West Coast.
Chevron and 17 partners, including Texaco, Phillips Petroleum and Pennzoil, invested more than $2 billion in the project over the last 10 years but have yet to produce a drop of oil. Earlier this month, they filed a lawsuit to contest the latest in a long string of bureaucratic and political obstacles.
 
Setback in Alaska
In Washington, a storm of protests persuaded Congress to turn its back on Chevron's pleas to drill in the coastal plain of the Arctic Natural Wildlife Refuge in northeast Alaska. Industry executives had expected Congress to open the area for exploration in 1989, but now some fear that drilling will be banned there for years.
Chevron is the largest leaseholder in the coastal plain, along with its partner, British Petroleum. They have not disclosed results of a well drilled two years ago, but experts estimate the region's recoverable crude at 3 billion to 7 billion barrels, which would make it the nation's largest new oilfield since Prudhoe Bay, with 10 billion barrels, was opened 20 years ago.
If these endangered projects are not rescued, it could take a heavy toll. Exxon put its tab for the Alaska cleanup at more than $1 billion, but write-offs and unrealized profits at Chevron would be much higher if the projects are scrapped. Its stake at Point Arguello alone exceeds $800 million.
Chevron could withstand the blow. A globe-straddling giant with $34.5 billion in assets, $15 billion in equity and $1.4 billion in cash, it is the nation's third-largest oil company as ranked by assets, after Exxon and Mobil. But the last thing Kenneth T. Derr, chairman and chief executive of Chevron since January, wanted as he started out was more delays.
 
'Very, Very Frustrating'
''After all this money's been spent, we've got oil sitting there unable to be produced,'' Mr. Derr said in an interview. ''This was an absolute reaction to the Exxon Valdez. Meanwhile, oil imports are hitting new highs every month. It is a very, very frustrating situation.''
Environmentalists in Santa Barbara argue that Chevron and its partners could not handle a spill a thousand times smaller than the one in Prince William Sound. They also say Chevron has not seriously studied opportunities to trade oil pumped from the Point Arguello fields.
Carole Ann Coles, public affairs director of Get Oil Out, an anti-oil group, said a pipeline under construction from Gaviota, Calif., to West Texas would enable Chevron to exchange its Point Arguello crude for oil shipped by existing pipelines to its refinery in El Segundo, Calif. [A study on trading oil from Point Arguello is to be released on Friday by Arthur D. Little, the consulting firm. Chevron, which paid $500,000 to underwrite the analysis, said earlier that trading was not a practical economic or technical option.] A Pledge to Stockholders Earnings and dividends at Chevron lagged during the industry's roller-coaster ride through the 1980's. Mr. Derr acknowledged early the urgency of turning Chevron around but boasted before the Valdez incident that Chevron's total return to stockholders would lead the industry over the next five years - a pledge he has not abandoned.
Most analysts agree that Chevron, the nation's largest refiner and marketer of petroleum products, has the assets and prospects for Mr. Derr to deliver more to the bottom line.
Chevron ranks sixth among the world's owners of oil and gas reserves and has properties in 98 countries, including high-potential fields in Angola, China, Indonesia, Papua New Guinea and Somalia. It wants to be the first Western oil giant to develop fields in the Soviet Union and hopes to obtain an equity stake to explore in the Caspian Sea next year.
 
Debt Reduced
After buying Gulf Oil in 1984 for $13.3 billion, Chevron pared its payroll by 25,000, to 53,000, and sold $6 billion in assets to cut debt to $6.8 billion at the end of September, a moderate 31 percent of capital.
In California, Chevron has narrowed the sales lead this year in gasoline that the Atlantic Richfield Company wrested from it five years ago. Chevron trailed ARCO in the first seven months, averaging a market share of 16.2 percent against ARCO's 18 percent, and edged past ARCO in July.
Frederick P. Leuffer, an analyst with C. J. Lawrence, Morgan Grenfell in New York, and Bryan Jacoboski of Paine Webber Inc. said Mr. Derr must cut payroll and other costs further to improve Chevron's earnings but had moved too deliberately.
''There has been very little followthrough,'' Mr. Jacoboski said. ''He decentralized the company, but the results so far are fairly meager.''
In a report issued last month, Mr. Leuffer said corporate raiders or unwelcome bids from within the industry could force Mr. Derr to sell assets or repurchase stock to bolster Chevron's stock price. ''There is tremendous value in the company,'' Mr. Leuffer said.
To be sure, bidders would need at least $26 billion to buy Chevron, which would make it the most costly takeover ever. Some analysts see as possible suitors British Petroleum, nearly twice Chevron's size, and Nippon Steel of Japan. But others say Chevron is too large to be acquired.
 
Distressed by Rulings
Mr. Derr, a blunt-spoken mechanical engineer who rose to Chevron's top job by the age of 52, declined to discuss takeover rumors or possible asset sales. He appeared more distressed by local regulators in California and by Congress, pointing out that Chevron had spent millions to guard against spills, leaks and other potential damage to California's scenic coastline near Santa Barbara.
Now, he said, as protests block new production from huge domestic reservoirs, more tankers filled with foreign oil are plying America's waterways. The nation's dependence on foreign oil reached 47 percent of all oil deliveries for the nine months ended Sept. 30, and experts say it could exceed 50 percent as early as next year. Mr. Derr said protests against drilling in the United States had, perversely, resulted in more tanker traffic, raising the odds for another bad spill.
''Somehow the process has to work better,'' he said. ''If we were starting all over again, we'd just say there are better places. We'll go spend our money in the North Sea or somewhere else where if we find oil, we can develop it.''
 
Toxic Gas Problem
Chevron discovered oil in the Point Arguello field in 1981, two years after it paid $333.6 million for a Federal lease, the highest ever recorded for offshore drilling rights. Geologists initially thought 500 million barrels could be produced from the field, but later said 300 million was a better guess. Worse yet, concentrations of lethal hydrogen sulfide in natural gas reserves were triple the level Chevron had estimated.
An outcry over the higher levels among local property owners near the Chevron-operated processing plant at Gaviota forced Chevron early in 1988 to install, at a cost of $7.5 million, a smaller pipeline above the main gas pipeline in the foothills of the Santa Ynez Mountains. Its purpose is to monitor for traces of hydrogen sulfide in surrounding dirt.
Before that, Chevron and its partners added many other safety and civic-related features into their three offshore production platforms, pipelines in the ocean and beneath the coastline, and the processing plant. These are some of the projects:
* Members of several American Indian tribes were paid $25 an hour to sift the dirt dug from onshore-pipeline trenches for relics or artifacts that would warn construction workers that they had entered ancient burial grounds.
* Landscaping at the plant site included shrubs, grasses, eucalyptus trees and other vegetation that met Coastal Commission guidelines.
* A payment of $7.5 million was made to relocate 70 children in a temporary school, and an additional $12 million was spent for a new building.
* A gas turbine co-generation plant was built on the site, It produces all the steam and electricity required to operate the oil and gas units, with some of the excess to be sold to Southern California Edison.
 
Protests Bar Tankers
Santa Barbara County commissioners approved the plant for start-up in April after the pipeline was in place to monitor toxic gas leaks. But by then the League of Women Voters and Get Oil Out asked the Coastal Commission to keep tankers from docking at the Gaviota plant. On Aug. 8, the commission agreed. Chevron and its partners recently asked a county court in Santa Barbara to throw out the ruling.
Chevron does not expect any action from regulators or the courts until early next year. Meanwhile, Mr. Derr said the costs at Point Arguello, mounting by $3 million a day, were so high that the project would probably generate little profit even if it did go forward. But he has vowed to keep up the fight.

HEADLINE: Greenspan Supports Anti-Inflation Legislation

BYLINE: By DAVID E. ROSENBAUM, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 25

 BODY:
Alan Greenspan, the chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, said today that ending inflation in the next five years might lead to higher interest rates and lower economic growth temporarily, but would not lead to recession.
He said that stopping inflation, now running at an annual rate of around 4.5 percent, was ''a prerequisite for, over time, maximizing economic growth and standards of living,'' and added, ''I see no reason why over a five-year period we cannot restore price stability without incurring recession as a consequence of those actions.''
Testifying before the House Banking Committee's subcommittee on domestic monetary policy, Mr. Greenspan welcomed legislation that would instruct the central bank to adopt a monetary policy to ''eliminate'' inflation over five years. But he vigorously opposed another bill intended to make the bank more politically accountable. 
The second measure, he said, would discourage the Federal Reserve from taking unpopular steps that might be in the best interest of the country -like raising interest rates.
''We all know what happens when you have someone looking over your shoulder,'' he declared.
 
Enactment Called Unlikely
Mr. Greenspan's views on these matters were generally known before today, but this was the first time he had articulated and defended them publicly.
Neither bill is likely to become law. But the hearings, which are to continue into next year, provide a forum for a rare public examination of the operations of the Federal Reserve, one of the most powerful and secretive institutions in the Government.
In answers to lawmakers' questions, Mr. Greenspan made these other points:
* Tension between the Fed and the Bush Administration over interest and exchange rates has been overstated. The only disagreement, he said, revolves around ''relatively minor issues of tactics.''
* He would like to see a lower capital gains tax rate, but not if the political price were an eventual increase in overall income tax rates.
* He is concerned about a trend toward increased corporate debt.
Mr. Greenspan was treated with a degree of respect that Congress rarely grants public officials.
One after another, members of Congress from both parties praised the Fed's monetary policies, and asked gentle questions.
The anti-inflation measure under consideration today is sponsored by Representative Stephen L. Neal, a North Carolina Democrat who is chairman of the subcommittee on domestic monetary policy.
The bill offers no specifics on how the five-year goal should be reached and provides for no penalties if the Fed falls short. Its purpose, Mr. Neal said, is to give political muscle to the Fed's anti-inflation efforts.
 
Closed-Door Meetings
The other measure is sponsored by Representative Lee H. Hamilton of Indiana and Byron L. Dorgan of North Dakota, both Democrats. Mr. Hamilton has said they want to stimulate discussion of the Fed's structure and practices in relation ''to the normal standards of government accountability in a democracy.''
Despite its power, the Fed is more independent from the political process than any other part of the Government outside the judiciary.
The meetings of its Federal Open Market Committee, where policy decisions are made, are held behind closed doors. The decisions are not announced for six weeks, and even then only a skeletal summary of what happened is made public. No other branch of Government can veto the decisions.
The proposed measure would require the Fed's policy committee to meet formally three times a year with the Treasury Secretary, the budget director and the chairman of the Council of Economic Advisers; would allow new Presidents to appoint their own Fed chairmen; require immediate disclosure of policy decisions; permit Congressional accountants to audit the Fed, and require its budget to be published with the rest of the Government's budget .
Mr. Greenspan argued that such restrictions would limit the Fed's capacity to ''resist short-term inflationary biases that might be inherent in some aspects of the political process.''

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Ends Mostly Lower; Gold Prices Off in New York

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar ended mostly lower against major foreign currencies in thin, narrow trading yesterday.
Gold prices declined. On the Commodity Exchange in New York, gold bullion for current delivery settled at $369.10 an ounce, down $1.10 from Tuesday. 
Currency dealers said the dollar got an early lift from comments from Alan Greenspan, the Federal Reserve chairman, but edged lower mainly on technical factors. They said many dealers were awaiting today's release of third-quarter gross national product data, which should shed more light on the direction of the economy and interest rates.
 
Comments on Inflation
In testimony before Congress, Mr. Greenspan hinted that the central bank was unlikely to ease credit by lowering interest rates any time soon because the current inflation rate of 4.4 percent was too high to be ignored.
Firm interest rates are seen as bullish for the dollar partly because they make dollar-denominated securities more attractive to foreigners, thereby increasing the need for those investors to convert their money into dollars.
In late New York trading, the dollar was at 141.57 yen, up from 141.50 yen on Tuesday.
But it was weaker against the British pound, which brought $1.6143, up from $1.6075 late Tuesday.
Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with Tuesday's quotes, included: 1.8350 West German marks, down from 1.8358; 1.6075 Swiss francs, down from 1.6095; 6.2270 French francs, down from 6.2370; 1.17545 Canadian dollars, up from 1.17135, and 1,345.00 Italian lire, down from 1345.75.
Silver prices lost ground. On the Comex silver bullion for current delivery dropped to $5.114 an ounce from $5.148.

HEADLINE: Home Resale Rise Is 4.3%

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 25

 BODY:
Sales of existing homes rose for the second consecutive month in September, climbing 4.3 percent to the highest level this year, a real estate trade group said today.
The National Association of Realtors credited lower mortgage rates for the spurt in home sales, which rose to a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 3.63 million units. 
The September increase followed a 4.5 percent rise in August and marked the third time in the last four months that rates have increased since hitting a low point this year in May.
At the end of last week, fixed-rate mortgages had dipped below 10 percent, averaging 9.92 percent, according to a weekly survey conducted by the Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corporation. Last spring, mortgage rates hit a peak of 11.22 percent.
''Many people who were forced to put off trading upon entering the market earlier this year are making their move now,'' said Ira Gribin, president of the realtors association.
The national median price for an existing single-family home fell by $1,400 from August to September, to $93,400. This was still 5.5 percent higher than a median-priced home sold for a year ago. The median is the point at which half the homes sell for more and half for less.
Regionally, the sales advance was paced by a 12.7 percent increase in the West. Sales were up 3.7 percent in the South and 1 percent in the Midwest. Sales were unchanged in the Northeast.
The national sales pace of 3.63 million units was the fastest since homes were sold at a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 3.92 million units last December.
