HEADLINE: JAPAN LEADING U.S. IN RAISING CAPITAL FOR CORPORATIONS

BYLINE: By JAMES STERNGOLD, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TOKYO, Oct. 26

 BODY:
At a time when volatile swings and uncertainty on Wall Street have made it increasingly tough for American companies to raise money, the comparatively stable and strong Japanese stock market has been churning out record levels of fresh capital for Japanese corporations.
But in the United States, the amount of money raised from the sale of stock, the fuel for corporate expansion, has been shrinking from a peak three years ago. In the first eight months of this year, Japanese corporations raised more than $110 billion, compared with $20 billion by American companies, by far the largest gap ever between the countries, according to figures from the Tokyo Stock Exchange and the Securities Data Company in New York.
 
A Profound Message
The boom in raising capital in Japan carries a profound message for competition between American and Japanese banks and corporations: Japanese companies are finding it easier to raise relatively cheap capital to modernize, increase productivity and expand. That could benefit them as they prepare for increasingly tough competition in the global marketplace. 
''The really awesome thing is what this will mean in three or four years, when the Japanese begin to realize the benefits of their investments and their productivity shoots up,'' said Eric Rasmussen, an economist at Jardine Fleming Securities in Tokyo.
In some ways, companies prefer selling stock to borrowing, because they do not have to repay the money, as they do with a loan. Of course, stock prices and interest rates can be volatile, which sometimes makes it more advantageous for companies to borrow funds. But because equity capital is permanent, managers can generally plan for the long term in a more stable environment.
 
The Rewards of Patience
Much depends on how patient the company's shareholders are in waiting for a return on their investment. That is another big difference between Japan and the United States: Japanese shareholders have been far more willing to hold their stakes for the long term. The short-term perspective of American shareholders, and their desire to take quick profits, is regarded as one important reason for the takeover and buyout boom in the United States.
Every month there are more huge offerings of stock here. For example, Sanwa Bank's announcement last week that it would issue stock to raise nearly $2.5 billion seemed such a commonplace that Japanese newspapers barely took notice. The deal would have made headlines in the United States, where such issues have been few and far between. The stock market crash in October 1987 marked a watershed in this capital-raising trend. In 1986 American companies raised a record $67.9 billion from the sale of stock and similar securities - money known as equity capital. That was more than double the level in Japan that year. In 1987 the two nations were nearly equal, with slightly more than $60 billion raised in each market.
That was when the uncertainties from the market turmoil took their toll. Equity-raising in the United States withered, while it rose sharply in Japan, where the market weathered the market crash with far less volatility and a swifter recovery. A stronger economy and greater stability in shareholdings in Japan, along with the firm hand of Government regulators, helped the Japanese market hold its ground and then resume its upward course.
 
More Than a Casino
What the contrast in the amount of newly raised capital underscores is that a strong stock market provides more than a casino for speculators.
Of course, many people criticize the Japanese market for shortcomings like high fixed commissions on trades and paltry dividend payments. In addition, extensive networks of cross-holdings, in which groups of corporations own large blocks of shares in each other, tend to reduce the voice of smaller shareholders.
But the market is performing the classical economic function of providing a means for investors to channel their savings into productive enterprises. Japanese save far more than Americans. And Japanese companies are feverishly translating that money into more productive operations.
''It's clear that this is helping Japanese companies in no small way,'' said Richard Koo, senior economist at the Nomura Research Institute. He said that the American market, unlike the Japanese market, has devoted much more time to takeover battles rather than capital-raising.
''It's true that in our country the focus has been much more on asset management and not raising capital,'' said John J. Phelan Jr., chairman of the New York Stock Exchange, who is visiting Tokyo this week. ''Capital is pouring into Japan because of their economic growth rate, and it's looking for a home.''
 
'Massive Amounts' for Banks
Particularly for commercial banks, where capital can play an even more critical role in competitive strength, the difference between the markets has been lopsided.
Since the crash of 1987, American banks have raised $5.7 billion in equity, according to Securities Data; in the same period, just eight major Japanese banks have raised more than $22 billion, a study by Salomon Brothers found.
''The buoyancy and discipline of the Tokyo capital markets have enabled the banks to raise massive amounts of capital - sums beyond the wildest dreams of Western bank chiefs,'' Salomon Brothers wrote in the report.
Prices on the Tokyo Stock Exchange have risen spectacularly over the last decade, prompting criticism in Japan and on Wall Street that it is built on a foundation of soap bubbles that could burst at any moment. While Japanese stock prices trade on average at more than 40 times the companies' earnings per share, American shares trade for only slightly more than 10 times earnings.
As a result, it takes significantly fewer shares in Japan to raise the same amount of capital. And by issuing fewer shares, there is less dilution of the holdings of existing shareholders and of the company's earnings per share. In other words, the lofty level of the Japanese stock market makes it far cheaper to raise equity capital.
 
Interest Rates Low, Too
And when Japanese companies want to borrow money, they also have an advantage over American companies: Japan's relatively low inflation rate - less than 3.5 percent - and low interest rates make borrowing relatively inexpensive as well.
With its strong gains, the Japanese market has defied doomsayers for more than five years, particularly during moments of enormous stress, as at the time of the crash on Oct. 19, 1987, and two weeks ago, when Wall Street suffered its second-biggest drop ever.
The Tokyo stock market hardly skipped a beat when the New York Stock Exchange fell nearly 7 percent on Oct. 13; it dropped less than 2 percent and then bounced right back, causing no delay in Sanwa Bank's long-planned new-share issue.
Whatever the reason for that stability - and few agree on just what is behind it - the benefits to Japanese corporations are clear.
Nowhere is the difference between the two countries more pronounced than in commercial banking, where there is a worldwide struggle to build capital to meet strict new regulatory standards and to compete in the emerging international marketplace.
A study by Merrill Lynch Japan Inc. found that since the stock market crash two years ago, Japanese banks have nearly doubled their equity capital. About three-fourths of the gainis directly related to the strength of the Japanese stock market.
 
'Enormous Flexibility'
''If you can raise these funds in such massive amounts this easily, it gives you enormous flexibility in terms of expanding your business,'' said James Russell, Merrill Lynch's banking analyst here. ''This trend has all sorts of implications for even the average American company, in terms of where it's going to be getting its banking services in the future.''
For instance, after its just-announced offering, Sanwa Bank's shareholders' equity will stand at about $11.2 billion, more than double the $4.5 billion at the end of March 1987.
To be sure, Japanese banks face significant hurdles in their international expansion. Their major problem is that they have grown up in a highly protected domestic market. As a result, they lag behind their foreign rivals in developing high-margin new products and more sophisticated services. But their ability to invest heavily is allowing them to close this gap quickly.
The Japanese banks have benefited in two ways from the strong stock market. The first, of course, is that they have issued new shares and billions of dollars worth of bonds that later are converted to stock. The second is that their own portfolios of stocks have sharply risen in value.
 
The Rules Are Different
While American banks are restricted from owning shares in other companies, unless the holdings are in businesses that relate directly to their financial operations, Japanese banks can own up to 5 percent of other corporations.
Historically, the Japanese banks have used their shareholdings to reinforce ties to clients and other members of integrated financial and industrial groupings, known as keiretsu. Over time the value of those holdings has exploded.
That gain has generally not been recognized, because the banks reflect only what they paid for the stock on their balance sheets. But if they sell a fraction of those shares, they realize the gains to bolster their earnings and capital base.
And that well of capital runs deep. For instance, in a recent public filing in the United States in which it had to disclose the value of its stock portfolio, Mitsubishi Bank said that as of last March 31 it had the equivalent of $28.5 billion in unrealized stock gains, at current exchange rates.
 
Impact of Stock Profits
Salomon Brothers estimated that Japan's major banks earned $7.9 billion, or just under half of their pretax profits in the fiscal year 1988, from selling small amounts of their stock holdings.
And Mr. Russell found that 75 percent of the $24.4 billion increase in the shareholders' equity of Japan's seven largest banks from the end of March 1987 to the end of March 1989 had been accounted for by the issuance of new shares and the sale of some stock from their portfolios.

LENGTH: 1181 words

HEADLINE: Economic Growth in 3d Quarter Maintained Pace of Early 1989

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr., Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 26

 BODY:
The economy grew at a 2.5 percent rate in the quarter that ended in September as a surge in consumer spending offset weakness in exports and the industrial sector, Commerce Department reported today.
The overall advance, which was somewhat higher than expected, matched that of the April-June period. And economists found reason to cheer in the report's indication of lower third-quarter inflation, even though that was mostly a reflection of falling energy prices.
The Bush Administration said it found little of concern in today's report on the gross national product - the total of goods and services generated by the economy - and portrayed the latest data as essentially positive. 
''The news is good,'' Michael J. Boskin, the President's top economic adviser, told reporters at a White House briefing. ''The economy has sustained its moderate growth through the third quarter. We expect it to be able to continue to do that for some time to come.''
But a highly pessimistic dissent was registered by C. Fred Bergsten, head of the Institute for International Economics and a Treasury official during the Carter Administration.
 
No Growth in Exports
He said the trade data in today's report, which showed no growth in exports and a 15.1 percent rise in imports, were ''really bad news.'' The United States, he said, is in danger of moving suddenly from years of export-led expansion to ''import-led recession.''
Michael R. Darby, Under Secretary of Commerce for economic affairs, acknowledged ''disappointment'' over the trade data, but he said recent surveys of corporate purchasing managers indicated that export orders were starting to rebound. He added, however, that the strike against the Boeing Company, a top exporter, could undermine that trend.
The dominant sentiment among private analysts was that growth is likely to slacken significantly in the current quarter.
''When you look at the sources of strength,'' said Stuart G. Hoffman, the chief economist at Pittsburgh National Bank, ''it seems to me you won't be able to repeat many of them in the fourth quarter.'' Prominent among the strengths was a boom in sales of bargain-priced automobiles as the model year ended.
The inflation data in today's report were largely favorable. Combined with evidence of a slumping industrial sector, this suggested to many that the Federal Reserve would shortly take another modest step to reduce interest rates. In the credit markets today, however, bond prices edged lower, sending interest rates up slightly as market participants were generally unmoved by the report. The stock market had a broad-based decline that traders said was in part a reaction to negative aspects of today's statistics.
The G.N.P report's fixed-weight price index, which reflects the changing prices of a constant basket of goods and services assembled in 1982, climbed at a rate of just 2.9 percent in the third quarter, down from a 5 percent increase in the spring quarter. Falling energy prices contributed significantly to the improvement.
The G.N.P. price deflator, a less precise inflation gauge since it makes adjustments for changes in composition of the basket, also rose at a 2.9 percent rate during the quarter, down from 4.6 percent in the April-June period, the report showed.
Reflecting the heavy spending by consumers, who account for about two-thirds of economic activity, personal savings as a percentage of disposable income slipped to 5.1 percent, from 5.4 percent during the spring and 5.6 percent in the first quarter.
 
Spending Remains Heavy
Personal consumption spending increased by $37.5 billion in the third quarter from the second, or at an annual rate of 5.8 percent. This was slightly more than triple the 1.9 percent rate of gain posted during the spring and was the biggest jump since the first quarter of 1988.
Purchases of cars and other durable goods, which are items intended to last three years or longer, rose $15.1 billion, after a $5.6 billion increase in the second quarter, while nondurables jumped $8.9 billion, after a drop of $5.3 billion in the previous quarter. Spending on services climbed more slowly, by $13.5 billion compared with $12.3 billion in the second quarter.
But this bounce in the consumer sector was largely offset by a rise of only $6.6 billion in business investment in plant and equipment, down from a $10.4 billion increase in the second quarter; a decline of $2.3 billion in housing construction after a second-quarter drop of $6.3 billion; a $7.7 billion downward move in the Government's purchases of goods and services, and a $22.9 billion decline in the net export sector, in sharp contrast to a $3.8 billion gain in the second quarter.
 
A 'Split Personality'
In all, suggested Lacy H. Hunt, chief economist for Carroll McEntee & McGinley, a firm that deals in government bonds, the data ''reveal an economy with a severely split personality.'' He said the corporate and manufacturing sectors are weak, a situation that is likely to produce a third straight quarter of declining corporate profits. The report on third-quarter corporate profits is due to come out a month from now, when the first revision of today's G.N.P. data is released.
Weakness in profits, other analysts have suggested, could become an obstacle to lower interest rates as companies are forced to borrow money they had hoped to earn. In some cases, those borrowings may have to be used to service other debt.
Another worrisome sign, analysts said, was an acceleration in inventory buildup, much of it apparently involuntary. Business inventories added $11.1 billion to the third-quarter G.N.P. - $6 billion from the farm sector and $5.1 billion nonfarm - despite a sizable decrease in car and truck inventories.
Mr. Darby of the Commerce Department contended that in general ''inventories do not appear to be high relative to sales,'' but private economists said that car sales in the first 20 days of this month have been poor and that a fresh round of price concessions would probably be needed to move the vehicles.
 
Hurricane's Effect 'Negligible'
The report said that Hurricane Hugo, which battered the Carolinas in the quarter, had only a ''negligible'' effect on G.N.P. but that it had cut personal income at an annual rate of about $4 billion.
The latest figures put the annualized figure for gross national product at $4.16 trillion, compared with $4.13 trillion in the second quarter, after adjusting for inflation.
Because the figures are the first estimate for the quarter, various assumptions had to be made about the month of September. One, officials said, was that inventory buildup in September was about the same as in August. And another was that the trade deficit was about $9.9 billion in September, higher than July's $9.3 billion but well below August's $11.3 billion.
Today's report also showed that G.N.P. expressed in current dollars, rather than adjusting output for inflation, climbed at a rate of 5.6 percent in the third quarter, compared with a 7.1 percent increase in the spring.

HEADLINE: Aquino Reaffirms Her Pledge to Not Run for a Second Term

BYLINE: By STEVEN ERLANGER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MANILA, Oct. 26

 BODY:
With her approval rating slipping in the opinion polls and criticism of her administration rising, President Corazon C. Aquino of the Philippines is saying more unequivocally than ever that she will keep her pledge not to run again in 1992.
In an interview today, on the eve of her second state visit to the United States, she dismissed the pressure here on her to run and said she had done her duty in helping to restore democracy to the Philippines. After 1992, she said, she intended to write her memoirs and work with the poor. 
Asked whether she wanted to leave herself any opening for a change of mind, she said: ''If you ask me about an opening, well, in this world, of course, we cannot be 100 percent sure. But I guess I would say 99.9 percent, I am sure.''
Mrs. Aquino continues to be dogged by charges that she is indecisive and reactive and has allowed Government policy to drift and corruption to go unpunished. In the last eight months, according to an opinion poll published last week by Ateneo University, Mrs. Aquino's approval rating has slipped from 64 percent to 57 percent.
Mrs. Aquino said that criticism was endemic in a flourishing democracy, and that many other leaders would envy approval ratings of nearly 60 percent. ''I always knew this job was a difficult one,'' she said, but added: ''I did not know it would become more and more difficult.''
After Benigno S. Aquino, her husband and the country's leading opposition figure, was assassinated at the Manila airport upon his return from exile in 1983, Mrs. Aquino became the focus for the country's resentment of the 20-year rule of Ferdinand E. Marcos. Mrs. Aquino took power in February 1986 in a military-led civilian revolt after presidential elections generally seen as having been stolen from Mrs. Aquino. Mr. Marcos went into exile in Hawaii, where he died last month.
She has overseen the writing of a new constitution and free elections at every level of Filipino life, she said. She had restored the economy to moderate growth, attracted new investment and had gained the upper hand in the war against the indigenous Communist insurgency, she said.
Mrs. Aquino leaves on Nov. 4 for Canada and the United States on a visit largely devoted to the search for new foreign investment.

HEADLINE: Gorbachev Plans to Destroy His A-Armed Subs in Baltic

BYLINE: By BILL KELLER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: HELSINKI, Finland, Oct. 26

 BODY:
President Mikhail S. Gorbachev announced plans today to destroy four Soviet nuclear-missile submarines based in the Baltic Sea, as a step toward ridding the region of nuclear weapons.
The Soviet leader also said Moscow had withdrawn all of its short-range nuclear missiles to sites beyond range of northern Europe.
Mr. Gorbachev's announcements, in a speech to Finnish leaders tonight, was the latest in a series of concessions aimed at building good will in the region and increasing pressure for wider disarmament in Europe.
Western military specialists said the moves were significant political gestures but would not have a major effect on the military balance in the region. 
 
European Summit Urged
Mr. Gorbachev also called for a summit meeting of the leaders of Europe, the United States and Canada here in 1992, to take a fresh look at the future of Europe.
The Soviet leader has been using his three-day visit here to expand a northern disarmament campaign that he began two years ago with a speech in Murmansk, and to focus attention on neutral Finland as a model neighbor at a time when tumultuous change is shaking Communist Eastern Europe.
Underscoring his pledge that Moscow will not intervene in Eastern Europe, Mr. Gorbachev signed a joint declaration of principles today with President Mauno Koivisto of Finland, advocating ''absolute respect'' for the internal affairs of other countries.
The document endorses ''absolute respect for the principle of the freedom of social and political choice, de-ideologization and humanization of the relations between states, adherence to international law in foreign policy activities, and giving priority to human interests and values.''
''The use of force of any kind cannot be justified: neither by a military alliance against another alliance, nor within these alliances, nor against neutral countries from any quarter,'' the Soviet and Finnish leaders agreed.
 
Subs Will Not Be Replaced
Mr. Gorbachev told the audience tonight at the sleek Finlandia Concert Hall here that Moscow would retire its last four Golf-class nuclear missile submarines in the Baltic Sea by the end of 1990, destroying them along with their payloads and not replacing them with newer models.
They are the last of six submarines deployed in the region in 1976, and are the only vessels in the Baltic armed with nuclear ballistic missiles. The Soviet Union announced last spring that the two others were being withdrawn from operation.
Norman Polmar, a leading American naval analyst, said the submarines were nearly 30 years old and thus approaching the end of their useful life. The removal of their nuclear missiles - three per ship, with an estimated range of 900 nautical miles - still leaves many other submarines in the Baltic Sea able to carry nuclear cruise missiles and nuclear torpedos, he said.
''I look at this as a political gesture to the Baltic states - to West Germany, Denmark, Norway and Sweden, and certainly it would also be a gesture to Poland and East Germany,'' Mr. Polmar said.
 
Nuclear-Free Baltic Urged
Mr. Gorbachev said Moscow ''is prepared to come to agreement with all the nuclear powers and the Baltic States on effective guarantees for the nuclear-free status of the Baltic Sea.''
The Soviet leader said Moscow had made ''unilateral steps'' to pull back its land-based nuclear missiles from Northern Europe. The Soviet Union is eliminating medium-range nuclear missiles as part of an agreement with the United States, but his report tonight indicated that Moscow had also moved back short-range tactical weapons not covered by that treaty.
''As of now, we have no medium or shorter-range missiles on operational status in areas adjacent to the north of Europe,'' he said. ''Soviet tactical nuclear systems are now deployed in areas from which they cannot reach northern Europe from any given site in Soviet territory.''
Officials in the Finnish Foreign Ministry praised this as a sign of Moscow's commitment to reduce tensions in the region, although tactical nuclear weapons, being quite portable, could be quickly returned in a time of crisis.
 
Finland's Neutrality Backed
In his speech tonight, Mr. Gorbachev said Moscow ''unreservedly recognizes Finland's neutral status and shall continue to do so in the future.''
Soviet leaders have previously equivocated on Finland's neutrality, suggesting that Finland owes special deference to its giant eastern neighbor, so Mr. Gorbachev's statement was an important point of pride for Finns.
The two nations also signed an array of agreements promising cooperation on environmental protection, in economic development of the Kola Peninsula and in resolving trade difficulties.
While Mr. Gorbachev was pressing his case for nuclear disarmament, United States officials said today that new intelligence reports showed that the Soviet military had begun a long-expected upgrading of its anti-missile defense system around Moscow.
The ring of anti-missile defenses is permitted under the 1972 Anti-Ballistic Missile Treaty, and the Pentagon had recently predicted that improvements in the system might begin this year.
American officials said the more advanced system included two layers of nuclear-tipped missiles to stop attacking missiles either inside or outside the earth's atmosphere.

HEADLINE: Bush Administration Is Divided Over Move to Halt Global Warming

BYLINE: By ALLAN R. GOLD, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 26

 BODY:
The Bush Administration is facing increasing pressure from other nations, Congress and environmental groups to take more aggressive action on the problem of global warming. But members of the Administration are divided on what course to follow.
On one side is the Environmental Protection Agency, which favors bolder steps by the United States, including stabilizing the emissions of carbon dioxide and other gases linked to a rise in temperatures worldwide, said people familiar with the Administration discussions. Several European countries have already set such goals, and others are considering similar action. 
Other top Administration officials, among them the White House chief of staff, John H. Sununu, and the President's science adviser, D. Allan Bromley, acknowledge that global warming is a threat. But they have resisted setting specific goals on carbon dioxide emissions before there is more conclusive scientific evidence on the problem.
At the same time, the State Department official responsible for coordinating Government policy on global warming, William Nitze, said this week that because of growing international pressure, the United States would probably have to accept a goal of stabilizing carbon dioxide emissions.
 
Expense of Reducing Emissions
The carbon dioxide emissions are produced by burning fuels like coal and oil, the nation's major sources of energy, and are believed to be warming the earth by trapping heat in the atmosphere in a process like that in a greenhouse. Reducing those emissions would be costly to the nation's businesses, which are lobbying against quick action. The United States contributes about a fifth of the world's annual carbon dioxide emissions, according to Government statistics.
The division in the Administration on global warming has become more apparent in recent days as officials discussed what position to take at an international conference that begins late next week in the Netherlands. The conference is expected to endorse at least stabilizing carbon dioxide emissions.
William K. Reilly, Administrator of the Environmental Protection Agency, proposed that the United States support the stabilization measure at the Netherlands conference but was rebuffed at a meeting last Friday of a working group of the White House Domestic Policy Council, several people familiar with the meeting said.
White House officials favor a worldwide agreement that would initially acknowledge the problem of global warming and later work out specific steps to deal with it. Such a process is similar to the Vienna Convention and Montreal Protocol that produced an agreement to phase out use of the chemicals that deplete the earth's ozone layer.
The Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change, a United Nations-sponsored group, is currently working on ways to deal with possible global warming and is expected to produce a report next year that could lead to negotiations. Members of Congress and environmentalists assert that the process will take at least five years to complete.
 
Criticism of White House Stance
Marlin Fitzwater, the White House spokesman, today reiterated the President's support for that process and defended the Administration against criticism that it is moving too slowly.
''I think there are very legitimate concerns about what these policies mean for long-term economic impact and, well, economic impact in the macro sense,'' Mr. Fitzwater said. ''And those issues need to be considered and are being considered. But that does not diminish our overall commitment to deal with the global warming problem. There are economic aspects of this that cannot be ignored just blindly in the search for global warming solutions.''
The White House position was criticized today by 11 environmental and energy groups. ''President Bush said during the campaign that he would use the 'White House effect' to combat the greenhouse effect,'' the groups said in a statement. ''But a year later, the White House team hasn't even come out of the dugout.''
The environmentalists are concerned that the Administration has not moved quickly enough to fulfill a commitment it made in July with six other industrial nations at the Paris Economic Summit to limit emissions of carbon dioxide and other gases.
On Capitol Hill, the President's policies on global warming are being challenged by both Democrats and Republicans. Members in both houses have proposed legislation that would force reductions in carbon dioxide emissions.
 
'Dragging Its Feet'
On the Senate floor Tuesday night, Senator Tim Wirth, a Colorado Democrat, accused the Administration of ''dragging its feet'' on the issue, which he says is the most urgent facing the nation and world.
''We're getting the wool pulled over our heads by a group that has its head in the sand,'' Mr. Wirth said.
In a letter to Mr. Bush this week, Senator John H. Chafee, Republican of Rhode Island, and four other Republican Senators, urged the President to use the Netherlands meeting to ''put the United States in a position of world leadership.''
''We are concerned that, unless you provide personal leadership on this issue, the United States will continue to send mixed signals to the world community,'' the senators wrote.
They proposed aggressive action calling for the signing of an agreement on global warming no later than March 1991 and a commitment to freeze carbon dioxide emissions in the United States at 1988 or 1989 levels.
Mr. Nitze, Deputy Assistant Secretary of State, told a conference on global warming Tuesday that resisting a commitment to stabilize the emissions may prove difficult.
''The pressure for some sort of stabilization effort is going to be very strong and very hard to resist,'' Mr. Nitze said. He said his comments reflected his personal views and not a change in the Administration position. But environmentalists said the statement is the first in which an Administration official has publicly suggested that the United States may have to change its stated position.
In an interview, Mr. Nitze said his view on the subject had changed since he attended a meeting in Geneva earlier this month on climate change. More than a third of the 43 countries at the meeting expressed support for an agreement that included at least an initial goal of stabilizing emissions.

HEADLINE: Medicare and Social Security Aren't Welfare;
Benefits Will Increase

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Phillip Longman declared in his book, ''Born to Pay,'' that the ''moral'' flaw of Social Security is that it frees parents from the need to take care of their children in order to earn their support later in life. That seems unfounded and extreme, to say the least. In his Oct. 10 Op-Ed article, he repeats that Social Security unduly favors the elderly over the young, to their detriment, because the beneficiaries paid so little for their benefits, and that future retirees, those now at work, will get a poorer return. 
It is Mr. Longman's vision that is morally flawed. In his book, the family seems not to exist. But it does, especially for children. When current earners were children, their working parents' Social Security earned them life insurance coverage of enormous value - greater, in total, than that of private life insurance. It earned them income protection in the event of a working parent's disablement. Social Security gave - and gives - that protection to almost all children, except for the small percentage with neither parent working in a covered job. And it pays benefits to about 3 1/2 million children or those who became disabled as children.
Moreover, the children of today's retirees participated in the good deal their parents got: low Federal Insurance Contribution Act rates meant more take-home pay; comparatively substantial benefits for today's retired mean less financial load on today's employed.
Mr. Longman decries the ''windfall'' that early participants in Social Security and Medicare got. But that is a characteristic of any new program that produces decent benefits. Most defined benefit private pension plans did the same. More important, each generation derives financial benefit from the efforts of its predecessors -their parents' generation - who helped build the society and the economy and, indeed, suffered privation in World War II to protect it.
Future retirees will obtain Social Security benefits that replace the same portion of former income as current beneficiaries do. But, and it's a big but, future incomes should be more substantial than those earned by those now retired. Hence, the Social Security benefits of future retirees will be greater.
 
MERTON C. BERNSTEIN
St. Louis, Oct. 11, 1989
 The writer, Coles Professor of Law at Washington University in St. Louis, is co-author of ''Social Security: The System That Works.''

HEADLINE: What the New West Germans Can Expect

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Flight to West Germany, despite its appeal to many East Germans (front page, Oct. 4), may not be quite what they expected. Der Spiegel, the West German newsweekly, reported Sept. 18, even before the most recent wave coming through Czechoslovakia, intense controversy about the influx of East Germans.
With housing in shorter supply than since the early post-World War II period, and with nearly two million unemployed, not all West Germans share what one official has called the ''policy of open arms.'' Der Spiegel reported a poll finding that 46 percent of West Germans opposed a further influx of East Germans. Meanwhile, the conservative government is considering a bill to restrict their freedom of entry. 
Coverage of their reception in the West has focused almost exclusively on West German employers' enthusiastic offers of work. Some employers, Der Spiegel notes, have restricted job openings exclusively to East German refugees. The reason is obvious: like most immigrants, they must often work harder and accept greater sacrifice to make it in their new home. However, that is not always enough; social workers in Frankfurt and Hamburg estimate that 40 percent of those without a permanent address are immigrants from East Germany. The charity organization Caritas in Wurttemberg reports that one-third of all beggars are East German emigres.
Most American reporting of the emigration wave portrays the economic problems these people are fleeing, particularly substandard housing, as failings unique to Communism. But the poor in America experience the same problem. And while the poor may work, they do so at wages too meager to lift them out of poverty. The lack of affordable housing in both the United States and West Germany has been attributable to the same abandonment of public housing construction in favor of greater reliance on the market.
The desire of East Germans to share in the abundance and political freedoms in West Germany is understandable. But will they have jobs and a place to live?
 
JOHN TORPEY
Berkeley, Calif., Oct. 5, 1989

HEADLINE: Exxon Will Move Its Headquarters To Texas

BYLINE: By JAMES BARRON

 BODY:
The Exxon Corporation said yesterday that it would move its corporate headquarters and 300 employees from the Exxon Building in Manhattan to a 132-acre office park near Dallas.
Exxon's chairman, Lawrence G. Rawl, said the company had concluded that ''the Dallas area offered the best combination of factors from the standpoint of our employees' personal and professional lives and from an overall business standpoint.''
The company, which had already reduced its work force in New York to 300, from 2,100, would not say how much money it would save by leaving town. 
The company's move did not surprise real-estate analysts who said there was no longer a compelling reason for Exxon to have a headquarters with a New York address.
 
Corporate Exodus Continues
''If you have a good fax machine and a decent airport, it doesn't matter where you are,'' said L. Clinton Hoch, the president of the Metropolitan Consulting Group, a relocation and real-estate affiliate of the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company.
Exxon's departure next fall will make it the latest company to join the continuing corporate exodus from Manhattan. J. C. Penney & Company, once a neighbor of Exxon's among the steel-and-glass towers and bubbling fountains on the Avenue of the Americas, closed its headquarters and sent 4,000 employees to the Dallas area in 1987, saying the move would save $60 million a year in rent.
Exxon has been the last of the large oil companies with corporate headquarters in Manhattan, far from the oil wells that produce its wealth. But now it, too, is going the way of other large petroleum producers that have called in the movers.
The Mobil Corporation moved to Fairfax, Va., in 1987. Texaco, which once had offices in the Chrysler Building, relocated to White Plains in 1977. Among the other major energy companies based in Texas - mainly in Houston - are the Shell Oil Company, an affiliate of the Royal Dutch-Shell group of companies in the Netherlands; Tenneco Inc., and the Coastal Corporation, a pipeline company.
 
'An Individual Relocation'
At City Hall yesterday there were few damp eyes. Officials said Exxon had not called to discuss leaving town before it made the announcement, and Stanley Grayson, the deputy mayor for finance and economic development, contended that the departure was not a sign of economic trouble ahead, either for the office-rental market or the city's overall economy.
''This is an individual relocation,'' he said. ''It's part of an industry which I think is generally perceived as a southwest, Texas-based industry. It's part of an industry that's half the size it was 10 years ago. Its outlook is not necessarily bright and it's not perceived as a tremendous growth industry right now.''
Real-estate experts say that Exxon - with only six floors in its Rockefeller Center building, down from 23 in the 1970's - had become a relatively small player in a soft market.
Mr. Rawl said the company would lease temporary office space in Dallas before moving into permanent offices that will be built in Irving, close to the Dallas-Fort Worth airport.

HEADLINE: Daily Flights to Be Offered at Stewart Airport

BYLINE: By RICHARD SEVERO, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: NEWBURGH, N.Y., Oct. 26

 BODY:
In a deal that State Economic Development Commissioner Vincent Tese said was worked out with ''smoke and mirrors and no money,'' American Airlines reversed its position and announced today it would begin daily passenger service from Stewart International Airport to connecting hubs at Chicago and Raleigh/Durham, N.C.
The service is to begin April 17 and will be the first regular civilian passenger flights from the former Stewart Air Force Base, which is just west of Newburgh and about 60 miles north of New York City.
On Aug. 12, American said it could not spare any of its 482 planes for service at Stewart because it was trying to accelerate its plans to create a new major operations hub in Miami. James Brown, a spokesman for American, said then that American did not rule out service at Stewart eventually, but that it would come ''at no time soon.'' Today, Mr. Brown said American's situation had changed.
Mr. Tese said the state expects American to remain at Stewart for at least two years to determine whether there is a sufficient market for it in the Hudson Valley. The agreement followed a long effort to use the large former military base, which closed two decades ago and now houses the Air National Guard and several air freight and other companies. 
 
Ease Congestion at Other Airports
The state, which owns the airport, hopes that it will both serve the Hudson Valley and help relieve congestion at the three major New York City area airports. Hudson Valley residents now travel two hours or longer to the New York area airports.
In a sun-drenched ceremony near the main runway, Melvin E. Olsen, American's vice president for capacity planning, told Gov. Mario M. Cuomo and hundreds of other invited guests that the airline would make six round trips a day out of Stewart - three each to its hubs at Chicago and Raleigh/Durham.
The negotiations to bring American to Stewart were complex. Mr. Tese, who has been trying to induce the airline to start service at Stewart for months, said that originally, American wanted to be indemnified by the state for up to $6 million in annual losses. Mr. Tese said the state rejected the proposal and then, with the cooperation of the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey, offered to sweeten the deal by arranging for American to get six extra gates at Kennedy, LaGuardia and Newark Airports.
Mr. Tese said it was not clear whether any airlines would be asked to give up their gates at the three airports. He said that with the exception of one concession, the deal to bring air service into Stewart would not cost New York State anything. The one concession, he said, is that American will not have to pay state sales tax on any materials it buys in the state for an addition to the passenger terminal at Stewart.
 
Lawsuit Filed
But not all of Stewart's problems are behind it. The airport, which has been run by the State Department of Transportation since 1986, has become the subject of a lawsuit brought by several groups of environmentalists led by the Stewart Park and Reserve Coalition, a local organization. The coalition is being aided by the Sierra Club, the Hudson River Fishermen's Association, Scenic Hudson and Orange Environment.
The environmentalists say they are not opposed to all development at the airport, but charge that the state has been violating the State Environmental Quality Review Act by permitting piecemeal development and failing to assess the impact of what it is doing. The lawsuit, filed last July, is pending in State Supreme Court in Albany.
Recently, environmentalists were angered when they heard that an airport employee shot and killed a bald eagle. The employee reportedly mistook the bird for a turkey vulture and shot it because he thought it would interfere with aviation. State and Federal authorities are investigating the incident.

HEADLINE: Rivals in Nassau Offer Differing Visions of County

BYLINE: By SARAH LYALL, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: HEMPSTEAD, L.I., Oct. 25

 BODY:
As Richard Korn travels through Nassau County, campaigning for its highest office, he says he sees a place where people who came to pursue the American dream are being driven out by rising taxes.
Thomas S. Gulotta, the incumbent County Executive who is running for re-election, has a different vision. He sees an area envied by the rest of the country, where the good life is still obtainable.
Mr. Korn is a Democratic businessman who has never held public office. Mr. Gulotta is a longtime Republican politician who won his last election in a landslide. As they approach Election Day, their perceptions of the county have become an important part of the campaign. 
Mr. Korn, who gained attention when he sued Nassau County in 1987, forcing Mr. Gulotta to rewrite his $1.5 billion budget, is seeking to draw on residents' frustration over the increasingly high cost of living on Long Island. He points to what happened last spring, when voters balked at increases in school taxes and rejected more than one-third of the Island's proposed school budgets on the first ballot.
 
Middle-Class Issues
''Everyone is fed up with high taxes, with being misused and abused by Gulotta,'' Mr. Korn said in an interview during a recent campaign swing, as he smiled, gulped down coffee and shook hands with people coming in and out of a supermarket in Merrick.
''I'm addressing the issues that affect the middle class,'' he said. ''The response has been extremely gratifying.''
But Mr. Gulotta, who has promised a $10 million cut in county taxes for next year, says that Long Island remains one of the country's most desirable places and that its residents are hanging on to their dreams.
''The economy in Nassau County is extremely strong, one of the strongest economies in his nation,'' he said in an interview in his office, filled with expensive-looking furniture that his aides said he bought with his own money. ''Property values have come down a little recently, but compared to five years ago, they've dramatically increased.''
 
'Stronger Than Ever'
Mr. Gulotta said, however, that the county faced some tough issues - including taxes, the environment and illegal drugs and crime - that he was prepared to deal with in the next term.
''One of our biggest assets is that people have not lost their dream for the future,'' he said. ''The spark and the ability to dream of a better life is still there. If anything, it's stronger than ever.''
From the moment Mr. Korn announced his candidacy last spring, he knew the race would be difficult. Mr. Gulotta is an established figure in county politics, the son of a local District Attorney who later became a State Supreme Court judge. Formerly a state Assemblyman, he has come up through the Republican ranks as Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato did, serving as Hempstead Presiding Supervisor before becoming County Executive.
Registered Republicans outnumber registered Democrats 3 to 2 in Nassau, which has not had a Democratic County Executive in 20 years.
 
'Tough Race, Tough County'
Mr. Korn, who runs his campaign out of a cramped office next to a bakery in the small community of Williston Park, has been hampered by worries about money and by difficulties in getting recognition. He said he has spent $114,000 on his campaign, all but $17,000 his own. Mr. Gulotta said he has spent $510,144.
The business community, hurting from a downturn in Long Island's economy, has not lost its initial scepticism about Mr. Korn. But Democratic leaders remain hopeful. ''It's a tough race in a tough county,'' said John Marino, chairman of the New York State Democratic committee. ''But I don't regard it as a race that can't be won.''
Republicans say Mr. Gulotta is a formidable opponent in a race that plays to his strengths. And incumbency is always an advantage.
Referring to radio announcements in which Hempstead's Presiding Supervisor, Joseph N. Mondello, and Mr. Gulotta are heard promoting tourism, Hemspstead's Democratic leader, Edward A. Grause said, ''You hear Mondello hawking road maps on the radio, and then Gulotta comes along and hawks other road maps.''
 
Never Lost Election
Aides say the County Executive, known for his grueling schedule, is a hands-on leader who runs a 20,000-employee county government carefully and efficiently. He is cool and measured, and as he makes stop after stop at civic meetings and awards ceremonies on a typical night, seems to draw strength from being recognized and greeted.
Mr. Gulotta, 45 years old, was born on Long Island and educated at Trinity College in Hartford and at Columbia University Law School. He lives in North Merrick with his wife, Betsy, three children and a variety of pets, including a large white cockatiel. Mr. Gulotta has held public office since 1969 and has never lost an election.
Mr. Korn, 39, an owner of a video-editing business, was born in the town of Ellenville, in Ulster County, N.Y. He graduated from Adelphi University and received a law degree from Hofstra, settling in Long Island in 1968. He now lives in Glen Head and separated from his wife last winter. In 1976, Mr. Korn made an unsuccessful bid for the Democratic nomination for a seat in the State Senate.
A personable, excitable man, Mr. Korn has approached politics as an outsider from the beginning. His first contact with Mr. Gulotta, he says, was as a ''homeowner and a taxpayer'' - when he stood up at a Board of Supervisors meeting in 1987 and accused the executive of illegally concealing surplus money in the county's budget.
''He basically told me to sit down,'' Mr. Korn said. But he sued, and the matter went all the way to the State Court of Appeals, which ruled that Mr. Gulotta's budget was illegal and forced him to rewrite it.
Mr. Korn calls his effort a ''victory for all taxpayers.'' Mr. Gulotta says that the lawsuit was a waste of taxpayers' money, and that all it did was force a cosmetic accounting change.
Whether or not Mr. Korn wins, other Democrats say his candidacy has helped the party in Nassau County.
''We're really excited about seeing Nassau Democrats together,'' Mr. Marino said. ''They've had a history of killing each other within the party.''

Gulotta, the Republican incumbent, talking with Robert Pierce, the executive director of the Long Island Council of Churches, earlier this month (The New York Times/Barton Silverman)

HEADLINE: Business Digest

Economy
The economy grew at a 2.5 percent rate in the third quarter as a surge in consumer spending offset weakness in exports and the industrial sector. Economists found reason to cheer in the report's indication of lower inflation, even though that was mostly a reflection of falling energy prices. [Page A1.] 
State and Federal regulators accused senior officials of Lincoln Savings and Loan of resorting to wiretapping, political pressure and inducements to regulators to thwart efforts to close the unit. [A1.]
The Bush Administration has announced borrowing measures to insure that Social Security benefits will not be embroiled in the fight over capital gains tax cuts. [D1.]
Many large and profitable companies that managed to pay little or no Federal income tax have been pushed back onto the tax rolls by the 1986 overhaul of the tax code, a survey found. [D4.]
 
International
While it has become increasingly tough for American companies to raise money, the Japanese stock market has been churning out record levels of fresh capital for Japanese corporations. [A1.]
The U.S. remains divided from most of its allies over proposals to relax controls on shipping machine tools to Europe. [D3.]
Costa Rica and its commercial bankers are close to reaching a debt agreement. [D3.]
 
Companies
The Big Three auto makers overall had lower profits. Ford Motor fell 44.3 percent; G.M. was down nearly 40 percent, but Chrsyler had an increase because of a one time gain. [D1.]
A.T.&T. can continue to offer customized networks for large business customers, the F.C.C. ruled. But the commission voted to reject a discount plan that would allow A.T.&T. to match a competitor's low price for a long-distance service. [D1.]
Intel said design flaws had been discovered in its top-of-the-line microprocessor chip but that the errors would be corrected. [D1.]
McDonald's and eight plastics producers will set up a national program to recycle plastic hamburger containers. [D1.]
UAL's earnings fell 72.4 percent but revenues in the third quarter rose 7.1 percent from the corresponding period last year. [D4.]
Lawyers for the production team that Sony plans to hire to run argued in court papers that agreements with Warner Communications permit the pair to join Columbia Pictures. [D5.]
Presidential Airways filed for protection from creditors under Chapter 11 of the Federal Bankruptcy Act. [D4.]
The New York Post will stop publishing its Sunday issue on Nov. 26. [D5.]
 
Markets
Stocks finished broadly lower on moderate volume as the market continued a week of turbulent activity. The Dow dropped 39.55, to 2,613.73. [D6.] Trading in stock ''baskets'' began in New York and Chicago, marred by a computer problem in New York. [D6.]
Treasury securities prices edged lower in sluggish trading. [D12.] Prices of RJR Nabisco's ''junk bonds'' tumbled on rumors that a deal to sell its Del Monte division was in trouble. [D12.]
The dollar gained against most major currencies, particularly the British pound, which plunged after the country's Treasury chief resigned. [D14.] Wheat futures prices fell below $4 a bushel for the first time in a month. [D14.]
 
Today's Columns
The U.S. has been selling assets to foreigners to maintain its existing level of consumption and investment but a lot of non-economists feel it cannot go on. Leonard Silk: Economic Scene. [D2.]
After about a year of relative calm, a revolt is spreading across Wall Street against index arbitrage. Market Place. [D1.]
Coca-Cola has revived its ''I'd Like to Teach the World to Sing'' campaign that was popular 18 years ago. Advertising. [D5.]

HEADLINE: Profits on Autos Sales Off Sharply for Big 3

BYLINE: By DORON P. LEVIN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: DETROIT, Oct. 26

 BODY:
The downturn in the United States automotive industry was clearly evident today as the Big Three auto makers posted third-quarter results that showed each had sharply lower profits from domestic car and truck sales.
Moreover, industry executives and analysts said, prospects for renewed profit growth should remain dim until at least next year.
The poor earnings from vehicle sales reflected steep discounting by the manufacturers in the third quarter to reduce inventories on dealer lots, as well as scattered production cuts at several assembly plants.
Without profits from diversified and overseas operations, the General Motors Corporation and the Ford Motor Company would have posted only marginal profits or a loss for the period. As it was, G.M.'s earnings dropped nearly 40 percent and Ford's fell 44 percent. The Chrysler Corporation had a one-time gain from the sale of part of its stake in the Mitsubishi Motor Corporation and that caused third-quarter profit nearly to triple from last year's quarter. But without the gain the company barely made money. Chrysler is much less diversified than its domestic rivals. 
While the results were not a surprise, they indicated that auto executives are running out of ways to prop up sales.
''Volumes are lower and incentive costs are higher, and that's a deadly combination,'' said Harvey Heinbach, an industry analyst for Merrill Lynch & Company. Mr. Heinbach estimated that fourth-quarter production schedules of domestic auto makers would be down 16 percent from a year ago, meaning scattered shutdowns of assembly and component plants for a week or more. In the third quarter, the industry's production was down 13 percent from the period last year.
 
Fewer Vehicles Shipped
Executives said that a weakening economy may keep vehicle sales depressed for several more months. All three companies shipped fewer vehicles in the third quarter than they did a year earlier. Such shipments are the basic measure on which they record revenue and profit.
In addition to a softening economy and declining demand, earnings typically are weak in the third quarter because so many plants are closed for model changeovers.
G.M. reported net income for all operations of $517 million, which was off 39.8 percent from the $859 million earned in last year's third quarter. Earnings per share were 72 cents, compared with $1.23 a year earlier. Revenues rose slightly, to $28.8 billion, from $28.2 billion last year.
G.M's non-automotive subsidiaries also reported earnings yesterday. Its Electronic Data Systems Corporation had a 16 percent increase in profit, while its GM Hughes Electronics Corporation had a 17.7 percent decline.
G.M.'s stock fell 50 cents today, to $44.375 a share, on the New York Stock Exchange.
G.M. declined to say whether its United States automotive operations were profitable in the quarter, but it said all major operating groups were profitable for the first nine months of the year. Roger B. Smith, G.M.'s chairman, said in a prepared statement that the company's North American operations were affected favorably by ''improved operating efficiencies.''
 
Ford Profit Declines 44.3%
Ford earned $477.1 million in the third quarter, or $1.03 a share, down 44.3 percent from the $856.3 million, or $1.78 a share, earned in the same quarter last year. Revenue slipped to $20.24 billion, from $20.38 billion a year earlier.
Referring to Ford's United States automotive business, which had a $37 million loss in the period and has been down 36 percent for the first nine months of the year, Donald E. Petersen, chairman, said in a prepared statement that the quarter's financial results ''show the challenges facing all auto makers in the domestic market, which is being affected by a slight downturn at the same time that competition is increasing and marketing costs are rising.''
Ford's financial services subsidiary, which includes the Ford Motor Credit Company and the First Nationwide banks and savings and loan institutions, earned $190 million in the quarter, about even with last year's $193 million.
David McCammon, Ford's treasurer, said the nation's No. 2 auto maker is expecting fourth-quarter profit to be off, but to a lesser degree than in the third quarter.
Ford's stock fell 37.5 cents today, to $47.50 a share, on the New York Stock Exchange.
 
Stock Sale Lifts Chrysler
Chrysler's third-quarter net income was up 192.9 percent, to $331 million, or $1.42 a share, from $113 million, or 50 cents a share last year. Revenue was flat at $7.88 billion. However, the latest profit figure was affected by a one-time after-tax gain of $309 million, or $1.32 a share, from the previously announced sale of 75 million Mitsubishi shares. Without the gain, Chrysler's net fell nearly 81 percent.
''It's been a tough quarter,'' said Lee A. Iacocca, Chrysler's chairman, in a prepared statement. ''Our earnings have been squeezed by a softer retail market and by unprecedented sales incentive costs. We expect these extreme cost pressures to continue into the fourth quarter and beyond.''
Chrysler's stock fell 37.5 cents, to $22.25 a share, on the New York Stock Exchange today.

HEADLINE: President's Gains Tax Maneuver

BYLINE: By SUSAN F. RASKY, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 26

 BODY:
In an effort to regain momentum in its battle to cut capital gains taxes, the Bush Administration today announced extraordinary Government borrowing measures to insure that next month's Social Security checks would not be delayed by the political fight.
The Administration's decision means that the Government will have enough money to make the scheduled Social Security payments on Nov. 3, even if Congress has not approved legislation to extend the Government's borrowing authority.
The $2.87 trillion temporary debt ceiling will expire on Oct. 31, and Senate Republicans have been agonizing over whether to attach a proposal to cut capital gains taxes to legislation to extend the debt ceiling.
 
Few Remaining Opportunities
Republicans view the debt-ceiling bill as one of their few remaining opportunities to press for a cut in capital gains taxes this year. But they do not want to appear to be holding up Social Security payments or risking a Government shutdown while battling over the tax measure. 
In a letter to Congress, Treasury Secretary Nicholas F. Brady said the Treasury would move up its regular borrowing schedule to raise $17 billion in the financial markets before Oct. 31. The department said it would announce procedures on Friday for the special auction.
Mr. Brady's letter said that although the Government's borrowing authority would revert to $2.8 trillion after Oct. 31, the special borrowing would raise enough money to make the Social Security payments and to keep the Government operating through Nov. 7.
''It's obvious that politics are driving their decisions,'' said Senator Lloyd Bentsen, the Texas Democrat who heads the Senate Finance Committee. ''They are so determined to win the capital gains cut that they are resorting to extraordinary financing. This is unprecedented, and it will cost the Treasury an extra $20 million to do it.''
 
Treasury's Practice
A senior Treasury Department official confirmed that the financing procedure was unprecedented. As a matter of practice, the Treasury does not borrow up to its debt limit, but instead leaves a cushion.
Mr. Bentsen said that Mr. Brady had called him this afternoon to disclose the Treasury's plans and that he, in turn, immediately notified the Senate majority leader, George J. Mitchell of Maine. Mr. Mitchell, who has said that he would like to see a ''clean'' debt-limit bill with no amendments of any sort, had been planning to bring the debt legislation to the Senate floor on Monday or Tuesday.
It was not immediately clear how the Treasury announcement would affect the Republicans' strategy for attaching a proposal to cut capital gains taxes to the debt legislation. But it will almost certainly strengthen their position by removing the issue of Social Security benefits from the political calculations.
The Treasury's announcement also gives Republicans another week to decide how to proceed, but at the same time it intensifies the capital gains battle that is already under way as the Senate considers a bill providing economic aid to Poland and Hungary.
 
Mitchell's Accusation
Mr. Mitchell accused Republicans and the Bush Administration today of delaying aid to Poland and Hungary by seeking to attach a capitial gains tax cut proposal to the aid package.
''This unfortunate action could delay or could permit defeat of the aid to Poland and Hungary, which we thought was the President's priority,'' Mr. Mitchell told reporters. He added that it could be a week or more before the Senate returns to the assistance measure.
Republican leaders, who see their chances dimming for getting a capital gains tax cut approved this year, took a calculated political risk Wednesday night and offered their proposal as an amendment to the Eastern European assistance package. The practical effect of the maneuver is to create parliamentary gridlock for at least the next week, with the aid package and the capital gains tax cut in limbo while the Senate runs against the Oct. 31 deadline for raising the debt limit.
 
Dole's Defense
The Senate Republican leader, Bob Dole of Kansas, defended their effort to amend the aid package, insisting that if Republicans had not made their move, they would have been ''shut out completely'' from voting on a capital gains tax cut.
But the political consequences of the delay could be particularly severe for President Bush, who has already been criticized by Congressional Democrats and the press for appearing timid in his response to Eastern European needs.
At the White House today, Mr. Bush's press secretary, Marlin Fitzwater, said that while the White House had not planned the capital gains maneuver, it was aware of it and approved it. ''This was not our decision; it was the Senate leadership,'' he said. ''We do support it.'' Republicans admit that they do not have the 60 votes needed to overcome parliamentary obstacles that prevent them from attaching a capital gains tax cut amendment to other pieces of legislation with a simple majority of 51 votes.
 
Forcing Test Votes
As a result, they are prepared to force test votes on the amendment procedure to demonstrate that a majority of senators favor cutting the capital gains tax and that the will of the majority is being thwarted by the Senate Democratic leadership.
Senator Bob Packwood of Oregon, the senior Republican on the Senate Finance Committee and the chief sponsor of the proposed capital gains tax cut, conceded today that even this point would be difficult to make. Mr. Packwood said 44 of the Senate's 45 Republicans and 12 of the 55 Democrats support the substance of his plan, but many of the Democrats would be unwilling to buck Mr. Mitchell on a procedural vote.

HEADLINE: Economic Scene;
The Changes Forced by Deficits

BYLINE: By Leonard Silk

 BODY:
THE White House and Congress still pay lip service to the importance of getting rid of the budget deficit. But virtually nobody believes that the Government will come close to balancing its budget in the foreseeable future. This means that with the budget deficit subtracting from the already low national savings rate, the United States has been compelled to sell assets to foreigners to maintain its existing level of consumption and investment.
How long can this go on? Nobody knows, but a lot of non-economists instinctively feel it cannot go on indefinitely. In a speech to the United Nations Association in New York this week, H. Ross Perot, the Texas entrepreneur, held up a recent cover of Time magazine, showing George Washington with a tear rolling down his cheek, to mourn ''the death of Government.'' 
Mr. Perot said the United States was surrendering its world economic and political leadership role and, by refusing to discipline itself, piling unsustainable burdens of debt on its children.
There are still some economists who share this anxiety. At an international banking conference at Pace University in New York this week, Robert Triffin, professor emeritus of economics at Yale and a prime mover in the construction of the European Monetary System, observed that foreigners have been financing about 80 percent of the United States external and internal deficits, to the tune of hundreds of billions of dollars. ''Such an absurd pattern of international financial policies cannot continue indefinitely,'' he said.
But a great many economists and policy makers, at home and abroad, argue that this circular pattern, with the United States running big trade deficits, foreigners recycling the dollars and buying up American assets, and Americans emitting i.o.u.'s, can go on for a long time and that there is no urgent need to get rid of the budget and trade deficits.
At the Pace conference, Sylvia Ostry, special adviser to Canada's Secretary of State for External Affairs, said the threat of a dollar crisis, which she called ''the best international argument to spur U.S. budget action,'' had become ''embarrassingly less credible in the face of reasonable exchange rate stability and, indeed, recent dollar strengthening.''
Politically here at home, there is little prospect of decisive action to get rid of the deficit by steeply increasing taxes or cutting expenditures. Gramm-Rudman is simply forcing more spending off budget, as with the bailout of savings and loans.
And President Bush holds to ''read my lips, no new taxes'' harder than ever; David Broder, the political columnist of The Washington Post, says that having lost ground with his party's right wing on the two crucial issues of anti-Communism and anti-abortion, Mr. Bush is less willing than ever to change his anti-tax position, vital to retaining the support of his political base.
Does all this mean that with the true fiscal deficit (counting tax expenditures and off-budget as well as on-budget spending) likely to persist and even widen, Americans and their political representatives will simply settle down to enjoy the trade deficit, the deficit in the balance of payments on current account, the continuing inflow of capital and the transfer of assets to foreigners?
Mrs. Ostry suggests they cannot and will not. ''In the absence of fiscal action, the stalled current-account adjustment process will once again create mounting popular demands to 'do something,' '' she said. What will that ''something'' be?
One thing it is likely to be is more Japan-bashing. The Japanese themselves are worried about that trend and have begun some America-bashing of their own. Their importation of former President Ronald Reagan for healing speeches appears designed to head off an American anti-Japanese attack.
Another American response, directed more broadly at not only Japan but also the newly industrialized countries in Asia and the uniting Europe, will be a tougher trade policy, already labeled, among other things, ''aggressive reciprocity,'' ''bilateral activism'' and ''unilateralism.'' But as the current trade talks in Geneva show, the United States is still holding the line against out-and-out protectionism and instead seeking to open markets for trade in services and agricultural products, where it has strength.
A third area where the United States may press harder is on the ''competitiveness'' front, which may mean more government-industry research, as in semiconductors or other high-technology fields, and less antitrust resistance to collaboration by private companies.
Further, the United States is likely to press its allies harder to take over military and foreign-aid and foreign-loan burdens that this country has been carrying since the postwar period, when its economic strength was dominant. But there is uncertainty and anxiety here about what the consequences would be of trying to transfer such responsibilities to Japan, West Germany and others.
Thus, the startling changes in the United States' economic and financial position, exacerbated by the failure of the country to discipline itself at home, is forcing a fundamental and potentially hazardous restructuring of America's external and domestic policies.

HEADLINE: U.S. Divided From Allies on Easing Export Bans

BYLINE: By STEVEN GREENHOUSE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: PARIS, Oct. 26

 BODY:
As a meeting of high-level trade officials ended today, the United States remained divided from most of its allies over proposals to relax controls on shipping machine tools and other high-technology goods to Eastern Europe.
Nonetheless, American officials said Washington and its allies would continue studying whether and how to shorten the list of goods that Western companies are not permitted to sell to Eastern Europe.
''This is something that needs to be studied in light of developments there,'' said a United States official, who asked not to be identified. 
 
U.S. Seen as Isolated
European officials said that at the meeting of the 17-nation Coordinating Committee for Multilateral Export Controls, known as Cocom, the United States was largely isolated, with most of its allies wanting to move faster to relax export controls, especially with regard to Poland and Hungary.
European officials have accused the United States of clinging to cold-war attitudes on trade and not responding to the changes in Eastern Europe. Cocom, based in Paris, was formed more than 40 years ago, when the cold war had just begun. The 17-nation organization, consisting of NATO members, Japan and Australia, seeks to define and enforce limitations on what sophisticated goods can be shipped to Communist nations.
The advocates of relaxing export controls are led by West Germany, which has a strong machine tool industry and is eager to improve political and economic ties with Eastern Europe.
 
Strained Relations in NATO
Some European officials said the United States does not feel pressed to liberalize the rules because its machine tool industry is lagging and it has little to lose by keeping the rules strict.
Machine tools are essentially machines that make other machines. The more advanced tools are computer-operated, with a dozen or more cutting axes, or cutting directions, and are able to shape metal to an accuracy of 10 one-thousandths of an inch.
American officials have accused European companies of dodging Cocom's rules in order to get an inside track in developing trade relations with Western Europe. These differences have strained relations within NATO.
 
Charges Against Olivetti
The head of the American delegation, Reginald Bartholomew, Under Secretary of State for security affairs, traveled to Rome before the Paris meeting to voice charges that Olivetti S.p.A., the Italian office equipment company, had improperly sold goods to the Soviet Union.
American officials said Olivetti might be prohibited from selling certain products in the United States because of accusations that it had sold the Soviet Union machine tools that could be used to produce jet fighter engines.
This accusation followed a storm that erupted last year over the Toshiba Corporation's shipping sophisticated machine tools to the Soviet Union that were said to have helped it develop submarine propellers that could not be detected.
 
Bar to Development Cited
The greatest tensions at the meeting came over Europe's push to ease restrictions on machine tool exports. Some European officials said the restrictions cover many items that are not sensitive and hold back development in Poland and Hungary.
Some officials said the United States was outnumbered by 16 to 1 at the meeting. An American official denied this, however, saying, ''The fact that there are pulls and tugs at various times over precisely what should be done, and how, is normal in an organization like this.''
France has long backed the United States' view on export controls, but the French Government, eager to increase trade with Eastern Europe, has sided with West Germany.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS PEOPLE;
N.A.M., in Shift, Picks Economist as President

BYLINE: By Louis Uchitelle

 BODY:
Jerry J. Jasinowski became president of the National Association of Manufacturers this week, setting a sort of precedent. Normally the association recruits an executive of a manufacturing company to be president. Mr. Jasinowski is the first economist named to the group's top job, and he has never even worked in the private sector, except for odd jobs while in college.
But times have changed in manufacturing. Service companies have gained in importance and the manufacturing association, in reaction, is drawing on economics to argue that manufacturing should be nurtured as the biggest source of wealth for the American economy. 
''We've got to raise the decibel level about the key role of manufacturing,'' said Mr. Jasinowski, who had been the association's chief economist for nine years. ''Without a strong manufacturing sector, there's no solving the trade or budget deficits - and manufacturing is the chief source of new technology.''
Mr. Jasinowski, who is 50 years old and 6 feet 3 inches tall, replaced Alexander Trowbridge, a former vice chairman of the Allied Company, who retired. But as chief economist and executive vice president, he had already become its most-quoted spokesman, sometimes criticizing the Federal Reserve (for high interest rates) and leveraged buyouts (they disrupt manufacturing).
Mr. Jasinowski's installation as president on Wednesday - an event that took place at the association's board of directors meeting in Indianapolis - was a sweet, emotional victory for him.
He grew up in LaPorte, Ind., not far away. His widowed mother, who still lives there, raised four children and to supplement her meager income from many jobs, she collected welfare for the family for 10 years. She was present for the installation, and her son introduced her during his acceptance speech, and thanked her.
Mr. Jasinowski was the first member of his family to graduate from high school, and he is still the only one with a college degree - from Indiana University in 1962. He had gone there for business courses, thinking this was the ticket to a big income later, but switched to economics ''because it offered a better framework'' for understanding the country. Economics has also paid off; his new salary is more than $200,000 a year.
Soon after college, Mr. Jasinowski joined the Air Force as an intelligence officer and remained in the service into the 1970's, serving for a while in Vietnam and later teaching economics at the Air Force Academy.
Research work on Federal subsidies brought Mr. Jasinowski to the attention of former Senator William Proxmire, and he became an economist on the Joint Economic Committee of Congress. He played a role in drafting the Humphrey-Hawkins full employment bill and later headed a transition team for the incoming Carter Administration. His last job, before joining the manufacturers association in 1980, was as an Assistant Secretary of Commerce.
