HEADLINE: Reagan Warns Japanese on Trade

BYLINE: By STEVEN R. WEISMAN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TOKYO, Saturday, Oct. 28

 BODY:
In a tougher warning on trade than he issued as President, Ronald Reagan said today that Americans did not think their products had fair access to Japan and that trade barriers must be lowered to avoid rising anger in the United States.
''As a friend, I tell you that Americans are not as patient as the Japanese,'' Mr. Reagan said in the text of a speech scheduled to be delivered at the end of his nine-day visit in Japan. He added that the principle of fairness had been ''a very strong strain'' among Americans since the Boston Tea Party.
''We don't want a Japanese tea party,'' he said. ''Yet fairness is a real issue when it comes to trade between the U.S. and Japan.'' [In Washington on Friday, Carla A. Hills, the United States trade representative, called on Japan to take a series of sweeping domestic actions to avoid new American trade sanctions. Page 32.] 
 
Warns of Possible Boycott
 In another criticism of Japan's policies reserved for his last day in Japan, Mr. Reagan warned that Japan faced a possible boycott of its products unless it corrected certain environmentally dangerous policies.
''No country is without blame when it comes to the environment,'' Mr. Reagan said. But he cited, as the focus of worldwide protests, Japanese logging in tropical rain forests and drift-net fishing, in which nets dozens of miles long are said to be depleting large areas of the ocean of marine life.
Until today, Mr. Reagan's comments have generally avoided criticism of his hosts. His speech today was likely to be taken highly seriously in Japan, where Mr. Reagan remains enormously popular. His visit here has brought an outpouring of affectionate tributes and a special award from the Japanese Government that had been given to only one other American President, Dwight D. Eisenhower.
Aides traveling with Mr. Reagan have said repeatedly that he has been speaking for himself and not for the Bush Administration, although they suggested that he had been in touch with relevant officials on the substance of his remarks. There were no comments from American officials here.
Mr. Reagan did endorse a previous statement by the Ambassador to Japan, Michael Armacost, that Japan's $50 billion annual trade surplus with the United States ''is simply not politically sustainable,'' particularly because the United States has recently improved its trade balance with other nations.
In a more familiar vein, Mr. Reagan told Japanese audiences that contrary to much of what is written in Japan, the United States was not a declining nation and was ready to face its future challenges. He appealed with some emotion for greater efforts to resolve common problems.
 
'Breathtaking Plan'
 ''We are the two greatest economic powers in the world,'' he said. ''Let us leap beyond no-win squabbling by undertaking a breathtaking plan. Let us make our goal a free-trade zone between the U.S. and Japan.''
The former President's visit has been sponsored by the Japanese Government and the Fujisankei Communications Group, which has spent between $6 million and $8 million, including a $2 million honorarium for Mr. Reagan. In return, both Mr. and Mrs. Reagan have given exclusive interviews in the company's outlets.
Mr. Reagan has also raised money for his Presidential library at a ''friendship concert'' in an arena in Yokohama and in meetings among Japanese industrialists, some of whom are on the board of his library fund-raising committee.
The Reagan speech today was scheduled to be delivered before a luncheon group at Osaka, after which Mr. and Mrs. Reagan were planning to return to their home in Los Angeles.
Because the Reagan visit has come at a time of unusual strain in Japanese-American relations, the former President's comments have received unusual attention in both countries, particularly among political and business leaders who fear that the two countries may be on a collision course on trade and other issues.
Japanese politicians, diplomats and business executives were hoping that Mr. Reagan, as a respected figure at home, would help to quiet what they fear may be growing anti-Japanese feeling in the United States.
People here are especially concerned, for instance, about the negative news coverage of Japanese business and real estate acquisitions in the United States, including the proposed takeover by the Sony Corporation of Columbia Pictures, owned by the Coca-Cola Company. Surveys showing that Americans think Japan poses a greater threat to the United States than does the Soviet Union have been widely discussed in Japan.
In the beginning of his visit, Mr. Reagan spoke generally about Japanese-American friendship in a way that cheered his hosts. Today Mr. Reagan continued many of his upbeat themes but also showed that he had at least been listening to reports of American concerns.

GRAPHIC: Ronald Reagan was a guest at an awards ceremony sponsored by Fujisankei in Tokyo. (Agence France-Presse)

HEADLINE: Hills Urges Japanese To Act to Lift Imports

BYLINE: By CLYDE H. FARNSWORTH, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 27

 BODY:
Carla A. Hills, the United States trade representative, called on Japan today to take a series of sweeping domestic actions, including the slapping down of companies that fix prices and the restructuring of retail distribution, to avoid new trade sanctions from Washington.
She reasserted the view of the Bush Administration that Japan should become an import superpower instead of an export superpower to prevent a contraction in trade and a weakening of the global economy.
Mrs. Hills avoided talking about specific new sanctions, but did say that if the Japanese ''pull the string so tight that they force us to retaliate and restrict our market access to them, they will cause a contraction because they are so large and we are so large, and they will literally be the cause of the peril that results.''
 
First Details in Public
 It was the first time she has gone into detail publicly about the changes the Administration is looking for inside Japan to increase its propensity to import. 
Among other things, she said Japan should devote greater energy to stop collusion in its beef, construction and soda ash markets; should repeal legislation permitting small shops to block the opening of large department stores, and should buy more computer chips.
Her remarks were largely seen by business executives and certain lawmakers as seeking to dispel business concerns that she might be softening her trade stance against Japan. The concern arose after a trip she made to Japan earlier this month.
 
Reports of Retreat
 News accounts from Tokyo at the time suggested that she was backing away from the approach tied to results that has marked trade policy to date, apparently to enlist stronger Japanese support for the Uruguay Round of negotiations that seek a broad opening of world trade.
Corporate officials and some lawmakers fretted that the more moderate tone in Tokyo would diminish pressures to cut trade barriers, while little progress was being made in cutting the $50 billion American trade deficit with Japan. Heightening this concern were predictions that the deficit would grow again next year.
One manifestation of the unease was a letter to Mrs. Hills last week from Senator J. James Exon, Democrat of Nebraska, spurred by a published report that she had ''distanced'' herself from a 1986 agreement on computer chips. The Senator reminded her that while she did not negotiate the accord, it was her ''obligation to uphold the U.S. position on this important matter.''
 
'I Want the Market Open'
 Mrs. Hills seized the occasion today, at a breakfast meeting of the United States Chamber of Commerce, to state her intention to ''enforce the semiconductor agreement to the hilt.''
''My discussions with the Japanese were very clear,'' she said. ''I want the market open.''
Her comments on the enforcement of price-fixing laws came as a report circulated on Capitol Hill that six of Japan's biggest banks were holding regular ''informal'' meetings, with Finance Ministry officials present, at which they talked about setting deposit rates and other banking matters.
The report in the Far Eastern Economic Review said the meetings had been kept secret to avoid possible antitrust action by Japan's Fair Trade Commission.
Senator Frank H. Murkowski, Republican of Alaska, a former banker himself, called attention to the article in Senate floor remarks today, noting that such ''anti-competitive practices are detrimental to the global trading and banking system.''
Mrs. Hills, a former antitrust lawyer, said pointedly today that the last time Japan set financial penalties for price-fixing was in the early 1970's, while in the United States the Justice Department last year alone brought more than 200 such cases.
 
Talks to Start Next Month
 A Japanese delegation is expected here on Nov. 6 for a second round of talks on the structural barriers to trade and business between the United States and Japan. Mrs. Hills said she wanted a blueprint for action by next July at the latest.
In their turn, the Japanese are insisting that the United States also make structural changes, such as cutting the budget deficit and increasing savings that would work to ease the trade deficit.
The semiconductor agreement committed Japan to stop ''dumping'' its chips, or selling them below cost, and to open its own chip markets so that by 1991 the United States would have a 21 percent market share, up from 8.6 percent in 1986.
Mrs. Hills said today, ''I think we sell ourselves short with targets like that,'' noting that outside Japan, the United States averages market shares of at least 50 percent.
While objecting to 21 percent as a ceiling, she said for the first time that it should be the ''floor,'' and added that by any linear progression the United States should already have 15 percent of the Japanese market, instead of the present 11 percent.
Alan W. Wolff, counsel to the Semiconductor Industry Association, said that Mrs. Hills was issuing a ''pretty vigorous statement that the Japanese must improve market access dramatically.''
A spokesman for Senator Exon, who was in Nebraska and not immediately available, said the Senator ''will be reassured'' by the Hills comments and added that her remarks were a ''positive sign that the U.S. will maintain a consistent policy.''
A Bush interagency panel is studying whether to stiffen the already existing $165 million of sanctions that President Ronald Reagan applied against Japan in 1987 for Tokyo's failure to abide by the chip accord.

HEADLINE: Personal Income Up 0.3% in Month

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 27

 BODY:
Americans' personal income, dealt a blow by Hurricane Hugo, rose a lackluster three-tenths of 1 percent in September as consumer spending posted its weakest advance in a year.
The Commerce Department said today that personal income in September rose $12.8 billion, to a seasonally adjusted annual rate to $4.47 trillion, the smallest increase in four months. Last month's personal income growth followed an identical advance of three-tenths of 1 percent in August and an increase of six-tenths of 1 percent in July. 
Spending increased two-tenths of 1 percent, the most anemic gain in 12 months, to an annual rate of $3.53 trillion. Spending posted robust gains of nine-tenths of 1 percent in August and eight-tenths of 1 percent in July.
''September marks the beginning of the end of the consumer revival,'' said Allen Sinai, an economist of the Boston Company. ''Because of sluggish income growth and caution in spending, consumers will hunker down, especially on big-ticket items.''
 
Manufacturing Jobs Down
 Other signs of weakness in the month include a decline of 103,000 manufacturing jobs and a slight drop in orders for big-ticket durable goods.
Economists, who this spring were expecting a recession to develop, were somewhat relieved by a rebound in spending this summer.
But Mr. Sinai predicted that consumer spending would shrink in the current quarter, a rare event. That will lead to sluggish economic growth, as measured by the gross national product, at an annual rate of less than 1 percent, he said. By the first half of next year, the nation will topple into a mild recession, he forecast.
The Government announced earlier this week that the nation's economy grew a moderate 2.5 percent in the third quarter, the same as in the previous three-month period.
 
Swing in Car Buying Cited
 Other economists, however, noted that the September report was not so bad as it first appeared because consumer spending was held back by a swing in automobile purchases and incomes were depressed by one-time losses from Hugo, which struck North Carolina and South Carolina on Sept. 21.
The report noted that without the effects of Hugo, incomes would have risen twice as much, six-tenths of 1 percent, in September. The impact amounted to $13 billion at an annual rate, most of that coming in a $9 billion drop in rental incomes, which were figured after deducting uninsured losses from storm damage.
The key component of the income category, wages and salaries, increased $14.4 billion, compared with a rise of $5.7 billion in August. The hurricane reduced wages and salaries by about $2 billion at an annual rate.
On the spending side, the $8.7 billion increase in personal consumption spending, which includes everything except interest payments on debt, compared with a $33 billion increase in August.
Purchases of durable goods, items expected to last three or more years, dropped $6.1 billion, while nondurable goods purchases rose $3.6 billion. Spending on services rose $11.3 billion.
A swing in new car purchases more than accounted for the September decline in durable goods and accounted for most of a $19.4 billion increase in August.
The September report showed that Americans' income after taxes rose only two-tenths of 1 percent, down from the gain of three-tenths of 1 percent in August.

HEADLINE: British Shift Puts Spotlight On an Obscure U.S. Journal

BYLINE: By LOUIS UCHITELLE

 BODY:
The resignation of Nigel Lawson as Britain's Chancellor of the Exchequer has lifted an obscure American economic journal into the limelight.
Mr. Lawson resigned on Thursday because he could not persuade Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher to disavow a passage in a magazine article that had been written by Sir Alan Walters, her economic adviser. In advance of the article's publication in the December issue of The American Economist, the offending passage appeared in The Financial Times in London. 
''How the passage got to The Financial Times, I don't know,'' said Michael Zenberg, a Pace University professor who edits the magazine from his home in Brooklyn. ''But I received dozens of calls last week from British newspaper people who wanted to fish for additional bombshells. There weren't any. To me the whole article was innocuous.''
Among the nation's journals, The American Economist, which appears twice a year, is not the one to which prominent economists turn to publish ground-breaking research papers. Its sponsors are Pace and the International Honor Society in Economics, an organization of graduate students in economics with A averages. The readers are mainly these graduate students and academics who first subscribed to the magazine, for $15 a year, when they were named to the honor society.
 
Noted Contributors
 But since 1983, Mr. Zenberg has been running a series entitled ''The Life Philosophy of Eminent Economists''; it is this series that has brought his journal into the spotlight. Among the contributors were Paul Samuelson and Herbert Simon, who are Nobel laureates in economic science, and Walt Rostow, a confidant of President Lyndon Johnson. Sir Alan is the latest contributor.
The Rostow article prompted Mr. Zenberg to invite Sir Alan to contribute. He thought Sir Alan's position with Mrs. Thatcher was similar to the Rostow-Johnson relationship.
''Since I had used Walt Rostow, I was looking for someone outside the United States to balance him in Britain,'' said Mr. Zenberg, who teaches economics at Pace's Graduate School of Business.
With the uproar in London, Mr. Zenberg has released photocopies of Sir Alan's 21-page typewritten manuscript, first submitted more than a year ago. The biographical account includes a passage, on page 19, that reiterates Sir Alan's long-held view that Britain should not join the European Monetary System and that currencies should float freely.
Although Mr. Lawson and Sir Alan have disagreed on these issues for months, the publication of the passage in London this fall instigated the confrontation that ended Thursday in the resignation of Sir Alan as well as Mr. Lawson.

CORRECTION-DATE: October 31, 1989, Tuesday, Late Edition - Final

 CORRECTION:
An article in Business Day on Saturday about the resignation of Nigel Lawson as Chancellor of the Exchequer in Britain misidentified the editor of the magazine American Economist. He is Michael Szenberg.

HEADLINE: Unusual Bond Trading Disturbs the Market

BYLINE: By ANISE C. WALLACE

 BODY:
Unusual and very large trading by a single party, thought to be Japanese, has captivated and disrupted the government bond market, contributing to price swings and setting off fears of a corner in one issue of government bonds.
The trader, who may or may not represent a single institution or a consortium, first got the attention of traders by posting huge orders to buy bonds on an electronic system that normally handles much smaller trades. Since then, apparent large trades have set the market on edge.
Yesterday rumors swept Wall Street that the trader sold as much as $2 billion of his bond holdings, but by the end of the day the prevailing speculation was that he or she had sold much less, perhaps $200 million in bond futures contracts. 
Earlier in the week, there had been speculation among dealers that the mysterious trader was trying to ''corner the market'' in a $9.7 billion issue of 30-year Treasury bonds. Rumors said the trader had accumulated $3 billion or even $5 billion of the issue, the 8 1/8 percent bonds due in August 2019.
In a corner, those who sold the bond issue short, that is sold it without owning it, would have to buy it back, possibly at higher prices. Some of Wall Street's largest bond firms did short the bond issue, traders say. Since they did that, it has risen in price, causing losses for them and profits for the mysterious buyer. The price of the issue rose from 98 1/2 percent of par value on Sept. 29 to as high as 103 on Wednesday. Yesterday, the closing bid was just over 102.
''He's cost people a lot of money,'' the head of government bond trading at one of the largest bond firms complained early this week. That trader is convinced the mysterious trader is a Japanese institution but will not say what evidence he has to indicate that.
Some dealers said that they had traced the large-scale buying of this particular bond issue to a Japanese broker, although tales varied as to just which one. They said the suspected the trades were being executed on behalf of a Japanese bond dealer, insurance company or consortium of investors.
On Wednesday, an official at Daiwa Securities in New York said that contrary to rumors, his firm was not involved.
On Thursday, an official at Nippon Kangyo Kakumaru International Inc., a Japanese brokerage firm, said his firm had bought ''substantial'' amounts of the long bonds. But Eishi Wakabayashi, an executive vice president of the firm in New York, would not say whether his firm was the mysterious buyer flashing orders on the Cantor Fitzgerald Bond Quotation Service carried on the Telerate system.
He would also not say whether the firm was executing the trades for itself or for a customer or customers. ''I don't really know,'' he said. ''It's all done by Tokyo.''
Given the way the Cantor Fitzgerald system works, many traders can see that the bids go up, but it is difficult to determine whether an entire order was filled, or if a reported trade was for a smaller amount. Usually, that system handles small orders, of the $5 million-or-so variety, with big orders handled discreetly by telephone, using brokers that specialize in bond trading.
Mr. Wakabayashi said he was ''disappointed'' that Wall Street traders and dealers were openly discussing these transactions, saying he feels such things should be kept private and out of the media. ''I'm really disturbed these days,'' he said.
On Wednesday, the unidentified trader used the service to announce that he was willing to buy $1 billion of long bonds. The previous Thursday, Oct. 19, when bond prices fell after the Government released inflation figures, a trader, presumed to be the same one, displayed an order for almost $2 billion of the Treasury bonds.
Yesterday's rumored selling was said to have been done discreetly through dealers, although no one seems to know for sure.
So far, no one on Wall Street has been able to determine the motivations of this trader, which is not surprising since no one is sure of the identity. There is speculation the trader is trying to make a political point about the importance of Japanese investors in financing the United States budget deficit.
But speculations abound. Tadeo Sakashima, vice president of Daiwa in New York, thinks the trader was merely seeking 1980's-style fame. ''The only reason is to be famous and enjoy controlling the market for a short time,'' he said.
If that is the case, his visibility and fame may backfire, some on Wall Street say, hopefully, adding that traders are better prepared to react to him. ''They may have his license number now,'' said Alan Medaugh, a portfolio manager at C. J. Lawrence/ Morgan Grenfell Inc., in New York.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Substantially Lower, Following Stocks and Bonds

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar weakened substantially against all major currencies except the British pound yesterday. Currency traders said the dollar was undermined by another poor session in the stock market and expectations of lower interest rates.
Sterling stayed stuck in the slump that it lapsed into when the British Government's top finance official abruptly quit on Thursday. 
The dollar ended near its lowest levels of the day. Currency dealers said selling motivated by internal market factors accentuated the dollar's weakness.
But some impetus to unload dollars came from the stock market, where the Dow Jones industrial average closed with a loss for the week of 92.42 points, at 2,596.72.
The dollar was also depressed by rumors that a large Japanese investor was dumping long-term Treasury bonds. If United States stocks and bonds fall out of favor, demand for dollars would decline.
The report that the nation's budget deficit totaled $152.1 billion in the fiscal year 1989, which ended Sept. 30, added to the negative sentiment. The deficit has shown little improvement for three straight years.
''The market's perception of a fragile stock market, a possibly faltering economy and announcement of the size of the budget deficit'' pushed the dollar down,'' said Bob Morrissey, senior trader at the Bank of Boston in New York.
A bearish attitude toward the dollar has been reinforced lately by numerous economic numbers showing sluggish growth. There is speculation that the Federal Reserve Board will soon decide to stimulate growth by nudging interest rates lower. Declining United States rates would reduce returns on dollar-denominated investments, tending to curb dollar demand.
In late New York trading the dollar was at 141.75 yen, down from 142.12 late Thursday. Sterling fetched $1.5795, up slightly from $1.5780 on Thursday, when it plunged after Britain's Chancellor of the Exchequer, Nigel Lawson, resigned in a policy dispute.
Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with Thursday's quotes, included: 1.8295 West German marks, down from 1.8410; 1.6005 Swiss francs, down from 1.6115; 6.2150 French francs, down from 6.2545; 1.17475 Canadian dollars, down from 1.17545, and 1,348.00 Italian lire, down from 1,351.00.

HEADLINE: Ortega Now Says End to Rebel Aid Can Save Truce

BYLINE: By LINDSEY GRUSON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: SAN JOSE, Costa Rica, Oct. 28

 BODY:
Modifying a position he stated on Friday, President Daniel Ortega Saavedra of Nicaragua said today that he would adhere to a cease-fire with the contras if the United States halted its assistance to the rebels as a fighting force.
After arriving here on Friday for a conference of Western Hemisphere leaders, Mr. Ortega said that because of renewed contra attacks, the Nicaraguan Army would not extend the 19-month-old cease-fire after Tuesday, and he vowed to renew offensive operations as of Wednesday.
But today, as the conference ended, Mr. Ortega declined to put a specific date on the resumption of military operations, and said his decision to end the cease-fire was ''reversible.''
''We are looking for a solution,'' he said. ''If the Congress of the United States stops financing the counterrevolutionaries, then we will unilaterally declare a truce.'' 
Mr. Ortega repeatedly said the American money should be used to finance the dismantling of the contras.
Before he left the conference today, President Bush said several other leaders had met with Mr. Ortega on Friday night and ''they leaned on him pretty hard.''
Mr. Bush peppered his remarks today with personal attacks on Mr. Ortega, repeatedly describing him as ''a little man'' and once calling him ''an animal at a garden party.''
''The man had a little bit of backing off, a little bit, so let's wait and see,'' Mr. Bush said. But he warned Mr. Ortega, ''Do not break the cease-fire.''
Mr. Ortega's tactics at the meeting, the first summit meeting for the Western Hemisphere in 22 years, appeared to be an effort to increase pressure on the Congress to disband the rebels, who insist that they are the guarantors of Managua's promises to hold free elections on Feb. 25.
Next month, Congress is to decide whether to continue supplying food, clothing, shelter and medical aid to the rebels, most of whom are encamped in bases in Honduras.
The decision to end the cease-fire dominated discussions at the two-day meeting, and was considered a major setback to the two-year Central American peace process.
''It has destroyed everything that has been accomplished so far,'' said President Alfredo Cristiani of El Salvador, whose country has been ravaged by a decade-old insurgency. ''It will complicate the situation a great deal.''
 
No Reaction on Ortega Offer
Neither Mr. Bush nor the other 15 heads of state gathered here reacted to Mr. Ortega's offer to trade the cease-fire for the disbanding of the rebels.
But a spokesman for the contras denounced the proposal. ''Ortega is trying to deal a mortal blow to the resistance,'' Bosco Matamoros, the spokesman, said in a telephone interview from Washington.
Central American leaders have repeatedly and forcefully called for the disbanding of the contras. In an agreement signed earlier this year in Tela, Honduras, five Central American presidents agreed that the rebel army should be decommissioned by Dec. 5.
Nicaraguan officials say the United States has prevented the dispersal of the contras and that they had to take dramatic action to force the issue. Otherwise, the officials said, the rebels would continue to receive American aid and remain in Honduras.
''It was a shock tactic,'' an official close to President Ortega said this morning. ''What we are looking for is a commitment to dismantle the contras by Dec. 5. If we had not done this, it would never have happened.''
 
U.S. Officials Seem Ecstatic
But Bush Administration officials, who at first appeared stunned by President Ortega's declaration on Friday that he would end the cease-fire, seemed almost ecstatic today. ''We're incredulous that he made such a blunder,'' said Marlin Fitzwater, the White House spokesman. Another senior official said the Ortega decision would make it easier to push continued aid to the rebels through Congress.
Under a bipartisan agreement with the Administration, Congress in April approved $49.75 million in food, shelter and other humanitarian aid to last through Feb. 25. But it won a concession that the President would suspend the help on Nov. 30 if any of the key Congressional committees with jurisdiction in the area objected to its continuation.
In a news conference that began as President Ortega finished outlining his latest offer, President Bush, unaware of Mr. Ortega's modified position, criticized the Nicaraguan leader in unusually biting and personal language, repeatedly calling him ''a little man.'' At least once, a remarkably vituperative Mr. Bush confused Mr. Ortega with the Panamanian leader, Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega. When a television reporter compared Mr. Ortega to a ''skunk at a picnic,'' Mr. Bush concurred, calling the Nicaraguan ''an unwanted animal at a garden party.''
 
'Not the Most Comfortable Fit'
''We didn't come here to have any contretemps with this little man,'' Mr. Bush said. He added that it was ''a little odd'' to have the Nicaraguan President at a meeting to celebrate the centennial of Latin America's oldest democracy, Costa Rica.
''It wasn't exactly the most comfortable fit,'' Mr. Bush said. He noted that Mr. Ortega was the only leader to come to the conference dressed in a military uniform.
But Mr. Ortega, who blamed the United States for Nicaragua's economic depression, said he would replace his orange bandana with a tie once his country's economy is allowed to recover.
The American delegation had insisted that the meeting be largely ceremonial and devoid of substantive group discussions. It also had vetoed plans for a joint communique for fear of appearing to be negotiating with Mr. Ortega.
Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d went out of his way to portray a brief meeting between the Nicaraguan and American Presidents as nothing more than a greeting. ''I don't think it was what you would refer to as a serious, substantive discussion,'' Mr. Baker said.

GRAPHIC: President Bush with Violeta Barrios de Chamorro, the opposition candidate for President of Nicaragua, in San Jose, Costa Rica, yesterday, where Mr. Bush attended a meeting of Western Hemisphere leaders. (Reuters) (pg. 16)

LENGTH: 1456 words

HEADLINE: New York Mayoral Race Focuses On Voters' Sense of Party Loyalty

BYLINE: By SAM ROBERTS

 BODY:
Whether to resist or respond to party loyalty is emerging as a dominant question in the final 10 days of New York City's mayoral campaign, with David N. Dinkins wrapping himself in the mantle of prominent Democrats and Rudolph W. Giuliani, his Republican-Liberal rival, by necessity appealing for Democratic and independent votes by invoking John F. Kennedy's maxim that sometimes party loyalty demands too much.
Yesterday, Mayor Edward I. Koch taped a television advertisement for Mr. Dinkins in which he reminded New Yorkers that his administration saved the day-care centers and centers for the elderly that would have been shuttered because of economies by Republican administrations in Washington. ''David was there with me,'' Mr. Koch said.
Mr. Koch and Representative Joseph P. Kennedy 2d, Democrat of Massachusetts, are to campaign with Mr. Dinkins today, and appearances with Senators Joseph I. Lieberman of Connecticut and Howard M. Metzenbaum of Ohio - Democrats who have been recruited to reassure Jewish voters -are planned for this week.
Mr. Giuliani, meanwhile, has been importing prominent Republicans -including Barbara Bush, the First Lady, who is due Friday - primarily for private fund-raising events. On the stump, he has largely been appealing to disaffected Democrats by emphasizing his political independence and his willingness to sever party leaders' ties to city government - most recently, to local school boards. 
 
Still Deadlocked on Debates
While both candidates revised their paid television campaigns for the final full week of the campaign, they remained deadlocked over debates.
Mr. Dinkins has demanded that two other Republicans also be invited to take part - Ronald S. Lauder, the Conservative Party candidate, and Henry Hewes, the Right to Life Party nominee - ostensibly to be inclusionary, but also to divide the Republican vote and to exploit Mr. Giuliani's potential vulnerability on the abortion issue, about which Mr. Giuliani has made a new commercial. Mr. Giuliani, in turn, has insisted that only the two acknowledged front-runners debate.
Mr. Dinkins, who emerged from last month's Democratic primary as the heavy favorite, has generally been viewed by political consultants, editorial commentators and his opponent as ducking debates. But after Mr. Dinkins spent much of this month on the defensive and saw his lead erode in every public opinion poll, some supporters suggested that he now had more to gain by debating - even with as polished a litigator as Mr. Giuliani.
Over the weekend, with no negotiations scheduled, each campaign appeared to be waiting for the other to blink.
Invoking party loyalty is one component in a strategy of reassuring potential Democratic defectors - from those who consider Mr. Dinkins too liberal, to those troubled by his tax problems 16 years ago and to white voters, Jews in particular, concerned not so much about his own record but about his ties to the Rev. Jesse Jackson and, more recently, to a minor campaign worker who later proclaimed himself to be ''anti-white.''
Jews, who comprised the bulk of Mr. Dinkins's white voters in the primary, are considered pivotal in the general election.
To further demonstrate continuity from one Democratic administration to another, Mr. Dinkins named Nathan Leventhal, Mr. Koch's former deputy mayor, to head his transition team and has offered the post of corporation counsel, the administration's top legal post, to Victor L. Kovner, who has served on a number of mayoral panels and was once Mr. Koch's law partner.
 
Belmont Boos Dinkins
As he did in the primary, Mr. Dinkins, the Manhattan Borough President, is courting Democrats of all stripes in an effort to demonstrate the breadth of his campaign, if not his appeal, in a city where enrolled Democrats outnumber Republicans by 5 to 1.
To dramatize that he wants to be ''mayor of all the people,'' Mr. Dinkins campaigned yesterday in the Belmont section of the Bronx, a predominantly Italian neighborhood that even Democratic leaders estimate will vote 70 percent for Mr. Giuliani.
As Mr. Dinkins walked down Arthur Avenue past fragrant cheese shops and Italian groceries, he was heckled loudly by Giuliani supporters who screamed ''Pay your taxes, Dave'' and ''Debate, debate.'' Dinkins supporters tried to drown out the hecklers with chants of ''Dave, Dave.''
Mr. Dinkins said his trip to Belmont ''is a bit more than symbolism.''
''I think it's important to go into every community,'' he said. ''Belmont does not belong all to someone else.''
 
The Times Endorses Dinkins
The New York Times endorsed Mr. Dinkins today. The editorial said a vote for Mr. Giuliani, who has never held elective office, represented ''a gamble,'' while Mr. Dinkins, ''warts and all,'' is a known quantity who understands city government.
''He is not the ideal candidate but he is a good man likely to make a decent mayor,'' the editorial said.
Mr. Dinkins said yesterday: ''I'm pleased The New York Times endorses my candidacy, and I'm confident it will help a lot. There's a fairly large pool of undecided voters, and I'm sure that many will be persuaded.''
Mr. Giuliani has been seeking Democratic deserters from the ranks of Koch voters in the primary - Jews, white Catholics and Hispanic New Yorkers. Yesterday, he campaigned in the central and South Bronx in a caravan led by a salsa band whose vocalists repeated the refrain, ''Giuliani para alcalde,'' meaning ''Giuliani for Mayor.''
Escorted by Detective Walter Alicea of the police Hispanic Society and the Rev. Ruben Diaz, a Bronx minister who supported Mr. Koch in the primary, he was warmly received.
He criticized Mr. Dinkins on two counts yesterday. He said Mr. Dinkins's suggestion that free tuition at the City University of New York eventually be restored would add $58 million to what Mr. Giuliani called the ''Dinkins deficit'' - the cost of programs he has proposed. Also, he said that by surrounding himself with prominent Democrats and by suggesting names of people who might serve in his administration, Mr. Dinkins was ''trying to get elected by endorsement and by naming other people.''
 
Giuliani Mentions Carey
Mr. Giuliani, even if so inclined, would be constrained from doing likewise since so many prominent Democrats, whose names Mr. Giuliani could cite to demonstrate the scope of his own potential cabinet, are united behind Mr. Dinkins. Mr. Giuliani said former Gov. Hugh L. Carey is one Democrat he has consulted on fiscal matters, but did not mean to imply that he was a supporter.
Mr. Giuliani also mentioned Richard D. Parsons, president of the Dime Savings Bank of New York and a former adviser to Gov. Nelson A. Rockefeller, as someone who would help ''what I'd like to accomplish, which is have high-ranking blacks'' in his administration.
Mr. Giuliani's most notable Democratic defector, John S. Dyson, chairman of the State Power Authority, loaned the campaign $100,000 last week to reserve television time. Mr. Giuliani nearly kept pace with Mr. Dinkins in contributions during the latest 20-day reporting period, though he continued to lag behind Mr. Dinkins overall.
Today, seeking to nudge Jewish voters from the undecided column to the Republican or Liberal lines, Mr. Giuliani is to meet with the Police Department's Shomrim Society, a Jewish group; visit with Teddy Kollek, the Mayor of Jerusalem, and campaign in the Canarsie section of Brooklyn and in in Belle Harbor, Queens, before an evening appearance at Young Israel in Flatbush.
Mr. Dinkins's schedule, too, is heavy with events aimed at Jewish voters.
 
'You Haven't Paid Taxes'
Yesterday, Mr. Dinkins received a signal, perhaps more powerful than any poll results, that Mr. Giuliani's negative advertisements may be having an effect.
After delivering an inspirational speech to Harlem youngsters bused to the ''I Have a Dream'' program at Marble Collegiate Church on lower Fifth Avenue, Mr. Dinkins asked for questions. The first hand raised was that of 13-year-old James D. Pickett, who said, ''I've heard on TV that you haven't paid your taxes.''
Mr. Dinkins explained the details of his failure to pay taxes for four years nearly two decades ago, saying ''the Government always knew that I wasn't hiding income.''
Young Mr. Pickett, an eighth-grader at Intermediate School 275 in Harlem, said he had heard about Mr. Dinkins's tax problems on the news and in Mr. Giuliani's commercials, as well as from his parents. ''They've been telling me they liked him and they voted for him,'' Mr. Pickett said, ''but they just wanted to know why'' he did not pay his taxes. He said Mr. Dinkins's response had satisfied him and he would vote for him if he could.

The New York Times

PUB-DATE: October 29, 1989

SECTION: Section 1; Part 1, Page 1, Column 1; National Desk

LENGTH: 3978 words

HEADLINE: THE FREEWAY DEAD: Portraits From Oakland - A special report.;
11 WHOSE LIVES ENDED AS QUAKE CRUSHED I-880

BYLINE: The following article was prepared by Robert Reinhold, Mireya Navarro and Jonathan Rabinovitz; Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: OAKLAND, Oct. 28

 BODY:
They were brought together by chance, by fate, by an act of God, some might say: 23 men, 15 women and a little boy. Strangers caught together in a terrifying moment as the earth's mantle shrugged, blithely shattering a fragile man-made structure, the Nimitz Freeway in Oakland.
Few in the Bay Area had thought much about the road. It was just part of the network of highways that knitted the region together, routinely feeding commuters onto the San Francisco-Oakland Bay Bridge. Suddenly on Oct. 17, a powerful earthquake turned the routine into the extraordinary. The cars that are as much a part of Californians' everyday lives as subways are to New Yorkers suddenly became deathtraps.
When the rubble and dust had settled, 39 victims were extracted, lives lost to the whims of nature. The coroner's list was like a census report on the polyglot Bay Area: victims were Asian, black, white, Hispanic. There was a Palestinian, a refugee from Vietnam, Midwesterners, Easterners. Most were not native to the Bay Area: they had come for economic opportunity, for personal or political freedom, for the climate, the beauty. Most gave only passing thought to the dangers of earthquakes, or at least, wrote that off as a price of living in the Bay Area. 
Here is how the lives of 10 people intersected and ended on the Nimitz Freeway:
 
Donna Marsden
Hospital Administrator, 36
 
Born in Torrance, Calif. . . . daughter of a Los Angeles police officer . . . married, divorced and remarried . . . an administrator in the pathology department at the University of California at San Francisco . . . lived in Alameda . . . died at the age of 36.
Like most people born and reared in California, Donna Marsden had adopted a casual attitude about earthquakes. She had taken the precaution of wrapping rubber bands around the knobs of the china cabinet in her three-story Victorian home in Alameda. That saved her china when the jolt hit on Oct. 17, but Mrs. Marsden died with four others in a university van.
She boarded the blue and gray Dodge van every weekday morning, and again at 4:40 P.M. in San Francisco for the return home. That day had been no different, except that her husband had taken her to lunch to celebrate her promotion at the University of California at San Francisco. Later, the van traveled the upper deck of the Nimitz Freeway at almost the same time it did every day. Had the quake struck seconds earlier or later, Mrs. Marsden would scarcely have been affected, apart from picking up some fallen items at home.
With her blue-green eyes and nearly floor-length hair wrapped in a large bun, Mrs. Marsden was striking, and she was known among friends for her sarcastic wit, keen sense of the absurd and, above all, a nurturing spirit. She kept hundreds of plants, two dogs and two cats. A favorite charity was the Starcross Monestery in Santa Rosa, which cares for children with AIDS.
For two years she worked in the anesthesiology department as coordinator for resident doctors until being promoted to the pathology department the day before the quake. Colleagues said she exuded energy and self-confidence, exhibiting a directness bordering on bluntness. Her husband, Bruce, who designs and installs software for the International Business Machines Corporation in Oakland, said one of her greatest joys was fixing the Victorian house the couple bought two years ago, and she spent hours painting and papering the walls and fixing furniture.
They knew earthquakes were a threat, but never thought much of it. ''We grew up out here,'' said Mr. Marsden. ''We tended to adopt a cavalier attitude. It's a fact of life out here. Every time there was a rumble, we'd make a joke when it quit.''
 
Delores Ardoin Stewart
Administrative Assistant, 48
 
Born in Lakes Charles, La. . . . raised by grandparents after being orphaned . . . moved to San Francisco in 1964 to be near her sister . . . married and divorced . . . lived in Alameda . . . an administrative records assistant in chancellor's office at the University of California at San Francisco . . . died at the age of 48.
Delores Ardoin Stewart, a product of Louisiana's Creole culture, loved the Bay Area, the climate, the more tolerant attitudes about race, the San Francisco 49'ers football team and the Oakland A's baseball team -''my men,'' as she called them. But after 25 years here, one thing still terrified her: earthquakes. During the last quake in August, she called her brother-in-law, Jerry Bernard, in nearby Union City, Calif., to vent her feelings.
On Oct. 17, she left the apartment she shared with her companion for the last five years, Michael D. Reardon, at 7:05 A.M. to meet the van that took her to the University of California at San Francisco. She had worked there for 20 years, most of that time keeping records and correspondence at the chancellor's office.
Just as punctually, she met the van for the return to the East Bay. When the quake hit, the van bounced off the upper deck of the freeway; in another few seconds she would have been out of danger.
''She was scared to death of earthquakes,'' said Mr. Reardon, a clerk at the California Department of Health Services in Berkeley. ''Her brother-in-law began to have a feeling something was wrong because after the last one, she talked to him for an hour and a half.''
She once attended a university meeting on earthquake preparedness, but would not go back after the first one. ''She really had difficulties with earthquakes,'' Mr. Reardon said. ''She would really rather get on with the business of living.''
Ms. Stewart, an energetic and statuesque black woman, came to the area in the 60's and lived in the Haight-Ashbury district. It was a heady experience for a Louisiana farm girl, but friends said she was proud to have lived through those times and remained imbued with its idealism. A liberal Democrat, she was strongly committed politically, but she also had a materialistic streak.
She lived in a beautifully decorated apartment and was a considerably skilled cook. She also had a taste for the slot machines in Reno and was an avid dart player.
 
James Thomas Hansen
Businessman, 64
 
Born in Berkeley . . . a B-29 mechanic in the Army in World War II . . . received a bachelor's degree in business administration at the University of California at Berkeley . . . father of four and grandfather of five . . . general manager of the State Shingle Company in Oakland . . . lived in Albany . . . died at the age of 64.
Probably none of the commuters knew the Nimitz Freeway better than James Hansen. He drove his 1985 Toyota Camry back and forth over the elevated road four times a day, twice to and twice from work, the extra round trip to have lunch with his wife of 36 years, Gloria. He was a punctual man, but on Oct. 17 he left work five minutes early to go home and watch the World Series. That cost him his life; his car was one of those caught on the lower level when the upper deck of the two-tiered highway collapsed.
''That day the freeway wasn't crowded,'' said Mrs. Hansen. ''He hits one stop sign and he goes on. About three short blocks or about 20 seconds more and he would have made it through.''
 
Melissa E. Maxwell
Deputy District Attorney, 32
 
Born in San Francisco . . . a fifth-generation Californian . . . 1978 graduate of University of California at San Diego . . . graduated from Hastings Law School in 1983 . . . an Alameda County deputy district attorney . . . lived in Burlingame . . . died at the age of 32.
The World Series saved the lives of hundreds of people on Oct. 17, but it was the death sentence for Melissa E. Maxwell. Many commuters had rushed home early or stayed at bars to watch the third game, and were not on the Nimitz Freeway when it collapsed at 5:04 P.M.
But Ms. Maxwell had arranged to be on the freeway at precisely 5 P.M. so that she could pick up her 7-year-old niece, Erin, at a day care center in Burlingame. Her sister and brother-in-law had tickets to the game, and Ms. Maxwell had agreed to watch the girl.
To remind herself to leave the prosecutor's office earlier than usual - she generally stayed until around 6 P.M. - she had posted a note on her wall to be on the freeway by 5.
All day Ms. Maxwell told her partner, Jim Kinnison, that they had to finish early so that she would not keep her niece waiting. ''She was really looking forward to it,'' Mr. Kinnison said. ''She loved her family. She was always talking about them.''
Ms. Maxwell was one of nine children, raised in an old wooden house that survived the great 1906 earthquake. She had a relaxed Californian attitude toward quakes.
''I don't believe that she worried about quakes,'' her sister, Melanie Fuller of Hawaii, said in an interview while in the Bay Area. ''She was not a fearful person. She was very religious.''
Friends and family members described Ms. Maxwell as an imposing figure, 5 feet 10 inches tall, with fiery red hair. Her presence commanded respect, both in court and in some of the roughest parts of Oakland.
Ms. Maxwell knew all her life that she wanted to be a lawyer, Mrs. Fuller said. ''When she was hired by the Alameda County District Attorney's office four years ago, it was a dream come true.''
Her family recently found a note she had written and stashed in her desk: ''I love to say that I am Melissa E. Maxwell for the People of the State of California.''
Minutes before she got on the freeway, an inspector in her office, Bob Cox, saw her drive by and honk. ''I was returning from a run,'' he said. ''She called out, 'Hey, Mr. Healthy,' and then zoomed off. If she had been parked, I would have talked with her and this wouldn't have happened.''
 
Petra Berumen
Housekeeper, 25
 
Born in Mexico . . . came to the Bay Area about nine years ago . . . mother of Julio, 6, and Cathy, 8 . . . cleaned homes . . . lived in Richmond . . . died at the age of 25.
Petra Berumen would do just about anything for her two children. The slight shy Mexican woman was learning English to help them with their homework. She also learned to drive recently so she could take them to school when it rained and to doctors' appointments.
And so it was on Tuesday afternoon. She was driving the children home from the orthodontist's office in Oakland in the family's red Ford, when the freeway collapsed.
Mrs. Berumen died, along with a passenger, her good friend Yolanda Orozco. The two Berumen children were saved, although Julio's right leg had to be amputated so he could be removed from the wreckage in one of the more dramatic episodes of the rescue efforts. Mrs. Orozco's body also impeded the workers.
Cathy suffered serious head injuries.
If Mrs. Berumen worried much about earthquakes, they were low on her list of priorities as a young immigrant trying to get started in a new land. She had married another Mexican, Pastor Berumen, a construction worker, and two months ago the two bought their first home.
''The Berumens were kind of the American dream,'' said Catherine Syverson, principal of the Downer Elementary School, which both children attend. ''They came to this country, got a good job, lived in a neighborhood with nice people. They had just bought a pretty little house, no small feat in California. They really had it made.'' Mrs. Berumen worked three days a week cleaning houses to supplement the family income, but apart from that her entire daily life revolved around her children. She was active at the school.
A friend, Graciela Almonte, said: ''She was a very good mother. She took them to school and wouldn't leave until they went into the classroom. And she always picked them up.''
And like other mothers, she was determined to have children with nice straight teeth. On Tuesday the the orthdontist's appointment turned out to be a date with death.
 
Raymonde Beauregard-Sund
Personnel Analyst, 42
 
Born in Granby, Quebec . . . reared in West Warwick, R.I. . . . lived in Alameda . . . a personnel analyst in the anesthesiology department at University of California at San Francisco . . . died at the age of 42.
Like others in the university van pool, Raymonde Beauregarde-Sund was a daily freeway commuter. And like most of them, she gave little thought to earthquakes. ''She never expressed any concerns about earthquakes,'' said her husband, Lieut. Cmdr. Jim Sund of the aircraft carrier Carl Vincent. ''We took it as part of living here.'' The two were married 21 years ago and moved to the Bay Area in 1978. She later attended San Francisco State University, where she received a bachelor's degree in psychology in 1980 and began working at the University of California medical center. She was liked there for her zany sense of humor and her generosity toward colleagues.
She had adapted easily to her new home state, taking up marathon running and gourmet cooking, and her concerns about industrial growth in Alameda led her to campaign for ballot measures intended to limit development.
 
Ramzi Farid Asfour
Banker, 50
 
Born in Haifa, Palestine . . . married for 20 years to Lily, a sales clerk at Emporium Capwell's . . . a son, Fareed, 18, and two daughters, Zeina, 16, and Leina, 12 . . . vice president of private investment services for the BankAmerica Corporation . . . lived in Novato . . . died at the age of 50.
Ramzi Farid Asfour had been telling family and friends that he wanted to quit his job as an investment counselor and do consulting work. After an accomplished career as a stockbroker and executive for the BankAmerica Corporation, he wanted to devote more time to his church and to his work on behalf of fellow Palestinians.
On Oct. 17, he was expected in Fremont to discuss investments with a potential client. He was an hour late because of heavy traffic, and he headed back toward San Francisco at 4:30 P.M. Barely half an hour later, his Cadillac Seville was crushed by the crumbling upper deck of the Nimitz Freeway.
His sister-in-law, Lucy Asfour, said he seldom traveled to the East Bay. ''It's incredible he was at that spot at that time,'' she said. ''It was really his destiny.''
Mr. Asfour first moved to the Bay Area in 1972 and had just returned in August 1988 after spending three years working for the bank in London.
''He had connections all over the world,'' said Mrs. Asfour, who is married to Mr. Asfour's brother, Sami. ''Anybody who knew Ramzi loved him.''
Mr. Asfour was also active in the Episcopalian Diocese of California and his local church, St. Francis of Assissi in Novato. This year, the Anglican Bishop of Jerusalem, Samir Kafity, a longtime friend, appointed Mr. Asfour as his representative in the Bay Area. Episcopal church officials here said Mr. Asfour raised funds for hospitals and schools in the occupied territories and spoke publicly on the Palestinian-Israeli conflict.
''It was done in the spirit of justice for the Palestinians,'' said the Rev. Mary Blair of St. Francis of Assisi.
''The few days before he died he was feeling especially upbeat, especially inspired,'' she said. '''He thought that he was doing exactly what he should be doing.''
Nobody remembered him as being concerned about earthquakes.
''He probably felt about earthquakes the way he felt about anything in life,'' said his friend and colleague, Jack Cooper, managing director of BankAmerica investment real estate. ''Ramzi would think that it was one of God's creations, the same as rain.''
Mr. Asfour's memorial service at St. Francis of Assisi in Novato was attended by 450 people, and his funeral Mass at Grace Cathedral in San Francisco drew 1,000.
He would have been 51 this past Monday, the day of the Mass. In her parting words at the service, his daughter, Zeina, said, ''Happy Birthday, Dad.''
 
Ray L. Holmes
Structural Engineer, 50
 
Born in Norfolk, Va. . . . married for 22 years to Tamara . . . daughters Tracy, 19; Holly, 18, and Christy, 9 . . . a structural engineer with Vickerman Zachary Miller in Oakland . . . lived in Mill Valley . . . died at the age of 50.
Ray L. Holmes's death amid the rubble of the Nimitz Freeway followed a career that often involved strengthening buildings so that they would withstand earthquakes.
One job a few years ago involved directing the seismic upgrading of two buildings of the International Business Machines Corporation in San Jose, a five-story 250,000-square-foot administration building and a two-story 200,000-square-foot development laboratory. I.B.M. officials said both buildings survived the earthquake unscathed.
''He was an expert in the seismic analysis and design of structures,'' said Ed Curran, vice president of the San Francisco company URS/John A. Blume & Associates, where Mr. Holmes had worked on the two buildings. Mr. Curran said he had lunch with Mr. Holmes a month ago and tried to woo him back.
Normally, Mr. Holmes worked until at least 5 P.M. But on Oct. 17 he left about 10 minutes early to watch his favorite team, the Giants, play in the World Series on television.
He was wearing the charm he thought would bring luck to his team, which had lost the first two games of the Series: boxer shorts emblazoned with the team logo. At the office, he had let colleagues take a peek by pulling the boxers up an inch above his belt.
A longtime friend and colleague, Leo Conoscente, described him as ''Mr. Sunshine.''
''He was an extremely gentle, kind and generous man,'' he said.
Mr. Conoscente said that Mr. Holmes took earthquakes ''very seriously'' in his work.
Personally, ''he was probably more blase about it, that there wasn't anything to worry about.''
But ''if he took that highway, he felt it was O.K. to drive on,'' Mr. Conoscente said.
 
Timothy Moss
Sales Manager, 40
 
Born in Ontario, Ore. . . . received a bachelor's degree from the University of Santa Clara in 1978 and master's in business administration and economics from Golden Gate University in 1985 . . . an administrative sales manager for Pacific Bell . . . died at the age of 40.
A few weeks ago Timothy Moss tried to find special screws to wire his bookshelves to a wall to keep them from falling in an earthquake.
Like many Californians, Mr. Moss understood that earthquakes are a part of life here. But he did not expect to die in one.
On Oct. 17, Mr. Moss's gray Acura Integra was one of the last cars to enter the freeway section that was crushed when the upper level collapsed.
''He never really had an attitude about earthquakes,'' said his brother, Tony, in a telephone interview from Payette, Idaho. ''He liked the city so much he didn't care about them. We would jokingly discuss them, like you do with people from California. But who could believe that he would be in such a wrong place at such a wrong time.''
Mr. Moss's family owns American Fine Foods Inc. in Payette, but he chose to live in San Francisco rather than take over the family's multimillion-dollar business.
A friend, Greg Mathews, said Mr. Moss loved the city's culture, its scenic views and its diversity. The two shared a two-story condominium with vaulted ceilings for two years, and they had prepared for a major earthquake by stocking supplies like bottled water, batteries and flashlights.
''Tim sort of felt that some of this stuff was in the way, but he went along with the program,'' Mr. Mathews said.
Mr. Moss had spent most of that Tuesday at a meeting he was not required to attend. When it adjourned, he hurried from the building, declined an invitation to go to a bar and rushed on to the Nimitz Freeway. He was not hurrying home to watch the World Series; he was trying to beat the traffic.
''Apparently he was the last car to drive into the section that collapsed,'' said Bruce Oliver, Mr. Moss's supervisor. ''If he had stopped to sneeze, he wouldn't have been there.''
 
Juan Daniel Luis Rubi
Installed Sunroofs, 28
 
Born in San Francisco . . . married for six years to Deanna, a machine operator at a baking company . . . 8-year-old twin sons, Juan and Daniel . . . an installer of car sunroofs . . . lived in San Francisco . . . died at the age of 28.
Juan Rubi checked in with his Daly City office at 4:45 P.M. He and a co-worker had just picked up a 1989 Chevrolet Camaro from a client in the East Bay city of San Leandro and were ready to head back to their place of work. Mr. Rubi was to drive the Camaro, which was to have a sunroof installed, and his colleague was to follow in another car.
''I'm on my way,'' Mr. Rubi said on the telephone.
Twenty minutes later, Mr. Rubi became one of the 39 victims buried in the rubble of the Nimitz Freeway. The co-worker, in an unwitting yet life-saving decision, stopped for gas and was spared.
In San Francisco, Mr. Rubi's family members rushed to reach one another in the chaos after the quake. Concern focused on Mr. Rubi's mother, Juana, who was feared trapped in a Bay Area Rapid Transit train somewhere under downtown San Francisco.
Mrs. Rubi showed up safely at her house at 8:15 that night. But her son never returned home.
''Nobody had worried about him,'' recalled his father, Daniel Rubi. ''He was a survivor.''
Mr. Rubi's body was recovered three days later. A collage of pictures his relatives put together for memorial services showed him as a family man with an especially broad smile when holding his twin sons. Mr. Rubi's funeral Mass on Tuesday at St. Peter's Church in San Francisco's Mission district featured a children's choir to which the twins belonged - but they did not sing.
His father said Mr. Rubi would pitch in when the twins, putting their allowances together and coming short, could not buy the latest video game.
''It was like they were little kids together,'' Daniel Rubi said. ''He always found time to play and stay with his kids.''
 
Vinh Phu
Automobile Mechanic, 32
 
 Born in Vietnam . . . married for 14 years to Mary, 32 . . . three children, Ivan, 13, Jimmy, 9, and Jenny, 6 . . . auto mechanic . . . died at the age of 32.
The family of Vin Phu, who was Chinese, fled the poverty of Vietnam in 1980 only to be confronted with tragedy in the Bay Area less than a decade later.
Two months ago, Mr. Phu moved his family from the cramped studio apartment they had shared in the Tenderloin district of San Francisco to a two-bedroom single-family house in Oakland.
With the three children still attending their old schools, Mr. Phu shuttled them back and forth across the bay as he commuted to the Show Place Garage in San Francisco, where he had worked for seven years.
On Oct. 17, his wife, Mary, came along for the ride. A friend in San Francisco had just given birth and Mrs. Phu wanted to spend the day with them, said a friend, Hana Ho.
School let out at 3 P.M. and the children met their mother at her friend's. At 4 P.M., Mr. Phu left work and picked up his family. Barely an hour later, the earthquake caught them on the upper deck of Interstate 880.
All survived but Mr. Phu. The three children, after being briefly hospitalized, are recovering from cuts and bruises at Mrs. Ho's home in Alameda. The daughter, Jenny, fractured her left arm. Mrs. Phu underwent hip and knee surgery Wednesday and is listed in fair condition at Kaiser Permanente Medical Center in Oakland.
Mrs. Phu has yet to be told about her husband's death, Mrs. Ho said, but the children know.
''They are strong and brave,'' she said. ''They're doing very well.'' But Mrs. Ho and other friends worry about the application by Mr. Phu's parents to immigrate to the United States from Vietnam. Mrs. Ho said the couple, after years of waiting, were about to move here under their son's sponsorship.
''They're just waiting for a ticket,'' she said. ''We're afraid immigration will close the case. I hope they let the grandparents come here to take care of the children.''

HEADLINE: Japan Moves Toward Modest Aid for Poland

BYLINE: By STEVEN R. WEISMAN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TOKYO, Oct. 28

 BODY:
Prodded by the United States and other Western democracies, Japan is moving cautiously toward approving a modest program of aid for Poland. It would be the first time that Tokyo has provided economic assistance to a nation in the Eastern bloc.
But despite its enormous financial resources and its status as the world's second-biggest aid donor, Japan is not expected to come up with anything more than a tiny fraction of the aid pledged for Poland by Western governments, officials here say. Prime Minister Toshiki Kaifu is eager to announce an aid program soon, possibly visiting Poland and Hungary next year, the officials said, although the sums would probably be in the range of tens of millions of dollars. 
Japan's slow, almost tentative pace in aiding Poland is widely seen as a reflection of its continuing uncertainty about how far to go in translating its economic might into political power.
''A Polish aid program is a noble idea,'' an official said. ''But for it to be implemented, it must first be fully understood by the Japanese people. That will require a little bit of time. This is all part of our growing awareness of Japan's role as a global power.''
Officials say a Polish aid package, even if small, would entail a partial redirection of Japan's aid objectives, which until now have been defined as nonpolitical, emphasizing aid to poor countries in Asia. A debate is said to be raging in the Government, pitting the Foreign Ministry against officials in the Finance Ministry, over the wisdom of aiding Poland, and over how much Japan can afford at a time of deficits and charges of waste and mismanagement in foreign aid.
Under Japanese regulations for foreign aid, Poland and Hungary would not qualify as poor countries because of their higher per capita income and related indicators. To aid Poland, Japan would have to redefine the purposes of its program, a step that would open up a bureacratic disagreements.
The concerns are testimony to Japan's fear, a legacy of Japanese aggression in the first half of this century, that it might be seen as throwing its economic weight around in a menacing way. Tokyo officials are especially nervous about being seen as enlisting aggressively in East-West battles. Pressure From the U.S. Only after considerable pressure from the United States, for example, did Japan agree to step up its aid to Turkey and Pakistan, which are regarded by Washington as ''frontline states'' in the battle against Communism. While siding with the West in principle, many Japanese had long been uncomfortable with becoming involved directly in the cold war.
Now that great changes appear to be under way in the Eastern bloc, Japanese officials say they are still concerned about stirring resentment in the Soviet Union, with which Japan has many specific agreements and a dispute over Soviet possession of four northern islands claimed by Japan.
''Aiding Poland is something we should do to show our position a a major player among the Western nations,'' said a Government official in favor of aiding Poland. He added, ''This view is not necessarily shared by everyone in the Government.''
One measure of the sensitivity of the issue came this week when former President Ronald Reagan, at roughly mid-point in his nine-day visit here, called on Japan to use its financial resources to ''help save Poland.''
''Let no one doubt, this is a golden age for Japan,'' the former President declared in a speech Wednesday. But he then posed what he said was a personal question: ''What will be Japan's legacy? What will be said about Japan when the history of man is written?''
Emphasizing that he was not speaking for the United States Government, Mr. Reagan answered that Japan should join with the United States ''in a golden partnership for democracy in Poland and around the world.''
The comments made some officials nervous, however, because of a concern that they might strengthen the hand of opponents of aiding Poland, many of whom say Japan is already doing too much simply to accommodate the wishes of the United States.

HEADLINE: Effort to Repair an Old Project Lifts Tenants' Spirits (and Paintbrushes)

BYLINE: By WILLIAM E. SCHMIDT, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: CHICAGO, Oct. 26

 BODY:
Parishioners from middle-class churches in the Chicago area have been spending their weekends since July fixing abandoned apartments in a rundown public housing project where even the police are reluctant to venture after dark.
The efforts by the parishioners, most of the white, have already lifted spirits in the Cabrini-Green complex, inspiring tenants to pick up paintbrushes and rollers to cover walls that have not been touched in decades. The repair effort, which started modestly with a dozen volunteers and limited ambitions, has become an officially sanctioned experiment in restoration of both buildings and pride.
The program has also brought inspiration to the Chicago Housing Authority, which is expanding the volunteer effort to a public housing development across town. #41 Apartments Reclaimed ''I have never seen anything like this,'' said Gertte Smith, the tenant housing manager at Cabrini-Green. ''Suddenly everybody wants to know when the volunteers are going to come and fix up their buildings, and can they get some paint to do it themselves? I can't find anyone who can remember the last time anyone asked for a can of paint at Cabrini-Green.'' 
The ''Cabrini Alive'' effort took shape last summer at a church group in the Gold Coast neighborhood a few blocks east of Cabrini-Green on the North Side. Parishioners were looking for a way to improve relations with their neighbors.
Now groups of 70 to 100 volunteers, joined by a handful of tenants, gather each Saturday in two buildings that are watched by guards. So far they have reclaimed 41 apartments that had been made uninhabitable by gangs, vandals, drug dealers and squatters. The total work force is now about 500 people, including suburban volunteers.
 
'People Already Feel Safer'
Dave Koenig, a financial consultant who is a congregant of Trinity Lutheran Church in suburban Evanston, said he had made several trips to the Cabrini complex since July. ''To me this is the very essence of community, of being a good neighbor,'' said Mr. Koenig, whose face and hair were spattered with paint. ''I feel good about what I'm doing and know the people here do too, because a lot of them have come up and thanked me and told me so.''
Gracie Armstrong, who lives in the building and is the president of the tenants' organization, rolled paint onto a concrete ceiling in a fifth-floor stairwell last Saturday. ''Where we have painted, you don't see them covering it again with graffiti like they do in other buildings,'' she said. ''I know people already feel safer inside the building. Now it seems they don't want to spoil what's been fixed up either.''
Cabrini's towers are bleak fortresses near the affluent neighborhoods just north of downtown Chicago. The towers are home to more than 10,000 people, many of them black and almost all on some form of welfare.
They live scattered among 31 high-rise and 55 row-house buildings, which among them have 3,514 apartments; more than 1,400 apartments are unoccupied. To cut vandalism and crime, housing officials at Cabrini-Green have arranged to move tenants into the lower floors and have sealed off the top floors. The complex is plagued by drug dealers and gangs. Gunfire is a familiar sound. In that atmosphere, the church volunteers' progress is easily overlooked.
But at least 35 of the restored and repainted apartments are occupied by new families. Housing officials say they hope to fill all 140 units in the two buildings being worked on by the volunteers by the end of the year, said Melvin Brooks, who is coordinating the effort.
 
Dealers and Squatters Ousted
Before work began on the buildings they were cleared by the police of drug dealers and squatters, and guards were stationed at the doors to make sure only residents and guests got in. The buildings were each nearly a third empty, in spite of high demand for apartments and prospective tenants who wait as long as a year to be placed.
Although many volunteers admitted feeling uneasy before arriving at Cabrini-Green, none there last Saturday expressed fear. Officials say there has not been one troublesome incident since the volunteers started working in the summer.
Although it began with a small group of churches, the housing authority has now incorporated the idea of volunteer labor in public housing projects into a larger strategy to improve the lives of tenants.
 
'People Do Care'
''It is part of our effort to convince the tenants of public housing that people do care, that the whole community cares about them,'' said Vincent Lane, chairman of the authority. ''We are going to do it as best we can, even if it means doing just one family at a time, one building at a time.''
Mr. Lane said the effort would not have been possible before last December, when the buildings were cleared of the squatters, gang members and drug dealers. In office 16 months, he has had 16 such buildings around the city cleared out and secured with guards.
Robert McKay, executive director of the Council of Large Public Housing Authorities, says Chicago is the first city to use volunteer labor on such a scale to help restore decaying public housing. ''What a great morale booster for the tenants,'' Mr. McKay said. ''It gives them a sense that they are not alone.''
Mr. Lane said he hoped to expand the program to other projects by the end of the year. He said he would seek to enlist other churches and civic organizations to supply not only labor but also baby sitting, day care and transportation for tenants.
As a result of the North Side example, more than 100 volunteers from a Baptist church in a southern suburb of Chicago where most of the members are black showed up at a South Side housing project, Altgeld Gardens, last Saturday and Sunday to begin repainting vacated apartments there.
 
Responses Came From All Over
The Cabrini-Green effort was organized by the Near North Side Ministerial Alliance, using a dozen church volunteers to clean and repaint only five units in one building, said the Rev. Ted Miller, an associate pastor at Fourth Presbyterian Church in Chicago. He said the volunteers have just kept growing.
Along with 15 city and suburban churches, labor was supplied by church networks from as far away as Texas and Oregon. This month a pastor at a Lutheran church in rural Flanagan, Ill., 90 miles southwest of Chicago, brought half a dozen young people in to work at Cabrini-Green.
Carl Bostrum, an official of Lutheran General Hospital, said the inspiration for the effort grew out of discussions about ways to improve contacts among the poor blacks and the affluent whites of the Near North Side. ''And then someone came from C.H.A. to talk about the sweeps'' - the police action - ''and we all hit on the idea of helping fix up some of the abandoned apartments,'' he said.
 
The Day Begins at 8:15
The volunteers show up at 8:15 A.M. on weekends, put on hard hats and fan out over the buildings. Some groups clean. Some install floor tiles. Some paint. It's an eight-hour shift.
On the second floor last Saturday, volunteers from Fourth Presbyterian Church painted walls and scoured grease off kitchen cabinets. Sharyl Hess, a manufacturer's representative, says she lives only five blocks from Cabrini-Green in an apartment on the Gold Coast.
''Yuppies get a bad rap, I know,'' said Ms. Hess, holding a dripping paintbrush.
''But I have helped tutor a young girl who lives here and I decided if there was some chance I could make her home better too, well, I ought to come on over here and do it.''
