HEADLINE: Conference on Black Theology Unites Scholars and Pastors

BYLINE: By PETER STEINFELS

 BODY:
Black theology, a distinctive understanding of Christianity based on the religious experience of African Americans, was forged in the days of the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr., Malcolm X and the Vietnam War, but its proponents believe it is no less relevant in the days of President Bush, televangelism, Spike Lee and the crack epidemic.
And at a conference last week in Manhattan, more than 300 church leaders and scholars agreed, urging that the message of black theology be carried beyond the classrooms to the pews.
The conference was also meant to celebrate the 20th anniversary of a landmark book on black theology, but the organizers were embarrassed when the author declined to participate because of a misunderstanding.
 
'A Missing Link'
Organized by four New York City seminaries, the conference was intended to provide ''a missing link'' between the academically based black theologians and black church leaders ''in the trenches,'' said the Rev. Preston Washington, pastor of Memorial Baptist Church in Harlem and the head of the meeting's steering committee. 
The organizers said that while black theology has been well developed intelectually, its message still needs to be made relevant to black congregations.
Black theology emerged in the 1960's as both a criticism of white Christianity and a search for a black Christian identity. While the proponents of black theology accept the traditional Christian belief in Jesus as the Redeemer, they believe that His message to His followers today is one of freedom from oppression. Like Latin American liberation theologians, black theologians believe that Christianity demands engaging in the struggle for political, economic and racial equality. Black theology also teaches that blacks, by pressing their claims for equality, can redeem white Christianity from its sins of racial prejudice and economic exploitation.
 
Scholarship and Preaching
From the opening worship service last Monday evening at Canaan Baptist Church in Harlem, through three days of lectures and workshops at Riverside Memorial Church on the Upper West Side, the gathering comfortably mixed scholarship with Gospel singing and exuberant preaching.
''This is a momentous conference,'' said J. Deotis Roberts, one of the pioneers of black theology who teaches at Eastern Baptist Seminary in Philadelphia. ''Black theologians and black pastors haven't been together meeting for many years.''
The emergence of black theology is often dated to 1969 when ''Black Theology and Black Power,'' a book by James H. Cone, crystalized black dissatisfaction with the European and American theological currents then dominant.
 
Explanations Demanded
Last week's meeting was also supposed to mark the anniversary of Mr. Cone's book. Mr. Cone, the Briggs Distinguished Professor of Theology at Union Theological Seminary, was not there. Instead, he was teaching his classes only a few hundred yards away.
Because of Mr. Cone's absence, several black theologians decided not to participate in the conference. Some of his students handed out leaflets at the opening service, demanding explanations from the organizers as to why he was not a central part of the conference.
Both the organizers and Mr. Cone said that the problem began with the planning committee's failure to consult him early in its work. Conflicts with his teaching schedule were said to have defeated later efforts to assure his participation, but it was clear that injured feelings were a major factor.
 
'We Blew This One'
The meeting was sponsored by Union Theological Seminary, New York Theological Seminary, Auburn Theological Seminary and General Theological Seminary.
''We blew this one,'' Mr. Washington said. ''All of us are feeling a deep sense of pain.'' He said that Mr. Cone ''was my professor, and his book opened my mind to the possibility of being both black and Christian when I was growing up in Harlem.
Mr. Cone's black theology reflected the Black Power movement of the late 1960s in its determination to shake off the dominance of liberal Christian theologies and in its impatience with the integrationist perspective of Dr. King. But black theology also rejected the condemnation of Christianity as ''the white man's religion'' by Malcolm X and black nationalists.
Peter Paris, who teaches social ethics at Princeton Theological Seminary, described how black theologians used the Bible, black sermons, spirituals and blues to develop its themes.
 
'A New Black Ecumenism'
More recently, Mr. Roberts said, black theology has begun to incorporate the perspectives of black women and biblical scholars. It has produced ''a new black ecumenism,'' he said, and made contact with third-world theologians, especially in Africa.
Indeed, female preachers and biblical scholars played prominent roles at the conference as did black Roman Catholics. Sister Jamie Phelps, a black nun who teaches at the Catholic Theological Union in Chicago, said that black Catholics ''find ourselves in the margins twice - white Catholics don't take us seriously and black Protestants don't either.'' She told the conference:
''I come to you as a black Catholic sister and theologian, your sister in blackness, your sister in struggle, your colleague in trying to think out what is the meaning of God in these times, times that are deadly.''
Although the mood of the conference was decidedly upbeat, neither black theology nor the black churches escaped criticism.
 
A Warning of a Chasm
Bishop Ithiel Clemmons, who heads one of the eastern New York districts of the 3.7 million-member Church of God in Christ, warned of a growing ''chasm between the black church pews and the black church pulpit.'' Black middle-class religious and political leadership often shares a ''vacillation about right and wrong'' that ''does not sit well'' with the working people in the pews, he said.
Reflecting the Pentecostalism of his denomination, Bishop Clemmons criticized black theology for ''playing down the role of the Holy Spirit in the world.''
Interviewed by telephone, Mr. Cone said: ''The black church has produced outstanding preachers ranking with any in the world, but the church hasn't produced theologians of equal quality. Without strong theology, preaching becomes entertainment, and there is a tendency to make church life center around the preacher.''
Mr. Cone, who acknowledged that ''some see me as going too far in my critique,'' has denounced black churches and denominations for being authoritarian and complacent and for excluding women from leadership. ''It's easy for the black church to be critical of the white church, but it also has to be critical of itself,'' he said.
Speakers at the conference did not match the sweeping denunciations of white America found in Mr. Cone's book 20 years ago, but referring to rates of poverty, drug abuse, violence and unemployment among blacks, they sharply questioned the values of the society.
''In some respects,'' Mr. Roberts said, ''we've gone backwards in this decade, and racism itself has become more insidious. If our people are to survive,'' he added, ''it will be largely due to how well the black church carries out its mission.''

HEADLINE: Milwaukeeans Seek to Stem Rising Violence

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: MILWAUKEE, Oct. 28

 BODY:
Earlier this month the city broke its record of 95 homicides in a year, set in 1987. This year, one of drive-by shootings, drug-running and nightly gunfire, is being called the year of 100 murders.
''We started on New Year's morning with two drug-related homicides and it hasn't stopped since,'' Police Capt. George W. Hegerty said. Last week the police logged the 100th homicide of the year. The number rose to 101 Sunday night when a 24-year-old man was shot to death in his car on a North Side street. 
''There's only been two weeks this year when we didn't have a homicide reported,'' Captain Hegerty said. ''I was hoping the numbers would drop off, but they keep going up.''
 
Citizens Taking a Hand
Milwaukeeans who had treasured their ethnic neighborhoods, clean streets and tradition of progressive government are mobilizing to turn back the violence.
Many neighborhoods are forming watch groups. Some individuals are taking it on themselves to call the police when they see drug dealing or other illegal activity, said Alderwoman Marlene E. Johnson, who represents an inner-city ward.
''There have been a lot of busts lately, and many of those have been due to citzen alerts,'' she said. ''The key is the people in the community saying, 'Hey, this is enough of this.' ''
In fact, except for a drop last year, the number of murders has been climbing since 1985 despite a decline in city population that started at least two decades ago. There were 73 murders in 1985, 85 in 1986, 95 in 1987 and 73 in 1988. The latest population estimate of about 600,000 in January 1988 was down by about 36,000 from the 1980 census total.
Drugs get much of the blame for the increase in killings. At least 12 of this year's homicides have been directly linked to drug activity, Captain Hegerty said.
Sometimes, the killer fires a gun from a car in a drive-by shooting, then speeds away. The police have linked three drive-by shootings last summer to Milwaukee gangs, including one that killed a 30-year-old man standing outside a tavern less than a block from his house.
 
'We Ought to Be Alarmed'
Karen Hendrickson sadly remembers different Halloweens. ''When we were kids, we went out when it was dark and our parents let us have the run of the neighborhood,'' she said. ''We would never let that happen today. We ought to be alarmed by that.'' The problem goes deeper than drugs, to poverty and racial discrimination, which keep minorities unemployed, Ms. Hendrickson and others say. ''Give people a better environment to live in and give them something constructive to do, then you'll see a turnaround,'' said the Rev. LeHavre Buck, director of Harambee, an organization seeking to improve city dwellers' lives.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

COUNTRY: UNITED STATES (95%); 

STATE: WISCONSIN, USA (95%);

HEADLINE: Appointments Worry Environmentalists

BYLINE: By ALLAN R. GOLD, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 27

 BODY:
President Bush won applause when he chose William K. Reilly, a career conservationist, as Administrator of the Environmental Protection Agency. But since then the President's choices for top environmental jobs have raised questions among some preservation groups and lawmakers about Mr. Bush's commitment to protecting the environment.
With a few exceptions, the appointments have been dominated by people sympathetic to development interests in the West and with few environmental credentials. In some cases, the appointees have been derided by conservationists as ''Watt clones,'' referring to James G. Watt, the Reagan Administration's Secretary of the Interior who sold off public lands and encouraged development of natural resources in wilderness areas. 
''At best, it's a mixed record,'' David Alberswerth, a National Wildlife Federation official, said of Mr. Bush's appointments. ''At worst, it's somewhat of a disappointment for someone who is presenting himself as an environmental President.''
 
'Nomination Sends a Signal'
The latest example, and the one that has drawn the greatest fire, is that of James E. Cason, an Interior Department official and former real estate developer who is under Senate consideration as Assistant Secretary of Agriculture for Natural Resources and the Environment. Conservationists say he is inclined to business interests at the expense of the environment and the taxpayer.
''The Cason nomination sends a signal that the Administration will not administer the environmental laws as they were intended to be administered,'' said Senator Patrick J. Leahy, the Vermont Democrat who is chairman of the Agriculture Committee, which is handling the Cason nomination.
A White House spokesman, Stephen T. Hart, defended Mr. Bush's appointments, calling the nominees ''people of quality.''
''What's happening here,'' he said, ''is you have a President with a good environmental record and some people out there aren't able to accept that.''
Conservationists have praised two nominations in addition to Mr. Reilly's: those of Michael R. Deland, the former New England regional director of the Environmental Protection Agency, to head the Council on Environmental Quality, and John Turner, a former Wyoming legislator and wildlife ecologist, to direct the United States Fish and Wildlife Service.
Some conservationists also say they have more access to Government officials than in the Reagan Administration. But they suspect that the development-oriented Reagan agenda has only been repackaged.
 
An Uncomfortable Mandate
That conclusion is drawn from nominations like Mr. Cason's, as well as major ones in the Interior Department, beginning with the Secretary, Manuel Lujan Jr., and including Cy Jamison, Director of the Bureau of Land Management, and James M. Ridenour, Director of the National Park Service.
The Interior Department has always had to balance conservation with development of natural resources and has frequently been accused of favoring business interests. Senator Tim Wirth, a Colorado Democrat active on environmental issues, said the Cason and Interior Department appointments reflect Mr. Bush's view that public lands exist to be exploited for natural resources rather than managed for a broader constituency.
''Public lands are bringing back to the state of Colorado and the West, through fishing, skiing, hunting, rafting and hunting, greater economic return than the narrow exploitative interests, particularly when they have to be subsidized by the taxpayer,'' Mr. Wirth said in an interview.
 
'No Chance' of Persuasion
Mr. Lujan, a New Mexico Republican, served in the House of Representatives and its Interior Committee 20 years, and has a history of representing ranchers and the timber industry.
But while environmental groups were dissatisfied with his nomination, they did not wage much of a fight because there was ''no chance of persuading a single senator to vote against him,'' said George T. Frampton, president of the Wilderness Society. The Senate usually gives Presidents wide latitude in nominations. Mr. Lujan was confirmed 100 to 0.
Mr. Frampton said that under Mr. Lujan the Reagan Administration's pro-development agenda has proceeded mostly unfettered.
But an Interior Department spokesman, Steve Goldstein, said the Secretary had tried to be conciliatory. ''Do environmentalists like every decision we make?'' he asked. ''No. But neither do the developers.''
Far more than their boss, Mr. Jamison and Mr. Ridenour are viewed by many conservationists as outright hostile to their concerns.
As director of the land bureau, Mr. Jamison is responsible for almost 300 million acres of public land, including some of the nation's most spectacular scenery.
He served briefly as a legislative liaison for Mr. Watt and for eight years was an aide to Representative Ron Marlenee on public-lands issues. Conservationists say Mr. Marlenee, Republican of Montana, is one of Congress's leading anti-environmentalists. His spokesman, Dan DuBray, said the Congressman believes that public lands should be considered for all possible uses, not just ''locked up'' for recreation.
 
No Record on Which to Focus
Since Mr. Jamison had never held a formal policymaking position, conservationists who opposed his nomination were unable to focus on his record in Senate confirmation hearings. Terry Sopher, who follows the bureau for the Wilderness Society, said that on the basis of Mr. Jamison's contributions to Mr. Marlenee's ''strong anti-wilderness policies'' there was no reason to doubt that Mr. Jamison shared his employer's views.
Mr. Jamison responded, ''You represent the people you work for.'' He said he is now representing the the Bush Administration's views, which are more sensitive to environmental concerns.
He also said he wants ''to keep our relationship with traditional users'' but give equal weight to conservationists whose interests had been neglected. For example, he said, he has proposed additional money for fish and wildlife and recreation programs.
The Senate confirmed Mr. Jamison's nomination on June 26 by a voice vote.
Mr. Ridenour, whose nomination as national parks director did not require Senate confirmation, served eight years as director of the Indiana Department of Natural Resources.
Some Indiana environmentalists called him ''the James Watt of Indiana,'' saying he cared little about preserving the state's remaining wilderness areas and favored aggressive development of public lands.
But Mr. Ridenour said his environmental record is strong, including setting aside more nature preserves and wilderness area than any previous director of the Indiana agency. He surprised conservation groups on Tuesday by rejecting a proposal by the United States Forest Service that would have allowed the hauling of logs along the narrow roads of Yellowstone National Park.
 
Sharply Divided Committee
But of all the appointments, Mr. Cason's, pending since March, has aroused the most concern. He would be responsible for the Forest Service and the Soil Conservation Service.
On Oct. 19 the Senate Agriculture Committee voted, 12 to 7, to confirm Mr. Cason, three Democrats joining nine Republicans, but Senator Leahy said he would continue the fight on the Senate floor.
Conservationists say Mr. Cason's record as Deputy Assistant Secretary for Land and Minerals Management in the Interior Department shows numerous examples of favoring business interests over conservation concerns while costing the taxpayers millions of dollars.
Opponents say he strongly supported Interior Department decisions to resume selling Federal shale oil land for below-market costs. Mr. Cason said he was carrying out existing law because Congress had failed to revise it, but Mr. Lujan later imposed a moratorium on the sales.
At a recent Agriculture Committee hearing, Mr. Cason pledged to do ''a good job of conservation'' and to weigh the views of all constituencies.

Cason is under Senate consideration as Assistant Secretary of Agriculture for Natural Resources and the Environment, and is said by conservationists to be unfit for the job.

HEADLINE: In Nuclear Cleanup, Costs Grow and Promise Fades

BYLINE: By MATTHEW L. WALD, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WEST VALLEY, N.Y.

 BODY:
Engineers arrived here in 1982 to begin cleaning up a factory that once processed nuclear waste. Their task was to employ a pioneering technology: remove hundreds of thousands of gallons of radioactive liquids and sludge from an aging storage tank and make the radioactive materials safe from spills or leaks by mixing them with cement or glass.
The job was expected to cost $400 million and take six to eight years to complete. But almost eight years into the cleanup, the work is at least six years from completion and the cost estimate is up to $890 million. Meanwhile, the amount of work needed to make West Valley safe seems to be growing.
The West Valley project will be repeated at cleanups elsewhere. The United States Department of Energy faces this problem - what to do with wastes that will be radioactive for millenniums but are stored in tanks designed to last only decades - at two plants that manufacture nuclear bombs: the Savannah River site, near Aiken, S.C., and the Hanford reservation, near Richland, Wash., where even larger volumes are stored. 
 
A Nuclear Edsel
Only the passing of years will reduce the radiation, but engineers say they can stabilize the material so it will stay put until time does its work. The job, which will cost billions of dollars, was described by one official here as producing a ''quality waste product.''
But as the liquids here are solidified, attention is turning to another environmental challenge: wastes that have been dumped in shallow trenches and holes, for which no cleanup strategy has been chosen.
West Valley is a nuclear Edsel. The plant processed used fuel from commercial and Government reactors, sorting it into components and recycling unused uranium and plutonium which was used in bombs and reactors. The plant became a business failure, and the simple recycling vision of the early 1960's produced a technological nightmare for the late 1980's.
Now Government officials and contractors are striving, amid disagreements with environmentalists, to avoid doing something in cleaning up West Valley that could be a nightmare for the next century.
 
'Peeling Away the Layers'
Not all the waste was in tanks. A current nightmare involves the trenches where solid waste has been buried. Not even certain of what is there, planners here speak of their surveys with metal detectors, surveillance wells and sniffing tools as an attempt to ''raise the confidence level'' about their knowledge of what is underground and what may be leaking out.
The official in charge here, Willis W. Bixby of the Westinghouse Electric Corporation, a contractor, described part of what has been accomplished here as ''peeling away the layers of the onion.''
The stark concrete building in which the used fuel was reprocessed has beds of impatiens and geraniums in front. All around it are workers who have reduced the building's contamination so that more of its space can be used in the solidification operation. They are working toward tearing the factory down and restoring the entire 3,000-acre site, a job that could double the current $890 million budget.
The plant was lured to western New York by Gov. Nelson A. Rockefeller to help bolster the area's economy, and built for $32 million. It operated for six years, until it closed for modifications in 1972. It never reopened, partly because the Government insisted on earthquake precautions and the owners decided that they would be too expensive.
Its legacy was 600,000 gallons of wastes that will be radioactive for hundreds of thousands of years, in a tank designed to last for 40.
 
Monitored for Moisture
Last year Westinghouse began pumping out the liquid and filtering out most of the radioactivity, then using the liquid in place of water to make the first of 15,000 cement blocks. Each is mixed with meticulous care in a square steel barrel and labeled with a striped bar code like those found on cereal boxes to record its singular pedigree.
It is gingerly stacked by a robot crane in a storage building that humans observe through video cameras, and which sensing instruments assure is warm so the cold does not interfere with the curing of the cement. It is monitored for moisture to prevent water from dissolving the mixture.
In two years, if there is enough money, the most radioactive sludge will be mixed with melted glass, in steel containers. It is not clear what will happen to the glass logs, which are meant to join the rest of the nation's spent nuclear fuel in a deep geologic repository that the Department of Energy and its predecessors dating back to the Atomic Energy Commission have been trying to establish for decades. The cement barrels may go to a different repository, or may stay.
In either case, Westinghouse officials emphasize that they are producing a ''quality waste product.'' This, in fact, may be an achievement: at other Department of Energy sites, improperly mixed cement blocks collapsed, allowing radioactive material to wash away in the rain.
 
Audits and Investigations
The handling of hazardous chemicals here was the subject of an audit, released last week, by a team of specialists from Washington, who decided that Westinghouse should pay as much attention to chemicals as it does to radiation, but found relatively few faults. A team of F.B.I. agents visited the site in July but it is not clear if any crimes were found.
Meanwhile, wastes produced in the cleanup job itself are piling up. Under an agreement with environmentalists, the wastes are being temporarily stored in barrels and boxes stacked in tent-like buildings of plastic-coated fabric. But as the project drags on, engineers are evaluating whether those buildings will last long enough.
While the price of the solidification project here has risen and budget cuts have stretched out the completion, important progress is being made; tough technical problems seem to be yielding to patience, skill and money. Simply changing the form of the waste is a major step forward, experts agree.
But it is only one step, as Carol Mongerson, a leading critic, pointed out. ''All they are doing is turning radioactive waste into radioactive waste,'' she said.
 
Tanks Filled With Clay
With the solidification of the most radioactive materials now in sight, attention is turning to the burial ground, which has already leaked. Recently, Westinghouse found kerosine, a chemical used in the reprocessing, escaping from one hole, and had to exhume eight tanks. The tanks were filled with crushed clay, resembling kitty litter, meant to hold the kerosine in place, and the tanks were sealed with duct tape; neither method proved effective.
More problems wait underground. Much of the material reprocessed at West Valley and eventually finding its way into the waste tank was highly radioactive fuel from a Government reactor in Hanford, Wash., but one fuel load was ruptured too badly to process.
Rather than send it back, operators buried it in concrete here, in a hole about 50 feet deep, in wet soil. Spent fuel is supposed to be disposed of in a deep geologic repository, and a multibillion-dollar search is under way to find a suitable spot.
A much larger disposal area is loosely filled with boxes and barrels of wastes in trenches that may be 60 percent empty. That allows the soil above to collapse, and water to enter, and water is the agent that carries radioactive material into the environment.
And while the largest portion of the dump is described as suitable for ''low-level'' waste, its 2.4 million cubic feet of wastes include a hodgepodge that would never be allowed in such a repository now.
 
Subject to Erosion
The site itself would probably not pass muster. West Valley is in an area of heavy rainfall that environmentalists say is prone to underground water flow. It is also subject to erosion. The burial trenches end at a ravine, which a brook is gradually expanding toward the wastes.
''You cannot walk away from the site for the long term - eventually you would lose the end of the trenches,'' said Theodore K. De Boer, the program director for radioactive-waste management of the New York State Energy Research and Development Authority.
The long term means several centuries.
The state agency is paying 10 percent of the cost of cleaning up the high-level waste, with the Federal Government paying the rest, but the state has sole custody of a large part of the burial ground. It is not clear what the solution is, since digging up the wastes would involve substantial exposure of workers to radiation, and as of now, there is no place to re-bury the wastes.
The cost would be horrendous. ''It boggles the mind to think what it would take to dig that up,'' Ms. Mongerson said.
In the interim, the state periodically pumps out the water that gradually fills the burial trenches, to prevent it from running out freely. Past practice was to dump that water into a lagoon and let the radioactive contaminants drain into the soil, so now that, too, is a candidate for cleanup.
To guard the burial ground, a chain-link fence surrounds it. For good measure, the fence is protected by a pair of horseshoes.

HEADLINE: Six Candidates Seek Ears, Not Votes

BYLINE: By DONATELLA LORCH

 BODY:
The Libertarian Party candidate for mayor of New York City runs his one-man campaign organization out of his midtown Manhattan stockbroker's office, where he writes his own literature - ''I'm anti-big government'' - photocopies it and mails it out.
The New Alliance Party candidate is campaigning, she says, for ''fair elections,'' and also for one of her opponents, David N. Dinkins.
And the best known of the six minor-party candidates for mayor is the least visible: Ronald S. Lauder, of the Conservative Party, is in Europe on business, and, his spokesman said, he will not be back till the end of the month.
''It is clear at this point that one of the two front-runners will be mayor of New York City,'' said the Lauder spokesman, Nelson Warfield. 
 
Other Reasons for Running
With the public's attention focused on Mr. Dinkins and Rudolph W. Giuliani in their last frantic weeks of campaigning, the six minor-party mayoral candidates have largely gone unnoticed, not least because none expects to win. Indeed, they are not in the race to win, anyway. Most are in it mainly to put across ideas that they say the major-party candidates are not expressing.
Henry R. Hewes, the Right to Life Party candidate, is perhaps second to Mr. Lauder in public recognition. He has probably been trying the hardest of the six to raise his profile, calling newspapers and speaking at dinners and church meetings. He is campaigning not only against abortion on demand but on the broader theme of a city suffering from moral decay.
Mr. Lauder, however, the cosmetics-company executive who ran an aggressive, high-spending but unsuccessful campaign for the Republican nomination, has all but dropped from public view since he stayed in the race under the Conservative flag.
Mr. Lauder, 45 years old, spent $13.7 million of his own money on his Republican primary campaign and still owes $400,000. But since Sept. 13, the day after the primary, his Conservative campaign has spent $420,000. He has also closed his offices in all five boroughs, has kept only one political consultant and has reduced his staff to 10 people from 25.
 
Weekly Letter on Conservatism
Mr. Lauder's spokesman, Mr. Warfield, said that until the election Mr. Lauder's campaigning would consist of issuing a weekly ''white letter'' to the press outlining his party's platform. The aim is to bring conservative ideas into the general campaign, Mr. Warfield said.
As stated in one ''white letter,'' Mr. Lauder would ''run New York City like a business,'' slash the bureaucracy, cut administrative costs, lower taxes and turn municipal services over to private hands. He supports women's rights to abortions but is against government financing of abortions.
''The people voting for us on Nov. 7 probably wouldn't bother to vote if the choice was just between the two front-runners,'' Mr. Warfield said.
Mr. Hewes is dedicating most of his time to trying to drum up press coverage. He said he had spent 50 percent of his time calling reporters and $1,000 of his own money on the campaign. The rest of his financing comes from the national Right to Life Party; party workers said they were unable to supply figures on how much.
Mr. Hewes, 40, runs his campaign from his office on Madison Avenue with a staff of six to eight volunteers. He says he is more conservative than Mr. Giuliani, is opposed to abortion and sex education in schools and wants the mayor's office to aggressively advocate the protection of fetuses. He also agrees that winning is not everything.
 
Message to Next Mayor
''If we were concerned who won or who lost,'' Mr. Hewes said, ''we could dissolve the Republican Party in the city.'' Describing abortion as a ''very hot'' issue, Mr Hewes believes his campaign will send a strong message to the next mayor, and he believes the next mayor will be Mr. Dinkins.
Mr. Dinkins, a Democrat, has lately been an unlikely source of exposure for Mr. Hewes. Mr. Dinkins has repeatedly asserted that he will not debate Mr. Giuliani unless Mr. Hewes, along with Mr. Lauder, are invited to join in. That would be an undesirable prospect for Mr. Giuliani, whose Conservative credentials and his recently adopted position favoring a woman's right to choose an abortion would almost certainly be questioned by the two men. Mr. Giuliani, a Republican, is also running on the Liberal Party line.
The four other minor-party candidates are independents and, like Mr. Hewes and Mr. Lauder, are not participating in public financing. Each party had to collect at least 7,500 signatures to be on the mayoral ballot.
 
Libertarian Runs Own Campaign
Warren L. Raum, the Libertarian candidate and stockbroker who handles all his own campaign tasks, describes himself as a conservative Republican on economic issues but a liberal Democrat on personal ones.
''I'm for personal freedom and anti-big government,'' said Mr. Raum, who is 31. The party advocates making government enterprises and schools private, cutting taxes, ending rent control, dismantling the welfare system and phasing out Social Security. Mr. Raum considers abortion a personal religious issue, is against school prayer and advocates the legalization of drugs.
Leonore B. Fulani, 39, a child developmental psychologist, is running on the New Alliance line. Members claim that the New Alliance, which was founded 10 years ago in New York, is the nation's fastest growing party. Dr. Fulani said the party's membership stood at 20,000 in 1987. Critics contend that the party's politics are hazy.
Dr. Fulani ran for mayor in 1985, receiving 7,597 votes, or 0.6 percent of the 1,170,904 votes cast. She also ran for President in 1988, gathering 0.24 percent of the national vote. The Libertarian Party candidate received 0.47 percent of the votes cast.
 
'Issues of the Black Agenda'
Dr. Fulani was angered by Mr. Dinkins's refusal to hold a joint signature-gathering drive during the Democratic primary campaign and accused him of blatantly wooing the Jewish vote. But she said that despite their differences, she was campaigning for Mr. Dinkins.
Dr. Fulani remains in the race because she believes it is important to ''speak the issues of the black agenda.'' In an interview, she argued strongly that housing, education and health care should be basic rights, but she offered no new programs. She said instead that the prime issue was ''fair elections.''
James E. Harris Jr., 41, a former auto worker, describes himself as a full-time candidate from the Socialist Workers Party. He campaigns, he said, in public meetings and through his party's paper, ''The Militant.''
Fred Mazelis is the Worker's League candidate. He could not be reached and did not answer a telegram.

HEADLINE: CAMPUS LIFE: Harvard;
Two Fraternities Set Up Operations Near a Campus

DATELINE: CAMBRIDGE, Mass.

 BODY:
The Dean of Students says Harvard University does not have a fraternity program. Two such groups, however, exist off campus.
This month 38 members were initiated into the Lambda colony of Sigma Alpha Mu. The president, Jon Brisman, a senior from Teaneck, N.J., majoring in history and science, thought about starting a fraternity over the summer and chose Sigma Alpha Mu because ''all my friends were in Sammy and they enjoyed it.'' The fraternity was preceded by a chapter of Zeta Psi, which was chartered in 1987. 
No national social fraternity has been on campus since the 1930's. But even then the university did not have the fraternity system of today. Many societies did not have national affiliations, and those that did were often classified in the club system. The club system has existed since the late 18th century. The organizations invited members in their sophomore years.
 
Nine Clubs Off Campus
Many so-called final clubs actually formed in the 19th century out of national fraternities like Alpha Delta Phi and Delta Epsilon. Nine final clubs remain off campus; the university severed ties with them in 1984.
Fraternities were classified as waiting clubs, a less-elite version, and were severely restricted in 1928, by limits on recruiting and advertising. In a few years, all the fraternities left, when Harvard was developing its house system. After their freshman years, most students live, eat and socialize in their house.
The social chairman of Sigma Alpha Mu, Richard Geyser, a history major from Tempe, Ariz., said, ''My social life is much better now,'' adding that the group had been meeting in restaurants and planned to rent space for larger events.
Most people socialize through their extracurricular activities, Mr. Brisman said, adding:
''The inference is that we're all going to be friends, and I don't see that as possible in a house with 400 other people. I think there is a severe need for social clubs on campus.''
 
Open Rushes Planned
For the final clubs, men have to receive invitations in order to have a chance to become a member. The fraternities have open rushes.
Members said Sigma Alpha Mu would conduct open rushes. ''We are looking for people we enjoy being with, and that cuts across any social, economic, religious or ethnic barriers,'' Mr. Geyser said.
Neither the fraternities nor final clubs allow women to be members. One final club, the Fly Club, is being sued in a sexual-discrimination case.
Mr. Geyser said that ''outside of Harvard, this wouldn't be an issue'' and that by becoming coeducational the chapter lose its charter. Fraternities and sororities have had their rights to remain single-sex upheld by the courts, Mr. Brisman said.
A charter member of Zeta Psi, Daniel Ramos, a junior from Valencia, Calif., majoring in government, recalled how his group started. ''Some people from the grand chapter in New York City came up here and recruited us,'' he said. ''Thirteen or 15 of us said, 'We'll give it a shot.' ''
Fraternity leaders did not indicate interest in replacing the house system. ''Most people don't want to live off campus,'' Mr. Geyser said. Mr. Brisman said he ''wouldn't want to see the house system fall apart.''
''I've never been to a meeting before where suddenly you meet 40 other guys,'' said a member of Sigma Alpha Mu, Gregory Pulier, a senior from Teaneck, N.J., who has majoring in physics. ''It happens to be a bunch of guys having fun.''

LENGTH: 370 words

HEADLINE: CAMPUS LIFE: Texas;
Gambling Den Off Campus Shut, Austin Police Say

DATELINE: AUSTIN, Tex.

 BODY:
When vice squad officers raided a suspected gambling den near the University of Texas, the ring was said to be handling $100,000 a weekend in sports bets.
The suspects are Adam David Don, 20 years old, a junior in business administration from Highland Park, Ill.; Dan Anthony Sachnowitz, 21, a junior economics major from Longview, and Christopher John Trapp, 23, of Memphis, who graduated in August with a major in finance.
Senior Sgt. Byron Cates of the vice squad said that on Monday, the night of the raid, the den took in $3,000 in bets in 30 minutes from students and others. The police said they found ledgers and betting slips, many with students' names, and detailed wagering transactions in the apartment north of the campus. The officers also seized telephones and four cars. 
The officers said the suspects faced 2- to 20-year prison terms and $10,000 fines, if they are convicted on their second-degree felony charges. Mr. Don was also charged with engaging in organized crime by promotion of gambling. The others were charged with engaging in organized crime by maintaining a gambling place.
''If something like this doesn't stop people from betting, I don't know what will,'' said Gregory Mann, a senior from El Paso majoring in finance and real estate. Mr. Mann is a member of the same fraternity, Sigma Alpha Mu, as Mr. Don and Mr. Sachnowitz.
''I never heard anything that would have made me think twice about them,'' he said. ''They are really sharp guys, and the types you expect to excel in the future.
''Anytime people find out someone is in your fraternity they think the whole fraternity is involved. We didn't know anyting about it.''
An assistant dean of students, Gage Paine, said the incident would not affect the students' standing. Because the incident was off campus, she said school officials would not investigate the case, adding, ''We don't look into off-campus incidents, unless it involves hazing.''
Some students said finding ways to place bets would not be difficult. ''If you talk to people, I'm sure you could find someone to take your bet,'' said Daniel Friedman, a junior in government from St. Louis. ''A chance to win money is something some people can't pass up.''

HEADLINE: THEATER;
For a Bit of a Gamble, Meet Them in St. Louis

BYLINE: By PATRICK PACHECO; Patrick Pacheco is a freelance writer who specializes in the arts.

 BODY:
In South Africa in 1959 one would hardly have expected to find the American musical thriving, much less splashing in the rain that Louis Burke and Joan Brickhill concocted for their revival of Gershwin's ''Lady Be Good'' that year. Yet musicals and dramas with such special effects as Borzois, chariots, 45-foot sequined cloaks, shipwrecks and flying Ariels became the trademarks of this married couple who eventually mounted more than 80 productions in their native country. Doing triple and even quadruple duty as directors, choreographers, designers and actors, they were known as ''the King and Queen of South African theater'' before Mr. Burke abdicated to immigrate to America in 1984.
That extravagant Brickhill-Burke style is currently on view at the Gershwin Theater in the new Broadway musical ''Meet Me in St. Louis,'' based on the 1944 Vincente Minnelli-Judy Garland film classic and the Sally Benson New Yorker short stories that inspired it. Accompanied by the popular songs of Hugh Martin and Ralph Blane, the domestic adventures of a St. Louis family at the turn of the century is the motor driving this $6 million production. It opens Thursday with a cast of 35, including George Hearn, Charlotte Moore, Betty Garrett and Milo O'Shea. 
True to form, Miss Brickhill and Mr. Burke have garlanded the seasonal vignettes with fountains, sumptuous costumes, fireworks, a five-ton ice-skating rink and, of course, a trolley that goes clang-clang-clang. According to the producers, almost $3 million has been spent on the physical production, designed by Keith Anderson. Mr. Burke is also credited as director and Miss Brickhill as choreographer in this production, which marks their American debut.
''The challenge was to take this enchanting family story and embellish it without overwhelming it,'' says Mr. Burke, sitting with his wife of 30 years in the study of their rented East Side apartment, the temporary headquarters of Brickhill-Burke Productions.
The Burkes say their talents have always been directed toward the realm of light musicals and comedies and classic English theater. Their own families had come out of that cultural tradition in South Africa; Mr. Burke's mother danced with Anna Pavlova's company and his great-aunt was a founding member of a repertory company.
The Burkes say their reasons for immigrating to the United States were less political than artistic and economic. They felt isolated in South Africa as the international boycotts grew. Also, their runs ''were getting shorter and shorter,'' says Miss Brickhill, as their audience shrank because of white flight. After 25 years of producing in South Africa, they decided it was time to move to Broadway. London might have been the more logical choice, but their experience, emphasizes Mr. Burke, is in American musicals.
Nonetheless, when Mr. Burke came to New York to pave the way for the move, he says he found ''doors slammed in my face, right, left and center'' because Broadway producers had not seen his work. It took two years of byzantine negotiations to secure the stage rights for ''Meet Me in St. Louis'' - complicated by the sale of the M-G-M film library to Turner Broadcasting and a legal tangle between Sally Benson's heirs and the Actors' Fund - and another three years to obtain financing. During that time, Mr. Burke taught acting and lived out of a cramped West Side apartment while his wife worked in South Africa.
Mr. Burke's angel for ''Meet Me in St. Louis'' finally came in the form of EPI Products, a family-owned health and beauty aids company that has put up a large share of financing. Members of the family, the Kroks, who immigrated to California from South Africa 10 years ago, had seen the Burkes' productions there. It is the first theatrical venture for EPI, a company with domestic sales of $250 million a year. But the three sisters who run the company thought that the show, with its emphasis on wholesome family values, would serve as a good promotional tie-in. They also felt, says a co-producer, Christopher Seabrooke, a businessman who is responsible for their involvement, that a musical that features ''Have Yourself a Merry Little Christmas'' would augur well for a commercial run at this time of year.
Mr. Seabrooke says there is only American money invested in the production. ''There is no South African investment for obvious political reasons,'' he says. ''It would've been impossible at any rate. The amount of rands [the South African currency] an individual is allowed to take out of the country is the equivalent of approximately $95,000 per year.''
While many insiders, Mr. Burke says, warned him away from ''Meet Me in St. Louis'' as a risky enterprise because it was ''old hat and slight,'' he was convinced it was the right choice for the Brickhill-Burke calling card. Although the producer-director says he has as many as 10 projects in the works - including ''A Midsummer Night's Dream'' with Mickey Rooney - the musical was simply the first one out of the gate. ''The show is about family, which has a universal and enduring appeal,'' he says, adding that he didn't think it was ''all that risky'' to start with a score that includes perennial favorites like ''The Boy Next Door'' and ''The Trolley Song.''
''It is an American classic because the film was so beautiful, done with great style and finesse. I wanted to keep those elements while reinventing the story to capture the excitement onstage,'' he says.
To that end, Hugh Blane and Ralph Martin have added 10 new songs to the score. Ironically, Mr. Burke says that he wanted to ''open up'' the musical even more, using a term usually reserved for stage musicals that become movies, not vice versa. As an example, the director notes that, in the film, the ''Trolley Song'' consisted largely of close-ups of Judy Garland. Here, the number is rendered as a misty dream sequence taking advantage of the Gershwin Theater's enormous stage.
In the reconstruction, the director says that he was immeasurably aided by Hugh Wheeler, the veteran musical book writer (''Sweeney Todd,'' ''A Little Night Music''), who died nine months into the project.
''Although we fought and argued about many things,'' Mr. Burke said, ''Hugh agreed that the star of this production had to be the entire Smith family.''
When the film was released, the critic James Agee said, ''The real love story is between a happy family and a way of living.'' It was this aspect of the current production that enticed George Hearn. The actor, who won a Tony Award for his drag queen, Albin, in ''La Cage aux Folles,'' plays a Victorian martinet in charge of an independent brood, which includes a doting wife (Charlotte Moore), a jig-happy Irish grandpa (Milo O'Shea), a crusty maid (Betty Garrett) and four daughters, including little Tootie (Courtney Peldon), who decapitates dolls and entombs them in a backyard cemetery, and naive Esther (Donna Kane), who primps for the boy next door.
''I suppose you could call this a fantasy,'' says Mr. Hearn in his dressing room. ''But as dreams go, it's not a bad one and one we could use a lot more of these days given the drug problem and the disintegration of the family.'' I absolutely think there is a place on Broadway for this type of show along with 'Les Miz' and 'Phantom.' ''
Brickhill-Burke's five-year struggle to gain a toehold in New York theater was made all the more difficult by what the couple refer to as ''an accident of birth.'' As white South Africans, their claim to be ''not political'' was somewhat incompatible with the international image of South African theater largely shaped through the politically charged works of Athol Fugard ('' 'Master Harold' . . . and the Boys'') and Barney Simon's Market Theater in Johannesburg, which first presented the musical ''Sarafina,'' based on the violent Soweto school boycotts in 1976.
Yet, one wonders, how did they manage to cope as apolitical artists in a country whose apartheid policies inevitably defines one as ''political'' at birth?
''You cope by doing what little you can to change the system,'' says Miss Brickhill. They did this, she adds, by pressing early on for government permission to play to integrated audiences in the Johannesburg theater they managed for more than five years. And in 1974 they created ''KwaZulu,'' which featured a cast of 35 black performers in ethnic dances. The show toured internationally to acclaim. They also taught classes for black actors, some of whom now sit on integrated arts councils in South Africa.
For the most part, however, Brickhill-Burke Productions is in the business of escaping reality, not addressing it. Mr. Burke says that the objective of using the theater as a place of magic transformation crystalized on his first visit to the traditional pantomime at the London Palladium in 1962. ''I sat transfixed,'' he says, ''as Gillian Lynne [the choreographer of ''Phantom of the Opera''] swashbuckled across the stage as Puss n' Boots and went through a series of metamorphoses. I've never doubted since then that you can do practically anything on stage that you put your mind to.''
But it was 10 years earlier, in 1952, says Miss Brickhill, that the couple's embrace of the American musical theater became inevitable.
''An international company of 'Oklahoma' was touring South Africa,'' she recalls. ''I saw it in Johannesburg, Louis saw it in Durban. We hadn't even met yet, but we both had the same reaction. The show had this vitality, fire and energy that we both related to. It was the milieu in which we wanted to operate.''

HEADLINE: THEATER;
One Struggle Over, Attention Turns to Guilt

BYLINE: By SAMUEL G. FREEDMAN; Samuel G. Freedman, a former Times reporter, is the author of ''Small Victories,'' a book about one year in an inner-city school, to be published this spring by Harper & Row.

 BODY:
One afternoon two years ago, when Richard Wesley was feeling especially frustrated in his effort to write a play about what W. E. B. Du Bois had called ''the talented tenth'' of black America, he drove from his suburban New Jersey home to visit cousins in Harlem. Heading across 145th Street, he noticed a car wash and decided to pull in. And as he did, a skinny young man with a bucket and squeegee in hand and a sheath of rags draped across his shoulder offered to do the job for a few dollars less.
Mr. Wesley accepted, and the man ran off to fill his bucket. In his absence, two or three other hustlers arrived to displace him. From the safety of his front seat, Mr. Wesley watched in shock as the first returned not only with clean water but a broom handle to attack his competitors.
He drove off quaking, remembering all the other times his car had been besieged by thin men with squeegees, measuring his own comfort against the desperation of fellow blacks battling over a 50-cent payday. That moment, that realization, became a monologue in his evolving play. But more importantly, it provided the sorrowful emotional fuel he required to bring the drama as a whole to fruition. The end result, ''The Talented Tenth,'' opens tonight at the Manhattan Theater Club's Stage I at City Center. 
For audiences whose image of black characters has been shaped by the ghetto-dwellers of August Wilson's ''Fences'' or Spike Lee's ''Do the Right Thing'' or, for that matter, by Mr. Wesley's 1978 breakthrough play ''The Mighty Gents,'' the men and women of ''The Talented Tenth'' may come as quite a revelation. Graduates of Howard University, they include a realtor, an advertising agent, a Fortune 500 middle manager and a Republican. They vacation in Negril, unwind at the health club, speak of ''networking'' and ''discretionary money.'' And, most clearly in the case of Mr. Wesley's fictional surrogate, a radio executive named Bernard, they feel enormously guilty at having betrayed their political origins, at having escaped rather than uplifted much of what they refer to as ''The Race.''
''That day on 145th Street galvanized everything,'' Mr. Wesley said in a recent interview. ''It made me wonder what happened to those guys that 50 cents and a dirty windshield became what stood between today and tomorrow. It made me wonder how I had gotten so lucky. And what were the responsibilities of that. It made me say you've got to address this - the disparity in the black community, the line of demarcation that is so apparent and so unbridgeable.
''Because that hasn't been the case historically. In the old segregated America, you had Duke Ellington and Louis Armstrong living on Sugar Hill, a block from folks who worked as cooks and maids. Now there's an economic segregation in black America. If you're a buppie, a black yuppie, you're not concerned about busing, you're not concerned about public accommodations - except as intellectual issues. You've made enough money to insulate yourself. ''Now it's possible to have a situation where you have a black surgeon who lives in Chappaqua and has kids in private school who play squash. For him, the inner city is a remote place where 'those people' live. He's no more concerned about them than an Irish-American who's living on the Philadelphia Main Line cares about some distant relatives stuck in South Boston.''
Still, it was far easier for Mr. Wesley to perceive his subject and themes than to penetrate them. Although he grew up in a stable, working-class family in Newark and graduated from Howard University, the very hatchery of the black elite, his earlier plays dealt almost exclusively with street life and militant politics.
Mr. Wesley, who is 43 years old, first drew acclaim in 1971 when the New York Shakespeare Festival mounted ''Black Terror,'' which unsentimentally dramatized a black revolution in ''the very near future.'' His 1975 drama, ''The Past Is the Past,'' depicted the encounter between a black father and the grown son he had abandoned long ago. (The play is being revived at the Billie Holiday Theater in the Bedford-Stuyvesant section of Brooklyn, with John Amos and Ralph Carter, beginning Nov. 9.) ''The Mighty Gents'' was an elegiac look at the former members of a street gang, who 10 years after their last rumble had no other source of pride or meaning in their lives.
Mr. Wesley's own career meanwhile had taken off with relatively little struggle. His playwriting mentor, Ed Bullins, had steered ''Black Terror'' to Joseph Papp, and from that point on Mr. Wesley's life as an in-demand author carried him further and further from his characters. ''The Mighty Gents,'' in that respect, signaled the end of an era. In its maiden production at the Manhattan Theater Club, in fact, the work had been entitled ''The Last Street Play.''
''I felt my generation of black writers had exhausted the possibilities of writing about the street,'' said Mr. Wesley. ''We'd written about drugs. We'd written about prostitution. We'd written about alienated youth. There had to be some new territory to be limned. And that meant for me a period of self-examination. ''I had to realize I was the grandson of two ministers, who provided a secure life for my parents. And they passed on to my brother and me their values and aspirations. There were things that were expected of us - a college education, definitely; a career, absolutely; upward mobility.
''In order to function on the street, you had to have a sense there are no possibilities for you. I always saw long-term payoffs. That's why I wasn't a gang member; that's why I wasn't a great athlete. I had alternatives.'' Mr. Wesley, to be sure, was radicalized by the civil rights and black nationalist movements at Howard, and most immediately by the 1967 riot that laid waste to Newark. Yet as his home city slid further into misery - entire blocks never rebuilt, housing projects declared uninhabitable and demolished - he was able to move to Montclair and send a daughter to private school. While he had made his name with critics with his unflinching stage dramas, he had made a good deal of his money on the comedic screenplays for ''Uptown Saturday Night'' and ''Let's Do It Again,'' popular vehicles for Sidney Poitier and Bill Cosby. And he was surrounded by blacks who had enjoyed a similar trajectory.
The question was how to turn their collective story into art. As he contemplated ''The Talented Tenth,'' Mr. Wesley's first inclination was to take the character of Essex Braxton from ''The Mighty Gents'' and insert him into a buppie dinner party. As ''The Mighty Gents'' had established, Braxton had achieved upper-middle-class income and accouterments by leaving his street gang for a career in loan sharking and prostitution. Perhaps, Mr. Wesley thought, Braxton would own a few legitimate businesses to launder money, and perhaps his middle-class friends would never know the true source of his bank account.
The playwright ultimately dropped the idea of including Braxton as being too artificial. But for the better part of six years, until his drive across 145th Street, he could not develop anything better.
''I could never get to the center of it,'' he said of the nascent play. ''I just had this vague idea of what I wanted to write about. I didn't have the insight to bring the characters sufficiently to life. I wasn't willing to go deeply enough into myself and my feelings. I was intellectualizing too much. It was difficult to write about black professionals because I'm always around them. I tend to take what we all say and do for granted. It was hard to realize this was profound material.''
With his emotions unlocked by his encounter with the car washers, Mr. Wesley soon had a play so packed with detail it ran nearly three hours. The Manhattan Theater Club, which gave premieres to three of Mr. Wesley's earlier plays, last spring produced ''The Talented Tenth'' as part of its Stage II series, which is generally not open to critics. The current Main Stage version is one of six shows at not-for-profit theaters nationwide to be underwritten by A.T.&T.'s ''New Plays for the 90's'' program. Bernard is portrayed by Richard Lawson, a veteran of four Wesley plays.
Between last spring and now, Mr. Wesley and the director, M. Neema Barnette, have pruned 50 minutes from the play. The stage action mixes Bernard's retrospective monologues with scenes showing his current relations with his wife, his mistress, his boss, and his closest friends and their wives. But one of the strongest presences in ''The Talented Tenth'' is never seen onstage. She is Bernard's college girlfriend, Habiba, a black nationalist and Pan-Africanist so committed that she fought and died in the Angolan revolution. It is she who embodies the political idealism he fears he has lost.
''The Talented Tenth,'' however, hardly rhapsodizes about black militancy. One of Bernard's longest speeches tells of a radical who berates and then beats a Howard student for leaving his pregnant girlfriend, promises to assume the fatherly responsibilities himself, and in turn abdicates them. Two other characters lambaste a black mayor for indifference and corruption. Considering Mr. Wesley's background in Newark, it is difficult not to assume that this politician bears some resemblance to Kenneth Gibson, who was elected the city's first black mayor in a virtual crusade in 1970 and voted out amid a sense of betrayal 16 years later.
''I believed the people I was following,'' Mr. Wesley said, with some rue. ''I canvassed in the housing projects for Ken Gibson when he ran. The problem with the elected officials is that with a few exceptions they became bureaucrats and caretakers. And with the more militant nationalists, you had the dogma, the cult of personality. So many proved to be charlatans and kooks. They disappointed not only us but the generations that followed. I'm not only talking about black leaders, either. I'm talking about Eldridge Cleaver and Jerry Rubin.'' He paused. ''Still, the problem was the messenger, not the message itself.''
For all the racial specificity in ''The Talented Tenth,'' the play's mood of bittersweet reflection on unrealized ideals seems bound to draw comparisons to Wendy Wasserstein's ''Heidi Chronicles'' and Michael Weller's ''Loose Ends.'' And Mr. Wesley does little to discourage the parallels.
''All of us baby boomers have experienced the same kind of changes,'' he said. ''It's a drag sometimes to think that some of the most exciting days, when every sunrise brought a new challenge, were when you were between 18 and 28. And one day you cut your hair, shave your beard, put away your sandals, go from yippie to yuppie, nationalist to buppie. Everyone tells you you've done the right thing. And you wonder if you really have.''

HEADLINE: FILM VIEW;
Seeing 'Intolerance' Is Hard Work

BYLINE: By Vincent Canby

 BODY:
''I don't think I ever want to see 'Potemkin' again.''
Arthur L. Mayer, the pioneer motion picture distributor, exhibitor, producer and, in his later years, a popular teacher of film, made this admission privately over lunch one day in 1981, shortly before he died.
Mayer was entitled, being then 94 and having sat through ''Potemkin'' more times than the rest of us have tuned in Johnny Carson. He wasn't expressing heresy. He was simply acknowledging that seeing some movies is not as easy as watching them. Seeing movies can be hard work. 
Mayer's rueful words came to mind earlier this month during the New York Film Festival's presentation of D. W. Griffith's 1916 epic, ''Intolerance.''
This was not just another retrospective of some seldom-shown classic. This was the first time that most of us could attend an ''Intolerance'' that approximated the ambitious, gaudy production conceived by Griffith 75 years ago Following its New York premiere at the Liberty Theater on Sept. 5, 1916, ''Intolerance'' was repeatedly cut and re-edited, at first by Griffith himself, in an effort to stimulate box-office activity. At one point, two of the four sequences comprised by the nearly four-hour film were excised and released as separate features. During the years that followed, footage was lost, and butchered prints moldered.
Earlier efforts to restore the film were hampered by the fact that there was no written screenplay. Griffith, who died in 1948, had carried his plans around in his head.
This latest restoration was done by Gillian B. Anderson, the music specialist of the Library of Congress, and Peter Williamson of the Museum of Modern Art. They have re-created as much of the original as now seems possible by using, as their scene-by-scene guide, Joseph Carl Briel's original musical score, composed for the live orchestras that accompanied the silent film's initial engagements.
The result is a triumph of scholarship, sleuthing and dedication. By using still photographs (filed with the Library of Congress at the time the film was copyrighted) as freeze frames, Miss Anderson and Mr. Williamson were able to fill in the estimated 11 minutes of lost footage to complete their restoration.
The festival presentation, with Miss Anderson conducting the Brooklyn Philharmonic Orchestra and a chorus of 16 voices, was something of a stunner. It was a roller-coaster ride back through film history to the time when the art was still in the process of finding its identity. It was also hard work. Griffith was a cinema genius and visionary, but his terms of expression were rooted in the 19th century in which he had been born (1880) and bred. To see ''Intolerance'' today one has to look through bombast, sentimentality and thematic chaos. That Griffith was always more of a showman than a thinker is never more apparent than in this masterwork, whose confused pieties make the racist sentiments of ''The Birth of a Nation'' (1914) look like pure reason.
In the four separate but intercut stories of ''Intolerance,'' Griffith attempts to illustrate the ravages wrought by intolerance throughout the ages.
''The Mother and the Law'' is a ''modern'' tale about industrial America and the terrible deeds done in the name of social uplift. ''The Nazarene'' deals with Jesus' betrayal and crucifixion. In ''The Medieval Story,'' a Huguenot lass named Brown Eyes, her betrothed and her family are caught in the St. Bartholomew's Day Massacre instigated by Catherine de Medicis in 1572. ''The Fall of Babylon,'' the film's true centerpiece, has much less to do with intolerance than with cinema as spectacle.
There's no difficulty in keeping track of these spliced-together stories, designed, says a note at the film's beginning, ''to express thoughts as they might flash through the mind.''
The difficulty is in staying interested, which, it seems, is a difficulty that today's audiences share with those of 1916. Much like an otherwise good storyteller who has had one too many drinks, Griffith keeps getting sidetracked by extraneous details.
In spite of its intended reverence, ''The Nazarene'' plays like a tab version of a Passion Play. It's the shortest of the film's four sections as well as its most ordinary. ''The Medieval Story'' is also perfunctory Griffith. Yet without these two sections, ''Intolerance'' would never acquire its genuine cumulative impact.
No other film has ever matched the dizzy exhilaration of the film's final 20 minutes, in which its four sequences are crosscut at a constantly increasing, ever more alarming tempo. As Christ hauls his cross to Calvary, Brown Eyes watches her family being slaughtered, the Dear One (in ''The Mother and the Law'') races to find the governor to stay her innocent husband's hanging, and Babylon teeters on the edge of doom.
In pursuit of suspense, Griffith raised crosscutting to a crazy art, and never more shamelessly than in ''Intolerance.'' The demands of the other three stories gave him an excuse to keep cutting away from Christ's passion (the end of which most people in the audience knew anyway), something that would have been unthinkably sacrilegious in a conventional Passion Play.
It is in ''The Mother and the Law'' and ''The Fall of Babylon,'' which later had brief lives as separate features, that Griffith's personality and concerns are most clearly manifest. He may have respected Jesus, but he was more dazzled by Babylon, whose excessive feasting, dancing and general all-round debauching gave the Barnum in him something he could sink his teeth into.
Three-quarters of a century later, the gigantic Babylonian sets continue to stupefy, as do the scenes of the Persian siege and the shots of horse-drawn chariots racing atop the battlements. Nothing Cecil B. DeMille ever did, including his parting of the Red Sea in his second ''Ten Commandments,'' ever came close to Griffith's achievements.
He was a master of spectacle and its significant detail, but it is in ''The Mother and the Law'' that Griffith's 19th-century guilelessness shines through. He was firmly against all injustice, if only as he perceived it.
In this story, the man who had romanticized the Ku Klux Klan in ''The Birth of a Nation'' tells a heartfelt tale of unemployed mill workers, venal employers, cruel strikebreakers and a bunch of heedless self-appointed guardians of the morality of the lower orders. That these guardians are all women seems not to be a coincidence. Reads one title card: ''When women cease to attract men, they often turn to reform as a second chance.''
''The Mother and the Law'' is incredibly naive and sexist by our standards, but it is also a moving and unexpectedly blunt report on the lot of labor in this country on the eve of America's entry into World War I. The means of expression may look old-fashioned. The report itself and the feelings expressed are as genuine today as they were when Griffith made the film.
The pristine print and the live orchestra accompaniment made the Lincoln Center presentation of ''Intolerance'' easy to watch. It was not, however, easy to see, certainly not in the context of today's movies. We have become lazy. We are used to a cinema composed largely of close-ups, cutting between faces that are of interest not so much for what the faces express but for what the mouths are saying. They are fast-food images that arrive in such a precooked way that all one has to do to receive them is to keep the ear open.
To see ''Intolerance,'' one must read between the lines of the title cards (''The loom of fate weaves death for The Boy's father''). One must accept a notion of a popular theater in which generalizations are openly acceptable as characters: The Dear One, The Dear One's Father, The Friendless One, The Mountain Girl, Rhapsode and The Girl Who Rocks the Cradle.
Today's films deal in cliches that pretend to be particular, such as the morally bent cop who has no home life and pursues serial killers, drug pushers and other disturbers of the peace simply because they are there. He is never called The Morally Bent Cop. He has a particular name, Joe or Mike or Tony.
Yet our cinema is no more or less sophisticated than Griffith's. It is different. We have sound and color, and we no longer appreciate the sort of epic in which moral positions are labeled. We are rutted in what's taken to be realism. Our cinema reflects a society that pays lip service to idiosyncrasy (as long as it isn't too different).
Recent films imported from China have much more in common with the cinema of Griffith than they have with ours, at least in part because these Chinese directors are less concerned with the individual than with the fate of society as reflected by the individual. They can't afford the luxury of worrying about alienation. And no matter how bold their films may look in China, they tend to look just a bit old-fashioned to us. Too epic.
Griffith was a master whom time overtook. Sergei Eisenstein, born in 1898, constructed his far more cerebral cinema-of-montage on techniques developed by Griffith in his mass-market melodramas. In turn, Abel Gance built upon both Griffith and Eisenstein to create, in ''Napoleon Vue par Abel Gance'' (1926), an epic that continues to speak to us today without the sort of apologies that must accompany the showing of ''Intolerance.''
I couldn't say that I don't want to see ''Intolerance'' ever again, but I don't think I want to see it again immediately.
