HEADLINE: The N.F.L.'s Painful Profit Crunch

BYLINE: By THOMAS C. HAYES

 BODY:
It is a curious enterprise: an intercity alliance of 28 monopolies, blessed by Congress and invariably ruled by fabulously rich capitalists, bound up in its own form of socialism. Yet the National Football League is as much a part of everyday American life as apple pie, Coca-Cola and Disney World.
This afternoon, in Cincinnati, Los Angeles, and 11 other locations including Giants Stadium, and again in Giants Stadium on Monday night, a total of nearly one million people will pay about $25 each to see a professional football games. Twelve of these games were sold out before the teams took the field, and league bosses are hoping for their biggest box-office weekend ever.
The 1989 season is shaping up to be the biggest fan-grabber in the N.F.L.'s 70-year history. Before the season's half-way mark arrived today, nearly six million people had already passed through the turnstiles. Television viewership of pro football games is on the upswing, too. And a bidding war for the broadcast rights to major league sporting events has team owners ready to play hard ball with networks and cable executives when contracts expire next year. 
With prospects like these, why did the task of choosing a commissioner deteriorate into a three-month stalemate among owners that was not solved until last Thursday morning?
In spite of the outward appearance of prosperity, many of the 28 N.F.L. franchises have run aground financially. And the owners have been divided for some time over how to reverse their fortunes. The dispute spilled over into the search for a replacement for Pete Rozelle, the longtime commissioner, who announced his retirement earlier this year.
League records show that half the teams lost money last year, said Art Modell, owner of the Cleveland Browns. And Victor Kiam, who resuscitated the Remington electric shaver business and owns the New England Patriots, claims that nearly all teams lost money.
The trouble is that the teams, which will take in a combined $900 million in revenues this year, have been unable to offset their rising costs. Television revenues, which typically contribute 60 percent of a team's sales, have been flat for the last three seasons, at $17 million per team. Stadium attendance has increased slightly, to 90 percent of available seats, as have ticket prices in most cities. But because ticket sales contribute only 35 percent of a team's total revenues, these gains have not been much help. Meanwhile, player salaries, which account for more than half of most teams' costs, jumped to an estimated $14 million this year, up from $10 million in 1986, according to the National Football League Players Association.
But the league may be entering a new era of profitability. By hiring Paul J. Tagliabue, a Washington lawyer, as commissioner instead of his opponent, Jim Finks, a former pro quarterback and now president of the New Orleans Saints, a majority of the owners signaled that the league may soon be managed more like a $1-billion-a-year entertainment business than a collection of money-losing tax shelters, as many outsiders have viewed it.
''Mr. Finks is a good football man, but he is not the businessman that football needs to go forward,'' said Michael Megna, vice president of the American Appraisal Associates in Milwaukee, and an expert in valuing sports franchises. ''We have a highly litigious society. And with unions, TV contracts, cable contracts, all of these things require more of a legal awareness and a business awareness. This is no longer a sport per se. It's an entertainment business.''
In directing major sports leagues in America, lawyers have had a promising record. David Stern, commissioner of the National Basketball Association since 1983, has won high marks for putting the once stumbling league on solid footing. Fay Vincent, elected commissioner of major league baseball after the death of A. Bartlett Giamatti in September, has had a short tenure but has won respect for his calm handling of the World Series in the face of the disastrous earthquake that hit the Bay Area. Mr. Tagliabue, who accepted a five-year contract at an estimated $1 million a year, completes the trio of lawyers who have become commissioners of America's three major sports leagues.
 
Negotiating a Pact
 But he may not find the going easy. In addition to bringing peace to N.F.L.'s divided house, he must negotiate a new television contract when the current three-year pact, which he helped fashion, expires in early February. He will also have to lead the league in various antitrust battles.
The division among owners stems in large part from differing investment philosophies. Relative newcomers like Mr. Kiam; Norman Braman, who owns the Philadelphia Eagles; Pat Bowlen of the Denver Broncos, and Jerrel W. Jones of the Dallas Cowboys each paid $65 million or more to join the exclusive N.F.L. club. These new owners are eager for the ego rewards that ownership brings, but are more willing to take risks to increase the value of their investment than are the established owners.
The new breed supports aggressive steps to raise revenues. They want four new teams added to the league roster in the United States within two or three years, which would bring in at least $200 million in franchise fees to be split among the owners. They embraced the formation of the World League of American Football, a minor league that will begin in Europe, Mexico and Canada in 1991. And they believe that the N.F.L. can and should explore fielding franchise teams in Canada, Mexico City and even Japan.
The longtime owners like the Giants' Wellington Mara, Art Modell of the Cleveland Browns and the Chicago Bears' Mike McCaskey are more conservative. Their teams, many of them purchased before the 1960's for well below $1 million, are now worth more than $90 million, based on the sale price for the Dallas Cowboys earlier this year.
Concerned that a high-risk course could burst their bubble, the old guard prefers curbing inflation in player expenses to raising revenues. They fear that lurching for more revenues would overexpose the game on television and thin the pool of talented players by spreading them over too many teams. That could cheapen the game, dampen fan interest and, at some point, send both ticket sales and television ratings into a tailspin.
Beside pacifying these warring factions, Mr. Tagliabue faces other challenges. The players union is pursuing several legal actions involving antitrust claims against the league. Victory by the players in one case could bring a new era in which players could bargain with any team as their contracts expire. In other cases, players would reclaim $25 million in disputed pay and benefits related to a 24-day walkout in 1987 and $25 million in withheld pension benefits. Finally, the league's drug-testing program is under attack in the courts.
Some owners say Mr. Tagliabue's toughest job will be to bargain with Gene Upshaw, the union's director, to obtain an agreement with the players to cap rising salaries, bonuses and other incentive payments. ''Player payroll typically represents about 50 percent of total operating expenses for an N.F.L. club,'' said Steven J. Matt, a specialist in the finances and valuations of sports franchises with Arthur Andersen in Dallas. ''You can't allow that expense to continue to grow out of control. Otherwise, it will become very difficult for teams to make money.''
 
Potential Hostilities
 But striking a deal is likely to increase hostilities. Officials at the players union say owners are not hurting as badly as they claim. Doug Allen, assistant executive director of the union, said that if so many teams are losing money, it is because of spendthrift practices in the front office, not excessive player contracts. He also doubted the owners' complaints of losses because the owners have not agreed to open their financial statements to outsiders.
But keeping things civil is essential. ''We must have a labor peace,'' said Lamar Hunt, longtime owner of the Kansas City Chiefs and president of the American Football Conference. ''And we've got to have success in our business operations. Otherwise, we will fail as a league.''
Many owners do not want to discuss publicly the idea of salary caps, fearing it might provoke the union. Asked if he and other owners would press Mr. Tagliabue to negotiate an overall team salary limit, Mr. Modell replied, ''I don't want to get into that. It's not my department.'' Still, he complains, ''Our player costs are going out of sight.''
Mr. Tagliabue must also break new ground in shaping television contracts to exploit expanding opportunities in cable and in pay-per-view technology. The current contract, fixed at $476 million since 1987, includes ABC, NBC, CBS and ESPN. ESPN, the sports cable network, will broadcast eight Sunday night games, starting in a week, for the third year.
The networks ought to be in a friendly mood to negotiate. CBS shocked the sports world last December when it agreed to pay 26 major league baseball teams $1.1 billion over four years, beginning next year, compared with an expiring, six-year deal worth $1.2 billion. Some analysts expect the N.F.L.'s strong ratings this year, plus competition among the broadcasters, to produce a contract that raises average television revenues for each team to $22 million a year, up from $17 million. Though Mr. Modell declined to state a figure, he said: ''I'm confident of a significant increase. The price of poker has gone up.''
 
Other Considerations
 But money isn't the only consideration in negotiating a contract. Many fans were angered by the deal with CBS because the network cut in half the number of games broadcast on Saturdays. Although ESPN could conceivably fill in the gap in coverage - it paid $400 million for the rights to air 175 games a year - more than 40 million homes are not wired for cable.
Pay-per-view has also dissappointed fans in the few cases where it was tried by the N.F.L. When viewers called their cable system to sign up for a game in San Diego, for instance, telephone lines quickly overloaded and most callers could not get through, said Mr. Megna of American Appraisal Associates.
Yet those systems will some day permit viewers to leapfrog the handful of games offered by networks and cable systems and select whatever game they want to watch for the price of a movie ticket. Many analysts believe it is the gold mine just over the horizon that will give the N.F.L. staggering amounts of additional revenues.
But the technology would seriously threaten the league's efforts to keep a economic balance among teams if all of the pay-per-view money could be kept only by teams watched most often. Mr. Megna said the best teams and those from the biggest cities, like New York and Los Angeles, would reap millions in additional income, while teams in smaller areas, such as Green Bay, Cincinnati or Seattle, would starve. Still, Mr. Modell says the league decided long ago to split revenues from the medium evenly among owners, as they now do those from television.
 
Inequities in Baseball
 Such inequities already exist in major-league baseball, where all teams have local television contracts in addition to league contracts with various networks. The New York Yankees recently signed the most lucrative local baseball television contract - a $500 million agreement through the year 2000 with the Madison Square Garden cable network. George Steinbrenner, the Yankees owner, is not obligated or expected to contribute any of the money to other teams.
Under the promotion-minded Mr. Rozelle, the outgoing commissioner, the N.F.L. won a reputation as the most cleverly-optimized sports league, by brilliantly marrying the live spectacle and television. In 1966, he introduced the Super Bowl, which now commands one of the highest advertising rates in television. Of the 10 programs with the largest viewing audiences in television history, the only two that were not Super Bowls were the two-hour finale of ''M.A.S.H.'' in 1983, and the last episode of ''Roots,'' in 1977. Few 30-second spots, priced at $700,000, remain for advertisers on next January's Super Bowl.
But the N.F.L. appeared complacent, resting on its past successes, as rival sports leagues dressed up their marketing and finances in novel ways during the 1980's, while cutting back on embarrassing drug-abuse incidents. The National Basketball Association made an astonishing turnaround. In 1983, with several of its 23 franchises near collapse, and the Cleveland Cavaliers and Indianapolis Pacers in the most dire straits, the N.B.A. guaranteed that its players as a group would receive a minimum of 53 percent of the league's gross revenues, excluding income from licensing deals and arena concessions. In turn, salaries for each team were capped.
The deal, accepted by the players, was an elixir for the N.B.A. Expenses became more predictable, encouraging wealthier owners to acquire teams. A tough drug enforcement policy also was accepted by the players. The league's sullied image improved, and so did attendance. Teams in Milwaukee, Detroit and Sacramento moved into larger, more profitable arenas. Others are planned. In the last two years, four new teams, in Charlotte, N.C., Miami, Orlando and Minneapolis, each paid $32.5 million - split evenly among existing franchise owners - to join the league.
In turn, the average player salary rose to $510,000 last season from $275,000 in the '83-'84 season. Mr. Stern, the commissioner, said the average salary should reach $1 million in 1993. Meanwhile, league revenues have risen more rapidly than players' salaries, reaching $351 million last year, up from $160 million in '83-'84. They should reach $600 million in four years.
N.B.A. franchise values have soared faster than those of any other major-league sport during the 1980's, according to Mr. Megna. The Denver Nuggets recently was sold for $54 million. ''The N.B.A. had a long way to go,'' Mr. Megna said. ''And it came from nowhere over the last five years.''
 
Fast Honeymoon?
 The N.F.L. that Mr. Tagliabue takes over certainly is far healthier and more deeply imbedded in the nation's leisure culture than the N.B.A. was in its dark days.
But the new commissioner has no illusions about what lies ahead. He told a crowded news conference Thursday afternoon hat his urgent goals were settling the new television contract and striking an agreement with the players union as well as expanding the N.F.L. by awarding new franchises.
It was an agenda unanimously endorsed by the owners divided camps, at least for now. Of course, Mr. Tagliabue's honeymoon could end as suddenly as a quick, look-in pass by Joe Montana. With the owners as potentially fractious as ever, turmoil is only a phone call away.

HEADLINE: WHAT'S NEW IN THE NONPROFIT SECTOR;
Offsetting a Loss of Federal Support

BYLINE: By Craig Bloom

 BODY:
The conservative agenda of the Reagan era has forced many nonprofit groups to become much more sophisticated in the way they do business.
As part of its initiative to scale back big government, the Reagan Administration shifted the responsibility for social welfare from the public to the private sector. ''I believe the spirit of volunteerism still lives in America,'' Mr. Reagan said in a 1981 address on his proposed spending cuts. ''We've let Government take away many things we once considered were really ours to do voluntarily out of the goodness of our hearts and a sense of community pride and neighborliness.'' 
Federal assistance to nonprofit groups, excluding financing through Medicare and Medicaid, has dropped by 20 percent since 1980. Over that period, nonprofit groups in areas from the arts to social services have lost $30 billion in direct Federal aid, adjusted for inflation, and more if Government program cuts that increase demand for nonprofit services are considered, estimated Lester M. Salamon, director of the Institute for Policy Studies at Johns Hopkins University.
While the President's Task Force on Private Sector Initiatives in 1982 asked individuals and corporations to double their charitable contributions to compensate for the cuts, those sources have not obliged. Changes in the tax laws have made it less attractive to give to charity, and changes in the business climate - like the wave of leveraged buyouts, which squeeze corporate spending - have also curtailed philanthropy.
As a result, these sources have offset only about a third of the Federal cuts. Individual contributions have risen by just a third since 1982, while corporate donations have jumped by less than a quarter, and have actually fallen slightly since 1985, according to the American Association of Fund-Raising Counsel. In lieu of giving more money, some companies stress employee volunteerism.
With fiercer competition for donations, nonprofit groups have begun to operate more like their for-profit counterparts. ''We find a lot of ferment on the management side, with much more attention to efficiency,'' Mr. Salamon said. And some have adopted marketing practices to improve their services and reach the likeliest pools of donors.
While most nonprofits are simply trying to prevent a backward slide, one sector continues to grow. With their ideology under attack, several liberal advocacy groups like the American Civil Liberties Union, Amnesty International and Planned Parenthood have seen sympathizers rally to their defense.

HEADLINE:  CONFRONTING THE SOVIET UNION'S ECONOMICE MORASS

BYLINE: By JOEL KURTZMAN

 BODY:
In a speech in New York on Oct. 16, Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d said that perestroika's success in the Soviet Union is in the long-term interest of the United States. Mr. Baker offered to send American technical and economic experts to the Soviet Union to help with the reforms.
Help may be needed. The Soviet Union is still groping for ways to make its economy grow and increase its production of consumer goods. An announcement made by Gosbank, the state bank, last Wednesday, declared that the ruble would be subjected to a large devaluation on Nov. 1. But the devaluation is to be limited to transactions primarily related to tourism and might not stimulate the economy as a whole.
What should the Soviet Union do? Three longtime observers of that country shared their views with The New York Times. Donald M. Kendall, chairman of the executive committee of Pepsico Inc.; Anthony M. Solomon, chairman of S. G. Warburg Inc. and co-chairman of a study group on the Soviet economy at the Institute for East-West Security Studies in New York, and Marshall I. Goldman, associate director of the Russian Research Center at Harvard University offered sharply different views. 
 
 
 
Question: Given the deteriorating standard of living in the Soviet Union, is there any action the United States should be taking?
 
Mr. Solomon: The one area where economists and other experts can probably make a modest contribution is in helping the Soviets modernize their information gathering and data gathering ability. I would hope that we would not be so naively arrogant that we would send over teams to advise the Soviets about how to make the transition to a market economy.
 
Mr. Goldman: I would fault the Bush Administration for the strange situation we now have. If we're not careful, someone will look back some day and say ''who lost Mr. Gorbachev?'' This is a unique time if we look at the big picture. Mr. Gorbachev's reforms both inside and outside the country are things we have been asking for since World War II.
We have to remember that there is a lot of opposition to what Mr. Gorbachev is doing from the military. They are not happy about the demilitarization program. They are unhappy about the way the Soviet Union got out of Afghanistan, which they viewed as a defeat. I have had discussions in the Central Committee headquarters where people told me they were worried about a military coup in the Soviet Union. They said they were worried about a coup from either the left or the right. There is unhappiness because for many people the system seems to be breaking down.
It seems to me that our Administration is derelict. President Bush has been very conservative. He's worried about making a mistake on the economic and political side. We will have a summit meeting in late spring or early summer 1990 - that's two years since the last one.
 
Mr. Kendall: I don't agree with Marshall on this at all. You know it's great for people who really don't know what's going on in the Administration to sit down and criticize it like Marshall is doing and the press is doing. This Administration, unlike previous administrations, is planning things without going public on them. A very good example is the Open Skies agreement, which allows reconnaissance flights over Soviet and American territory. Nobody knew about that agreement until all of a sudden it was announced. Mr. Baker is that kind of guy.
I recently met with Soviet Foreign Minister Eduard A. Shevardnadze. He said to me that he was very pleased with the progress they are making with us. There are a lot of things that are going on that the Administration is not talking about. You can say they are slow to get started. But I happen to think they were right in re-evaluating the problem and then deciding on the direction. The Soviets are not unhappy with their meetings with Mr. Baker and President Bush.
You hear people saying what Marshall is saying but he hasn't come up with any ideas about what he can do for the Soviet Union either.
 
Mr. Solomon: I agree. The fact that Mr. Baker has given speeches supporting perestroika means that the Administration is planning something. Mr. Goldman: But Mr. Baker didn't give the speeches until October. Mr. Gorbachev needs to have meetings head to head. So far there hasn't been any action. I disagree with Don.
The Soviets were quite happy when a Republican was elected as President because they thought he would pick up and continue from the Reagan Administration. Now the Russians can't understand what is happening and why it is taking so long.
It is hard to come up with concrete ideas. But when the two heads of state get together for a summit meeting, their staffs are forced to think of things and be creative. That's what summit meetings require.
 
Q. Even if the Bush Administration were to work faster, would it be able to do anything to really change the lives of the Soviet people?
 
Mr. Goldman: Well, I think so. I think the United States should be talking about a Marshall Plan - not a big one. We could call it a kind of mini-Mikhail Plan. We should provide some kind of concrete assistance. After all, we're talking about sending food to Poland.
 
Mr. Kendall: What kind of a Marshall Plan?
 
Mr. Goldman: For example, the big American-Soviet joint-venture consortium of businesses has announced that next year they are going to send over toothpaste to the Soviet Union. This is important because toothpaste is not available in the shops in the Soviet Union. So the consortium has signed a $500,000 deal to bring over toothpaste.
 
Mr. Kendall: They're getting soap from England. Is that something the Administration ought to do? Send over toothpaste? It's not even a difficult technological problem.
 
Mr. Goldman: Yes, but for the Soviet consumer, things like toothpaste have disappeared. The Administration should also offer credits for food.
 
Q. How large should those credits be?
 
Mr. Goldman: We should begin with food aid of several hundred million dollars a year. That's something we could do. We have surpluses, not in grain, but in pork bellies. That's what we're giving to the Poles. We could do the same for the Soviets.
 
Mr. Solomon: I don't agree with you, Marshall. On this point I line up with Don. Yes, I think there are supportive actions that we can take. But at this point, to come up with some pretty massive food or financial aid is premature, and it is also probably not appropriate.
 
Mr. Goldman: That's why I said a mini-Marshall plan. I think it does make sense. Mr. Gorbachev's well being may well depend on whether or not people see any improvement in their shops. He made mistakes on cutting back on the consumer goods early on and he's acknowledged this. If he doesn't get goods in the shops, people are not going to be happy. It's a short-run survival tactic.
 
Mr. Solomon: But you are talking about billions and billions of dollars if you are talking about bringing over a significant number of consumer goods. And then what happens if at some point we stop? It will take years before the Soviets will be able to produce the goods themselves.
 
Mr. Goldman: Yes, but Tony, if Mr. Gorbachev doesn't get some short- term support, he won't be there in three years to get industry going.
 
Mr. Solomon: But how do you come up with massive financial support when they don't even have a real economic program yet? We have to be supportive, but we don't start pouring in massive sums of money before they have a program. It just doesn't make sense.
 
Mr. Kendall: I find this idea a little bit ridiculous because the Soviets haven't asked for anything like a Marshall Plan. They've never suggested it and they haven't asked for export credits either.
Realistically, I think the only thing this Administration can do is continue the negotiations on conventional weapons to get the costs down. An agreement there will benefit the Soviets because they won't have to spend so much money on arms. It will help us on our budget deficit, too. Waiving the Jackson-Vanik amendment, which links trade to human rights, is important. I know the Congress is moving on that and the Administration is prepared to move on that. But you have to get a trade agreement to implement it. We have to work with the Soviets on problems in the third world as well. Then we have to have support for joint ventures and even encourage them.
 
Q. The ruble is not freely convertible with other currencies. What should the Soviet Union do about the ruble?
 
Mr. Solomon: When the Soviets have goods to sell in the international market, and they do have some goods to sell, they simply set the price that is necessary to sell those goods. It's competitive in Western terms.
But the reason why overall price reform is so important is that it should result in domestic pricing which is market influenced and that will make for a more rational allocation of resources. This in turn means that people will know what to invest in and what not to invest in.
 
Q. What about linking the ruble to gold, as some Western economists are suggesting?
 
Mr. Solomon: They need some measure of convertibility of the ruble, yes. But to assume that a country with as many economic problems as the Soviet Union has would be able to move not only to full convertibility but also to a fixed exchange rate linked to gold, assumes an incredible amount of progress. I don't think it's realistic.
 
Q. What is your prognosis for the Soviet Union and its economy?
 
Mr. Solomon: I am agnostic about the future of the Soviet Union. I don't know whether it will ultimately succeed or not. But their chances to succeed will depend on whether they can fashion an overall program. I can't imagine there is any way they can succeed with random steps - moving ahead in some areas and then stepping back when there's a political reaction. They have to have an overall program and then they have to handle the politics of that program. And then they've got a good chance of succeeding - hopefully.
 
Mr. Kendall: Well, it is very difficult for anyone to see into the crystal ball. Mr. Gorbachev has shown a great ability to handle problems - the strike problem with the miners, the way he has handled the minority problems, for example. He has been able to get to a lot of problems. But I agree with Tony. Eventually they have to come up with a plan. Which means price reform.
What are the consequences of that? I don't really think we can tell. I happen to be optimistic. I happen to believe that Mr. Gorbachev will make it. I don't agree with people who think if Mr. Gorbachev doesn't make it then the military will take over because the military historically has never taken over in the Soviet Union. You might get a populist taking over, but I don't think the military.
 
Mr. Solomon: Even if the military did take over, they don't have the resources to start an arms race.
 
Mr. Kendall: The military issue is gone. I also don't think they can go back to what they had before.
 
Mr. Goldman: I am more pessimistic. Mr. Gorbachev is an incredible politician. I don't think there is a politician in the world as effective. Historians will look back and say he is the most dynamic, the most imaginative and the most daring leader that the 20th century has seen. He reminds me of when I went to the movies as a kid and watched the serials. The hero would always get into a predicament with no way to escape. But by the next week the hero, somehow, was able to get out of the predicament. Everytime Mr. Gorbachev gets into a problem, like the miners' strike or the ethnic problems, you think he won't get out of it - but he does. Yet, one day the serial comes to an end. I am not expecting a happy ending for Mr. Gorbachev.

HEADLINE: WEEK IN BUSINESS;
Another Quarter Of Economic Growth

BYLINE: By WILLIAM S. NIEDERKORN

 BODY:
The economy grew at a 2.5 percent rate in the quarter that ended in September as a surge in consumer spending offset weakness in exports and the industrial sector, the Commerce Department reported. The overall advance matched that of the April-June period. Economists found reason to cheer in the report's indication of lower third-quarter inflation, even though that was mostly a reflection of falling energy prices. The data also showed no growth in exports and a 15.1 percent increase in imports.
 
*
 In other reports, orders for durable goods slipped 0.1 percent in September despite the second-biggest increase on record in military orders; personal income rose 0.3 percent in September as consumer spending posted its weakest advance in a year; sales of U.S.-built cars plunged 19 percent in mid-October, and sales of light trucks dropped 22.8 percent. 
 
*
 The savings industry lost deposits of $5.1 billion in August, the Federal Office of Thrift Supervision reported. Separately, state and Federal regulators accused senior officials of the Lincoln Savings and Loan Association of using wiretaps, political pressure and inducements to regulators to avoid action against the institution.
 
*
 The Dow Jones average of 30 industrials fell every day last week, for a cumulative loss of 92.42 points, to 2,596.72. On the New York Stock Exchange, declines led advances by more than 2 to 1 on four of five days. Treasury bond prices edged up on the week, but bill prices tumbled. The dollar fell against all major currencies except the British pound and the Canadian dollar. Gold prices surged to $378.30 an ounce on the Comex, up $11 for the week.
 
*
 Chancellor of the Exchequer Nigel Lawson, below, angrily resigned in a dispute over who was in charge of British economic policy - the Chancellor or Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher's economic adviser. The adviser, Sir Alan Walters, also resigned, without an explanation. Mrs. Thatcher replaced Mr. Lawson with the man she had made Foreign Secretary three months ago, John Major.
 
*
 Japanese corporations raised more than $110 billion in the first eight months of this year from the sale of stock, compared with $20 billion by American companies, by far the largest gap ever between the countries, according to figures from the Tokyo Stock Exchange and the Securities Data Company in New York.
 
*
 The Soviet Union announced a drastic cut in the ruble exchange rate that applies mainly to foreigners in the country and to Soviet citizens traveling abroad.
 
*
 A.T.&T. can continue to offer customized networks for large business customers, the F.C.C. ruled. But the commission voted to reject an A.T.&T. discount plan for a long-distance service.
 
*
 The Bush Administration announced borrowing measures to insure that next month's Social Security checks would not be delayed by a fight that may result from its effort to cut capital gains taxes. Treasury Secretary Nicholas F. Brady said the Treasury would move up its regular borrowing schedule to raise $17 billion before Oct. 31.
 
*
 The Justice Department has revised the rules for Federal prosecutors' use of the racketeering law known as RICO. The changes could limit criminal racketeering charges against white-collar defendants.
 
*
 UAL's board said it would try to keep the company independent. A leader of the machinists' union at United Airlines said his union might be willing to participate in a deal to help the company defend itself against a takeover. UAL's earnings fell 72.4 percent in the third quarter, but revenues rose 7.1 percent.
 
*
 Miscellanea. The S.E.C. approved a new financial instrument that would allow investors to trade a ''basket'' of 500 stocks on the New York Stock Exchange . . . Intel said design flaws had been discovered in its top-of-the-line microprocessor chip and that the errors would be corrected . . . McDonald's and eight of the nation's largest plastics producers announced a national program to recycle plastic hamburger containers and other packages . . . The Big Three auto makers each posted third-quarter results that showed sharply lower profits from domestic car and truck sales . . . Sears, Roebuck's profits fell 15.6 percent in the third quarter . . . The New York Post plans to publish its last Sunday issue on Nov. 26 . . . Anheuser-Busch said it would begin cutting prices on its beers.

HEADLINE: WHAT'S NEW IN THE NONPROFIT SECTOR;
Doing More With Less: Companies Donate Volunteers

BYLINE: By Craig Bloom

 BODY:
After a surge early in the decade, the growth of corporate philanthropy has stalled. Corporate contributions, adjusted for inflation, have fallen by 7 percent since 1985, to $4.8 billion in 1988. By comparison, individuals donated $86.7 billion, up 15 percent for the same period. The most recent culprits for the decline in corporate giving: the rise of cash-draining mergers, the stock market crash in 1987, increased foreign competition and a reduced tax incentive. 
Whatever the cause, many corporations, faced with limited resources for charity, have sought to do more with less. They have become choosier about whom they give their money to, often seeking out projects that complement their corporate missions. And rather than concentrate on donations, they have turned to such things as volunteerism.
The number of formal corporate programs to foster volunteerism appears to have tripled since 1978, said Shirley Keller, deputy executive director for corporate programs at Volunteer: The National Center, a network for volunteer groups. The center estimates that at least 1,000 programs exist, up from 300 in 1978.
Volunteer work can benefit corporations, Ms. Keller said. Employee skill levels and morale improve and so does the company's image in the community. ''It makes good business sense,'' Ms. Keller said. ''It's enlightened altruism.''
Companies have found that the most successful programs are those with the most employee involvement. A few years ago, Levi Strauss set up a task force at its home office in San Francisco to find out why employees there had so little enthusiasm for its volunteer program, said Martha Montag-Brown, director of the Levi Strauss Foundation.
Employees reported that the program provided little inspiration. Employees were then allowed to form their own ''action teams'' to address whatever issues interested them. Participation jumped to 45 percent of the 1,800 employees at the headquarters, up from less than 10 percent in 1987. Projects include helping the homeless, AIDS victims and, most recently, earthquake victims.

GRAPHIC: Volunteers from Levi Strauss & Company sort through donations at a Salvation Army Warehouse in San Francisco after the earthquake (NYY/Terrence McCarthy)

LENGTH: 376 words

HEADLINE: Economic Miracle

 BODY:
To the Editor:
As a resident of Bolivia from 1984 to 1987, I had the privilege to witness a true economic miracle. Undoubtedly Jeffrey Sachs made a valuable contribution to Bolivia's turnaround (''A Doctor for Sick Economies,'' Oct. 1), but to portray him as the savior of Bolivia is inaccurate.
The decision to impose a moratorium on debt repayment was not made by his client Government but by a previous administration dominated by socialists. It was not a philosophical decision but was dictated by the actual bankruptcy of the national treasury as the nation slid into hyperinflation. 
The shock of simultaneously ending wage and price controls, terminating subsidies, closing state-owned industries, firing thousands of tin miners, slashing the pay of teachers and bureaucrats and floating the exchange rate of the national currency had an enormous social cost. This cost was bearable because of the primitive nature of the Bolivian economy. Many Bolivians have relatives in the countryside who provide them with food. Also, a large informal economy cushioned the blow. The cocaine business channeled millions of dollars into this informal economy and provided work for displaced miners in the coca fields.
It is unlikely that similar circumstances exist in more complex industrialized nations like Argentina, Brazil or Poland. In these cases shock treatments could lead to wide-scale social unrest and bring an end to democratically elected governments.
Granted the shock treatment worked in Bolivia; but to credit Mr. Sachs as the architect of Bolivia's recovery ignores the economic factors peculiar to that economy and the more substantial contribution of other players.
Before Mr. Sachs arrived on the scene, Victor Paz Estenssoro, the former President, and Hugo Banzer Suarez, the former military ruler, had undertaken a cold-eyed analysis of the situation. These two statesmen recognized the folly of the Latin American version of the socialist economic model. They made the intellectual and moral decision to pursue a free-market economy and took the political heat associated with its implementation. They deserve the credit, not the academic they hired to cross the t's and dot the i's.
 
TIMOTHY J. KILLEEN
Ames, Iowa, Oct. 1

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: LETTER

HEADLINE: THE REGION;
Sometimes, a Negative Isn't Positive

BYLINE: By PETER KERR

DATELINE: TRENTON

 BODY:
A QUICK scan of the political landscape last week suggested one lesson future candidates may draw from the campaigns of 1989: hit hard, hit fast, hit nasty.
But a closer look shows that the results of bitter assaults are more complicated. In some cases, the evidence suggests, a negative campaign can be a dismal failure. And in some cases, positive campaigns can work just as well or better. 
In New Jersey, the Democrat, who attacked first, was leading in the race for governor after he broadcast beginning last month a commercial with a caricature of his opponent's face with the nose of Pinocchio. In New York City, the Republican candidate was gaining fast, following a burst of attacks on his rival centering on tax problems and the questionable background of an associate. Now the Democrat has counterattacked.
From Virginia to Alabama to California, candidates were calling one another liars and crooks with remarkable enthusiasm, out-mudsplattering even the notoriously dirty campaigns of 1988.
By the end of the week, many of those involved in political image-making were lamenting that politics had reached this state. But like the creators of nuclear weapons they were telling the public that attacks can't simply be wished away, for both parties know how devastating they can be and everyone knows the need to retaliate against a first strike.
''Negative advertising is here to stay,'' said Roger Stone, a Washington-based Republican consultant who left the gubernatorial campaign of Representative Jim Courter in New Jersey in June, several months before that race turned negative. ''The question isn't where it is going to be used,'' he said. ''It is when and how. You are going to see more and more of it.''
Experience shows that negative campaigns only work, however, when voters already know something positive about the attacking candidate. And it is extremely dangerous for the mud throwing to be initiated by a candidate who is already seen by the public as mean-spirited.
Pressure to use such campaigning is particularly strong in races where there are spending limits. It takes more money and more time to reinforce a positive message than a negative one.
''I hear a lot of consultants this year saying we beat the guy over the head and that's why we won,'' said Gov. Thomas H. Kean of New Jersey, who has criticized both candidates here for using tactics that he says have obscured the issues. ''That is the current mythology in Washington. But in fact it is much more complicated than that. The negatives I've seen used in this state sometimes are not effective at all.''
In the race to succeed Mr. Kean, the candidates emerged from a relatively civil primary to face what many considered a classic setup for unleashing a barrage. The Republicans said early on that they planned to link the Democrat, Representative James J. Florio, to scandals in his home county of Camden. Mr. Florio's consultants attacked first.
An early Florio commercial referred to several barrels of fuel oil left on land owned by Mr. Courter and his brother as an emblem of what the Democrats portrayed as insensitivity to pollution. Another showed a cartoon of Mr. Courter squeaking as his nose grew, with an announcer accusing him of misleading voters on car insurance, civil rights and abortion.
 
Striking Back
The latest poll by the Eagleton Institute of Politics at Rutgers University shows Mr. Florio with a 17-point lead; other polls show a similar gap.
When Mr. Florio attacked Mr. Courter with the Pinocchio commercial, the Republican struck back with what is now known as Pinocchio II, a commercial that shows Mr. Courter's nose shrinking and Mr. Florio's growing. It accuses Mr. Florio of lying and other misdeeds.
Mr. Courter started the race with little voter recognition, while Mr. Florio, who had run for governor twice before, was far better known. Some consultants now say that Mr. Courter should have run positive commercials first to give voters a reason to vote for him. They say that although Mr. Florio's attacks put Mr. Courter in a tough position, at least early on he needed to wage more of a positive campaign. Some new poll data suggest they are right. Earlier in the campaign, Mr. Courter's strategists said their surveys showed Mr. Courter could run a strong race on the issues of economic growth and no higher taxes. They also believed many voters would favor Mr. Courter if they were convinced he was tough on drugs and crime and once they heard his free-market solution to the high cost of car insurance.
 
Lost Messages
But an Eagleton poll of 717 likely voters in mid-October showed that after a negative campaign by both sides, voters were about split on which candidate would better handle the economy and taxes. They favored Mr. Florio by 40 to 28 percent on the drug issue. Two-thirds did not know where the candidates stood on auto insurance. Mr. Courter had not driven home positive messages about himself.
In New York City, a quick glance would seem to suggest a negative race is the way to go. Rudolph W. Giuliani, the Republican mayoral candidate, has run a campaign against David N. Dinkins that repeatedly raised Mr. Dinkins's failure to pay taxes, disparities in reports on the sale of stock and his relationship with Robert (Sonny) Carson, a black community leader who has made statements against whites.
''Why does he always wait until he gets caught?'' asked one Giuliani television commercial, produced by Roger Ailes, who is also the media adviser to Mr. Courter. As the race tightened last week, Mr. Dinkins went on the attack, running a commercial that charged Mr. Giuliani with switching positions throughout his career. Mr. Giuliani, meanwhile, has taken a softer tack.
But the current campaign tends to obscure what happened in the primary, when Mayor Edward I. Koch, an underdog whose opponents had already painted him as mean spirited on race, ran a positive campaign against Mr. Dinkins. Polls showed he came close to overcoming Mr. Dinkins. Some experts say that if not for the racially motivated killing in Bensonhurst, which reminded voters of racial divisions during the Koch years, he might just have won.

LENGTH: 995 words

HEADLINE: THE WORLD;
Is East Europe Too Amazing for the West?

BYLINE: By CRAIG R. WHITNEY

DATELINE: LONDON

 BODY:
AS one astounding development succeeds another in what used to be known as the Soviet bloc, it is no longer visionary to think of the possibility of a new Europe from the Atlantic to the Urals by the end of the century. The extent of change in the East became even clearer last week, but so did the implication that the Western countries may soon have to rethink some fundamental assumptions of the old postwar order if they want to help shape the new one.
The first of these is what Europe is. Until a few months ago, the governments of the 12 countries of the European Community thought its original promise would be fulfilled if they created a single market of 320 million people, with no legal, trade or travel barriers by 1992. Now Poland and Hungary are clamoring for associate-membership status, and finding sympathetic listeners in West Germany, France and even Britain. The community is slowly developing a consensus that it should provide the food, loan guarantees and investment capital that it believes could spell the difference between success and failure for the Poles and Hungarians. Now it is hoping to bring the United States to the same conclusion. 
No less far reaching are the implications for security in the 1990's. Hopes are high that the huge conventional and nuclear arms reductions the Soviet Union and the United States are discussing in Vienna and Geneva could lead, soon, to the chance to convert both NATO and the Warsaw Pact alliances from instruments of mutual deterrence into organizations of mutual reassurance, creating a zone of security from San Diego to Vladivostok.
As these implications dawn on leaders from Bonn to Washington, the sense of urgency is increasing. Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d said in San Francisco last week that the Soviet ''new thinking'' promised possibilities, but that the United States should seize the opportunity. The same day, the Soviet Foreign Minister, Eduard A. Shevardnadze, acknowledged that the invasion of Afghanistan was illegal.
Two days later, President Mikhail S. Gorbachev applied the lesson of Afghanistan to Eastern Europe. In effect, he gave his seal of approval to Poland's first non-Communist government since the wars, and encouraged Hungary to go down the same path. Hungary was already ahead of him, its leaders proclaiming to a cheering crowd of 100,000 that their country was no longer a Communist Hungarian People's Republic but simply the Republic of Hungary, planning to become a democracy.
One consequence of Hungary's decision to open its borders with Austria was an exodus of 40,000 East Germans that cost that country's hard-line leader, Erich Honecker, his job earlier this month. Last week Egon Krenz went before the nominal legislature in Berlin for confirmation as his successor, and 52 members voted against him or abstained. He said he would listen to the East Germans who had elected not to flee, and hundreds of thousands of them held him to his word, taking to the streets in East Berlin, Dresden and Leipzig.
Now, the wonder - or worry - is whether the ultimate logic of an East Germany without Communist autocracy would be one German state instead of two.
President Bush said last week that he wasn't going to be ''stampeded into overreacting'' to change in Eastern Europe, but he added that he didn't share some Western European fears about German reunification either, because West Germany was firmly anchored in the West.
In Europe, too, the realization seems to be sinking in that if reunification did occur, it would not be in this century. In a speech in Strasbourg, President Francois Mitterrand of France seemed to agree, dismissing fears of ''intellectuals and journalists'' that change in the East could lead to ''dislocation'' in the NATO alliance and the European Community. ''Couldn't it produce the opposite effect?'' he asked. ''My conclusion is simple: We must strengthen and accelerate the political construction of Europe.''
Within that simple idea lurk great complexities. In Brussels, diplomats and military officers struggling with the conventional arms reductions that now seem within reach say that both NATO and the Warsaw Pact would be needed for years, just to oversee treaty compliance and insure stability. But all the allies except the United States want NATO to relax its restrictions on trade in technology with the East, and last week Washington was alone in arguing against relaxation.
Powerful disagreements remain about what the single market of 1992 should be, powerful enough to cause a break between Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher of Britain and her longtime Chancellor of the Exchequer, Nigel Lawson, who resigned. Should the European Community of 1992 be just a free-trade market, as Mrs. Thatcher wants, a social organism, as the European Commission wants, or a federation, as Chancellor Helmut Kohl of West Germany wants?
Poland needs emergency food aid, more than the $169 million President Bush has pledged so far, just to get through the winter, and both Poland and Hungary need huge infusions of capital and loan guarantees to convert to free-market economies. But the Western response has been only tentative until recently. Last month, the European Community's executive commission, coordinating aid from 24 Western countries, suggested $660 million for next year. More than that now seems likely to be provided to Poland alone by the United States, West Germany and France, all of which have been raising their pledges.
Unless the West acts soon, the West German Government warns, reform - in Poland at least - could fail, encouraging Rumania, Czechoslovakia and East Germany to stick with their neo-Stalinist systems and ending the dream of a new, united Europe. As Hans-Dietrich Genscher, the West German Foreign Minister, said in a recent speech in Frankfurt, ''History will judge us by whether we have taken the opportunities which emerge from these reforms for the whole of Europe.''

HEADLINE: THE NATION;
Tearing at the Deep Roots of Protectionism

BYLINE: By CLYDE H. FARNSWORTH

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
AS the Bush Administration sought in Geneva last week to push the world toward a freer agricultural economy, it was facing opposition not only from Europe but from some important farm interests at home.
 
The problem is that the United
States cannot get more open markets abroad without sacrificing protection for some of its own. In many countries, price supports and import curbs keep internal food prices high, creating excess production. As surpluses rise, they are unloaded on world markets, depressing prices and hurting farmers elsewhere. 
Almost all nations maintain distorting farm subsidies and other programs. ''Our European colleagues have said repeatedly that there are no angels in agricultural trade,'' said Agriculture Secretary Clayton K. Yeutter. ''We agree. The question is how do we get closer to heaven?''
Mr. Yeutter turned his eyes to the sky as the United States disclosed its long-awaited plan in the current Uruguay Round of negotiations to liberalize trade. The round, which began three years ago at the Uruguay resort of Punta del Este, is scheduled to conclude next year.
The American plan seeks to achieve free trade in agriculture and eliminate most farm subsidies by the year 2000.
Predictably, the European Community, whose long-established farm-support programs have contributed to economic integration of the 12 member states, bristled. Ray MacSharry, the Community's commissioner for agriculture, said the proposals ''could not be considered as a basis for negotiation.'' The Japanese, with the most highly protected farmers in the world, were also critical.
And certain American farm groups that have grown used to subsidies and protection against imports - peanut farmers, sugar growers and dairy producers, among others - found themselves cheering the naysayers.
The United States also presented sweeping proposals to reduce restrictions on financial, construction, tourism and other services, and to enforce greater protection for patents, copyrights and other intellectual property. The American negotiators want rules for services similar to those written for commerce in goods four decades ago under the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade.
One reason is basic economic self-interest. The United States is probably the world's most efficient provider of both food and services, and the $1 trillion in food and services represents half of world trade.
Under current conditions, said United States Trade Representative Carla A. Hills, ''corn growers in Iowa, lawyers in New York, citrus farmers in Florida, high-tech manufacturers in California, and a host of our best and most competitive entrepreneurs from coast to coast are denied the chance to do what they do best - compete fairly and squarely in international markets.''
Yet while the proposals won the strong backing of American businesses from American Express to construction companies, the farm plan is stirring anxiety. More than 30,000 peanut growers, shielded from foreign competition by strict import quotas, would be ''devastated,'' said Walter H. Mitchell, executive director of the Georgia Peanut Producers Association.
The nation's 160,000 dairy farmers, while facing limited foreign competition, have been content with the current price supports, enacted to insure ample milk supplies. ''Producers want predictability,'' said James C. Barr, chief executive of the National Milk Producers Federation. ''We're pretty nervous right now.'' Though foreign sugar production is far cheaper, only one million tons of sugar is being allowed into the United States this year - a tiny portion of domestic consumption - compared with five million tons in the early 1980's. Quotas and price supports cost American consumers $3 billion a year.
The growers say they would change their ways if other countries did. But they are skeptical. ''Our country's proposal is theoretically wonderful, but practically it's pie in the sky,'' said Pete de Gravelles, general manager of the American Sugar Cane League in New Orleans.
Predictably, farm groups with the biggest chance for export gains -the great mid-continent grain and soybean producers and the cotton and rice growers of the South - are the biggest backers of freer trade. Largely reflecting such interests, the 3.5 million-member American Farm Bureau said that it ''strongly supports'' more market-oriented agriculture, but that other countries must make concessions.
It is widely expected that a farm bill due to clear Congress next year will continue all existing programs. But there could be fierce battles on Capitol Hill if an agreement is reached in Geneva, for the lawmakers would then be called on to remove American farmers' protections to meet the new international obligations.
On one point there is agreement: liberalization would greatly benefit the world's taxpayers and consumers. The Administration assesses the cost of current farm policies at almost $200 billion a year for the European Community and the United States together.
''If we let this opportunity fade,'' said Mr. Yeutter, who was Trade Representative under President Ronald Reagan, ''the agricultural situation will be worse than the economic havoc any natural disaster may cause.''

HEADLINE: THE REGION;
A New Mayor, Just in Time For the Hard Time After the Boom

BYLINE: By RICHARD LEVINE

 BODY:
A FEW months ago Felix G. Rohatyn caused a stir when he told the City Club that he believed New York may be heading for a period even more painful than the fiscal crisis of the 1970's.
The investment banker qualifies as an authority on the city's problems in the 1970's, since he helped resolve them. Mr. Rohatyn is also chairman of the Municipal Assistance Corporation, the agency established in those bad old days to offer financial aid to the city and keep an eye on its books, and so is knowledgeable about the current problems. And if some regard him as prone to a gloomy view, his pessimism has since been echoed by others.
Mayor Edward I. Koch, himself not one to shy away from bad fiscal news, added the latest confirmation of hard times last week, outlining a more than half-a-billion-dollar gap in the budget for the fiscal year that ends in June and putting forth a package of spending cuts and other measures to close it. Not since the early 1980's has the city had to grapple with so big a budgetary hole so late in its fiscal year. 
Mr. Koch's plan entails $200 million of cuts that would affect nearly every city agency. And even if Mr. Koch's successor follows the plan, he will be faced with a large deficit in the next fiscal year that is likely to grow larger still after a new labor settlement with municipal workers is negotiated. Nor will he have much time for on-the-job training. The next financial plan by Mayor David N. Dinkins or Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani is due two or three weeks after Inauguration Day on Jan. 1.
A part of the problem is a lag in revenues from almost every important tax the city imposes. Comparing this fiscal year's first quarter proceeds with those from the same period last year, the general corporation tax was down 18 percent, the mortgage recording tax was down 25 percent and the real property transfer tax was down 30 percent. Sales tax revenues lagged behind the inflation rate. The declines might seem insignificant in a $27 billion budget, but to Paul Dickstein, the city budget director, they signal ''barely perceptible economic growth and could be the forerunner of a recession.''
New York City boomed through much of the 1980's, driven by the financial services industry. Then came the stock market plunge of October 1987.
 
After the Fall
In a recent briefing on what has happened since, Samuel M. Ehrenhalt, regional commissioner of the Federal Bureau of Labor Statistics, said the growth in employment the city enjoyed in the 1980's had stopped. It was to be expected that Wall Street would retrench and it did, losing 15,000 jobs in the two years since the stock market fall after gaining an average of 12,000 jobs in each of the five previous years. But the manufacturing sector, which was already thought to be down to the bone, lost even more jobs - 21,000. ''I don't know how to account for it, except with a sigh,'' Mr. Ehrenhalt said.
Mr. Ehrenhalt saw hope in the average pay of private sector workers in the city. It stood at $31,700 last year, a 9 percent increase from 1987 and $10,000 more than the national average, suggesting, he said, ''New York City's resilience and its prodigious capacity to generate income.''
Then again, as of 1987 nearly one in four New York City residents was living below the poverty level, a percentage that had not been significantly changed by the preceeding years of improving economic health.
Nor does it seem likely that there will be a quick turnaround. Raymond D. Horton, president of the Citizens Budget Commission, a private group that watches the city's fiscal issues, said that for nearly three decades the New York City economy has been characterized by long swings of growth and long swings of decline. ''If you're a cycle man, it suggests that we're at the top and starting down,'' he said, ''and when you start down, it's not an overnight thing.''
All this would be bad enough but, as Mr. Rohatyn, Mr. Horton, Mr. Dickstein and others have noted, the economy is sagging and tax revenues are drooping just as the demand for city services is rising. Crack addiction has put pressure on the criminal justice system and is blamed for a surge in child abuse reports. AIDS is straining the health care network. Homelessness has compelled the city to undertake a costly housing rehabilitation effort.
Still, there are differences from 1975. The city operates under more rigorous accounting rules that discourage such practices as the pumping of capital money into the operating budget or selling bonds backed by dubious sources of revenue. Fiscal watchdogs issue periodic reports analyzing the city's budget and the Financial Control Board is prepared to step in and run it if City Hall demonstrates an inability to live within its means. Too Tight or Too Loose? That budget has grown substantially, and although the administration insists it is already stretched tightly others have suggested there is room for more trimming and greater efficiency.
''We're not going to have a bankruptcy crisis,'' said Mr. Rohatyn, ''and I don't believe we're going to be shorn of market access.'' In fact, even though Mr. Koch will not be around to carry out most of the budget cuts he planned, two major rating services, which affect the ease with which the city can enter the financial markets, responded positively to his program. And while some investors have sold city securities, jittery about the city's finances and the coming transition, , the administration is moving ahead with plans for a refinancing of bonds.
But in meeting the challenges of the 1990's City Hall will need a large measure of self reliance, at least over the near term. Washington pulled back from many of its commitments to the city during the Reagan years and is not likely to change soon. And New York State has serious budget problems of its own.

HEADLINE: IDEAS & TRENDS;
Northeast Forests, Too, Get Congress's Interest

BYLINE: By ALLAN R. GOLD

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
CONGRESSIONAL debate over the future of American forests has almost always concentrated on the vast timber-growing areas of the Pacific Northwest and Alaska. But slowly, the future of another heavily forested region, the Northeast, has begun to stir concern on Capitol Hill.
Unlike the Northwest or Alaska, the Northeast is not mainly concerned with how many trees should be logged and at what cost. Instead, places like Vermont's Northeast Kingdom, New Hampshire's North Country, the Maine Woods and the Adirondack Mountains of New York are increasingly troubled by the encroachment of real estate development. 
''The forests of New Hampshire, as are those of our neighboring states, are being subdivided, chopped up,'' said Paul O. Bofinger, president of the Society for the Protection of New Hampshire Forests.
The forests of New England and New York are popular spots for tourism, and many people are willing to pay top dollar for a piece of the good life. But more and more residents of the states have complained that the changes threaten the land's traditional uses - commercial logging and recreation like hiking, hunting and fishing.
In the last year, New York and the three northern New England states turned to Washington for help.
At the outset, they did not ask Congress for much. Among residents of the rugged woodland areas, there is great suspicion of government in general and of federally imposed solutions. About 85 percent of the 26 million acres of the forests in the four states are privately owned by individuals or companies. The residents like it that way, because they don't want Washington to tell them whether they can hunt or drive snowmobiles through the woods.
Lawmakers authorized the United States Forest Service to work with the states, conservationists and the forest products industry to study what was happening in the northern forests and to propose ways to deal with the changes. This month, the Forest Service released a report that told Congress what many people in the Northeast already knew.
Changes in land ownership ''pose a threat to the long-term integrity and traditional uses of the land'' in parts of region, said George M. Leonard, associate chief of the Forest Service, in testimony before a House subcommittee last week.
Land values have risen sharply. Today, in many spots throughout the northern forests, a property owner can make more money selling woodland for development than for timber production. An average acre sold for timber growing might bring $100, Mr. Bofinger said, but the same acre sold for its real estate value could bring 10 times as much.
Big corporations like the Great Northern Paper Company and the International Paper Corporation are under pressure to sell vast tracts to raise cash, lest they become takeover targets. That could mean cashing in undervalued timberlands. The region got a taste of this last year when the Diamond International Corporation put its vast timber holdings on the block, eventually selling some of it to developers. Diamond's move led to protests in all four states.
Once the Forest Service study is in final form early next year, Congress will be faced with many choices. The report offers lawmakers two dozen strategies for preserving the Northeast forests.
 
Incentives for Owners
Among them are proposals for the creation of tax incentives for landholders who continue to maintain their land for timber growing and suggestions that the Government purchase environmentally sensitive tracts. It appears likely that more than one approach ultimately will be employed.
''Traditional solutions will not meet the challenge of long-term protection,'' the report said.
For example, the Forest Service suggested that owners who agree not to develop their land for 10 years be given favorable tax treatment on capital gains income from the sale of timber. Family landowners could have their land assessed for estate tax purposes on the basis of its current use rather than its potential developed value. That might reduce the incentive to liquidate timber holdings to pay taxes. Landowners who sell to public agencies or conservation groups would not pay income tax on the gains.
Increased use of conservation easements was also recommended. Under this approach, government pays owners to give up their rights to develop their land. The report raised the possibility of creating a national forest or park but pointed out local resistance to this idea.
Indeed, an important consideration for Congress will be the Forest Service's conclusion, based on public hearings and interviews, that residents liked the status quo, that most of the land is in private hands and that owners generally permit free or inexpensive access to those lands. Also, they noted the economic importance of the forest industry in the region.
''Although many who commented said that environmental and economic conditions could be improved,'' said Mr. Leonard, ''most expressed a desire to maintain the northern forest as it exists today.''

SECTION: Section 4; Page 22, Column 1; Editorial Desk

LENGTH: 720 words

HEADLINE: For Mayor: David Dinkins

 BODY:
What a disappointing campaign: voters have heard almost as much about Jackie Mason and Jesse Jackson as about David Dinkins and Rudolph Giuliani. So far, the two candidates haven't even managed to debate each other.
The sorry nature of this contest makes a hard choice harder. Neither man has demonstrated compelling qualifications for the job Ed Koch has filled for half a generation. Their candidacies, both plausible, are also flawed. Democrat Dinkins has shown little in the way of managerial skills; Republican Giuliani has demonstrated few political skills. Taking into account his understanding of New York, we cast our vote for David Dinkins. 
Rudolph Giuliani is, at age 45, energetic, sensible and ambitious. He's a former United States Attorney who offers a clear message to voters upset by instances of corruption in the Koch administration. His experience as a prosecutor means he knows the underside of society; he's hardly naive about politics. But he is a novice, having never before held elective office. That's not just a formal deficiency. Serving an unruly, sometimes unreasonable public requires skills that do not automatically accompany an analytical mind.
After a deplorable start, Mr. Giuliani has got his campaign on track, done his homework and now makes credible arguments about issues. Yet it's often hard to discern where he stands. He's a Kennedy Democrat who turned Reagan Republican who now runs as a Republican-Liberal.
Likewise, there's not much in Mr. Giuliani's career or campaign that shows an instinct for managing savage conflicts. He analyzes problems rationally. But how well does he handle people's irrationalities? Is he apt to be harsh and moralistic? More than once as a prosecutor, Mr. Giuliani pursued defendants with unseemly zealotry.
Mr. Dinkins is a 62-year-old lawyer and former marine who has spent two decades serving the city, most recently as Manhattan Borough President. He has a reputation for indecision and reinforced it during the campaign. When questions were raised about a stock transfer to his son, he dodged and delayed, transforming what might have been just a stumble into a storm - and reviving questions about his failure to file tax returns 16 years ago. On some issues, Mr. Dinkins takes troubling positions. He still supports the damaging concept of commercial rent control; unwisely, he would delay the city's first garbage-burning incinerator. Yet these are flaws of judgment or matters of honest dispute.
What no one disputes is his most evident characteristic. New York knows David Dinkins to be, above all, a conciliator. If he sometimes takes forever to make up his mind, his ultimate decisions are generally prudent. His instinct is to unify. He gave an example two weeks ago, when he met a crowd of booing whites in Bensonhurst. He addressed them calmly, without rancor, and ultimately won some grudging applause.
This decency can help the city confront its biggest foreseeable problems: a sagging economy and tension between the races. The two go together. Because tax revenues are down, the city already faces a deficit of half a billion or more. The next mayor will have to ask for, and sell, sacrifice to all New Yorkers, most notably the poor citizens hurt most by reductions in city services. Mr. Dinkins seems better qualified to persuade all New Yorkers to share the burdens ahead.
That's also true for another reason: race. Mr. Dinkins would be New York's first black mayor - a fact likely to instill a sense of pride and participation in blacks and other minority groups, following the historical ethnic pattern.
A vote for Rudolph Giuliani is a gamble. It might be a gamble worth taking because, as a Republican, he'd bring a whole new team into a city government long run by Democrats, and because he might learn to excel. But voters know little about him, and even less about the people he might appoint. He lacks experience as a political professional, and nowhere is such professionalism more needed than in City Hall.
David Dinkins, warts and all, is a known quantity. He's a practical Democrat who has come up through the ranks and who knows what he stands for. He understands New York's government, neighborhoods and people. He is not the ideal candidate but he is a good man likely to make a decent mayor.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: TOPICS OF THE TIMES;
Loophole for an Earthquake

 BODY:
Where did Congress suddenly find $3.5 billion for earthquake disaster relief? In a loophole. If the quake had hit last month, as Hurricane Hugo did, money to aid its victims would have had to come from cutting other programs. But, as luck would have it, the deadline for trimming this year's budget deficit has passed now, and with it this year's spending ceiling.
The Gramm-Rudman-Hollings budget law says that the deficit in fiscal 1990, which began Oct. 1, can't exceed $110 billion. But the final official tally of each fiscal year's deficit is made on Oct. 15, just two weeks into the year. Rather than measure actual results, the law only requires an early forecast, based on legislation enacted before Oct. 15 and data on the economic outlook. Anything that comes later is ignored.
The earthquake did not work its devastation until Oct. 17, and Congress did not approve the aid bill until last week. With no budget ceiling to worry about, the bill passed easily. An earlier, smaller bill for Hurricane Hugo relief was complicated by the need to find cuts in other programs.
What will it take to make Congress confront the fallacies of its budget process? Apparently more than a hurricane, or an earthquake.

HEADLINE: What's Keeping Us From Building New Cities;
Part of the Problem

 BODY:
To the Editor:
By proposing that we abandon old cities for new ones in rural areas, William Safire (column, Sept. 25) is suggesting that we also abandon an entire population of the poor, the preservation of an American architectural heritage and the continuation of a 200-hundred-year-old culture. It is precisely the creation of ''Levittowns'' that has debased the economic viability of most cities in the United States, encouraged the use of the automobile and increased the rate of urban sprawl. Suburbanization has not enhanced the social well-being of anyone except the white, middle-class population, who saw an opportunity to flee the crowded, dirty and, yes, black and ethnic urban centers of the first half of the 20th century. 
What makes Mr. Safire believe that these new cities will be any different? In ''The Crabgrass Frontier: A History of Suburbanization in the United States,'' Kenneth Jackson develops the argument that suburbanization has mostly occurred because public policy has supported metropolitan sprawl. Moreover, he shows that America has suburbanized because Federal land development policy since World War II has been inequitable and made with a racial bias.
Mr. Safire is viewing cities as an economic creation and is not considering the social consequences of his scheme. Although economics is the primary reason for urbanization, it would be ignorant to argue that cultural institutions that have evolved out of early urban settlements in the United States do not constitute just as equally the meaning and importance of a city.
Despite the lack of need for businesses to be close together or of retailers to have stores, people do have a fundamental need to be near one another. Human interaction is what makes life meaningful. The narrowness of Mr. Safire's urban vision epitomizes the ever-increasing privatization of American culture. His land-development pattern leaves little room for the public realm.
Mr. Safire should seriously consider exactly who will benefit from his scheme.
 
ANNE COTTRELL
City Historic Preservation Officer
 Jersey City, Oct. 4, 1989

SECTION: Section 4; Page 22, Column 6; Editorial Desk

LENGTH: 550 words

HEADLINE: What's Keeping Us From Building New Cities;
Princeton and Irvine

 BODY:
To the Editor:
What William Safire identifies as new cities on the peripheries of American metropolises (column, Sept. 25) are better understood by the word ''sprawl'' (defined by Prof. Richard F. Lamb as ''the seemingly unorganized scattering of homes and businesses across a landscape with no focal points or nodes'').
In 1958, the editors of Fortune magazine sponsored a volume called ''The Exploding Metropolis,'' which is the classic statement of the problem. ''You can't stop progress,'' wrote William H. Whyte, one of the contributors, ''yet much more of this kind of progress and we shall have the paradox of prosperity lowering our real standard of living.'' 
We can measure the prognostication in two very different instances.
Princeton, N.J., 60 miles from New York City and Philadelphia, is a university community dating from the 18th century. Since 1945, the vast popularity of living and working there has put the charms associated with the community at risk. Sensing its own lure, Princeton University acquired 850 acres from the Rockefeller Medical Institute in 1951 and transformed them into the Forrestal Campus.
What evolved is a mix of academic, scientific and business enterprises. Soon, the new campus, a few miles to the east, was occupied by companies in research and development, including I.B.M., Mobil, Squibb, RCA, Xerox and Johnson & Johnson.
Most important, this spawned a 26-mile stretch along Route 1 known as the Princeton Corridor. Its concentration of office facilities is unsurpassed between New York City and Washington. One study, by geographers for the Department of Commerce, anticipates 12 million to 15 million square feet of office space by the mid-1990's, surpassing downtown Newark and making it New Jersey's largest downtown.
Then consider Irvine, Calif., in Orange County, about 40 miles south of Los Angeles, a planned community that was incorporated only in 1971. It was envisioned as a model for suburban growth. Some viewed it as an American standard for the next century. A system for local control was to offset the massive growth that enveloped much of the county since Disneyland was constructed at Anaheim in 1955. Forty distinctive residential villages were planned, with the new campus of the University of California as cultural focus.
As Irvine nears the 20th anniversary of its incorporation, it has not escaped the magnetic influence of Los Angeles. It suffers from the same centerless existence that afflicts much of the multicounty metropolitan expanse of Southern California.
If the dimensions and ramifications of sprawl are self-apparent, there is too little consensus about what to do. Regional planning, ideally devised and administered by state-level agencies, seems the logical answer. Yet anyone familiar with the political economy of the American metropolis recognizes the difficulty in attaining the consent of the locally governed for such resolutions. Residents of each locale prize their autonomy over neighboring communities.
All the while, given our longstanding inability to formulate policies that control metropolitan sprawl, we continue to suffer its perilous consequences.
 
MICHAEL H. EBNER
 Lake Forest, Ill., Oct. 3, 1989
 
The writer is a professor of history at Lake Forest College.
