HEADLINE: WHAT'S DOING IN: Nassau

BYLINE: By CATHARINE SKIPP; CATHARINE SKIPP, who works in the Miami bureau of The Times, often visits the Bahamas.

 BODY:
The Bahamian capital, Nassau, spared the destruction that Hurricane Hugo wreaked on the neighboring Caribbean, is in the midst of its biggest construction boom ever. Casinos are being renovated and expanded and new development is evident all over the island. A flourishing economy is apparent in a multitude of new city buses, shopping malls and services.
With the buildup of hotels and resorts, the flavor of Nassau and its two big tourist enclaves, Paradise Island and Cable Beach, has lost some of its island spice. But with that loss has come a more businesslike approach to tourism, its biggest industry. The Bahamian Government has set up education and training programs to attune residents to the benefits of tourism. Carnival, the cruise line that owns the Crystal Palace Resort and runs the casino there, has spent $4 million putting its staff through an in-house service academy, with workers required to attend refresher courses every six months.
Yet many of the formalities of the more than 250 years of English rule are still evident in the workings of the Government and in the colonial beauty of the streets and many of the restaurants and hotels. 
The 80-square-mile island of New Providence where Nassau is situated is home to well over half the 320,000 people that live in the chain of more than 700 islands and cays. Over the years Nassau has become synonymous with the whole island in both name and character. Paradise Island, a much smaller island just to the north, is joined to New Providence by a bridge.
Taxis are expensive and attractions spread out, so renting a car makes sense for overnight guests. English traditions prevail, with left-hand driving and many roundabouts.
 
Getting There
Nassau International Airport, the primary gateway, with several flights daily on various carriers from major cities in the United States, is a long drive from the resort areas. Paradise Island has a new strip that drops you right in the middle of everything. Seaplanes fly out of Fort Lauderdale and Miami directly to Paradise Island, as does Paradise Island Airlines out of Miami.
A passport or birth certificate is needed to enter the Bahamas. United States or Bahamian currency is accepted in all places. Despite the proliferation of ''Bahama No Problem'' T-shirts, Nassau does have some street crime. Visitors should take sensible precautions like locking hotel rooms and rental cars and not wandering off in deserted areas at night.
 
The Reefs
Nassau is surrounded by clear blue water because there are no rivers emptying cloudy sediment into the sea. Against the white sandy bottom you can see clearly to depths of 60 feet. Whether you prefer to see fish on the end of a hook, from the safety of a glass-bottom boat or underwater, an abundance of trips is available.
Perhaps the easiest and most convienent view is to be had at Coral World, an underwater observatory and marine park recently opened off the road between downtown Nassau and Cable Beach on Silver Cay. An observation tower allows visitors both a look at the skyline of New Providence and at the ocean floor 15 feet below. The tower is built in the middle of a natural reef teeming with lobsters, grouper, angelfish and hundreds of other fish attracted by daily feedings, as well as coral and plant life. Huge tanks contain sharks, stingrays and turtles and a building housing 24 aquariums displaying aquatic life from all over the world provides an education on undersea life.
Coral World is open all year. Admission is $12, $8 for children (rising to $14 and $10 respectively on Jan. 1).
Hartley's Underwater Exploration (809-393-8234) takes visitors reef walking. Groups of six don large brass diving helmets tethered to an air supply and are led by the hand around a reef. A big friendly grouper is Mr. Hartley's sidekick and nuzzles up to visitors while Mr. Hartley snaps their picture ($5). Visitors are transported to and from the reef on a 57-foot cabin cruiser, the Pied Piper. A caveat: at 20 minutes the reef walk is a bit short in duration. The cost is $35 a person; the Pied Piper leaves the docks at Nassau Yacht Haven marina (on East Bay Street just east of the Paradise Island bridge) daily at 9:30 A.M. and 1:30 P.M. Tuesday to Saturday.
A variety of diving and snorkeling trips can be arranged through Nigel Bower, owner of Caribbean Images. His 31-foot cigarette boat can transport people down to Spirit Cay and Highborne Cay in the Exuma Islands about 40 miles away. The $130-a-person cost includes a full day of diving or snorkeling, all equipment, food and beverages. Short trips to a private beach on nearby Rose Island are about $85 a person a day.
Mr. Bower can also make arrangements for overnight lodging on Rose Island for an additional $300 a night for a group of up to eight people. A four-day, three-night package is available on Spirit Cay, a private island, for $3,600 for eight people, all inclusive. Mr. Bower can be reached at 809-362-1467 or 809-322-3724.
Fishing charters can be arranged through Nassau Yacht Haven (809-393-8173) and Hurricane Hole marina (809-363-3000). Prices depend on what type of fish are being pursued, which determines where and how far the boats go.
Calypso I and II (809-363-3577) are party boats that go out for day trips to Blue Lagoon and on evening dinner cruises. Each trip is $35 a person and leaves from Paradise Island docks. No cruises are run on Sunday and Wednesday. The day trip leaves at 10 A.M. and returns at 4 P.M. and includes a buffet lunch, wine and fruit punch, snorkeling at Blue Lagoon and a live band. The three-hour dinner cruise leaves the dock at 8 P.M. and includes a steak and grouper dinner and a Bahamian band.
 
Casinos
Gambling draws many to the island although Bahamian citizens are prohibited from visiting the casinos. The Government owns both 30,000-square-foot casinos but they are leased and operated by American companies. Akin to Atlantic City or Las Vegas, the Paradise Island Casino and Crystal Palace at Cable Beach are glitzy affairs, with all the usual games of chance, entertainment and the like. Crystal Palace has been open only a year in the same location as the old Cable Beach casino. The show ($38 for show and dinner or $25 for show and two drinks; 809-327-6200) features the usual singers and dancers and a good magician.
At the Paradise Island Resort and Casino, recently taken over by Merv Griffin's group and under renovation, the ambiance is not quite as glitzy or frenetic as Crystal Palace's but it has a large gaming floor. The show ($42 for dinner and show and $27 for the show and two drinks; 809-363-3000) also features a magician, a comic and dancers. Both shows include some topless dancing.
 
Where to Eat
Every few steps in the business dictrict of Nassau you pass a place to eat, with conch fritters and conch salad to be found on almost every corner. Everything from American fast-food chains and Tony Roma's rib restaurant to expensive white-glove dining is available. The big hotels have a multitude of restaurants to choose from. Around town there are several restaurants worth noting.
The restaurant in the 250-year-old Graycliff Hotel and Restaurant (West Hill Street; 809-322-2796) has a longstanding reputation as being one of the finest in the area.
Five dining rooms overlook the beautiful gardens. The menu features island specialties and traditional fare and an exceptional wine list. Entrees are in the $27 to $36 range. Reservations and jackets for men are required.
Some say Sun And . . . (Lakeview Avenue off East Shirley Street; 809-393-1205) is competing with Graycliff. Ronny Deryckere, the former chef at Greycliff, owns Sun And . . ., which specializes in French, American and Bahamian cuisine and wild game imported from Europe. Entrees range from $23 to $32.50 a person. Dinner is served from 6:30 to 10 P.M. daily except Monday. Reservations are required. Men should wear jackets. Buena Vista (Delancy Street just off Nassau Street; 809-322-2811) serves Continental cuisine and Bahamian seafood in elegant surroundings. In addition to a full menu in the $25 to $35 range for entrees, nightly fixed-price specials are around $35 a person for a full dinner.
Reservations are required; men are asked to wear jackets. Open daily from 7 to 10 P.M. from mid-December to mid-April; closed Sunday the rest of the year.
The Green Shutters (on Parliament Street a block and a half south of Bay Street; 809-325-5702) is one of the few remaining restaurants serving traditional English fare. Steak and kidney pie and shepherd's pie coexist with lobster and conch at lunch; roast beef and Yorkshire pudding are dinner specialties. The Green Shutters is a cheery place to play darts and sample the many drafts and ales. Open Monday to Saturday. Pub hours are 11 A.M. to midnight; dining room is open 11:30 A.M. to 10:30 P.M. Reservations are suggested in the dining room and men are asked to wear jackets.
 
Where to Stay
Nassau, Cable Beach and Paradise Island offer everything from deluxe, private mansions or glitzy hotel suites to the very basic, rustic family-run hotel. The big chains all have hotels here and the Bahamian Department of Tourism runs a reservation service (800-327-0787).
The Ocean Club (809-326-2501) on the beach at Paradise Island is an all-year resort with a backdrop of cloister and gardens for the 71-room hotel and villas. It has clay tennis courts, an 18-hole P.G.A. golf course and a swimming pool. Prices start at $190 a night for a double and go as high as $875 a night for the villas.
Graycliff Hotel (West Hill Street; 809-322-2796), situated in the same mansion as the restaurant in downtown Nassau has 14 beautifully decorated rooms. Rates begin at $150 a night for a double and are booked months in advance.
The out-of-the-way Divi Bahamas Resort and Country Club (809-326-4391 or 800-367-3484) is situated on the southwest shore of the island on the site of the former South Ocean Beach Club. The main hotel is on the P.G.A. golf course, considered by many to be one of the best on the island. The resort is in the process of opening more hotel rooms and a time-share complex on the ocean will open this winter. The skin-diving operation is first rate, it has tennis and wind surfing and horseback riding is available nearby. Rates start at $170 for a double. Buses run all day and late into the night to downtown Nassau and the casinos.
Carnival's Crystal Palace Resort and Casino (809-327-6200 or 800-222-7466), which opened last December on Cable Beach, is an 867-room behemoth with a golf course, tennis courts, health club, water sports and the works. Rates start at $180 for a double.
Budget choice: Buena Vista, at the same address as the restaurant, has five comfortable rooms with a homey atmosphere, each with private bath and air-conditioning, for $80 a night for a double ($70 for a single).

GRAPHIC: Cruise ship in Nassau harbor; marine life at Coral World; dinner at the Ocean Club (Len Kaufman); map of Nassau

SECTION: Section 6; Page 43, Column 1; Magazine Desk

LENGTH: 3593 words

HEADLINE: Japan's Emperor Of Film

BYLINE: Ian Buruma; Ian Buruma's most recent book is ''God's Dust: A Modern Asian Journey,'' published by Farrar, Straus & Giroux.

 BODY:
WE THAT IS TO SAY, A GROUP OF Japanese journalists and I - were waiting for Akira Kurosawa. It was February, the week of Emperor Hirohito's funeral, and the director was to hold a press conference about his new film, ''Akira Kurosawa's Dreams,'' shot in various locations around Japan. It is to be released next spring.
There was a slight air of apprehension in the dingy room at Toho film studios in Tokyo, where Kurosawa filmed such masterpieces as ''To Live'' and parts of ''Seven Samurai.'' It was a bit as though we were schoolboys waiting for the stern headmaster, for Kurosawa has a reputation for being difficult.
He arrived on time, tall, smiling, in dark glasses and jeans, not at all the legendary tyrant for whom the Japanese press a long time ago coined the nickname ''Tenno,'' or ''Emperor.'' Seventy-nine years old, he looked more like a retired general who has taken up carpentry or painting. 
He began the press conference with a series of complaints about the state of Japanese cinema: ''It's as if the cinema owners don't want people to watch movies in this country; they close too early, the sound systems are terrible, the projectionists don't know their jobs. And the films they show are hardly worth seeing anyway; it's by and large the same stuff you see on TV, and why pay for what you can see at home for nothing?
''It's much better in other countries, of course. Why, in America you can watch films day and night, in comfort, properly projected. Moreover, foreign critics do their homework, and they love the cinema, unlike the so-called critics here, who are really more like public relations hacks. Well, are there any questions. . . .?''
After an embarrassed silence, a young television reporter raised his hand, scraped his throat, and, as politely as he knew how, asked whether it was true that Kurosawa was often angry on the set. The reporter might have been thinking of a memorable television documentary of the filming of Kurosawa's last epic film, ''Ran,'' in which the director was seen to torment his first assistant by flying into fearsome rages.
Kurosawa smiled sweetly: ''No, not at all, not at all. That's just an impression created by you reporters. I don't get angry often. How could I? I'd be exhausted if I did.''
He felt for his packet of cigarettes, drew one out and put it in his mouth. He looked for an ashtray, couldn't find one, and peered through his dark glasses with a hint of irritation: ''Why isn't there an ashtray here? Get me an ashtray.'' The film's production manager, Teruyo Nogami, who has worked with Kurosawa since ''Rashomon'' (1950), pointed out that we were not supposed to smoke in this room. Indeed, there was a no smoking sign right behind the director's head. ''Nonsense,'' said Kurosawa, the hint of irritation getting noticeably stronger, ''get me an ashtray at once!'' The ashtray was duly supplied and the avuncular smile reappeared. In the end, Kurosawa usually gets what he wants.
KUROSAWA STRIKES ONE AS A lonely figure in Japan, even more so than might be expected in the case of an exceptional artist. Despite his zest for making films, paintings, sculptures, anything that will serve as an outlet for his prodigious energy, he seems a bit out of step with the society around him - a society which, in his mind, appears to have let him down. Younger critics tend to regard him as an anachronism, an arrogant dinosaur trying in ever more grandiose fashion to recreate a forgotten and, today, irrelevant past. His humanistic concerns and worship of classical art seem out of place in post-modern Tokyo, which worships slick design and immediate sensual gratification. His respect for traditional craftsmanship is regarded as positively eccentric in our fast and plastic age.
Kurosawa's greatest films - among others, ''Rashomon,'' ''Seven Samurai,''
 
''Throne of Blood'' and ''The Lower
Depths'' - were made in the 1950's, the Golden Age of Japanese cinema. In those palmy times, the big studios allowed perfectionists like Kurosawa or Kenji Mizoguchi to make films as they saw fit. If Kurosawa wished to keep his crew and actors on location for days waiting for a perfect sky, the studio bosses would complain but put up with it. If he decided that the facade of a medieval castle, specially built for ''Throne of Blood,'' had to be dismantled and replaced by a three-dimensional one, because the roof didn't look right, well, the bosses didn't like that either, but they allowed him to do as he pleased. If, for the sake of realism, Kurosawa insisted on using real antiques rather than cheap approximations, the bosses shook their heads at the expense, but went along.
In those days, Japanese cinema was still a good business; a few quick formula hits more than paid for Kurosawa's art - and his art made money, too. But in the 1960's, television arrived, and the Japanese film studios never recovered from the shock. They reacted to dwindling cinema audiences by producing cheaper and less imaginative pictures, which caused the audience to dwindle further, leading to more bad films, and so on. By mid-decade, the two great masters of Japan's Golden Age, Yasujiro Ozu and Kenji Mizoguchi, had died, leaving Kurosawa to carry on the tradition.
While younger directors adapted to the new age by making cheaper films or working for television, Kurosawa refused. In December 1971, he became so demoralized that he attempted suicide. It was a year after ''Dodes'kaden,'' his first color film, had done poorly, and three years after he withdrew from a disastrous venture in Hollywood - he had been hired to direct the war movie ''Tora! Tora! Tora!'' Rumor had it that he had treated his American actors like soldiers in boot camp, to which they did not take kindly, no matter how famous the director.
True or not, the story illustrates how out of his element Kurosawa must have felt in Hollywood. He was far happier in Siberia, where he made the well-received ''Dersu Uzala'' with Soviet money in 1975.
This is not to say that Kurosawa has no following in Japan. In fact, many of his films have had considerable success at home, and he is still held in awe by most Japanese. But since the ill-fated ''Dodes'kaden,'' Kurosawa has not been able to make a single film without foreign financial support. Steven Spielberg backed ''Akira Kurosawa's Dreams,'' the special effects are done by George Lucas's company, Industrial Light & Magic, and Warner Bros. will distribute it. The movie will be released first in the United States. The involvement of these American directors, as well as that of Martin Scorsese, who has a small part in the film, is more than professional; they feel they are rescuing a man they consider a master.
''But,'' asked an American visitor in Tokyo, ''aren't the Japanese ashamed that with all their wealth they cannot support the most famous Japanese film maker in the world?'' The simple answer is: no, the Japanese are not particularly ashamed, least of all the studio bosses, who make more money on real estate than on films anyway. As Kurosawa himself puts it, ''There is nothing they hate more than taking a risk on new ideas.''
Kurosawa likes to point out that the Japanese often take pride in their artistic culture only after foreigners have given a project the seal of approval. But, in fact, success abroad can cut both ways; envious locals love to accuse Kurosawa of pandering to foreign tastes, of not being ''purely'' Japanese. When Francis Coppola came to Japan to back Kurosawa's film ''Kagemusha'' (1980), a popular Japanese novelist told the press that only foreigners liked Kurosawa; if Coppola wanted to understand the real Japan, the novelist said, he should see the films of a soft-porn director in fashion at the time.
Then too, Kurosawa's samurai pictures are famous for their homage to the American western -much to the disapproval of some Japanese critics -and he would be the last to deny his admiration for John Ford. Kurosawa has told the American critic Donald Richie that ''westerns have been done over and over again, and in the process a kind of grammar has evolved. I have learned from this grammar of the western.'' His mastery of this influence is such that two of his movies, ''Seven Samurai'' and ''Yojimbo,'' were used as models for the well-known westerns ''The Magnificent Seven'' and ''A Fistful of Dollars.''
But once tainted with the(Continued on Page 64) foreign brush, it would seem, a Japanese artist can never become ''purely'' Japanese again - he loses his sacred bond with the land, like a Brahman who leaves India. When ''Rashomon,'' a film Japanese studio bosses resisted strongly because they claimed they could not understand it, made Kurosawa world famous, winning first prize at the 1951 Venice film festival, some Japanese critics decided it proved the film catered to the Western taste for Oriental exoticism. Others declared that ''Rashomon'' was ''analytical'' and thus ''Western.'' Of course, once the prize was won, the same studio bosses who had resisted the project claimed the success as their own.
No wonder, then, that the old master tends to get tetchy with his countrymen. But why the propensity to pull the emperor down? The answer must be sought, I think, in the traditional nature of Japanese emperor worship. Emperors - real ones, that is -exist precisely to hide or divert attention from the exercise of raw power. Emperors were formally invested with supreme power without being able to exercise it, while the men who did wield power hid behind the sacred imperial symbol. A dual purpose was served: secular power was sanctified and because of the imperial aura it seemed not only natural but inherently benign.
In other words, Japanese power tends to work on the principle of dissimulation: power that does not declare its name, that is naturally benevolent, that is not really power at all. That is why powerful Japanese, though often insufferably arrogant in private, tend to be modest and self-effacing in public.
Kurosawa is not like that. He is neither modest nor self-effacing, and to achieve what he wants he is not always considerate of the ''face'' of others. His strong views are stated with a directness that many Japanese find disconcerting. His extraordinary talent, his directness, his egotism, make Kurosawa stick out in Japan. He has, at considerable personal cost, always resisted this maxim of mediocrity, as have the heroes in his films. He refuses to conform to a society that tends to celebrate the ordinary (heibon) as a virtue. Perhaps this is why in his present film, he has turned away from a time and place he so patently dislikes, to the purely imaginary world of his dreams.
''All my films are dreams,'' Kurosawa said at his press conference, and one sees what he means. Kurosawa's taste for period films, however modern in style, is evidence of a romantic temperament. There are dreamlike scenes, or, at any rate, scenes of make-believe, in several Kurosawa films. In ''One Wonderful Sunday'' (1947), for instance, we see a factory worker and his girlfriend trying to enjoy themselves with no money to spend in bombed-out Tokyo. ''If you don't believe in dreams you can't live properly,'' says the woman at one point.
And they end up inventing the things they cannot afford. They stand in an empty bandshell in the park. He pretends to be a conductor and Schubert's ''Unfinished Symphony'' swells on the soundtrack. He falters, the music stops; she asks us, the audience, to clap our hands, the music swells again, and tears come streaming down. It is Kurosawa at his sentimental worst. At his best, which is very often, Kurosawa's romantic idea that we can make things happen if only we try hard enough, merges with his sharp eye for the weakness of man, to produce great and compassionate art.
Compassion and anger often go together. And Kurosawa, as well as being a sometimes sentimental dreamer, is certainly an angry man. In his fascinating memoir, ''Something Like an Autobiography,'' there is a chapter called ''Congenital Defects,'' the first sentence of which runs: ''I am short-tempered and obstinate.'' His rage is vented on hapless assistants, on stupid critics, oafish censors, pompous authorities, or unimaginative and greedy studio bosses, but these people are merely the targets of tantrums. His real rage is an artistic one, directed only at himself, for not getting his dreams to look perfect, on paper, on the screen. Like all great artists, Kurosawa is driven by the need to get things right.
On the sets of his movies, he is constantly busy, checking a light here, a lens there, adjusting the collar of somebody's coat, making sure of every detail. On locations one sees him striding through fields scouting for different angles, followed by men half his age scrambling to keep up with him. But though he is driven to distraction by incompetent or lazy crew members, he tends to be patient with his actors. Problems are ironed out not by screaming at them - that is reserved for the man who doesn't get the water pressure right in a rain scene -but by coaxing the best out of them through long rehearsals.
Kurosawa's imagery is often violent and extreme. He has said that he likes extreme weather conditions, and indeed many of his most memorable scenes take place in lashing rains, icy snowstorms or suffocating heat. His battle scenes are among the greatest ever put on film. One recalls the long battle in the mud and rain at the end of ''Seven Samurai,'' or the death of Toshiro Mifune, impaled by dozens of arrows in ''Throne of Blood,'' or the grand slaughter of the Takeda clan in ''Kagemusha.'' I saw this last scene being shot and shall always remember Kurosawa, general-like, in his director's chair, ordering the huge mounted army to march to their deaths. All through the battle he didn't move a muscle, every fiber in his body fraught with tension. When it was over, he beamed a smile of deep satisfaction.
VIOLENCE, DREAMS and sentimentality: it is a combination often found in great generals. The source of these emotions is usually embedded in childhood. In his memoir, Kurosawa paints an interesting picture (even in prose, he is more painter than writer) of his early life. He was born in Tokyo, in 1910, the son of a soldier who took pride in his northern samurai ancestry. Pictures of his father, who later became a gym teacher, show a stern man with, as was the martial fashion at the time, a clean-shaven skull.
Akira, by his own account, was a crybaby. Pictures of him, in a kimono and an outsize hat, show a young dreamer. He was such an awkward little boy that his early teachers thought he was backward. There he was, in his words, ''A haircut like a sheltered little sissy's, a belted, double-breasted coat over short pants, red socks and low, buckled shoes. What's more, I was still in a wide-eyed daze and had a face as white as a girl's. I immediately became a laughingstock.''
What brought him out of his shell was a facility for drawing, much encouraged by an imaginative teacher called Mr. Tachikawa, to whom Kurosawa felt grateful for the rest of his life. He began to take a keen interest in such manly pursuits as kendo, Japanese sword fighting. Apparently he was rather weak and never became much good at physical exercises, but he made up for his deficiencies by sheer strength of will: he tried and tried and tried.
Toward the end of his book, Kurosawa sums up his own character: ''I am not especially strong; I am not especially gifted. I simply do not like to show my weakness, and I hate to lose, so I am a person who tries hard. That's all there is to me.''
This was to be the theme of almost all of his films: people overcoming their weakness by force of will, by trying hard. There is a Japanese word for this much admired quality, ''konjo,'' perhaps best translated as ''fighting spirit'' or simply ''guts.'' ''Konjo mono,'' literally ''guts stories,'' are a recognized genre in Japanese novels, films and comic books, a genre that frequently combines violence and sentimentality: the little fellow or girl who never gives up, no matter what it takes. If John Ford is one of Kurosawa's favorite American directors, Frank Capra is another.
Kurosawa's first and already very fine film,''Sugata Sanshiro,'' released in 1943 -a period in Japanese history when fighting spirit was especially admired - was a konjo mono. It is about the physical and, more importantly, spiritual education of a young man. Sanshiro is attracted by a judo master and wishes to acquire his skill. He succeeds and becomes quite a fighter, but the master is not satisfied, because Sanshiro is still a callow and unenlightened youth, with no control over his own strength. In an extraordinary test of will we are shown the process of Sanshiro's enlightenment. He learns a lesson about himself and by extension, about life: the raison d'etre of every Kurosawa hero.
One thing Sanshiro learns is how to contain his power, how to subdue the violence in himself and transform it into an art. As the impetuous hero in a much later samurai picture - ''Sanjuro,'' made in 1962 - is told: ''You cut well. But swords, you know, really good ones, should be kept in their scabbards, and not used at all.'' This is the typical wisdom of much samurai entertainment, the kind of thing Japanese boys still imbibe in comic books.
The theme, then, is a conventional one in Japanese art. Kurosawa's genius lies in the way he tells his stories. The style reflects the theme, for it is all about control, economy of means, simplicity. Kurosawa is known as a masterly editor of his films. He never leaves loose ends. Scenes, however marvelous, are ruthlessly discarded if they impede the flow of the story. This is why many Kurosawa films, though quite long (the original ''Seven Samurai'' was 208 minutes), never seem long. Kurosawa's sense of tempo in his best work is like that of a great composer, with an instinctive feel for the rhythm of his art.
But something happened in the late 1960's. Perhaps it had to do with his switch from black-and-white to color, or his difficulties in getting Japanese backing for his films, or his suicide attempt. Whatever the reason, there appears to be a break between ''Red Beard'' and all the subsequent movies.
It is not that the later films are failures. ''Kagemusha,'' about the tragedy of a simple man made to act the role of a great military lord, only to be discarded like a stage prop at the end, is a fine film. ''Ran,'' Kurosawa's version of ''King Lear,'' set in medieval Japan, has scenes of great beauty. ''Dodes'kaden,'' about the broken dreams of people living in an imaginary shantytown, has moments of high comedy and haunting pathos. But despite the flashes of genius that still shine through, the old genius for simplicity and pacing seems to have been lost. One has the feeling that Kurosawa is a bit like Lear, howling his rage into the stormy winds, only to contain it in the end by becoming increasingly mannered.
Donald Richie, the critic who has done more than anybody to introduce Kurosawa's films to the West, told me a story he had heard which, if true, throws an interesting light on Kurosawa's later development. On a visit to Paris in the late 1960's, Kurosawa apparently met the late Henri Langlois, legendary founder of the Cinematheque Francaise. Langlois, a brilliant but sometimes remarkably flippant man, promised to show the Japanese director a film that would change his life, and proceeded to screen Sergei Eisenstein's ''Ivan the Terrible,'' a mannered work if ever there was one. According to Richie, this event, if it actually took place, ''does seem to have changed Kurosawa's life.''
How his latest film will turn out is, of course, impossible to tell. The sets, looking rather surreal and painted in lurid colors, remind one of ''Dodes'kaden.'' The dream sequences, some set in the days of Kurosawa's youth, some in present-day Japan, some in a timeless world that can only exist in the imagination, are unlike anything Kurosawa has ever done before, unless one counts a rather embarrassing dream sequence in ''Kagemusha'' that was later deleted. The film does, however, lend a kind of symmetry to the life of a man who began as a crybaby, dreaming in art class, and went on to be a keen sword fighter and creator of willful heroes, only to return in the end to his dreams.
I saw him on the set of one of his dreams, sitting in his director's chair, frowning through his dark glasses, which were almost hidden in the shadow of his customary cap. In front of him was a kind of three-dimensional cutout of a van Gogh painting, with a white road leading through a southern French landscape to a huge, orange, van Gogh sun. Kurosawa loved van Gogh as a child, when painting saved him from feeling a failure, and he dreamt of pursuing van Gogh through one of his paintings.
Kurosawa's first assistant asked for quiet in the studio. The red lights came on, the clapper boy stood ready, the actor Akira Terao, playing the young Kurosawa, was on his mark. Kurosawa leaned forward in his chair, all concentration: ''Yoi (ready)! Staato (start)!'' The camera rolled. Terao started walking toward us, searching for van Gogh, to be played by Martin Scorsese. Kurosawa looked at Terao, very intently, seeing perhaps not Terao but his own younger self. When the scene was over, he turned to his cameraman, Takao Saito, and softly said: ''O.K.'' He beamed with satisfaction. He was making another dream come true.

SECTION: Section 6; Page 46, Column 1; Magazine Desk

LENGTH: 3951 words

HEADLINE: THE PLAYERS' MAIN MAN

BYLINE: By David A. Kaplan; David A. Kaplan writes often about baseball. He is legal affairs editor for Newsweek.

 BODY:
ONE DAY IN THE middle of the baseball season, nine Houston Astros, in New York for a series against the Mets, spent an afternoon in midtown Manhattan. For 90 minutes they sat around a conference table on the 26th floor of a Third Avenue office tower, listening to Don Fehr, a man more important to their careers than any manager, umpire or opposing pitcher. By many accounts, in fact, it is Fehr, executive director of the Major League Baseball Players Association, the players' union, who controls the future of the sport, and his message that afternoon was grim: there is a coming labor war in baseball. 
Dressed in his standard uniform of shirtsleeves and Reeboks, surrounded by shelves of law digests and photographs of legends like Willie Mays and Maury Wills, Fehr fielded the Astros' questions: Could the owners stage a lockout during spring training next February? Might there be a strike later in the year instead? How much money does the union have in reserve for the players? Will there even be baseball in 1990? In general, Fehr's verbal style is lawyerly - careful, intelligent, sometimes rambling - but his answers that day were mean and simple: Yes. Maybe. Plenty. Don't bet on it. Months later, Fehr's stance is largely the same. Sometime soon, probably around Thanksgiving, he will square off against Barry Rona, lead negotiator for the 26 club owners, in bargaining to reach a new labor agreement for Major League Baseball. If the two lawyers can't strike a deal - and their current differences appear intransigent - there may not be a baseball season come next year.
''I expect the worst,'' says Fehr.
BASEBALL'S FIVE-YEAR BASIC Agreement, which governs the employment relationship between players and owners - including the issues of free agency, salary arbitration and pension structure - doesn't expire until Dec. 31. But both camps have been blustering all year long.
Rona and the club owners openly discuss the prospect of a lockout; they've already tried to force language into the contracts of some individual players that would deprive them of pay in case of such a shutdown. And through their Player Relations Committee, which Rona serves as executive director and general counsel, the owners have put aside $200 million in ''a mutual assistance fund'' to help teams meet expenses during a season with no games.
Throughout the summer, scores of athletes routinely dropped by Fehr's office for briefings, much in the manner of the nine Astros. It was even earlier, during spring training, that Fehr traveled across Florida and Arizona with special assistant Mark Belanger, the former Baltimore Oriole shortstop, to gauge sentiment and advise players. ''Before the season ever began,'' says Joe Carter, the Cleveland Indians' outfielder and team labor representative, ''players were asking what was going to happen next year.''
Fehr stops just short of accusing management of looking to break the union, and the only reason he doesn't think the players will strike is that the owners seem so intent on drawing first blood. For its own emergency fund, the union plans to withhold at least $70 million in licensing fees that normally would have been distributed to the players.
All this preparation comes, amazingly, at a time when the game is awash in green. Major League Baseball recently signed network and cable television contracts worth $1.5 billion over four years beginning in 1990, a windfall for each owner of about $14 million per annum. Attendance is at record levels, and despite the pronouncement in April by the Pittsburgh Pirates president Carl Barger that baseball was heading into a ''financial death spiral,'' most clubs are doing better than they were five years ago. The workers aren't starving either: Players earned an average of more than half-a-million dollars this summer.
Why, then, in the name of greed and need, are the principals even contemplating a confrontation that would halt the 1990 season?
That depends on whom you ask.
Rona and the owners cite ''fiscal responsibility'' and the necessity of controlling labor costs. Fehr says salaries should be set by a free market, just as in any other billion-dollar American industry. It's time, he says, to address the inequities borne by younger ballplayers, who lack the freedom of their senior brethren to switch teams as free agents or to have their pay determined by an independent party through salary arbitration. In short, the economic terrain is simple: The players want to get more, the owners want to give less.
For Fehr, however, the stakes extend beyond baseball. ''I recognize that the public cares about these negotiations only because they affect baseball next year,'' he says. ''But the talks are important because they'll show again that something's wrong with American sports. For reasons I can't fathom, we tolerate in sports what we wouldn't accept in any other industry. Can you imagine, here at the end of the 20th century, an annual draft of scientists or exclusive territorial markets for Popsicles or two companies trading insurance salesmen without their permission? If you apply the bizarre labor rules of sports anywhere else, you start laughing.
''For the owners, baseball is all a big game. They don't care that it affects players' lives. For that, we hold them in contempt.''
INTERVIEWING DON-ald Martin Fehr (pronounced, appropriately enough, somewhere between fair and fear) is in itself a little like collective bargaining. So many questions become negotiations: Why are you asking that? Tell me what you already know. What are you really trying to get at, and how come I should answer?
''I'm a straight-shooter,'' he says. ''I never lie.'' And in labor, a field not known for fostering harmonious relations, Fehr is highly regarded for those qualities. But he can also be cagey, crafty and contentious - the stock-in-trade qualities of a negotiator. ''Sure,'' he acknowledges, ''I guess I've been called them all at different times.''
Argumentative but not pugnacious, Fehr, a boyish-looking 41, round-faced, a little pudgy, is, by nature, less labor leader than lawyer; he prefers settlement to confrontation. Unlike his mentor, Marvin Miller, the first head of the players' union and the man who taught baseball about collective bargaining, Fehr is not a labor activist at the core, a romantic about the union mission.
''I'm a politician,'' he explains. ''I think it's important for people to obtain equality of opportunity. This is one way to do it.
''I don't expect the public to view this union's members the same way as the people who work the line in Detroit. I do want people, though, to understand that there is an essential issue of fairness. Despite the money, ballplayers don't have the same rights as everybody else.''
An introspective, soft-spoken man who was born in Indiana and grew up in Prairie Village, Kan., he has been at the helm of the players' union since 1983, but is uncomfortable even now with his notoriety. He dislikes being photographed and many of his interviews are only for background. His interests are eclectic: He likes to go to the ball park with his family; he is also a voracious reader of history, philosophy and esoterica. ''When we're on a plane,'' says Lauren Rich, an assistant union counsel, ''I watch the movie. Don reads about string theory in Scientific American.''
The son of a businessman, Fehr came to the union serendipitously. Following graduation from law school in 1973, he clerked for United States District Court Judge Elmo Hunter of Kansas City, Mo., then joined a small respected labor law firm there. When the landmark arbitration decree, creating baseball's first free agents, was issued in 1975, baseball's owners marched into Federal court in Kansas City to try to overturn it. The union sought a local firm to oppose the owners and chose Fehr's. Because of his experiences in Federal court, the partners had Fehr work on it. They won.
Subsequently, in 1977, Marvin Miller asked Fehr to join the union staff as general counsel. At the end of 1982, Miller retired, and Kenneth E. Moffett - who had been the Federal mediator during the strike that interrupted the 1981 baseball season -took over as executive director. Moffett was dismissed after a 10-month tenure, and the players ultimately turned to Fehr, who agreed to take the title of ''acting executive director'' through 1985, a kind of audition. Now in the fourth year of a six-year contract, at a current salary of $450,000 - one of the highest of any sports union leader - Fehr works a grueling schedule. His duties include administration of lucrative licensing deals, supervising a $440 million pension fund and advising individual players on such matters as drug testing and club discipline. In this season of the Pete Rose gambling scandal, he also handled endless press inquiries, though he is quick to point out that he was not officially involved with Rose, who, as former manager of the Cincinnati Reds, was not eligible for most union services. All this while preparing for the coming negotiations.
Fehr says he wishes for a time when he is not constantly butting heads with the baseball owners. Looking out his office window at a city he doesn't particularly love, he muses about returning to the heartland to teach college or practice law or, he jokes, to have a ''normal labor job like representing the Eastern Airlines machinists.''
BAD BLOOD AT BASEBALL'S bargaining table has been around for nearly a quarter-century. Since 1966 - when Marvin Miller arrived from the United Steelworkers Union and led the players' union into the modern era - there have been five work stoppages: strikes in 1972, 1980, 1981 and 1985, and a lockout in the spring of 1976.
It wasn't always so. Before the union's emergence, going back to the old National League and American Association of the 1880's, clubs treated players like chattel - and got away with it. Under baseball's feudal ''reserve system,'' players, unless traded, sold or fired were forever bound to their clubs. A Yankee, say, could never jump to the Dodgers, so owners set salaries at their pleasure. It was a textbook monopoly, remaining in effect only because of baseball's exemption from Federal antitrust laws, granted in 1922.
Shrewd and impassioned, Marvin Miller was able to unite unsophisticated athletes who'd thought life under the owners' cartel wasn't so bad. By the early 1970's, Miller had achieved for players the right to arbitrate grievances, a limited ability by veteran players to block trades, and the right of all but first- and second-year players to have their salaries determined by arbitration. While losing a round in 1972 when the United States Supreme Court narrowly upheld baseball's antitrust immunity, Miller's crowning moment came three years later with the establishment of free agency.
In 1975, two pitchers, the Los Angeles Dodgers' Andy Messersmith and Dave McNally of the Montreal Expos, played the season without contracts. The union filed a grievance on their behalf, arguing that the reserve system contemplated only one automatic contract renewal for an unsigned player. The owners, despite warnings about the foolishness of (Continued on Page 54) their position, claimed perpetual rights. An arbitrator, Peter Seitz, heard the dispute, and two days before Christmas he issued the ruling that revolutionized the game's economics: Messersmith and McNally were proclaimed free agents, and their services were available to the highest bidder - or anyone else. Thus could any player become free a year following his refusal to sign a contract.
Baseball's rulers were apoplectic: The owners went to court to block the Seitz edict (and lost); they locked the players out of training camps (then-Commissioner Bowie Kuhn eventually opened them, though admonishing that free agency could ruin the sport); they appealed to public sympathy (which, typically, wasn't great on either side). Finally, in July 1976, management and labor reached a four-year deal, an agreement that retained the reserve system - except that players with six or more years in the majors were eligible for free agency.
It might have appeared that Miller had yielded a lot of turf. But in fact, the restrictions on the supply of free agents created a bidding war among club owners for the few available stars; this, coupled with the salary arbitration available to many other players, drove up pay. In 1977, average compensation for a major league player rose 50 percent to $76,000. Two years later, it was $113,500; this season it was $513,731.
During several subsequent negotiations, management sought ways to rein in its own profligate tendencies. Owners suggested percentage limits on pay increases (after all, there are limits on pay cuts) and salary caps based on length of service. They got just about nothing from the union, except in the most recent collective bargaining agreement, in 1985, when Fehr, leading the players for the first time, yielded a crumb; players previously eligible for salary arbitration after two years in the major leagues, now had to play three. It's a concession for which he still hears criticism.
MEANWHILE, BIDDING FOR free agents continued to resemble an auction for the crown jewels - until the off-season of 1985.
That winter, the 9-year-old free-agent market vanished. Teams simply ceased going after their rivals' talent, stars were forced to return to their old clubs and a few players found no work at all. The same happened in 1986. Owners called it fiscal sanity; Don Fehr charged collusion, orchestrated by then-commissioner Peter Ueberroth. In two sweeping grievances, the union accused management of violating the Basic Agreement by ''acting in concert'' to destroy free agency and reduce salaries.
After lengthy hearings, two respective arbitrators found a conspiracy and ruled for the union. Preliminary damages of $10.5 million in the 1985 case were awarded in late August; potentially tens of millions more may follow. Awards have not yet been decided in the 1986 case. A separate collusion grievance is pending for the 1987 season and one is possible for 1988.
For Fehr, the collusion cases - his victories notwithstanding - remain the key obstacle to breaking bread with the owners. ''How is it I negotiate another contract with them when I assume they'll just go out and violate it again?'' he asks. ''I don't trust anything they tell me. That's what makes this negotiation different.''
Without some declaration of wrongdoing, Fehr says, any handshake on substantive matters - the terms of free agency and salary arbitration, pension contributions, minimum pay, league expansion and the length of a contract - is meaningless because ''the owners have already demonstrated they won't live by their word.''
The owners continue to confess nothing. ''The clubs don't believe they violated the Basic Agreement,'' says Barry Rona, their labor representative, ''but they accept the arbitrators' decisions and will abide by them.''
Shortly before he died on Sept. 1, Commissioner A. Bartlett Giamatti said his concern would be ''to preserve the integrity of the 1990 season,'' although he noted that as commissioner, elected by the owners, he had no institutional role at the bargaining table. ''Since the commissioner lacks equal suasion over both sides,'' Giamatti said, ''he doesn't have it over either, and it is silly to expect him to make labor policy with a wave of the wand.'' The current commissioner, Francis T. (Fay) Vincent Jr., is equally persuaded of his lack of influence. ''Bart's view is my view,'' he says.
That inherent passivity and the fact that the owners' agenda in the last decade has largely been set by the union's demands, mean Fehr will be at the vortex. ''More than anyone, Don will determine if there will be a settlement,'' says Bowie Kuhn, who served as baseball's commissioner from 1969 to 1984.
TO MARVIN MILLER, now 72 and living on Manhattan's Upper East Side, labor causes don't leave a lot of middle ground. It may be in the nature of things that as the players' association matures and accomplishes its root goals, its leadership takes on a less harsh perspective. But for Miller, there are no shades of gray; to him, Don Fehr, even with his combativeness, is just too deferential.
''I don't mean Don is wrong, but he and I have different standards in labor-management relationships,'' Miller says. ''This is Don's first union. He's not as aggressive as he should be with people who lie and cheat. That doesn't show he wants to look weak, but it shows he lacks the background of a trade unionist and it shows a lawyer's mentality.''
Miller criticizes Fehr for ''taking backward steps for the first time'' in the 1985 negotiations, which, in addition to the compromise that players complete an extra year to be eligible for salary arbitration, reduced the percentage of television revenues contributed to player pensions. He says these concessions resulted not from the union ''selling the members out, but from the leadership not preparing and educating the players in the months leading up to bargaining.'' ''Don did fine in the last negotiations, but this one will be a truer test,'' says Don Baylor, a former player who was the chief American League representative in the 1985 talks. ''The players, with their high salaries, are more complacent. When I first came up in 1972, players read the Sporting News; now they're reading the Wall Street Journal. Don has to mobilize attitudes.''
Baylor, one of the most active ballplayers in the labor movement during the last decade, admits the union membership in 1985 was divided over salary arbitration. ''Younger players were mad,'' he recalls. ''Ask them who Don Fehr was and a few would tell you he's the guy who sold them out.''
But Baylor says the rift between young and old was inevitable given the remarkable achievements under Miller that made many players rich. ''Don has a tougher motivational job than Marvin ever did,'' says Baylor. ''Marvin came first and is a god. When he arrived, players were making $6,000 a year. It wasn't too hard to rally them. Today, players stand to lose a lot more when they're asked to make sacrifices. What they forget is that somebody 10 and 15 years ago made sacrifices for them.''
Miller and Fehr themselves say they are professionally close. Miller, moreover, stresses that his comments are isolated objections. ''Don's done well and he'll do better this time,'' he says.
Fehr, sometimes defensive about the relationship, says he and Miller coincide completely on the union's overall agenda, and that it's ridiculous to think he feels himself in Miller's shadow. ''I trust Marvin's instincts like no one else's,'' Fehr says. ''But that doesn't mean we always agree on the details.''
WHILE MILLER may tweak his successor now and then, it is obviously the barons of baseball who are Fehr's adversary. And the collusion cases and their aftermath have given him what he lacked in 1985 - a unifying cause to rouse the troops across economic lines.
Yet the negotiator for the owners says he's not itching (Continued on Page 101) for a fight at all. ''We're not looking to antagonize anybody,'' says the 48-year-old Barry Rona, who notes that he began his career doing union work, but has been with the Player Relations Committee, the owners' labor arm, since 1969. ''It was Marvin who personalized things. Don may perceive his job as maximizing rhetoric and whipping up hysteria, but he and I are lawyers and we're trained to deal with issues. We should be able to do it in the spirit of professionalism.''
Fehr responds incredulously to that kind of sentiment, querying if this is the same Barry Rona who recommended lockout language in player contracts for the 1990 season. Rona sees no inconsistency. ''I made that suggestion so owners would not be totally vulnerable to the union dictating when they would have the upper hand by calling a strike later in the summer,'' he says. ''The clubs are simply maintaining their options, as the union always has.''
''Maintaining options'' is a favorite term of those who conduct labor negotiations. Because collective bargaining is a game of chicken: Whoever blinks first loses. So neither side much wants to discuss the proposals it will bring to the table, lest it tip off the opponent about expectations. In informal talks last winter, only minor issues were explored and ''even then, the conversations didn't go anywhere,'' says Paul Molitor, who plays third base for the Milwaukee Brewers and is now the chief American League labor representative.
Rona does acknowledge, rather ominously, that ''it is fair to assume that the salary structure of Major League Baseball will be a central issue in the negotiations. Salary arbitration and free agency are two methods by which you set salaries at the present time, but they aren't necessarily the only ones.''
That statement would seem to hint at a possible management demand for a fundamental restructuring of player pay, perhaps the cap on salaries that the former Seattle Mariners owner George Argyros has suggested, or a collectively bargained salary scale. Rona won't comment on those specifics. He speaks vaguely of aiming for a ''partnership'' with the players, but offers no detail except to note that the concept clearly doesn't contemplate players getting a piece of any clubs.
Fehr isn't satisfied with the status quo either. He says that the lot of the younger ballplayers will rank high on his agenda, especially because of the givebacks in 1985. ''The abuse taken by players in their first three years is greater than anyone could have anticipated four years ago,'' Fehr says. ''They have their salaries set by the clubs without even the semblance of bargaining.'' The effect on pay is dramatic: In 1988, players with two to three years of major league experience - just under the arbitration cutoff - earned an average of $185,673; those with three to four years made $428,805.
And there is the intractable subject of collusion that Fehr will not forget, the matter of principle as much as principal. Fehr angrily insists that any collective bargaining agreement will have to contain provisions that deter owner conspiracies to restrict free agency. Precedent for such language exists in basketball. Wary of what baseball owners apparently did in 1985 and 1986, the National Basketball Players Association, according to its executive director, Charles Grantham, demanded and got draconian penalties put into its current labor contract; owners who collude are liable to fines of $1 million and punitive damages up to three times what a victimized player has lost due to conspiracy. Rona says these terms are unnecessary and that Fehr is grandstanding.
Bowie Kuhn, the former baseball commissioner who presided over four work stoppages, tries to be optimistic. ''With both sides prospering,'' he observes, ''you would think there would be someplace for them to compromise.''
But Bart Giamatti, the late baseball commissioner who had tried to downplay prognostications of doom, acknowledged big trouble approaching. ''There are deep, difficult issues between the sides,'' he said in an interview in July.
''My greatest concern is that this dispute unfolds as a morality play,'' says Giamatti's successor, Fay Vincent. ''The danger is interjecting morality into economics. When it becomes the white hats against the black hats, you get the real risk of deadlock.''
Perhaps, indeed, darkness is destined. In the voice of baseball's reluctant labor warrior, there is both resignation and disgust. ''I fear the apocalypse,'' says Don Fehr.

PUB-DATE: October 29, 1989

SECTION: Section 6; Part 2, Page 23, Column 1; Home Entertaining Magazine

LENGTH: 2318 words

HEADLINE: AMERICAN CONTEMPORARY;
The New Business Lunch: Offbeat Restaurants

BYLINE: By BRYAN MILLER

 BODY:
DICK BYRNE, AN EXECUTIVE vice president of a New York advertising agency, is a veteran of more long, bibulous business lunches than he cares to recall. Only 10 years ago, these affairs were routinely held at such Establishment bastions as La Cote Basque, The Four Seasons and Christ Cella. On a recent occasion, however, when clients came in from out of town, Mr. Byrne took them to a whimsical Chinese restaurant with a barnyard motif called Pig Heaven.
''It was a big hit with them,'' he said. ''Something very different, and fun.''
Bob Cummins, a lawyer in Chicago, used to take clients to such baronial settings as the University Club of Chicago or The Empire Room at the Palmer House and Towers hotel. ''Those places were almost de rigueur for leading lights in the Chicago financial, legal and business communities,'' Mr. Cummins said. Today, he is more likely to take business associates to lunch at Shaw's Crab House, a bustling, informal seafood place, or Bistro 110, an informal French restaurant with a lively dining bar and moderately priced menu. 
Ruth Manton, the owner and president of Aries Design Management, which represents fashion designers and celebrities, said she used to be a devotee of La Cote Basque and La Grenouille for business lunches. ''But now I don't have the time for a big production,'' she explained. ''And I don't want all those calories.'' Her current haunts include Bice, the snazzy Milan-style trattoria (''I can have pasta and a salad and get out in an hour and a half''), and Aglio e Olio (formerly Cafe Between the Bread), a breezy, casual spot specializing in lunch salads.
Such scenarios are increasingly common today, as the hallowed American business lunch becomes more casual, more adventuresome and - dare we say it? - occasionally fun. The reasons for the trend are varied. For one, the new abstemiousness, prompted by health concerns and changing life styles, has all but eliminated the proverbial three-martini lunch (see accompanying piece). White wine and mineral water are the current social lubricants.
''There is no more cocktail chitter-chatter,'' said Malcolm Forbes, who rates restaurants in Forbes magazine with particular attention to their suitability for business meetings. ''Most successful people are busier than they ever had MILLER spread FFFFFF to be, and there is no time for the three-hour lunch. It's more likely to be noon to 2:00.''
Jason Epstein, editorial director of Random House, observes: ''I haven't seen a three-course lunch with cocktails in a long, long time.'' At The Four Seasons, which is synonymous with the term power lunch, many of the clientele do not drink at all, said Alex von Bidder, the general manager. ''Those who drink wine tend to order a good bottle, but not finish it,'' he said. ''We also serve a lot of iced tea, iced coffee and iced espresso.''
THE TRUNCATED BUSINESS LUNCH IS transpiring in settings that just 5 or 10 years ago would have been considered frightfully downscale, if not undignified. Jim Weinstein, an advertising executive with Chiat/ Day/Mojo in Los Angeles, often takes clients to the clamorous and trendy West Beach Cafe in Venice. ''Clients are looking for an experience as much as the food,'' he said. ''They like an unusual place with an unusual crowd of people, different from what they normally see.'' He recently took a group to Ivy at the Shore, a movie-industry hangout with a regional American menu. ''We had meat loaf,'' he said.
B. Wallace Rucker Jr., an investment banker in Seattle, said he often takes business clients to informal places like Shuckers, a publike oyster bar and seafood restaurant in The Four Seasons Olympic Hotel. ''A lot of the formal, heavier-style restaurants that used to be open for lunch are now open just for dinner,'' he said, explaining one result of the new trend.
The hotel's lavish formal restaurant, The Georgian, is not as popular for lunch. Observed William Mackay, the hotel's manager: ''People have the impression, which is not really correct, that they can't get in and out of The Georgian in an hour or hour and a half.''
Mr. Epstein's Random House office is within a short walk of such celebrated Manhattan restaurants as Lutece, Aurora and The Four Seasons, yet recently he has frequented those spots only at dinner. At midday, he favors such neighborhood haunts as Stephanie's, a modest American cafe, where he recently had lunch with the author John Gregory Dunne. ''It's comfortable, not too loud and the food is light,'' he remarked.
Executives like Mr. Forbes note that clients and customers are no longer as impressed by the lavish trappings of the formal - and pricey - business lunch. ''Today you don't wow a customer by where you take him; you woo him by respecting his time,'' he commented.
Economy plays some part in the downscaling of business lunches, but a relatively minor one compared with economy of time, according to executives interviewed in major American cities. Another factor often cited is the heightened curiosity about cuisine among business people, particularly about ethnic foods and regional American cooking.
''Most cities today have their fancy French restaurants, and all their atmospheres are more or less the same,'' said Clint Clifford, an advertising executive with Wells, Rich, Greene in New York. ''So when they come here, they would rather see something that is special to Manhattan, like some funky place downtown.''
No reliable statistics are available to quantify the trend, but a critic's survey of restaurateurs, purveyors and trade journals indicates that lunchtime business at luxury establishments is off by as much as 25 percent. (The decrease is attributable in part to the 1986 tax law that limited deductions for business lunches to 80 percent of the tab.) And much of the slack is clearly being taken up by informal cafes, grills, trattorias and the new gastronomic hybrid known as the American bistro.
Lavish corporate entertaining is not entirely passe, however. When it occurs, though, chances are it is at dinner.
''If you really want to tie on the feedbag and go all the way - say, with dinner at Lutece,'' said Malcolm Forbes, ''you tend to do it at night.''
 
NEW YORK CITY
 
BELLEVUES, 496 Ninth Avenue, at 38th Street (212) 967-7855
Little more than a rejuvenated diner on a tawdry strip of Manhattan's Ninth Avenue, the French bistro Bellevues is a welcome oasis for lawyers and garment district executives. Customers sit on aqua banquettes - or if alone or in a rush, at the counter -and partake of such rustic fare as pork terrine, boudin noir with apples and onions, and calf's liver with bacon and onions. Service is brisk and upbeat. Prices are appropriately dinerlike, with lunch entrees from $4.95 to $13.50.
Cash only.
 
BRIDGE CAFE, 279 Water Street (212) 227-3344
Proximity to Wall Street and a dearth of serious restaurants in the South Street Seaport area have made this weather-beaten tavern-style restaurant an enduring favorite within the financial community. The menu offers basic American-style fare that is wholesome, fresh and generally well seasoned. Service is prompt. Lunch entrees run from $7.95 to $13.95. No reservations at lunch.
All major credit cards.
 
PARK BISTRO, 414 Park Avenue South, at 28th Street (212) 689-1360
Last year a new chef turned this languishing bistro into one of the most popular lunch spots in the area. The setting is plain, but the aromatic French Provencal fare, with lunch entrees in the $13 to $24 range, is anything but that. Considering the crowds at peak hours, pacing is relatively prompt, but reservations are de rigueur, preferably a day or two in advance.
American Express and Diners Club.
 
PERIYALI, 35 West 20th Street (212) 463-7890
Just a few years ago, the notion of upscale Greek food in a stylish Mediterranean setting was revolutionary in this town of gyros and moussaka parlors, but Periyali has shown how appealing this cuisine can be. The abstemious business crowd at lunch goes for the superb wine-marinated grilled octopus and grilled fresh porgies swathed with olive oil. Entrees are under $20. Some fine Greek wines are served at bargain prices, and the viscous espresso will keep the diner going all afternoon. Waiters are friendly and well informed about the food.
American Express, MasterCard and Visa.
 
CHICAGO
 
FRONTERA GRILL, 445 North Clark Street (312) 661-1434
A colorful Mexican cafe festooned with exotic folk art, Frontera Grill is one of the most authentic restaurants of its type north of the border states. The regional Mexican lunch menu begins with small plates of tasty morsels such as ceviche of fish over tostadas and chicken taquitos, followed by a roster of dynamic charcoal-grilled fish and meat in assorted guises (some spicy, some mild, all complex). An extensive list of Mexican beers is available, as well as an eclectic lineup of wines chosen for their stamina in the company of such assertive fare. Lunch is very reasonable, with entrees under $10. The staff is intelligent and enthusiastic. Reservations are taken for lunch for a party of five or more. Closed Monday.
All major credit cards.
 
SCOOZI!, 410 West Huron, one block west of Orleans Street (312) 943-5900
At the dinner hour, this post-modern, neo-Italianate warehouse-like space makes a night game at Wrigley Field look sedate. The lunch scene is far more tranquil, and the crowd less aggressively trendy. Businessmen shed their dark jackets, roll up their sleeves and nibble on wafer-thin pizzas, vibrant salads and a changing selection of pastas and mostly northern Italian entrees. The two mezzanines on either side of the room, with big comfortable booths, are favored by larger groups from downtown offices nearby. The staff is relentlessly cheerful and earnest. Prices are right, too: A recent lunch for two, including drinks, came to $50 before tip.
All major credit cards.
 
SHAW'S CRAB HOUSE, 21 East Hubbard Street (312) 527-2722
This sprawling fish house evokes Chicago's rollicking jazz age without resorting to theme-park silliness. Beyond a big, lively bar is the knotty-pine and tiled dining room with spacious, paper-draped tables and high-backed banquettes. The light, assiduously fresh seafood and fast-paced service make Shaw's one of Chicago's prime business lunch spots. The menu is more adventuresome than that of most fish houses, perhaps because the chef is French, and offers everything from excellent charred raw tuna with watercress to winter oysters from Chile. Entrees at lunch peak at $22. The wine list is exceptionally well chosen and bargain priced.
All major credit cards.
 
LOS ANGELES
 
CITRUS, 6703 Melrose Avenue (213) 857-0034
A breezy, sunny French restaurant with an outdoor patio, Citrus remains one of the hottest restaurants in Los Angeles, at lunch as well as dinner. The California-inspired French nouvelle-cuisine entrees and stunning desserts make it a prime spot for local executives to show off the city's best to out-of-towners. Lunch entrees range between $10 and $14. Service is professional; reservations are necessary.
American Express, MasterCard and Visa.
 
PAZZIA, 755 North La Cienega Boulevard, West Hollywood (213) 657-9271
This Florentine- and Roman-style trattoria, dominated by a giant mural depicting a bicycle race, draws a stylish business lunch crowd with its elaborate salads, carpaccios, light pastas and grilled entrees. Prices range from $14 to $22. The staff is efficient in an insouciant sort of way. Closed Monday. American Express, MasterCard and Visa.
 
WEST BEACH CAFE, 60 North Venice Boulevard, Venice (213) 823-5396
Just a block from the ocean, this perpetually hip, stylishly elegant cafe attracts a lively midday crowd of business lunchers. The contemporary California fare - with lunch entrees averaging about $12 - is light and sprightly, sometimes adventurous, and the wine list is superior. The noise level can make conversation trying at peak hours, though. Service is casually efficient. Closed Monday. All major credit cards.
 
SEATTLE
 
CAFE SPORT, 2020 Western Avenue (206) 443-6000
A spiffy, pastel-colored Art Deco cafe near the city's bustling Pike Place Market, Cafe Sport draws a local business clientele as well as out-of-town tourists. The food is light, focused on regional seafood, and prepared with an Oriental accent. Among the offerings are peppery pan-fried oysters with cucumber and sprout salad, and steamed Pacific mussels in a lemony, pepper-edged broth. Lunch is a bargain, with most entrees under $10. The staff, though casually paced, is well versed on the food.
All major credit cards.
 
McCORMICK'S FISH HOUSE & BAR, Fourth Avenue and Columbia Street (206) 682-3900
At noon on any weekday, the bar of this masculine Irish restaurant in the center of Seattle's commercial and corporate district is packed with office workers who order sandwiches, salads and chowders and seafood specials. The more spacious, wood-paneled main dining room is geared to fast-paced executives, and serves basic American fare with an emphasis on fresh local seafood. Entrees for lunch range from $5 to $10. Waiters are prompt; reservations are recommended.
All major credit cards.
 
SHUCKERS, Four Seasons Olympic Hotel 411 University Street, at Seneca Street (206) 621-1984
This wood-paneled tavern and oyster bar is the casual counterpart to the hotel's luxurious Georgian Room. Five or six varieties of local oysters are available daily, as well as a wide selection of wines and beers from the Pacific Northwest. Seafood stews and simply prepared fresh fish are the most popular dishes at lunch. Prices are extremely moderate (lunch entrees from $7 to $14). Cheerful waiters are well-schooled on seafood.
All major credit cards.
