The New York Times

PUB-DATE: October 29, 1989

SECTION: Section 7; Page 26, Column 1; Book Review Desk

LENGTH: 1580 words

HEADLINE: BOOK & BUSINESS;
THE SELLING OF DNA

BYLINE: By NATALIE ANGIER; Natalie Angier, the author of ''Natural Obsessions: The Search for the Oncogene,'' frequently writes about biology and medicine.

 BODY:

GENE DREAMS
Wall Street, Academia, and the Rise of Biotechnology.
By Robert Teitelman.
237 pp. New York: Basic Books. $19.95.
From cold fusion to high-temperature superconductivity, from robotics to neural networks, many of the recent ''revolutions'' in science and technology seem to have the half-life of an average teen-age crush. Each one strides onto center stage to the boom of the media's timpani, promising to revitalize our sluggish economy, trounce our competitors, light up our homes, levitate our trains and otherwise make life easier, cheaper and more entertaining for all Americans. And almost inevitably, the ''miracle breakthroughs'' prove disappointing: the science behind them is either wrong or too difficult to meet the demand for instant results. 
Perhaps the biggest letdown in recent history has been the business of biotechnology, which involves the manufacture of vast quantities of genetic material by isolating the DNA from the cells of one species (usually human) and splicing it into the cells of another (usually bacteria).
Not only did biotechnology seem to guarantee America's resurgence on the world market - after all, we invented genetic engineering - it also held forth the hope of curing our most intractable scourges. Through recombinant DNA and related techniques, enterprising scientists would spin out amazing new therapeutics to thwart cancer, heart disease, diabetes and infectious diseases. Even the names of the vaunted disease-busting agents had a muscular rhythm to them: interferon, interleukin, monoclonal antibodies. They had to work. And if they worked, some lucky visionaries would get very, very rich.
As Robert Teitelman recounts with delightful verve, occasional bite and persuasive detail in ''Gene Dreams,'' the promise of biotechnology whipped Wall Street into an unprecedented state of near-religious febrility. In the early- to mid-1980's, investors who knew as little about DNA and RNA as they did about muons and quarks poured tens of millions of dollars into a passel of aggressive biotechnology ventures, among them Genentech, Cetus and Biogen. More astonishing still, the investments were made despite one niggling detail: all the biotech companies went public long before they had generated a single marketable or effective product. Their goods were either in the most embryonic stages of development and testing, or remained to be discovered. A few astute observers realized that the Wall Street frenzy - dubbed ''biomania'' - was faintly ridiculous. ''Interferon,'' one scientist told a Forbes magazine reporter in 1980, ''is a substance you rub on stockbrokers.''
Mr. Teitelman, a writer for both Financial World and Oncology Times, begins his tale with the story of Genentech, the largest and most ambitious of the fledgling biofirms. Genentech was the creation of Herbert Boyer, one of the fathers of gene splicing, and Robert Swanson, a venture capitalist turned entrepreneur. Based in South San Francisco, Calif., Genentech was to be an entirely new species of company, one that ''could combine both the pure science of the academic world and the product development of the drug industry.'' It hired employees from the legions of post-doctoral fellows being churned out by the universities and it cultivated a freewheeling atmosphere with Friday afternoon beer bashes, during which Mr. Swanson, Genentech's chief executive officer, often dressed up in a grass skirt or a bumblebee outfit.
The quirky, folksy formula looked like the future of corporate America. And though Genentech had nothing immediately salable, Wall Street wanted it. On Oct. 14, 1980, Genentech and its underwriters offered one million shares of stock at $35 each. That was quite high for an untested company - but not high enough. Within 30 minutes after market opening, the stock had been bid up to $89 a share by eager buyers - a record for an initial public offering - before dropping down to $70 on the final bell.
The Genentech offering was a revelation to many other biologists and entrepreneurs, including those who started up Genetic Systems, a Seattle-based operation and the primary object of Mr. Teitelman's attention. In the Genentech mold, Genetic Systems was the dual creation of a scientific luminary: Robert Nowinski, then with the Fred Hutchinson Cancer Research Center in Seattle, and David and Isaac Blech, brothers and financial wizards. Yet it was the ''strong, aggressive'' Bob Nowinski, with his ''quick wit, boundless confidence, and a real talent for articulating the romance of science,'' who was to wheel and deal so relentlessly that his little company became someone else's.
Genetic Systems was built around Mr. Nowinski's specialty, monoclonal antibodies - designer molecules or ''magic bullets'' that can home in on specific targets, such as viral proteins and cancer cells. Mr. Nowinski had a two-fold plan: to develop monoclonals for the diagnosis of venereal and other infectious diseases; and to use the profits from the diagnostic kits to fashion more sophisticated therapeutic monoclonals that would destroy tumor cells. Even the first step required money, however, so the company's founders cobbled together a complex financial plan and took Genetic Systems public in June of 1981. Trading once again was manic, millions of dollars cascaded into the company coffers and research began. So, too, did an attitude of extravagance - business affairs were catered by the priciest gourmet shop in Seattle, while Bob Nowinski drove a company Ferrari and always went first class.
Financial troubles were not far behind, and by the end of 1981 the company was ''burning'' cash at a frightening rate. To ease the pressure, Mr. Teitelman tells us, Mr. Nowinski and other principals went chasing money again, offering warrants, limited partnerships and similar paper promises. Mr. Nowinski also struck a deal with George Todaro, a renowned biologist at the National Cancer Institute, to start an offshoot of Genetic Systems, dubbed Oncogen, which would explore the potential profitability of research in cancer genes.
Indeed, striking deals seemed to become a habit with Mr. Nowinski. Whenever Genetic Systems ran into difficulty developing a particular product, he negotiated with other, better-equipped companies - an approach that, while broadening the technical base of the enterprise, effectively spread real or potential profits too thin. And despite the best efforts of scores of young scientists, some biological problems were just too complicated, too messy, for the corporate balance sheet. Far from being the ''magic bullets'' of Mr. Nowinski's dream, monoclonal antibodies have not proved to be the long-sought cure for cancer.
By 1984, Genetic Systems' outlook was bleak. Profits from its diagnostic kits were barely dribbling in, executives were at each other's throats, the accounting records were in chaos and nobody knew how much cash was on hand. A year later, Bristol-Myers, an old-fashioned, bureaucracy-riddled, distinctly nonentrepreneurial pharmaceuticals giant, bought Genetic Systems. ''The [biotechnology] revolution clearly was dead,'' the author writes, ''or it had not yet begun.''
Whether explaining difficult biological concepts or tortuous financial stratagems, Mr. Teitelman writes with lucid grace and an insider's grasp. He points out that there have been some genuine successes in biotechnology, most notably Genentech's development of tissue-plasminogen activator, which dissolves clots in clogged arteries. Yet Mr. Teitelman believes that nature is profoundly complicated, and that the battle against cancer might well be ''not a sweeping victory'' of ''powerfully elegant simplicity,'' but a ''long, difficult war one tumor type, one disease, at a time.'' No stock prospectus can make it otherwise.
 
THE PROOF IS IN THE PUDDING
Biotechnology sold itself on the belief that it could remedy the most profound economic and medical ills of the age, and please Wall Street as well. . . . Talk of medical breakthroughs became pretexts to raise more money; capital accumulation was confused with speculation; rhetoric was mistaken for reality. . . . Genetic Systems, for all its flaws, was a solid scientific enterprise; Alfacell, on the other hand, has proven thus far to possess the substantiality of smoke. But both appeared . . . dressed in similar gaudy costumes. They were joined by scores of others. Most featured the same apparatus: advisory boards, mice, consultants, forecasts, and laboratory miracles. . . . Like the art market, biotech posed complexities and uncertainties that created a role for experts as powerful and indispensable guides. . . .
Selling Genetic Systems or Alfacell was not that much different from selling, say, a painting by Warhol, Robert Rauschenberg, or Jasper Johns. . . . Substance or technique begin to matter less than ideas and style. . . . Fortunately . . . art and medicine are finally very different things. Art must wait for history to judge its merit; until then, the game belongs to dealers and critics. In biotechnology and medicine, theories must sooner or later prove themselves among the sick and dying - an unforgiving jury - and in the marketplace. . . . Does the tumor shrink? Are there side effects? Can the technology be sold profitably? . . . Does it provide much help to the physician? In that way, it finally gains exit from the world of fashion and hype.
 
From ''Gene Dreams.''

The New York Times

PUB-DATE: October 29, 1989

SECTION: Section 7; Page 42, Column 2; Book Review Desk

LENGTH: 1090 words

HEADLINE: BOOKS & BUSINESS;
DAMAGE CONTROL DIDN'T WORK

BYLINE: By JEFFERY E. GARTEN; Jeffrey E. Garten is a managing director of the Stamford Company, a New York investment bank.

 BODY:

THE FALL OF THE HOUSE OF HUTTON
By Donna Sammons Carpenter and John Feloni.
322 pp. New York:
Henry Holt & Company. $19.95.
 
SUDDEN DEATH
The Rise and Fall of E. F. Hutton.
By Mark Stevens.
298 pp. New York:
NAL Books/New American Library. $19.95. 
An unusual number of America's once great companies fell upon hard times in the 1980's. Deregulation, foreign competition, roller-coaster interest rates were some of the causes. But for the most part, the big problems were bad management and infighting within the companies themselves.
And so it was with E.F. Hutton & Company, which barely avoided liquidation before being bought and rescued by Shearson Lehman Brothers last year. ''The Fall of the House of Hutton'' and ''Sudden Death'' tell essentially the same tale. This venerable securities firm had an 85-year franchise as the most illustrious stockbroker to America's rich and famous. When E.F. Hutton talked to the gang in Palm Beach, Palm Springs, Southampton and Zermatt everybody was listening. The stock market crash of October 1987 dealt the company a death blow, but the hemorrhaging had begun years earlier when it pleaded guilty to 2,000 counts of mail and wire fraud in connection with illegal use of bank overdrafts. In fact, the scandal never seemed to end, caroming from Congressional investigations to lawsuits to endlessly bad publicity, and resulting in the steady defection of key employees and customers.
If you are looking for a story of villains and good guys, or of outsized greed, this isn't it. Rather the downfall of Hutton, as described in these two books, is a sad account of Wall Streeters unable to adjust to changing times. It is a portrait of people at the top of one of the country's most famous securities firms who were totally unequipped to overcome a major crisis, or even to recognize its full dimensions. At the center was Robert M. Foman, described in both books as an eccentric, heavy-drinking executive who ran the company as if it were his personal plaything. In the organization that he created, professional control and supervision was nonexistent. There was no real chief financial officer, no functioning audit committee, no operational oversight of the ways different businesses interacted. The board of directors was, until the final months, composed mostly of employees who merely rubber-stamped Mr. Foman's decisions. Backstabbing, bad decisions and indecision were rampant. Deep clashes occurred between the brokers in the field, who generated most of Hutton's revenues by selling stocks to rich people, and the white-shoe investment bankers, who wanted Hutton to focus on earning fees from advising clients on mergers and other big deals.
In ''The Fall of the House of Hutton,'' Donna Sammons Carpenter, the author of ''The Price Waterhouse Book of Personal Financial Planning,'' and John Feloni, a former Hutton broker, recount events mostly from 1982 on. Writing in diary form, they achieve the impact of a fast-moving, investigative documentary describing a company facing one emergency after another. Of the two books, this one gives the better feeling for life in the eye of the crisis, describing the dramas surrounding Hutton's top executives, its employees, its customers, its lawyers, Congress and the press.
''Sudden Death,'' on the other hand, takes a more historical view. Mark Stevens, a syndicated financial columnist, gives us a better appreciation of what Hutton really was like as an American institution: its deep roots on both coasts, its presence in New York's Plaza Hotel and other fancy resorts, its vast national network of highly paid salesmen. Mr. Stevens also does a better job of describing the pressures of Wall Street, including the relentless search among companies for deep capital bases and the tensions among the trading, investment-banking and brokerage cultures within the big companies.
Because so much of the material in both books comes from insiders speaking on and off the record, the picture that emerges is no doubt heavily influenced by interviewees intent on protecting their own reputations or impugning someone else's. For this reason, much of the petty dirt dished out about some of the principal characters must be taken as the gossip it is. A more objective view of Hutton's demise would probably require that a little more time elapse between the event and the interpretation of what really happened and why. It would also include a more thoughtful analysis of the kind of people and control systems required to manage large financial institutions at a time when dollars move around the world electronically and the very definition of money and financial risk is increasingly fuzzy.
A deeper treatment would also answer these questions: What difference does it make if the E.F. Huttons or the Merrill Lynches collapse, anyway? Aside from the employees who are laid off, would customers, creditors or the nation's financial system be badly hurt? Neither of these books even touches on the bigger stakes. But until we know how close the Hutton demise was to becoming a widespread financial debacle, it's hard to know whether we are reading about just another corporate rise and fall, or whether all the drama was about something much more significant.
 

 
JUGGLING FOR DOLLARS
 What was most striking to Steve Milne [a bank auditor] about the Hutton account was the amount of money involved. The number of dollars deposited was clearly way out of line with the amount of business generated by the brokers at Hutton's four-man . . . office. Since opening its account just nine days earlier . . . Hutton had deposited . . . $26,427,507. All eleven deposits consisted of large checks written by Hutton to Hutton on its accounts at two banks in Pennsylvania. . . . Hutton was moving money back and forth between the two Pennsylvania institutions and Genesee [Mr. Milne's bank]. Also . . . Hutton had drawn checks on its Genesee account totaling $26,432,000 - or $4,493 more than the firm had deposited. Why? . . .
As he looked closer . . . something else caught Milne's eye: Many of the checks deposited in the account and many of the checks drawn on it carried the same date. . . . Finally . . . the checks deposited in Hutton's account carried the signatures of employees at the local brokerage office, while the checks drawn on the account did not. Milne wasn't sure, but what he had found so far led him to suspect a classic check kite.
 
From ''The Fall of the House of Hutton.''

PUB-DATE: October 29, 1989

SECTION: Section 7; Page 34, Column 2; Book Review Desk

LENGTH: 1114 words

HEADLINE: BOOK & BUSINESS;
THE NOUVEAU TYCOONS

BYLINE: By RON ROSENBAUM; Ron Rosenbaum is the author of ''Manhattan Passions,'' a collection of reports about New York culture in the 1980's.

 BODY:

THE NEW CROWD
The Changing of the Jewish Guard on Wall Street.
By Judith Ramsey Ehrlich and Barry J. Rehfeld.
Illustrated. 444 pp. Boston:
Little, Brown & Company. $19.95.
The most provocative - and down-to-earth - comment on the giddy world of ''The New Crowd,'' a mostly celebratory account of ''The Changing of the Jewish Guard on Wall Street,'' comes from the curmudgeonly Lewis Glucksman. He's the combative trading-desk Samson who helped bring the old-guard ''Our Crowd'' investment house of Lehman Brothers down around his head. Observing the rush of his Lehman partners to sell to Shearson/American Express, he tells the authors that people on Wall Street, including himself, are all greatly ''overpaid . . . relative to the value of the service provided.'' 
Curiously, the authors of this otherwise well-reported and mostly well-written chronicle of 1980's Wall Street and the nouvelle society it spawned dutifully record Mr. Glucksman's skeptical perspective, but fail to give much consideration to the fundamental question it raises: What exactly was the value of the services the New Crowd brought to society - beyond the entertainment value their parties brought to the society pages? Yes, the John Gutfreunds, the Henry Kravises, the Carl Icahns, the Felix Rohatyns, the Saul Steinbergs and the Ronald Perelmans made a lot of big deals; they were big deals, although not quite the civil rights pioneers the authors suggest when they tell us ''the New Crowd broke the stranglehold of the Establishment Wasp bankers and their Our Crowd [German-Jewish] competitors.'' Despite the pecularily strained, somewhat militaristic mixed metaphor of the subtitle, the authors are, if anything, philo-Semitic; in their view the New Crowd is a group of outstanding visionary leaders.
But the question of the value of their services is more problematic. The authors sum up what they characterize as the New Crowd's achievements as ''block trading, risk arbitrage . . . junk bond financing that helped companies expand and made almost every company vulnerable to a takeover, and leveraged buyouts that restructured corporate entities and raised critical debt levels. They provided vast amounts of liquidity.''
This is a fairly mixed record, considering the recent high-profile defaults in Kohlberg Kravis Roberts's leveraged-buyout financings and the recent near-panic liquidity crisis in the junk-bond market. Not to mention the guilty pleas of Ivan Boesky, Martin Siegel and the junk-bond colossus Drexel Burnham Lambert. A jury will decide whether the invisible emperor of the New Crowd economy, Michael Milken, is a martyred genius, as his supporters claim, or a venal racketeer, as the Government charges. But questions of value are not necessarily resolved in court, and the authors fail to address adequately the question of whether Mr. Boesky, Mr. Siegel and the others are aberrations of New Crowd culture or symptoms of something deeply wrong with its go-for-it values.
While Judith Ramsey Ehrlich and Barry J. Rehfeld, both freelance journalists, make careful note of all the charges, indictments, scandals and follies, the overall cheerleading tone of their prose seems to take for granted that the New Crowd is a roaring success story. They seem mightily impressed by the big deals their subjects have made, by their rapid rise, their astronomical salaries, the ''elegantly expensive taste'' and delicate personal touch with which the big shots' sexy second wives have furnished their larger and larger apartments. (There is a lot of gaga prose about imported English paneling and the like here - evidently the result of personal house tours the authors got from New Crowd wives.) Above all, there is the assumption that success itself is proof of value, even vision.
Are the New Crowd visionaries? It is instructive to compare the New Crowd with another group of entrepreneurial Jewish visionaries, the glove makers and furriers who left the Lower East Side to found the great Hollywood studios and forever changed America's vision of itself. Does merging Shearson and American Express or taking Nabisco private really rate up there on the scale of Jewish visionary achievements with those of the Hollywood moguls (not to mention with Freud, Einstein and Kafka)?
Consider the case of Sanford I. Weill, whose rise from small brokerage partnership to the presidency of American Express is one of the book's main narrative threads. Mr. Weill is described as ''a blunt-spoken, cigar-smoking stockbroker, who had grown up in Flatbush, Brooklyn, the son of immigrant Polish Jews.'' But like the other New Crowd stars, he didn't go from rags to riches; it was more like going from polyester to Polo. Mr. Weill doesn't come across here as smart as Bruce Wasserstein, as nimble as Felix Rohatyn, as bold as Carl Icahn. He was less a vaulter than a plodder, the authors write, and ''opportunity followed [him] like a faithful dog.'' But throughout all his acquisitions another thing followed him around: mass firings.
After his partnership acquired H. Hentz & Company in 1973, Mr. Weill ''laid off hundreds of employees,'' the authors write. When he acquired Shearson Hammill in 1974, ''only half of Shearson's 2,400 employees survived.'' When Shearson acquired Loeb Rhodes Hornblower in 1979, ''about 2,500 of the 10,800 employees were fired.'' Finally, Mr. Weill landed the presidency of American Express, found himself over his head in an alien corporate culture, bailed out, bounced around a bit and then landed on his feet as head of the financial services giant Primerica. The authors give him a Sinatra-like send-off: ''He was back on center stage. . . . He was back in the big time.'' But then, in what is evidently a last-minute footnote, they add: ''Less than two weeks before Christmas (1988)'' - three months after Mr. Weill took over - Smith Barney, Primerica's brokerage house, ''fired more than 150 employees.''
Still, the authors seem determined to interpret Mr. Weill's rise as an example of pluck and fortitude, a major Horatio Alger success story. They admiringly chronicle his parallel ascension in the socialite-charity world, capped when he and his wife headed up the Carnegie Hall restoration project, to which they contributed $2.5 million. In our last glimpse of the Weills, we see them proudly admiring their names over the door of the Weill Recital Hall. While it's undoubtedly true that Mr. Weill made the largest financial contribution to the recital hall, it might have been more appropriate to inscribe over the door the names of the thousands he fired. Mr. Weill made the biggest donation; they made the real sacrifice.

SECTION: Section 7; Page 39, Column 1; Book Review Desk

LENGTH: 668 words

HEADLINE: BOOK & BUSINESS;
OVERPAID AND GUILT-RIDDEN

BYLINE: By RICHARD L. STERN; Richard L. Stern is a senior editor at Forbes magazine.

 BODY:

LIAR'S POKER
Rising Through the Wreckage on Wall Street.
By Michael Lewis.
249 pp. New York:
W. W. Norton & Company. $18.95.
In 1984, through an improbable set of circumstances, Michael Lewis, a 24-year-old Princeton University graduate studying at the London School of Economics, turned up in a rented tuxedo at a dinner given by the Queen Mother. He found himself seated next to the wife of a managing partner of Salomon Brothers. Mr. Lewis soon landed a job with the company - one of the most sought-after opportunities for the money-minded college generation of the 1980's. 
''Liar's Poker'' is the very funny account of his three-year, dog-eat-dog climb there. Starting as an overpaid $48,000-a-year trainee, Mr. Lewis, by 1987, was on his way to triumph as an institutional bond salesman in Salomon's London office, earning $225,000.
This is a story with much irony. Here is one of America's top investment banking and securities trading firms, an adviser to the largest corporations and money managers, unable to run itself. Its management style is one of warring individuals and factions. While its chairman, John Gutfreund, moaned about underlings demanding too much money, he turned out to be the highest-paid chief executive on Wall Street. The message from the top down was contagious: Every man for himself.
In London, a naive Mr. Lewis was talked into selling some bonds from Salomon's inventory by a trader who had to get rid of them or face a loss. It didn't matter that the bonds quickly collapsed, that the company lost a new client or that the money manager who bought the bonds lost his job. Mr. Lewis performed nobly for Salomon Brothers.
But Mr. Lewis soon learned a valuable lesson. The only way to keep his clients - and perhaps assuage his growing feelings of guilt - was to protect them. So with an anxious junk bond trader standing over him and pressuring him to sell a new issue of bonds that everyone knew would go bad, Mr. Lewis cryptically told a grateful client not to touch them with a 10-foot pole.
The book's title, ''Liar's Poker,'' refers to an after-hours game played by Salomon's bond traders and arbitrageurs. The stakes can run as high as several hundred dollars a bet. The game, combining bluff and calculation, is based on guessing the serial numbers of dollar bills. In fact, Mr. Lewis notes, a good player combines all the skills of a good trader. One day, according to Mr. Lewis (Salomon Brothers has denied this story), Mr. Gutfreund walked into the New York trading room and challenged Salomon's top trader to bet $1 million on a single game. But the trader was better than Mr. Gutfreund at this: ''No, John,'' he said. ''I'd rather play for real money. Ten million dollars. No tears.'' Mr. Gutfreund declined, outbluffed before the game began.
Ultimately, Mr. Gutfreund and Salomon Brothers may have outbluffed themselves. With no real long-term game plan, no grasp of overhead and a tendency to live for the next deal, the company had vastly overspent and overexpanded before the 1987 market collapse. Afterward, it was forced to make major personnel cuts and to eliminate whole departments. Its huge expenditures for growth in Europe were unhinged by a number of major miscalculations. Not the least of these, according to Mr. Lewis, was that while many American institutional clients believed they had no choice but to deal with the company, European customers regarded Salomon Brothers as not only crass, but just one of hundreds of brokers. They were not as willing as the Americans to forgive or forget.
Yet the author believes Salomon will survive and prosper. As for Mr. Lewis, having survived the company's staff cuts because of his moneymaking ability, he says that he left Salomon Brothers not out of disillusionment but ''more because I didn't need to stay any longer.'' Whatever the case, he's obviously as good a writer as he was a bond salesman. Perhaps that's because both jobs involve being able to tell a good story.

717 of 768 DOCUMENTS

Copyright 1989 The New York Times Company 
The New York Times

PUB-DATE: October 29, 1989

SECTION: Section 7; Page 1, Column 1; Book Review Desk

LENGTH: 2784 words

HEADLINE: ECONOMICS: READING YOUR WAY OUT OF CHAOS

BYLINE: By PETER PASSELL; Peter Passell writes about economics for The New York Times.

 BODY:
Economics has long accommodated dozens of schools of thought. But in the last decade or so, it has become more like physics or chemistry, disciplines so broad and so complicated that, within the field, one group of specialists barely speaks the same language as the Ph.D.'s across the hall. And so much of what is published seems more to proselytize for an ideology than to make sense of the chaotic world inhabited by economists. It's no wonder that a single economic development can be interpreted as a godsend or a disaster, depending on the interpreter's frame of reference.
In such a morass it would be foolish to expect any single volume to sweep away the confusion for the noneconomist. But I've found that certain books help me think more clearly about the economy than others do; certain books call me back to them again and again in times of muddle.
Some of the best recent writing about modern economics is actually relatively painless as it guides the reader through the bewildering world of stock market crises, deficits, trade balances, monetary policy and interest rates. 
Here is my own short list of must-reads. If there is a bias in the selection, it is toward books that are politically astute and treat the English language with respect.
Readers who don't want to waste their time on flash-in-the-pan theories but seek an introduction to the kind of thinking about economics that will be useful even 20 years from now should take a look at Alan S. Blinder's ''Hard Heads, Soft Hearts: Tough-Minded Economics for a Just Society'' (Addison-Wesley, Cloth, $17.95; Paper, $10.95). This little book, written in 1987 by a Princeton economics professor and columnist for Business Week, surveys a lot of ground lightly. But there is enough between the covers to make the mainstream economists' way of looking at public policy comprehensible to anyone who is interested.
A decade ago it became fashionable for economic gurus to worry about ''the British disease,'' the apparent tendency of mature industrial economies to lose vigor. Today, the symptoms are described somewhat differently - the buzzword is competition, and there is a stronger moral cast to analyses of America's failure to pull up its socks.
But one of the first books on this big-think topic - ''The Rise and Decline of Nations: Economic Growth, Stagflation, and Social Rigidities'' (Yale University, Cloth, $30; Paper, $10.95) by Mancur Olson, published in 1982 - still strikes this reader as the most penetrating. Mr. Olson, a professor of economics at the University of Maryland, links slower growth to the gradual proliferation of interest groups seeking advantage at the expense of economic efficiency. Many of the examples in this fine essay on what has come to be known as the economics of public choice involve labor unions. But the analysis could apply equally well to small dairy farmers who now seek a ban on the use of hormones to promote milk output, or loggers who defend the subsidies they receive to harvest from Government-owned forests.
Conservatives no longer dismiss the poor as lazy or immoral. And liberals no longer quiver with rage at the idea that poverty is a consequence of cultural failure, as well as insufficient income. Somehow, though, this intellectual convergence has yet to translate into a commitment to a realistic antipoverty program.
If Washington ever does get serious about ending poverty, politicians could do worse than to use David T. Ellwood's ''Poor Support: Poverty in the American Family'' (Basic Books, Cloth, $19.95; Paper, $9.95) as the blueprint. In this 1988 book, Mr. Ellwood, a professor of public policy at Harvard's John F. Kennedy School of Government, argues that the problems facing two-parent, single-parent and underclass families are quite different and demand separate solutions. Some of his ideas are quite familiar: universal medical insurance, an increase in the minimum wage. Some will be new to all but policy aficionados: expanded Federal tax credits for low-wage earners, a uniform child-support system to cope with the problem of absent fathers. Just about every one of his proposals is smart, humane and practical.
At the heart of modern microeconomics is a 19th-century utilitarian notion of rationality, of people who act in consistent ways to advance their material interests, subject to practical constraints. The idea has the virtue of keeping models of economic behavior simple enough to seem scientific. And it meshes neatly with Darwinian natural selection - the impulse to economic gain is easily linked to the biological imperative to pass on one's genes. But unlike Mr. Spock on ''Star Trek,'' members of the human species hardly seem to fit the superrational profile. That is why Robert H. Frank's 1988 book, ''Passions Within Reason: The Strategic Role of the Emotions'' (Norton, $19.95), is such a find. Mr. Frank, a professor of economics at Cornell University, sets out to patch the utilitarian model, explaining how seemingly irrational altruism makes good economic sense. And he writes with real style - a rarity among economic theorists, who are generally more at home with the Greek alphabet.
Economists of almost every ideological stripe believe that free trade is a good thing. And many think it is about the only thing that keeps rich countries striving and gives poor ones a shot at the brass ring. The catch is that free trade is not good for everyone. And the losers - assorted unions and businesses that face stiff foreign competition - work overtime to make sure the economists' message does not get through to Washington.
Jagdish Bhagwati's 1988 book, ''Protectionism'' (MIT Press, $16.95), may not win the hearts or minds of the House majority leader, Richard Gephardt, and other politicians who have decided that real Americans should buy American. But it is the most eloquent statement to date of the logic of open trade. And it even offers reasons for optimism: while the protectionists are winning some battles, the Columbia University specialist in economic development argues, free traders are winning the war.
Can an 800-page book on monetary policy really be a page turner? William Greider, best remembered as the man to whom David Stockman confessed all, has managed the nearly impossible. His 1988 book, ''Secrets of the Temple: How the Federal Reserve Runs the Country'' (Touchstone/Simon & Schuster, Paper, $12.95), lucidly explains how the money is made and how it makes the world go round. He sometimes even makes the lesson exciting. The context is the recession of 1980, which Paul Volcker, then the chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, deliberately induced to contain rising prices. Mr. Volcker ended up with a reputation as the selfless leader who stopped the inflation vandals at the gates. But Mr. Greider, a journalist, is far less kind. The Federal Reserve, he argues, was doing what it has always done, defending the interests of the wealthy at the expense of homeowners, farmers and the folks who buy dining room sets on credit. That interpretation does not sit well with post-liberal economists, who worry more about the size of the economic pie than the size of the slices. But while Mr. Greider is, arguably, dead wrong, no one who reads his book will think he is foolish. Indeed, Congress is now considering a variety of proposals to put salt on the Fed's tail. It is hard to remember a work on the subject that is at once so technically sophisticated and so accessible.
Wondering why everyone else is driving a BMW while you can barely afford the monthly payments on a Chevy? Frank Levy explains it in ''Dollars and Dreams: The Changing American Income Distribution'' (Russell Sage, Cloth, $27.50; Norton, Paper, $7.95), a 1987 accounting of the economic plight of the baby boomers.
By every collective measure, Americans are more prosperous than they have ever been. But as Mr. Levy, an economist at the University of Maryland, points out, small increases in average earnings mask enormous variations in the fate of generations. Male workers under the age of 40, in particular those without college degrees, have borne the brunt of the collapse in employment in heavy industry. And they had the bad luck to enter the labor force just as women were asserting their rights to the really good jobs. The baby boomers' problems, moreover, have been compounded by the run-up in house prices in the 1970's that left young renters out in the cold and by the sharp increase in regressive payroll taxes used to fund the elderly's Social Security pensions. Mr. Levy does not explain how the boomers might dig themselves out of the trap. But his pathbreaking study does set the stage for the coming war of distribution between young and old.
The standard view of economic development these days is that free markets and fast growth go together like beer and nachos. But Alice H. Amsden, an economist at the Harvard Business School, suggests that tastes in development strategies may not be universal. Her 1989 book, ''Asia's Next Giant: South Korea and Late Industrialization'' (Oxford University, $29.95), argues that countries just now jumping on the growth track must use government intervention to compensate for technological backwardness in export markets. That may sound like a rationalization for the sort of meddling that has wrecked economic development prospects from Argentina to Algeria to Poland. In fact, it is a defense of the more disciplined government-business partnerships that have served South Korea and Japan very well. How applicable it is outside Asia is grist for economic policy mills.
Nobody says it better than John Kenneth Galbraith, the Harvard liberal icon who has been in the thick of the economic policy game for half a century. Unfortunately, a lot of what he has had to say has been dismissed by his many critics as unoriginal or just plain wrong. The one Galbraith book that pleases almost everybody is ''The Great Crash 1929'' (Houghton Mifflin, Cloth, $17.95; Paper, $8.95). This anecdote-stuffed account of greed, stupidity and innocence, first published in 1955, shows Mr. Galbraith at his sardonic best. The latest edition, published last year, includes a preface comparing the 1929 stock market collapse with the one in 1987. One might quibble with his world view. But what's the point? You would only assume I was jealous of the remarkable felicity of his prose - and you would be right.
For years economists said the sky would fall if Ronald Reagan and his profligate friends in Congress didn't mend their overspending, undertaxing ways. But most Americans have learned to stop worrying and love their tax cuts. And while Washington still pays lip service to the need to cut the budget and trade deficits, sacrifice just doesn't sell.
Benjamin Friedman's ''Day of Reckoning: The Consequences of American Economic Policy Under Reagan and After'' (Random House, Cloth, $19.95; Vintage, Paper, $8.95), written in 1988, after it was clear that President Reagan would never have to foot the political bill for his six-year-long party, does not predict that Western civilization will collapse anytime soon. But Mr. Friedman, who worked as an investment banker before he became a professor of economics at Harvard University, does offer a devastating analysis of the likely consequences of Reaganomics: permanently diminished living standards and declining world influence.
The Soviet Union is changing so rapidly that any analysis of its economy is bound to be a little dated before it is published. Ed A. Hewett, a senior fellow at the Brookings Institution in Washington and a seasoned perestroika watcher, could not foresee the crippling strikes and regional discontent that would lead Mikhail Gorbachev to warn last month of imminent economic collapse. But those who had read his ''Reforming the Soviet Economy: Equality Versus Efficiency'' (Brookings Institution, Cloth, $36.95; Paper, $16.95) in 1988 were not likely to be surprised by the subsequent unraveling. He explains how the economy that Stalin built muddled along, rudderless, for decades. Mr. Hewett outlines the botched half-efforts at reform under Nikita Khrushchev, Aleksei Kosygin and Yuri Andropov. And while the author is too much the scholar to go into the prediction business, he makes clear that the obstacles facing Mr. Gorbachev are indeed formidable.
At least one book on economic history belongs on the list, and the choice could hardly be easier. The first volume of Fernand Braudel's ''Civilization and Capitalism: 15th-18th Century'' - ''The Structures of Everyday Life'' (Harper & Row, Cloth, $35; Paper, $19.95) - is an idiosyncratic survey of how ordinary people lived from the Middle Ages through the Industrial Revolution. It is great history, great economics and great fun.
Mr. Braudel, a French polymath who began writing history in a German prison camp during World War II, flits from detail to grand thesis with the grace of a Nureyev. Where else, for example, is one likely to learn that the furniture of 20th-century Japan is based on designs from seventh-century China? And where else could one discover that carbohydrate is destiny, that accidents of climate and soil separating the regional domains of wheat, corn and rice critically influenced the rise of Europe and the fall of Asia and Latin America?
''If you know so much about the economy, how come you're not rich?'' The economists' answer, which has never satisfied anyone inclined to ask the question, is that most of what they learned in school is not useful in beating the averages in stocks and bonds.
Burton G. Malkiel, a former dean of the Yale School of Organization and Management, is the rare economist who is as at home on Wall Street as on campus. Rarest among the rare, he is also skilled at translating disciplined academic research on securities markets into practical advice for small investors. Read his book ''A Random Walk Down Wall Street'' (Norton, Paper, $11.95) - the fourth edition of which was published in 1985 - to discover why 90 percent of what stock brokers tell you is nonsense. Or, if you insist, read it, in Mr. Malkiel's words, ''to get rich slowly but surely.''
The recent ''More Like Us: Making America Great Again'' (Houghton Mifflin, $18.95) is not exactly about economics, and its author, James Fallows, is not a card-carrying member of the economists' fraternity. But the book, a clear-eyed look at the strengths and weaknesses of America's economic culture, is a fine antidote to the Japanese-do-it-better-and-besides-they-cheat school of public policy.
Mr. Fallows, a distinguished journalist who used to write speeches for President Jimmy Carter, lived in Asia for several years. But unlike many Japan watchers, he rejects the idea that the Japanese way of running an economy can be successfully emulated by us. Japan's success, he says, is closely linked to its revulsion at disorder and open conflict. America's great strength, by contrast, is its tolerance for rough edges and its capacity to harness individual initiative. The way to rouse the American economy from its lethargy, he argues, is to fight the tendency to allow those who have it made to shut the door behind them. His proposals, a mix of the very conservative (voucher systems for education) and the very liberal (open immigration), suggest just how irrelevant economic ideology has become.
Interested in owning a single reference work that promises the latest word on all of modern economics? One exists - ''The New Palgrave: A Dictionary of Economics,'' edited by John Eatwell, Murray Milgate and Peter Newman. The list of its contributors, including such extraordinary economists as Thomas Schelling, Albert Hirschman and James Buchanan, could hardly be more impressive.
Unfortunately, there is a catch - make that two catches. At $750, the four-volume, 2,000-entry, 4,100-page work is more expensive than a week in the Bahamas. And much of it is much less enjoyable: perhaps half the entries are written in econspeak, understandable only to those who know the jargon and the math. Happily, there is a much cheaper and more accessible version of ''Palgrave.'' The flashiest, least technical entries in the 1987 reference have been repackaged by W. W. Norton into individual volumes, each focusing on a broad topic. Three of them - ''Economic Development'' (Cloth, $39.95; Paper, $12.95), ''Social Economics'' (Cloth, $39.95; Paper, $14.95) and ''The Invisible Hand'' (Cloth, $39.95; Paper, $14.95) - are particularly user-friendly. They won't turn you into an economist overnight. But like the other books mentioned here, they'll help guide you through the morass.

SECTION: Section 7; Page 32, Column 1; Book Review Desk

LENGTH: 1586 words

HEADLINE: BOOK & BUSINESS;
DIGGING THEIR OWN CORPORATE GRAVESP

BYLINE: By JOHN D. DONAHUE; John D. Donahue teaches business and public policy at Harvard's John F. Kennedy School of Government. He is the author of ''The Privatization Decision: Public Ends, Private Means.''

 BODY:

CORPORATE MAKEOVER
The Reshaping of the American Economy.
By Harvey H. Segal.
269 pp. New York: Viking. $19.95.
Harvey H. Segal has seen a lot of corporate America, and it hasn't been pretty. Managerial megalomania. Empire-building. Slothful complacency. Fancy offices, unmerited perks and preposterous salaries. His indictments span the Fortune 500 as his baleful gaze falls on Ford, General Electric, Exxon, Citicorp, ITT and dozens of other corporations. Four decades' worth of outrage built up during Mr. Segal's career as a banker, an academic, a corporate director and a Wall Street journalist power ''Corporate Makeover,'' an extended cheer for the firestorm of restructuring that has swept through American industry in the 1980's. 
The corporate form just doesn't work, Mr. Segal believes. He has plenty of company in this lament - not just liberal and leftist critics but even the godfather of capitalism, Adam Smith, who had such dim hopes for the accountability of hired managers that he doubted shareholder-owned companies could survive in any but the most sheltered of markets. John Stuart Mill, though, found this judgment to be ''one of those overstatements of a true principle often met with in Adam Smith.'' Much the same can be said of Harvey Segal.
He sets out to tell tales and draw morals. The first task he carries off superbly. Few people are better equipped to serve up vignettes of managerial waste, fraud and abuse. His portfolio of jobs has endowed him with just the right blend of outsider's perspective and insider's familiarity. And he writes in a style that, at its best - and it's at its best most of the time - is vivid, heartfelt and wry all at once. Those who lack any sympathy for the corporate raider's mission will find this book especially enlightening. It is also entertaining, with the slightly illicit thrill any real-life disaster story delivers.
Unlike many other writers who shake their fists at the American corporation, Mr. Segal is admirably precise about his complaint: managers shortchange shareholders. The only proper definition of corporate success, he argues, is the return equity owners reap. Stagnant productivity, slipping American living standards and ebbing national competitiveness, in this view, are at most side effects of the central failure to maximize the present value of net earnings.
Mr. Segal insists that hostile takeovers, leveraged buyouts and forced restructurings - which he bundles together under the convenient if inelegant label ''corporate makeovers'' - are ''symptoms, not the disease.'' True enough. But neither are they a magic cure, and Mr. Segal goes astray when he moves from description to prescription. ''It may be wishfully premature,'' he writes, ''to speak of a market for corporate control. Yet the mind-set that increasingly regards companies as assets, casually to be bought and sold, is becoming more pervasive.'' This, he urges us to believe, is good news. What Mr. Segal, and the theorists who inspire him, mean by ''a market for corporate control'' is the set of legal, regulatory and financial arrangements that allow anyone with a sporty frame of mind and Drexel Burnham Lambert's telephone number to seize the helm of a corporation by offering an immediate bonus to shareholders.
The book zeroes in on the key question, asking whether ''corporate makeovers really enhance economic efficiency, or are they simply moves in a financial shell game?'' But Mr. Segal answers almost casually, reprising over and over again the theoretical case for why, in a certain sort of world, takeovers should boost efficiency, and piling up anecdotes about lousy managements that need to be booted out. There has been an enormous amount of careful work done in recent years on the effect of changes in corporate control (a research tradition that, according to the economist F. M. Scherer, has now ''advanced to the point of richly elaborated confusion''). One of the few solid conclusions to date (among many intriguing leads) is that nobody can say anything that is simple, sweeping and true about the net gains from such changes. Mr. Segal cites this hard-won body of evidence only where it happens to support his case.
Unreconstructed leftists are prone to a rookie error in logic that goes like this: Since some businesspeople are guilty of sloth and venality, anything that makes the business world squirm is good for the rest of us. Mr. Segal is no leftist, but he trots out the same non sequitur. His paean to the freewheeling market for corporate control just doesn't follow from his indictment of American industry.
For one thing, his magic bullet isn't well aimed. Many of the industrial dinosaurs he so devastatingly describes, like LTV, are still slouching along unchallenged, while some pretty good companies, such as Richardson-Vicks and Phillips Petroleum, have been swallowed up or forced into traumatic restructurings. Recent research on the topic shows it is not the worst corporations in each industry that typically draw raiders' attentions, but those near the middle of the pack. Any subsequent gains in efficiency are correspondingly modest. Signs are mounting, moreover, that pervasive corporate upheaval and uncertainty carry long-term economic costs.
On the other side of the ledger is the social fallout of takeovers and restructurings. Mr. Segal is understandably contemptuous of managers who entrench and enrich themselves at shareholders' expense while professing concern for workers, local communities and foundations that depend on the corporation. He handles the issue forthrightly, asserting that only shareholders matter - they're the owners, dammit - and on this point he has plenty of supporters and a coherent, logical case. But not everyone agrees. And just because some cynical managers hide behind the skirts of constituencies other than shareholders doesn't rob these groups of legitimate claims.
Finally, most corporate makeovers involve an enormous increase in debt. The deals Mr. Segal discusses, in fact, are just the most visible instances of the growing indebtedness of American industry. Here again, there is fierce and honest disagreement on the implications. The Federal tax code tempts companies to substitute debt for equity. Until recently, most firms limited their indulgence in tax-favored debt financing. The traditional view is that a heavy load of debt is bad, because it leaves managers no slack.
But the Harvard economist Michael Jensen (whom Mr. Segal cites often and approvingly) argues that a heavy load of debt is good, precisely because it leaves managers no slack. Any spare cash, he warns, would just be frittered away on perks, pay and wasteful monuments to managerial vanity. A financial structure that keeps managers right on the edge of default, where one false move means disaster, is the only way to concentrate their minds on efficient production. This extra efficiency will more than counterbalance the extra vulnerability, as managers learn to perform on the high wire better than they ever did on the ground.
A complex tangle of institutional and tax-code changes is turning much of the American economy into a messy and expensive test of this notion. Mr. Segal thinks it will work out fine. It might. But Benjamin Friedman, a Harvard colleague of Mr. Jensen's, notes that annual interest payments already claim over half of the average corporation's yearly earnings in the booming 1980's, and worries about what would happen in a slump. The Princeton economists Ben Bernanke and John Campbell calculate that at the debt levels prevailing in 1986 - and they are higher now - a recession like that of 1973-74 would bankrupt one out of 10 major companies.
Mr. Segal is confident that we will continue to avoid a major downturn; or, if a bad recession hits, that ''made-over'' corporations will be able to manage their way through it; or, if they fail, that innovations in finance and bankruptcy law will make corporate collapse painless for everybody except incompetent executives. He disparages the ''Cassandras of the old managerial establishment'' who fear the consequences of swollen debt loads. But Mr. Segal, and others who use the ''Cassandra'' tag to taunt those they see as timid, forget the point of the Greek myth. Cassandra's curse was that her prophecies would always be ignored, even though she turned out to be dead right every time.
The debate over mergers, leveraged buyouts and restructurings won't be settled for many years. Harvey Segal has written a richly informative contribution to that debate. If, as I fear, he is wrong in his conclusions, he is honorably and usefully wrong. It would be reckless for anybody to make up his mind on the takeover issue based solely on the case Mr. Segal presents. But it would be just as reckless to ignore it.
 
HOW MUCH IS TOO MUCH?
 Grumblings about exorbitant executive pay . . . would be more productive if they were shorter on moral indignation and longer on guiding principles. What's alarming is not that the average chief executive officer was paid $595,000 in 1987 or that Jim P. Manzi of Lotus Development Corporation, the computer software house, led the pecuniary parade with a cool $26.3 million in salary, bonus, and stock options. . . . It's not the levels of compensation that will make or break the American corporation but rather the lack of any reliable link between what CEOs are paid and how well they perform.
 
From ''Corporate Makeover.''

The New York Times

SECTION: Section 7; Page 35, Column 1; Book Review Desk

LENGTH: 1073 words

HEADLINE: BOOK & BUSINESS;
NOBODY'S PERFECT

BYLINE: By JOEL DREYFUSS; Joel Dreyfuss, who writes about technology for Fortune, spent two years as head of the magazine's Tokyo bureau.

 BODY:

THE SUN ALSO SETS
The Limits to Japan's Economic Power.
By Bill Emmott.
292 pp. New York:
Times Books. $19.95.
The rapid transformation of Japan from a defeated empire to one of the world's most powerful nations has always outraced the capacity of foreign analysts to keep up. In the 135 years since Commodore Matthew C. Perry introduced Japan to Western technology and gunboat diplomacy, the country has undergone various, sometimes extreme transformations in the Western imagination. The sequence of adjectives associated with Japan in this century has echoed its changing role on the world stage: exotic, evil, pathetic, laughable, admirable. 
Most recently, there has been a strong trend toward a perception of Japan as ''not quite like us.'' A number of analysts - led by the former United States trade negotiator Clyde Prestowitz, the American journalist James Fallows and the Dutch writer Karel van Wolferen - have begun to argue that Japan is somehow, well, different. They state variously that Japan does not understand the concept of free trade (Mr. Prestowitz), that its goal is industrial expansion rather than the general welfare of its citizens (Mr. Fallows), that bureaucrats and corporate interests really run the country (Mr. van Wolferen). In other words, the view of Japan as Evil Empire seems to be returning.
In ''The Sun Also Sets,'' Bill Emmott's unemotional, finely reasoned arguments could be regarded as an antidote to that consensus, which has a lot of political appeal among those who favor tough negotiating with Japan. The book's title comes from the author's assertion that Japan's huge financial surpluses could shrink as rapidly as they appeared and that its power and wealth could prove as ephemeral as that of OPEC.
But there is no need to run out and dump your Japanese holdings. The author concedes that Japan's clout could last another 50 years, although he offers evidence to suggest the reign could be much shorter. The valuable reminder here is that even Japan, which appears to be such an invincible economic juggernaut today, must inevitably succumb to the basic laws of economics: countries that build huge surpluses of money eventually see them shrink.
Mr. Emmott, a former Tokyo bureau chief of The Economist, argues that Japan's huge piles of money resulted from a fortuitous combination of circumstances in the early 1980's - a high savings rate, low Government spending and an excess of exports over imports - that is changing even as Japan's trading partners complain. He reminds us that Japan's wealth is a recent phenomenon and that for most of the period since World War II, the country has been a debtor nation - borrowing more than it could produce. For those who worry about drowning in a sea of yen, ''The Sun Also Sets'' is a fragile lifeline, offering hope that Japan will begin to behave like other nations and expose its problems, shortcomings and mistakes.
While the title suggests a promising thesis, the discussion of Japan's eventual decline is taken up only in the last part of the book. Most of it performs what has become a ritual in such works: debunking the numerous myths about Japan. (At some point, we need to ask ourselves why so many in the West continue to prefer the imaginary, threatening, near-perfect Japan to the real, flawed, often clumsy Japan.) In this case, the author does an effective job of cutting through the assumptions of terrifying efficiency to reassure us that the Japanese aren't that different after all. For example, Mr. Emmott tackles the myth of workaholicism. Yes, most factory workers work hard, he says, but not so the majority of white-collar workers. They do stay late in the office, but mainly to collect overtime pay and to make up for goofing off during normal hours.
Mr. Emmott whacks away at one of the most persistent fantasies: that Japan is unchanging and hidebound. Its civilization may be old, but the country is amazingly flexible and dynamic. Its ability to adjust to new circumstances and to embrace new technology has been the secret of its success. Japan's leaders have also been shrewd in gauging Western frustration and giving ground only when they have to. And they have used imaginary differences to resist those changes that were politically difficult to make. One irony is that the foreign critics accept the argument that Japan is different and use it to justify tough measures.
The book's central thesis is that change in Japan has taken on a momentum of its own. Reveling in their newfound affluence, the Japanese are beginning to act like the rest of us. They buy BMW's, vacation in Hawaii, play the wild Japanese real estate and stock markets and prowl the department stores of New York and Los Angeles with credit cards. The new affluence, the author argues, will lead Japan to behave like other wealthy countries: to become more open to imports, to foreign influence, even to the sins of excessive consumerism that have badly damaged the American economy. In making his case, Mr. Emmott offers a powerful challenge to the Japan-is-different school, although his opponents are likely to respond that this recently changed behavior may also be short-lived.
The author brings a valuable British perspective to issues that have often generated more heat than substance in debates between Americans and Japanese. He notes coolly that few United States politicians have had the courage to suggest that we deal with trade friction by tackling those things we can control: our high budget deficit and low savings rate. And in the interest of fairness, he enumerates the barriers erected by European nations against the Japanese.
Mr. Emmott rejects suggestions that Japan will overtake the United States economically. Since Japan's destiny is becoming more intertwined with that of America and Europe, he argues, its interests will more closely match those of its trading partners. In his scenario, the United States will remain No. 1, but No. 2 Japan will take its place alongside the major European countries as a respected, often-consulted ally. The author admits he is an optimist. He insists on seeing the Japanese not just as economic machines but as individuals with the same needs and drives as the citizens of other affluent nations. As the world adjusts to Japan's new clout, frustrated politicians should be reminded often of the real people behind the Japanese trade numbers.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: REVIEW

PUB-DATE: October 29, 1989

SECTION: Section 7; Page 27, Column 1; Book Review Desk

LENGTH: 1923 words

HEADLINE: BOOK & BUSINESS;
THE RISKS WEE TOO GOOD TO PASS UP

BYLINE: By ANTHONY M. SOLOMON; Anthony M. Solomon is the former Under Secretary of the Treasury for Monetary Affairs and the former president of the Federal Reserve Bank of New York.

 BODY:

OTHER PEOPLE'S MONEY
The Inside Story of the S&L Mess.
By Paul Zane Pilzer with Robert Deitz.
269 pp. New York:
Simon & Schuster. $18.95.
 
INSIDE JOB
The Looting of America's Savings and Loans.
By Stephen Pizzo, Mary Fricker and Paul Muolo.
443 pp. New York:
McGraw-Hill. $19.95.
 
THE S&L INSURANCE MESS
How Did It Happen?
By Edward J. Kane.
181 pp. Washington: The Urban Institute Press. 
Cloth, $24.95. Paper, $10.95.
The insolvency of huge segments of the United States savings and loan industry marks a sorry chapter in this nation's financial history. The magnitude of the corruption, greed, incompetence and cynicism of those who mismanaged or plundered hundreds of thrift institutions - or covered up what was going on - breaks all records. Many lawyers, accountants and regulatory specialists who should have blown the whistle were either duped or inept. A disturbing number of high Government officials displayed appalling judgment. In the end, the costs to the taxpayer, the real victim, will be colossal.
Now the whole disgraceful episode, though far from over, has spawned a flock of carefully researched, well-crafted books chronicling the fiasco. Three particularly good ones are ''Other People's Money,'' by Paul Zane Pilzer with Robert Deitz; ''Inside Job,'' by Stephen Pizzo, Mary Fricker and Paul Muolo; and ''The S&L Insurance Mess,'' by Edward J. Kane.
Each has a somewhat different focus and different audiences in mind, but all provide genuine value to their readers, whether they are already reasonably well informed or only casually acquainted with what has happened. If none are fully successful in coming to grips with the broadest policy dimensions and implications of the thrift industry debacle, that is surely forgivable, for the situation is still fluid.
Because Mr. Pilzer is in real estate development, he has some firsthand experience of what went on. He has teamed up with Mr. Deitz, an editor of The Dallas Times Herald, and together they have written a highly readable introduction to the thrift disaster. They recount the history, the legislative background, the gambits used to exploit new powers granted to the savings and loan institutions in the early 1980's by a deregulation-minded Congress, and the duplicity of Washington heavyweights who used their influence to stop remedial regulatory action. Of the three books, this one is probably the best all-round treatment, despite sometimes irritating overgeneralizations and hyperbole.
Mr. Pilzer reveals a key point: the dangers inherent in a system of large-scale Government insurance of deposits. These were clearly foreseen right at the outset - and by none other than Franklin D. Roosevelt in 1933, as he was about to become President. He (and others) understood the potential for abuses, and tried to head off legislation supported by populists like Huey Long and Texans like John Nance Garner (the incoming Vice President!). But the political pressures for deposit insurance were overwhelming. In 1933 the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation (F.D.I.C.) was established for banks; in 1934 the Federal Savings and Loan Insurance Corporation (F.S.L.I.C.) was added for thrifts.
Though the system, as Mr. Pilzer explains, held together until the 1970's, it was always fundamentally fragile. Savings and loan institutions provided long-term fixed-rate mortgages that were financed by short-term savings deposits. As long as interest rates remained relatively stable, this was a profitable activity. But when inflation dramatically escalated in the 1970's, the business was doomed. Many thrifts, subject to an inadvisable interest-rate ceiling imposed by Congress decades ago, faced calamity as deposits were withdrawn, lured by the far higher yields available on money market funds.
But interest rate deregulation, which began in 1980 under Jimmy Carter, was no panacea, either. Once free to compete, thrifts could hold onto deposits, but at the stiff price of offering higher interest to depositors - and that meant losses on the savings institutions' existing low-interest mortgage portfolios.
What ultimately proved more disastrous, as Mr. Pilzer and the other authors show, was a string of poorly thought-out decisions by Congress. The first was to increase the maximum deposit insured by the Government from $40,000 to $100,000. This encouraged deposit insurance brokers, who could place large sums divided into lots of $100,000 each, to shop for the thrift willing to pay the highest interest rate - no matter how shaky its assets or bad its management. These so-called ''brokered deposits'' poisoned the system.
Egged on by thrift industry lobbyists, the Reagan Administration went beyond mere interest-rate deregulation. Aided by willing Democrats, they hustled through Congress an incredibly shortsighted piece of legislation, the Garn-St Germain Act of 1982, which removed regulatory barriers to thrift industry business activities. No longer was the industry largely confined to financing housing. Overnight, the sky was the limit.
The results were devastating, as all of the authors show. Before the ink was dry on the new act, the staid thrift industry was invaded by all manner of promoter, swindler, land speculator, junk bond player and money launderer. Some of the more outrageous cases, spun out in rich detail by the authors of ''Inside Job,'' are so lurid that a novelist would blush to invent them.
Mr. Pizzo, Ms. Fricker and Mr. Muolo are investigative journalists and they have put together a chilling account, cast almost in cinematic terms, of greed and criminality. While tales of political interference by Washington officials on behalf of crooked savings and loan magnates are not ignored, the real juice of ''Inside Job'' is in the fascinating descriptions of the private-sector perpetrators - such as Charles H. Keating Jr., principal owner of Lincoln Savings and Loan in Irvine, Calif. - and how they went about fleecing thrifts. The authors' thesis of organized crime involvement is provocative.
Aside from racketeering and fraud, they make clear that the incentives to take excessive risks, even for law-abiding thrift managements, were overwhelming. The Government insurance funds, not the borrower or the depositor, were underwriting the financial outcomes. The philosophy was: ''It's heads I win, tails the F.S.L.I.C. loses.'' Mr. Kane's book is a scholarly monograph that basically arrives at the same conclusions as the other two. While he approaches the subject analytically, rather than by poring over the egregious cases, he, too, believes that the savings and loan crisis was an inevitable consequence of the ways Congress restructured deposit insurance and the thrift industry at the start of the 1980's. ''The S&L Insurance Mess'' demands a good deal from the reader, but for serious students of the issue the effort is worthwhile.
All of the authors are plainly of the view that the Government deserves a tremendous amount of blame for the thrift crisis, and I agree with them. The books name names. In Congress, Fernand J. St Germain, Jim Wright and Tony Coelho have been forced out (though for varying reasons, not all of them connected to the thrift scandal), yet incumbents like Jake Garn, Alan Cranston, Dennis DeConcini, Donald W. Riegle Jr. and many others have a lot of explaining to do.
Within the Reagan Administration, the authors of the three books have amassed convincing evidence of the questionable actions and interventions of several Presidential appointees. One of them, M. Danny Wall, once an aide to Senator Garn, remains chairman of the Office of Thrift Supervision (formerly the Federal Home Loan Bank Board).
But the person who stands out as exhibiting the most appalling lack of judgment is Donald Regan. As the Secretary of the Treasury, he was the nation's top financial official, with the ultimate fiduciary responsibility to the taxpayer, and he continued to play a pivotal role on this issue after he left his Treasury post to become White House chief of staff. As these books conclude, he pitted his entire political weight against those, especially the thrift regulator Edwin Gray, who were trying to avoid a catastrophe. Mr. Regan prevailed; the taxpayer lost.
The regulatory officials deserve a share of the blame, however, as the books underscore. They were amateurish in dealing with emerging cases, and left the impression in the industry that they were not in control. They failed to educate the public about the abuses of the deposit insurance system, did not alert the press to the scandals in the making and showed poor leadership in dealing with Congress on reforming the system.
Others share the guilt: Outside auditors did a lax job in questioning rosy profit results that should have been seen as too good to be true. Independent directors of many failed institutions did not exercise their fiduciary responsibilities. Depositing institutions knowingly placed large amounts in the weakest thrifts without caring what the consequences of their activity might be. The national news media failed utterly to see the public policy implications. And probably most cynically, the lobbyists for the solvent thrift institutions effectively delayed legislation to restructure the F.S.L.I.C. As a result of their efforts, the problem became so large that the Government has been forced to carry the bulk of the rescue operation's financial burden (which could approach $300 billion), thereby letting the industry off the hook.
Common to all three books is the sense of outrage and exasperation they leave in the reader. The outrage stems from the fact that most of the guilty are getting away without any meaningful punishment, either by the courts in the case of the thrift industry crooks, or by the voters in the case of the large number of Congressmen - Democrats and Republicans alike - and executive-branch officials who did not protect the public interest. Still, what may be worse is the feeling of exasperation: after everything that has happened, nothing was included in the recently enacted bailout legislation to eliminate the essential abuses of the deposit insurance system.
These three books were completed before the final compromises on the Bush program were known, but it is fair to infer that all of the authors would be mightily disappointed in what was done. There is a surprisingly strong consensus among them about what the major elements of true reform would be: substantial cutbacks in the size of deposit that the Government would fully insure, along with the imposition of deductibles; meaningful curbs on brokered deposits; better supervision of thrifts through upgraded personnel and tougher rules; better coordination and cooperation between bank and thrift supervisors on the one side and the Justice Department and the F.B.I. on the other; careful screening of thrift officers, directors and owners; realistic accounting; and, finally, significant increases in capital requirements, probably the only major reform of the Bush program and the legislative compromise that resulted.
A final thought. These books force us to face up to an embarrassing and painful reality: we as a nation are badly governed in situations where our lawmakers and executive-branch officials are preoccupied either by ideology or by the narrow interests of a relative handful of big campaign contributors. In this case, and no doubt in others to come, the public interest has simply been ignored.

SECTION: Section 7; Page 39, Column 1; Book Review Desk

HEADLINE: BOOK & BUSINESS;
MARKET MADNESS

BYLINE: By FLOYD NORRIS; Floyd Norris is assistant to the editor of the Business Day section of The New York Times and writes its Market Place column.

 BODY:

MANIAS, PANICS, AND CRASHES
A History of Financial Crises.
Revised Edition.
By Charles P. Kindleberger.
302 pp. New York:
Basic Books. Cloth, $21.95.
Paper, $12.95.
What should be done about crashes in financial markets? Two years after stock markets crashed around the world, the question had receded from public view until the markets again cracked this month. The 1987 crash produced more publicty than pain and lulled many into a belief that crashes don't matter. A poll of actuaries, professionals who help map investment strategies for pension funds, found earlier this year that a majority thought another stock market crash was likely in this century, but they expected it would not be followed by any real problems. They foresaw no depression, not even a deep recession, and were confident that Main Street would not be seriously affected by Wall Street's problems. 
In his new edition of ''Manias, Panics, and Crashes,'' a history of such phenomena from 1720 through 1987, Charles P. Kindleberger, the Ford International Professor of Economics Emeritus at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, argues persuasively that crashes do matter and that it is usually right for central banks to step in as lenders of last resort, although uncertainty about whether they will do so can help hold down the speculation that normally precedes a crash. In 1929, he argues, there was too little lending, and in the international crisis of 1931 no one came forward to be the principal lender. Different actions, he believes, would have led to a better outcome for the world.
Mr. Kindleberger is under the impression that not much can be done to curb the speculative excesses that occasionally end in disasters. Better monetary policies could help, he says, but markets will nonetheless sometimes act irrationally and need Government intervention. He is scornful of a younger generation of economists who take it for granted that investors always act rationally, quoting Isaac Newton's observation that ''I can calculate the motions of the heavenly bodies, but not the madness of people.''
Newton knew himself well. Having been an early investor in the South Sea Company, one of the most famous financial bubbles, he sold his shares for a 100 percent profit of 7,000. ''Unhappily,'' Mr. Kindleberger writes, ''a further impulse later seized him, an infection from the mania gripping the world that spring and summer. He reentered the market at the top for a larger amount and ended up losing 20,000.''
Once a crash comes, it is not easy for a lender of last resort to know when, and how, to act. ''Whether too soon and too much is worse than too little and too late is difficult to specify,'' the author writes. ''In 1857, the U.S. Treasury came to the rescue of the market far too early and helped it inflate still further. In 1873, response was too slow.'' A serious depression followed that crash.
Mr. Kindleberger praises Alan Greenspan, the chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, for having run a ''splendid operation'' in providing credit during and after the 1987 stock market crash. But he does not comment on whether the effect may have been only to encourage a rebirth of speculation.
Mr. Kindleberger is an economist of the old school. He writes fluidly, introduces economic concepts clearly and avoids equations. More willing to take on the current situation than he was when the first edition of this book was published in 1978, he is alarmed by the third-world debt problem, by speculation in stock prices and by the United States budget and trade deficits.
In addition, he is worried that, just as the Depression of the 1930's occurred after Britain had stopped being the world financial leader and before the United States replaced it, ''there is a possibility that an aging U.S. economy will increasingly be incapable or unwilling to furnish the leadership and resources that it provided. . . . If so, what will take its place?'' He discusses the possibility of the void being filled by international organizations, or by Japan or West Germany, but sees obstacles to all those possibilities.
