SECTION: Section 8; Page 9, Column 1; Sports Desk

LENGTH: 928 words

HEADLINE: Outdoors;
Help for the Atlantic Salmon

BYLINE: By Nelson Bryant

 BODY:
One of the world's most highly regarded game and food fishes, the beleaguered Atlantic salmon is also a symbol of pure, free-flowing rivers.
In North America, the largest and most prestigious organization working to improve the salmon's lot is the Canadian-American Atlantic Salmon Federation. This country's branch of the federation is holding its seventh annual fund-raising dinner at the Plaza Hotel in Manhattan on the evening of Nov. 16.
The federation, a nonprofit conservation organization, came into being in 1982, a marriage of the Canadian Atlantic Salmon Association, formed in 1949, and the International Atlantic Salmon Foundation, which was chartered in New York in 1968. 
At the time of its inception, the federation had a staff of two and its budget was approximately $100,000 a year. The budget this year is $2.5 million, about $2 million of which came from donations from private individuals and foundations. Through its regional councils in this country and Canada, the federation links the salmon conservation and restoration efforts of more than 120 affiliate organizations and their 500,000 members.
Spawning in rivers, with the resulting progeny's dropping down to the sea and returning in one, two or three years, the Atlantic salmon was blocked from ascending many of its spawning rivers in New England by the turn of the century, until only Maine had any significant runs of the fish. Blessed with an abundance of salmon rivers, Canada has not been so affected, although even now the federation is working to block a hydroelectric project that would spoil salmon spawning habitat in the Moisie River in Quebec, one of Canada's best producers of large salmon.
More than a decade ago, Canada's salmon runs had dwindled alarmingly, largely the result of overharvesting by commercial netters. Poaching, too-liberal angling regulations and so-called subsistence fisheries by native Canadians were also factors in the species' decline. The subsistence fisheries have often been tainted by black market sales of the fish. In the mid-1960's, Danish high seas drift-net fishermen working in the Davis Strait off Greenland discovered that salmon from many nations gathered there and an uncontrolled fishery for them was soon under way. That fishery now operates under a quota established by the North Atlantic Salmon Treaty Organization, which is made up of the salmon-producing nations of the world and those countries that harvest salmon but have no salmon rivers of their own.
As the high seas fishery was being brought under control, Canada's national and provincial governments restricted or banned commercial fishing for the species. This involved reimbursing salmon netters for their lost income. At the heart of this crackdown on commercial netting in Canada was a growing awareness by public officials that a salmon caught by a sport fisherman is worth many times more to the general economy than one taken in a commercial fisherman's net.
Sport fishermen have also been restricted. In Quebec during the season just ended, the angler limit was one fish a day and in New Brunswick only two grilse - small salmon returning after one year at sea - could be kept. In all the provinces the seasonal limit was 10 fish.
The result of all this has been a dramatic improvement in the runs of salmon in most Canadian rivers. Although the federation has played a significant role in these salubrious changes, other organizations were also at work, including Richard Buck's Committee on the Atlantic Salmon Emergency, which did battle with the Danes early on.
In more recent years, Buck's Restoration of Atlantic Salmon in America Inc. has focused on salmon conservation at the international level. In Canada, the influential and venerable Miramichi Salmon Association has also worked to aid the salmon. Making the wild salmon (production of farmed Atlantic salmon, pioneered in Norway, is under way in Canada) a game fish safe from commercial exploitation would bring more income to Canada, but longstanding traditions cannot be set aside overnight.
The province of Newfoundland, where there is no restriction on commercial salmon fishing, is a case in point. The federation and a Newfoundland group, the Salmon Preservation Association for the Water of Newfoundland have called upon that province to close its shore net fishery for five years. That fishery intercepts inordinate numbers of salmon bound for other Canadian provinces and New England, and has also, says the preservation association, resulted in ''nothing less than a total rape'' of Newfoundland's own salmon rivers.
Some innovative ideas to improve salmon runs in Canada have evolved. Quebec, for example, has turned over once-private streams to local groups for management. This move has resulted in improved salmon runs and a virtual end to poaching. It's one thing to play Robin Hood and steal a salmon from a stretch of stream controlled by a wealthy group of Canadians or Americans, and quite another to steal from your fellow townsmen.
The federation is also deeply involved in the New England salmon restoration effort. A short while ago, for example, it gave $10,000 to a coalition that is trying to block a hydroelectric dam on Maine's most productive salmon river, the Penobscot.
The upcoming federation dinner begins with cocktails at 6:30. Raffle and auction items include fishing gear, limited edition sporting prints and salmon and trout fishing trips on rivers in Canada and the United States. Tickets are $100 each. For reservations, call (508) 356-0717.

HEADLINE: Financing Repairs in Co-ops and Condos

BYLINE: By IVER PETERSON

 BODY:
THE boiler groans and expires. The windows were leaky last winter and now another cold season is on the way. The elevator won't pass inspection and the broken and buckled sidewalk outside, which everyone thought belonged to the city, turns out to be the building owners' responsibility.
These are the kinds of developments, whether surprises or a long time in coming, that confront New York's co-op and condominium owners with the need to spend a lot of money, and therefore with deciding where to get it. The choices are always borrowing the money or assessing the apartment owners for their share, and boards of directors are becoming increasingly sophisticated about which approach is best for them.
''It's one of the most common problems that comes up before a board,'' said Mary Ann Rothman, executive director of the Council for New York Cooperatives, a co-op and condominium owners' group. ''What do you do when you have to spend some money?'' 
Several co-op accountants and board members remarked that these days bring on a particularly large amount of financial juggling to co-op and condominium boards, both because so many buildings converted to owner-occupancy in the last decade are showing their age and because the drop in interest rates over the last year makes this a good time for many to review their debt ledgers.
The choice of the source of money often depends on the kind of people living in the building, the kinds of repairs or improvements needed, their cost and even the type of governance involved, such as the limited-equity rules for publicly sponsored co-ops.
''Each co-op finds out that it has its own situation,'' Ms. Rothman said. ''The secret is to find out what that situation is.''
It has been nearly 20 years since 670 West End Avenue was converted into a co-op, and the 19-story apartment house at 93d Street was showing its age when its board decided that necessary repairs could no longer be postponed.
''There was a lot of deferred maintenance,'' said Eugene Worden, president of the board. ''The windows were going, there were serious leaks; the sidewalks needed replacement, our two boilers were 40 years old and both were held together with bubblegum and baling wire and the elevators needed work.''
For co-ops, the choice comes down to borrowing from a bank or assessing each apartment owner for a share of the cost. For a condominium there can be no bank loan, since the owners' association owns no property for collateral. It must use assessments to raise money unless it has a large reserve fund.
In most cases, accountants say, the individual owners of condos end up borrowing for their assessments anyway, pledging their units for the loans. The terms, however, are usually less favorable that those available to a co-op corporation.
AT 670 West End Avenue, the engineer's report put the repair cost at between $1.5 million and $1.7 million, amounting to more than $18,000 for each of the 95 apartments - too much of an assessment even for a building where three-bedroom apartments sell for $700,000. The co-op may have profited from having an expert at the helm, for Mr. Worden is a real estate consultant and has been advising co-op conversion sponsors for years on the finances of large apartment buildings.
He noted that his building had a small mortgage, $800,000, at a big interest rate, 13 percent. So the co-op rolled over the old mortgage into a new $2.3 million one at 9.87 percent, leaving it with a substantial amount of cash for the repairs.
To refinance, however, the co-op had to pay a prepayment penalty on the old mortgage. Co-ops, as corporations, are not covered by the state law that prohibits prepayment penalties on individual homeowner mortgages. The building also had to pay points on the new loan, but both of these one-shot expenses were more than offset by the lower interest rate, Mr. Worden said.
Mark Shernicoff, an accountant with the Manhattan firm of Zuckerman and Shernicoff, said that refinancing with a larger loan may not make sense for every co-op. ''When it comes to paying off a prepayment penalty you have to look at the value of the new loan against the old one,'' he said, ''and if you recover your costs within a couple of years, you're O.K.''
But with interest rates stabilizing at relatively low levels, some lenders are demanding more than prepayment penalties, which generally are based on fixed percentages of the loan that decline as the loan approaches maturity. It is not uncommon for banks these days to require being ''made whole,'' or earning the full amount on a loan, regardless of when it is paid off. That amounts to paying the difference between what the loan's value is to the lender over its life and the lower return the money would gain in the market at the time of payoff.
The penalty for early payoff is hard to predict with ''made whole'' loans, because it would depend on interest rates at the time of the payoff. However, Mr. Shernicoff added, such loans are often offered at a lower rate.
When the co-op boom was beginning in New York City and real estate values were a fraction of today's, many co-op loans were self-amortizing, like most single-family home loans. As a result, many older co-ops have negligible debt burdens.
The trend these days, however, is toward the five- or 10-year interest-only loan - with the principal as a balloon on the due date, Mr. Shernicoff said. That means lower interest rates and more flexibility in rearranging building finances as the opportunity arises.
''Corporations exist in perpetuity,'' he explained. ''Since the building has many owners, it will outlive any one owner, and the bank will continue to lend as long as the building is there. So it doesn't make sense to be tied down to a long-term mortgage.''
SHAREHOLDERS benefit from tax deductions when their co-op borrows, since a portion of the interest payments is assigned to each lease. Any capital gains tax due on an apartment when it is sold can also be reduced by deducting the costs of capital improvements paid for by assessments, Mr. Shernicoff said. But, he added, capital gains are rarely charged against primary residences, since the law allows a seller to reinvest the profits in a new home without penalties, if the seller does so within two years.
Mr. Shernicoff played out a hypothetical scenario to describe the differing tax advantages for an owner in a 100-unit co-op in which each unit is assigned 10 shares.
If the building borrows $300,000 for capital expenses with a 11 percent interest rate in which 10 perdentage points are interest and 1 point is amortization, each owner would have a $300 interest deduction available in the first year of the loan.
For an owner in the 28 percent Federal bracket paying a total of 35 percent in income taxes (because of city and state levies), the interest rate would produce a $105 tax deduction, plus a $30 increase in the apartment cost basis, figured for capital gains purposes, in the 1 percent amortization payment.
But, ever the accountant, Mr. Shernicoff warned that the market price of the apartment might suffer as a result of the borrowing because the interest costs of the loan would raise maintenance charges.
Some buildings, the accountant went on, do not have to borrow at all.
''If you are dealing with a relatively wealthy population of shareholders on Fifth Avenue,'' he said, ''they might prefer to invest the money themselves in the building rather than having the corporation do it, so they simply assess themselves for the amount they need and write a check. In a more middle-class or modest-income building, where people are living from paycheck to paycheck, the shareholders might not be in a position to write a check for thousands of dollars, so they borrow, or use the reserve fund.''
BUT in small amounts, assessments can work very well, said David Smith, president of the Penn South co-op complex, the 2,820-apartment limited-equity co-op between 24th and 25th Streets on Eighth Avenue. Limited equity means that tenant/owners may recover only their purchase price, adjusted for inflation, when they sell their units. The figures for a long-term resident currently are $8,000 for a one-bedroom apartment, $10,000 for a two-bedroom and $13,000 for a three-bedroom unit.
The giant public development, sponsored by the International Ladies Garment Workers Union, is nearing the end of a renovation project costing $20 million, almost half its total 1962 construction cost. The improvements include a $7.5 million co-generation plant, allowing it to generate its own electricity. It has borrowed most of the money but needed $1.2 million quickly this fall.
To borrow further, approval of the New York City Board of Estimate is needed and action on the matter is not likely before late next month. Penn South was built with low-cost state bonds after the project was approved by the Board of Estimate. The board of directors has asked apartment owners to assess themselves $100 a room, to be added to their equity payback when they move out.
''Doesn't it make sense for us to go to ourselves instead of to a bank?'' Mr. Smith said. ''It's the cheapest rate anywhere and we pay ourselves back when we move. But if you need two, three thousand, you can't get that kind of money out of people, so you go to the bank.''
In some cases, a condominium or co-op could resort to the reserve fund, the rainy-day account that well-managed buildings gradually accumulate from a portion of each tenant's monthly charges. The size of the reserve depends on the age and condition of the building, experts say, and they also agree that it is best used for emergencies, and must always be replenished.
''Put the contingency charges in your budget and if you don't use them, don't spend it to reduce your maintenance, but bank it and watch it grow, '' Mr. Chernicoff said.
A far more typical example of co-op financing than either the huge Penn South or the relatively wealthy 670 West End Avenue is the Carlton, a 144-unit, five-year-old co-op at 3441 85th Street, in Jackson Heights, Queens. The 43-year old building was converted in 1984 with a $250,000 reserve fund from the sponsor and a $900,000, 11.75 percent, five-year mortgage due at the end of this year.
The reserve fund was quickly spent on badly needed new windows and the building needed more money for longer-term repairs, said Martha Goldstein, the board treasurer, who bought her parents' two-bedroom apartment in the building for its terrace and broad views of the Manhattan skyline.
In 1987, the co-op took out a $1 million second mortgage and spent $800,000 of that on a complete masonry waterproofing and the rest on additional amenities such as a master television antenna.
''At that point we realized that our balloon mortgage was coming due,'' Ms. Goldstein said, ''so our lawyer negotiated with Citibank to assume the entire mortgage debt and give us some extra money for more improvements, at a rate lower than on the first and second mortgages.''
The first mortgage interest rate of 11.75 percent dropped to 9.75 percent on the new, 10-year loan, and the building ended up with with an extra $500,000 to rebuild elevators, redecorate the lobby and halls, encapsulate asbestos in the basement, renovate gardens and repair the building's 85-space parking garage.
''All of this was done without raising the maintenance at all, because the interest rates are so much lower,'' Ms. Goldstein said.
The earlier second mortgage in 1987, charged at 1.5 points over the then 10.2 percent prime rate, necessitated a 30 percent maintenance increase the following year, however, and an additional 2.34 points may be necessary at the end of this year to pay for increased staff salaries. Monthly maintenance charges have accordingly grown from $200 to $400 a month when the building was converted to $300 to nearly $500 a month today.
''That doesn't sound bad, but this is Queens, this isn't Manhattan,'' Ms. Goldstein remarked. ''We now have the best building in our neighborhood, but our maintenance is also the one of the highest, to the point where people who would normally want to buy in our building can't afford it.''
HOW do co-op boards find out that their maintenance is getting out of line with the surrounding community? From real estate agents, Ms. Goldstein said. Would-be sellers quickly bring the message back from their visits with local brokers, a message, she said, mimicking a broker, that goes: ''If you could just get your board to do something about your maintenance . . .''
For Ms. Goldstein, a freelance book editor, learning the ins and out of co-op financing - and refinancing - has brought home one lesson in particular: Hire good help.
''Shareholders don't know an awful lot about it and they don't care,'' she remarked. ''They used to be renters, like I was, and they just want to go to work and pay their maintenance and live their lives, and they don't want to get involved with running a major real estate operation.''
So hiring a lawyer, Morris Ordover, became a first step in handling the myriad negotiations with banks and contractors, she declared.
''Lawyers don't just interpret real estate law, they do your negotiating so that your unpaid board members don't have to get involved in this,'' she said. ''I mean, we're talking about a $2.2 million mortage and another million-dollar capital improvement fund and here I am, being Donald Trump for nothing.''

HEADLINE: COMMERCIAL PROPERTY: The Capone Connection;
Transforming a Onetime Chicago Mob Headquarters

BYLINE: By JODY BROTT

DATELINE: CHICAGO

 BODY:
A $2.6 million Federal urban development action grant awarded to this city last month has provided the last link in the financing of a $28.6 million project to transform the historic Lexington Hotel, where Al Capone had his headquarters, and a neighboring building into a 258-suite hotel with 32,000 square feet of retail space.
Its developer, Dr. Ganesan Visvabharathy of Vilas Investment Properties of Chicago, plans to annex a three-story building and combine it with the hotel - known in its later years as the New Michigan Hotel - providing 50 suites and 16,000 square feet of retail space. One Capone suite will be restored as a tourist attraction.
Construction on the hotel, on the northeast corner of Michigan Avenue and Cermak Road, three miles south of the Loop and four blocks west of the McCormick Place exposition complex, is to begin in November and take two years. Its original name will be restored. 
The Lexington project joins a booming Chicago hotel market. Six hotels have been built downtown since 1987, bringing the number there to 55, with about 25,000 rooms, according to the Chicago Convention and Visitors' Bureau.
Half a dozen more are scheduled to open over the next two years. Unlike the Lexington, however, all the new hotels are either in or north of the Loop.
Dr. Visvabharathy, who has a Ph.D. in business administration from the University of Illinois, has retained for historical restoration John Vinci, an architect known for restorations of Carson Pirie Scott & Company, the Trading Room of the Art Institute of Chicago and the Frank Lloyd Wright Studio in Oak Park, Ill. He is now restoring the lobby of the Chicago Tribune Tower. The local architectural firm of Loebl, Schlossman & Hackl is designing new construction.
A Chicago landmark listed on the National Register of Historic Places, the Lexington is vacant, boarded and windowless, its once elegant plaster and marblework vandalized. It stands in what once was a thriving commercial and industrial neighborhood that has now been designated a tax-increment financing district, a 20-block blighted area bounded by 21st Street on the north, 23d Street on the south, Martin Luther King Jr. Drive on the east and State Street on the west.
Dr. Visvabharathy has an option to buy the hotel, which he has said he will exercise in November. The building was acquired in 1983 by the Sunbow Foundation, a professional women's group that intended to renovate it while training women in construction trades. But it ran out of money.
The developer said he will pay $750,000 for the hotel and $1.5 million for the adjacent building, which currently houses small businesses.
In addition to the urban development action grant, which lets the city make a low-interest loan of $2.6 million to Vilas Investment Properties, $17.5 million will come from private lenders, $3 million from private investors and $5.5 million from the city's tax-increment financing bonds. These are retired by tax increments gained from improved properties. The city expects the completed project to generate $685,000 in annual taxes.
''The city very much supports this project,'' said Joseph J. James, the Commissioner of Economic Development. ''It will provide a tourist attraction where there currently is an eyesore and we hope it will activate a ripple effect throughout the area in terms of revitalization.''
MR. JAMES also said that he hoped the hotel would handle the spillover from McCormick Place, which added 534,000 square feet of exhibit space - about a third more than it had - two and a half years ago and complement the 30-acre Chinatown expansion scheduled to begin next month six blocks west of the hotel.
He said the Lexington work would provide 175 jobs during construction and, once complete, 432 permanent jobs.
However, Eugene E. Krell, senior associate of the local Real Estate Research Corporation, a national consulting firm, called the project ''questionable,'' adding that ''it will be difficult to achieve the room rate required to cover the cost of renovation in that location.''
Dr. Visvabharathy said he will charge $99 a room, 20 percent less than downtown competitors. He said he will target ''the built-in market'' of the nearby McCormick Place, one of the country's busiest exhibition centers, which Charles L. Durham, financial consultant to the Lexington Hotel project, said lacks nearby hotel space.
From his hotel window, Capone watched Eliot Ness and his Prohibition agents drive a caravan of seized beer trucks. When Cornelius Vanderbilt Jr. interviewed him in his hotel suite for Liberty magazine in 1931, the mob leader called for a ''safe and unspoiled America'' and said he had fed ''350,000 people a day'' the previous winter.
But ''even if Capone never set foot in it,'' said Timothy J. Samuelson, an expert in Chicago architecture and history, the hotel would hold its own as ''a very important early building.''
In its heyday, the hotel was known as an extension of the fashionable Prairie Avenue District, where some of Chicago's wealthiest citizens, including George Pullman and Marshall Field, lived. It also is one of the few architectural survivors of its kind, as famous as a prototype of the Chicago School of architecture as it is infamous as the site of Capone's headquarters.
The buff-colored brick building has a terra-cotta cornice and a central skylighted court that extends from the second to the tenth floor. It was designed as a first-class hotel by Clinton J. Warren, one of the important architects of the turn of the century. Warren, who specialized in hotels, adapted the openness of Louis Sullivan's skyscraper metal frame office buildings to a hotel format.
The hotel opened in 1892. One of its first guests that year was President Grover Cleveland, in Chicago to dedicate the World's Columbian Exposition. Considered an exclusive address, the hotel provided permanent housing for the well-to-do and rooms for transients. However, by the early 1900's, the wealthy began to move to North Lake Shore Drive, making the area less desirable.
In 1928, during Prohibition, Capone and his gang moved onto the fourth and fifth floors of what had by then become a second-rate hotel in a declining neighborhood. One of his suites - with a bay window and one-of-a-kind luxurious pea-green-and-lavender-tiled bathroom - was on the southwest corner of the fifth floor.
IN 1931, when Capone was convicted of income-tax evasion and sent to prison, his entourage moved out. Seven years later, to try to create a more positive image, the name was changed to the New Michigan Hotel. The effort failed, the hotel became a brothel and the area continued to decline.
Despite the success of Mama Batt's, a well-known kosher restaurant on the ground floor, the hotel closed in 1980. Three years later it was put on the National Register of Historic Places and in 1985 was designated a Chicago landmark.
In 1985, too, the television talk-show host Geraldo Rivera did a program featuring the exploration of a vaulted space under the sidewalk that was to uncover what was believed to be Capone's secret vault. The only things found were a broken sidewalk and a few empty bottles believed to have belonged to contractors who worked on the building.

LENGTH: 463 words

HEADLINE: Drug Evictions

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Your article on Oct. 1 entitled ''Running Drug Dealers Out of Public Housing'' contains a serious error with regard to eviction procedures in New York State. Let me correct the record.
The article correctly states that in federally subsidized public housing, the Department of Housing and Urban Development is permitting a waiver of the grievance procedure (administrative hearing) before going to court to seek an eviction. The intent of this waiver is to expedite the eviction of drug dealers in public housing. Incorrectly, however, you state that ''the only state without a waiver that is not seeking one is New York.'' 
Not only has New York sought such a waiver, but it was successful in doing so, as Gov. Mario M. Cuomo announced in May of this year. Due to the Governor's initiative, New York State was the first state to receive on a statewide basis a waiver of the grievance procedure so that drug-related evictions could proceed expeditiously.
In January of this year, I established an antidrug program within the New York State Division of Housing and Community Renewal. Under this program, a number of significant steps were taken to assist housing managers throughout the state in reducing drugs and crime.
First, regulations governing evictions in state-assisted housing (18,000 units of Mitchell-Lama housing and 22,000 units of public housing) were changed earlier this year to allow faster access to the courts in drug-related cases. As a result, these housing managers can now initiate a drug-related eviction directly in court, without a prior administrative hearing. This change is similar to H.U.D.'s waiver of an administrative hearing, which affects 193,000 units of federally subsidized public housing in New York State.
Second, the state's housing agency revised the language in leases used in Mitchell-Lama housing to unequivocally state that possession of illegal drugs or weapons is grounds for eviction. Similar changes for state-assisted public housing leases will be recommended shortly.
Third, we are continuing to assist our housing managers in the field with a wide range of technical assistance on ways to improve security in their developments and seek funding for programs to prevent and reduce drugs and crime. Special training and materials for antidrug programs have been developed for this purpose.
The state housing agency has a long-term commitment to combating drugs in housing. We will remain actively involved in finding effective and sound ways to eliminate drugs and crime, to insure that safe, affordable housing is available for the people of the state, who deserve it.
 
RICHARD L. HIGGINS
 Bronx
 
The writer is Commissioner of the New York State Division of Housing and Community Renewal.

HEADLINE: POSTINGS: 51 Low-Cost Houses;
2-Families

 BODY:
More than two years after New York City began the nation's largest low- and moderate-income housing program, construction is moving at full throttle. In one recent initiative, work is nearing completion on El Rosario, a complex of 51 two-family homes in a blighted industrial section of the East Williamsburg neighborhood in Brooklyn. 
The noncontiguous project, bounded by Bushwick Avenue, White, McKibbin, Seigel and Moore Streets, is being financed by the city, the state and the New York City Partnership, a nonprofit economic development organization. The homes are being built by the Beechwood Organization of New Hyde Park, L.I. They are to be sold for $141,000, far below the price of a comparable Brooklyn property.
Each of the homes will have a two-bedroom, one-and-a-half-bath owner's unit and a three-bedroom income-producing apartment.
To qualify, buyers must be able to make a 10 percent down payment and have annual incomes of $35,000 to $53,000.

HEADLINE: CONNECTICUT OPINION;
Halloween: Big Business and Big Trouble

BYLINE: By Matt Sawyers; Matt Sawyers lives in Unionville.

 BODY:
AS certainly as suburban doorbells chime when the sun goes down each Oct. 31, cash registers everywhere will relentlessly ring in the weeks preceding Halloween. Candy corn is steady at 99 cents a pound. A decent Batman costume will go as high as $20. Child-sized candy bars are piled up at the entrances and exits and checkout counters of grocery stores. School is back in session. Halloween is coming; it's in the air. 
What galls me, though, is that whenever I go off about what a publicly sanctioned scam Halloween really is, people gape at me and say, ''It's for the kids! Where's your heart?'' In addition to being a numbing platitude, this is patently false. Halloween is big business and therefore big trouble, friends. I think greater scrutiny should be paid to see exactly who gets what from it.
The economic boons of Halloween begin well before it and peak around the night of Oct. 30 (known to some as Cabbage Night), when toilet paper and egg sales go to the moon. High school students especially love to pelt friends, houses, planes, trains and automobiles with eggs and are known to gift wrap small pickup trucks in toilet paper.
In my old neighborhood in Avon no thinking adult would step outside on the night of the 30th, except Mr. Stockwell, who turned on searchlights and walked the perimeter of his yard with a softball bat. Who could blame him? More to the point, who could simply explain to him that we were receiving our first exposure to the tenets of vigilantism and guerrilla warfare?
The economic dominoes fall. Expect to see an immediate run on cleaning products in the days after Cabbage Night and Halloween, when homesteaders emerge from the house to assess egg and soap damage to their cars, which somehow always seem to absorb the brunt.
In the next six months, orthodontists and dentists will probably notice a surplus of taffy deposits in young mouths. A dentist friend of mine in West Hartford confided in me once; ''From the mouths of babes comes a very good living. Sometimes even a whole Porsche.''
Lunacy is one with the moon, they say. So what can be done? I answered the door last year in my Ed Meese mask, and they still came in droves. The year before I played Barry Manilow at peak volume and the doorbell rang all night. One year I reached my limit and sprinkled dry pet food into the outstretched pillowcases after I ran out of candy. The following morning my neighbor called and asked if I was missing a mailbox bearing my name and street number and could I please remove it from his compost pile.
One department store will be announcing its ''Million Dollar Halloween Clearance Sale'' soon, as it always does two weeks or so before the 31st.
Now, though, it occurs to me that dwelling on the economics of Halloween ignores the truly nightmarish aspect of it: The mobilization of our children against their adult oppressors. Let us keep this in mind this Oct. 31 as we lurch out of our easy chairs, put down an old copy of ''Lord of the Flies'' and trudge to the door to feed the armies of the night.

HEADLINE: The Social Cost Of Low Wages

 BODY:
The article dealing with the homeless problem in New Jersey was very timely (''State Grapples With Homelessness,'' Sept. 17). The reference made to the low wages and high cost of rent facing the poor in our state has been confirmed by many private agencies involved in aiding the homeless. 
In our state, we have seen the decline of the manufacturing sector from 40 percent of all jobs to a new low of 20 percent. The closing of manufacturing plants, paying much higher wages than the service sector, has forced our middle class into the poverty level. Rampant unemployment and little hope for the future have spawned rising crime, divorce, suicides and a drug culture among the poor in inner cities.
The cure lies in providing more higher-paying jobs to skilled and semi skilled workers. We have to recognize the fact that a misguided trade policy by the Federal Government has exported millions of manufacturing jobs to countries with wage levels but a fraction of ours.
If our policy was founded on common sense and related to our people's needs, a revival in American industry would result. The policies of Japan and the European community are realistic, and their citizens the beneficiaries. Our Government has the responsibility to do likewise. Only then can we reverse the decline in the living standard of our middle class.
 
GEORGE VARGISH
 Saddle River

HEADLINE: FOCUS;
Fabricating 326 Rental Apartments in an Old Mill Town

BYLINE: By MICKY BACA

DATELINE: NASHUA N.H.

 BODY:
Since the completion last January of the conversion of a 160-year-old mill here that is on the National Register of Historic Places, all but a handful of its 143 apartments have been rented and this city considers the success of the project, called Clocktower Place, a major step in revitalizing its downtown.
Both the first and second phase of the project have substantial Federal funding and thus must provide units at below-market rents to low- and moderate-income families. The second phase, which will begin soon, will create an additional 183 apartments, bringing the total to 326, as well as a 492-space underground garage on the six-acre site. The site now has a 63-space parking lot. 
The one- to three-bedroom project is moving forward at a time when mill conversions, plentiful throughout New England since the mid-70's, have been curtailed in response to a slower economy and a scarcity of Federal housing funds, according to Margo Webber of Newton, Mass., a historic preservation consultant who worked on the project.
She said that the complex once housed the world's largest blanket mill, operated by the Nashua Manufacturing Company. It was purchased by Textron in 1945 and shut down three years later when many of the nation's textile manufacturers moved to the South, where both land and labor were cheaper.
On Wednesday, in Lowell, Mass., 15 miles south of this city, the first phase of a $60 million conversion of the former Massachusetts Mills complex will open. Joseph Mullins of Boston is the developer. Of 442 rental apartments planned, 130 will be ready for tenants, according to Reginald A. Ouellette, Lowell's director of Economic and Industrial Development. In addition, he said, a $50 million conversion of the former Boott Mill into 600,000-square feet of office space by Congress Group Properties of Boston is expected to be completed by the end of the year.
The Clocktower Housing Association Limited Partnership, whose general partner is Edward Brice of Brookline, Mass., secured housing development action grants to finance almost half of both phases of Clocktower Place. It is the first conversion of a mill complex to housing in this city of 80,000 residents.
Jane Adelman, the project manager, said the two-building first phase cost $12 million, with $5 million of that sum covered by the Federal grant.
The second phase, which will involve the conversion of three more of the old mill's seven connecting buildings, is expected to cost $21 million, including $10 million in Federal grants.
Under the grant requirements, Clocktower Place must offer below-market rents to low- and moderate-income tenants for 25 years on 20 percent of the units in the first phase and on 30 percent of the units in the second phase, according to David Boesch, the city's Community Development director.
Below-market rents for the first phase will range from $355 to $525; for the second phase, rents may be no more than 30 percent of a tenant's income.
Market rents range from $615 to $975 for the first phase and are expected to be $700 to $1,000 for the second, according to Ms. Adelman.
The five-story mill building complex hugs the bank of the Nashua River, whose waters were used to power the generators for the mammoth textile mill operations that once thrived here. Ms. Webber said a slower real estate market, the lack of Federal housing subsidies available for mill conversions and a 1986 tax reform measure that limited the tax credit for historic preservation have slowed the pace of mill conversion in the past two years. She said she is hopeful that an effort under way to restore the tax credit will revive mill conversions.
Bruce Polishook is president of CWC Builders, a Newton, Mass., which did the historic renovations for the first phase of Clocktower Place. Now he is transforming the Kennedy Biscuit Factory in Cambridge, Mass., into 142 apartments with the help of Massachusetts Housing Finance Agency funding. He said fewer mill renovations are now being planned in the region.
''We are looking at a couple of them but it is much tougher for developers to make them work,'' he said. ''There is less state and Federal money available.''
Many experts say mill conversions to condominiums are now on hold because the market is overbuilt and extremely soft. But Michael Prozeralik of the Architectural Team in Newton, Mass., the architectural project director for the Clocktower Place, said Nashua still is in need of good rental housing.''
Mr. Boesch termed Clocktower Place ''a substantial project in the downtown that signals that it is in a transition period.'' To implement the downtown revitalization, he said, the private sector has joined the city in promoting the Downtown 2000 Plan to encourage a mix of residential, retail and commercial development that would make the area the city's focal point.
He noted that a proposal for a 130,000-square-foot office-retail structure called Gateway Center is now in the final approval stages. The project will preserve the facade of the Chase-Sears block on Main Street, with new 10-story structure rising behind it.
A key element of the Downtown 2000 Plan will be the rejuvenation of the Millyard - 30 buildings, some of which are now occupied by light industrial enterprises, that once turned out miles of flannel, cotton and denim. Mr. Boesch said that the city hopes to see the revitalization of the district realized by the turn of the century.
He said that the rental success of Clocktower Place has been ''quite remarkable.''
''It's nice to see middle income, younger families locating in the downtown,'' Mr. Boesch said. ''We hope that this developer or others will be willing to pick up additional mill buildings and do similar good things.''
Ms. Adelman said she would not rule out a proposal by her company to do a third phase for Clocktower Place. ''It's moved fairly quickly and we're very pleased because it was an unknown,'' she said.
The Clocktower Place mills were built between 1823 and 1920 as the textile manufacturing business grew in Nashua, according to Ms. Webber. In recent decades, the buildings had been used for a variety of small manufacturing and warehouse ventures. Mill buildings adjoining the Clocktower Place project now house businesses ranging from tote-bag manufacturers to trucking operations.
The windows for Clocktower Place are replicas of the original mill windows, providing ample light and river views to the rental units, which feature 12- to 14-foot ceilings and sun porches. The mill complex contains two clocktowers that are in the process of being restored, according to the acting property manager Erol Duymazlar.
The project, which features a fitness center with a sauna and whirlpool, is within a block of the city's Mine Falls Park, a 350-acre recreational area along the river.

GRAPHIC: photo of Clocktower Place, mill converted to residences in Nashua, N.H. (NYT/Jon-Pierre Lasseigne)

LENGTH: 1199 words

HEADLINE: Scrutinizing the World of Taxation

BYLINE: By PENNY SINGER

DATELINE: HARTSDALE

 BODY:
WHEN it comes to international taxation, businessman and bankers here and abroad look to Walter H. and Dorothy B. Diamond. From their office here, the husband-and-wife team provide a constant stream of data on the changing world of finance and trade.
Their 46 books - on such topics as tax havens, capital formation, investment incentives and free-trade zones - were produced for a series published by Mathew Bender in Albany. Its volumes are sold to 10,000 subscribers worldwide. 
To produce these books, the Diamonds have 600 correspondents worldwide who provide them with timely financial information and they also make trips overseas each year. Some of the traveling also stems from Mr. Diamond's work as the United Nation's international trade adviser and as an adviser to the United States Agency for International Development. He is also the author of the monthly International Trade Newsletter, published by 17 banks and trade organizations, and writes a monthly column for The London Financial Times.
 
Closing Foreign Banks
Mr. Diamond, who is in his mid-70's, traces his career to the onset of World War II, when the Federal Government put him in charge of closing down the German, Japanese and Italian banks in this country. He later became the manager for international taxation at two major accounting firms and has been a national bank examiner and a Federal Reserve Bank foreign analyst.
Mrs. Diamond, an editor and columnist whose specialty was once consumer affairs, said she began collaborating with her husband shortly after their marriage 42 years ago.
''I started out by editing his copy and learned a good deal about taxation,'' she recalled. ''So in 1973, when we were in Taiwan and Matthew Bender, our publisher, asked Walter to do a book on tax havens of the world, I was able to encourage him to take the assignment and I said I'd help him do it.''
 
'A Quick Study'
Her husband added: ''Dorothy, who is a clever woman and a quick study, soon became an expert in capital formation, marketing and international relations, free-trade zones and tax treaties. We became a team,'' he added, ''and Dorothy has had the distinction of becoming the first woman to address the International Tax Planning Association.''
Earlier this month, the Diamonds were completing a 450-page looseleaf supplement their subscribers will receive in January. Four such supplements are issued each year to keep pace with the changing factors that influence investment decisions, Mr. Diamond said.
The couple spoke freely about how they believe recent events affect the position of the United States in the international marketplace.
''There would have been a lot more selling this last Friday the 13th if President Bush had had his way and the capital-gains tax had been reduced,'' Mr. Diamond said, discussing the sharp drop in the stock market that occurred Oct. 13. He noted that his opinion was different thatn that of the President and that he felt that a reduction in the capital-gains tax does not automatically result in increased investment in plants and equipment.
''That's the President's philosophy, but actually, investment in plants and equipment has been going up steadily - 4 to 12 percent every year - for the last 10 years,'' he said. ''As for our capital gains tax, which is presently 28 or 33 percent, it is already lower than the capital gains tax paid in the rest of the world, where the rate is anywhere from 35 percent to 60 percent.''
 
Encouraging the Tax Havens
A reduction in capital gains tax, Mr. Diamond suggested, would have encouraged people to leave the stock market and to invest their money at a higher rate of interest in offshore tax havens. ''That would have resulted in even a larger flight of capital out of the country,'' he said.
In recent years, Mr. Diamond said, billions of American dollars have gone to 50 tax havens in the world. ''Tax havens have become a tremendous business in a lot of countries,'' he said. ''Guernsey, in the Channel Islands, for instance, is so overloaded with management-investment firms and branches of foreign banks vying for business from American investors that overcrowding has become a problem.''
The Cayman Islands, with $240 billion in United States currency, ranks first on the tax-haven list, he said. ''Then comes Luxembourg, with $200 billion, followed by the Bahamas with $180 billion. That's a lot of money going out of the country to our disadvantage.''
''I heard John Maynard Keynes say once, 'So goes capital expenditure, so goes the economy,' and that certainly is the case in the United States today,'' he added.
 
The Value of Incentives
Other countries in the free world, Mrs. Diamond said, encourage spending for plants and equipment by giving corporations incentives. ''Governments abroad pass laws that give companies subsidies so they can invest in their manufacturing plants, while we, on the other hand, are becoming a service economy,'' she said.
Tax-free trade zones is another area in which the Diamonds have specialized. Mr. Diamond helped design free-trade zones at Colon in Panama, Shannon in Ireland and Kaoshiung in Taiwan. Taiwan is the largest free-trade zone in the world.
Mr. Diamond said that in 1970 there were only seven such zones in the United States. ''Now there are 160, including No. 37 in New Windsor, N.Y., where Stewart Airport is based, and No. 37A in North Tarrytown, where the General Motors plant is located.''
 
'Not the Original Intent'
''A zone is a fenced-in area,'' he explained. ''A subzone, such as the one in North Tarrytown, is an individual plant. Free trade zones first appeared in the United States in 1934, during the Depression; they were seen as an attempt to help exports. But now they're being used to help companies that have problems and companies that want to raise their profit margins, which was not the original intent at all.''
Mrs. Diamond, who has spoken to the Rotary Club of Manhattan on this subject, said companies that want free-trade-zone status must apply to the United States Foreign Trade Zone Board at the Department of Commerce.
''A zone designation gives a company the ability to import raw materials from abroad without duty, which in turn gives them the opportunity to cut costs,'' she said. ''Our objection to the zone status for companies is that only a few of them - seven or eight I believe - are exporting their goods, which was the rationale for the trade zones in the first place. Companies with trade-zone status, we believe, should be exporting goods. Especially now, which would help our outstanding trade deficit.''
In another project, the Diamonds have put together 37 volumes of ''International Tax Treaties of All Nations'' for Oceana Publications in Dobbs Ferry. One reviewer called the latest volume, which has just been published, the world's most comprehensive contribution to the literature of international taxation.
''The first International Tax Treaty volume was compiled in 1975,'' Mr. Diamond said. ''We bring out supplements when they're needed to keep current. And we've been averaging two to five a year. We have about 26,000 subscribers on our list.''

LENGTH: 1005 words

HEADLINE: More Boats Being Kept On Racks

BYLINE: By ROBERT A. HAMILTON

 BODY:
MORE Connecticut boats are being kept year round in warehouses instead of on the water, as rack storage buildings, or boat valet operations, are constructed along the coast.
A boat is stored on racks, under cover, until its owner wants to use it; then it is loaded on a forklift truck and brought to the water. Most services offer one launching and re-racking a day during the boating season.
A new rack storage building opened recently in Branford, and developers are hurrying to finish others in East Lyme, Norwalk and Waterford to accommodate boat owners looking for winter storage. 
Boat valet services are also being planned in Greenwich and Stamford, and the Harbor Development Commission in New Haven is considering one there.
''There certainly are a lot more of them now than there were even a few years ago,'' said Dan Rothenberg, the principal environmental analyst with the Coastal Resources Management unit of the State Department of Environmental Protection. ''And that extends from Greenwich to Stonington.''
Although the state keeps no list of rack storage buildings in Connecticut, Ray Bovich, president of the Connecticut Marine Trades Association, said his group knew of two sites in Clinton, and one each in Milford and Old Saybrook. He said another large boat valet service recently opened in West Haven.
The boat valets under development, or on the drawing board, would at least double the available spaces, Mr. Bovich acknowledged. ''This kind of facility makes a heck of a lot of sense.'' Rack storage is typically cheaper than renting a slip, and the boat's parts will last longer if they are out of the corrosive salt water. In addition, as coastal land has become scarce, regulations for building on it have stiffened.
''It's a lot easier to build a rack storage building than it is to get approval to build anything in the water,'' said William T. Gardella Jr., a spokesman for Rex Marine in Norwalk, which is completing a 207-space warehouse.
Stanley M. White, president of Ocean and Coastal Consultants, which is planning the 225-space boat valet service in Greenwich, said: ''The benefits to the boat owner is the boat is secure, and it's out of the elements. You're going to see a lot more of these in Fairfield County.''
Boat valet services have been popular for years in warmer climates, and in resort communities. But until about five years ago, there was a surplus of dock space, and no incentive to develop rack storage here.
But the number of boats has increased dramatically in Connecticut over the last few years. From 77,078 boats registered at the end of 1985, the number increased to 81,485 the following year, 86,444 in 1987, and 94,819 last year.
A few years ago, Mr. Rothenberg said, rack storage buildings typically housed boats 18 to 22 feet in length. ''Now they're trying to cram the largest boats they possibly can onto the racks,'' Mr. Rothenberg said. He said 30-foot boats were routinely racked at some services.
''Rack storage is an attractive option, environmentally and economically,'' he said. Rack storage reduces the danger of a fuel spill and the need to coat the boat's hull with anti-fouling paints, which dissolve into the water.
The owner benefits because the boat is more secure and storage on racks is as much as $600 lower than at a slip for a 30-foot boat, valet owners said. For example, Rex Marine is selling space in its nearly completed rack storage building for $80 per foot for the 1990 boating season, or $40 a foot for the winter, Mr. Gardella said. A slip can be as high as $100 a foot per season in the Norwalk area.
Rack storage permits the marina owner to use dock space for larger boats, which pay more. ''A smaller boat just doesn't give the marina the same dollar value for the area it takes up in the water,'' Mr. White said. ''This concept really helps the little guy, who might not even be able to find a slip otherwise.'' But many people are worried about a glut of boat valets. ''It used to be so bad you couldn't get an in-water slip no matter what price you were willing to pay,'' Mr. Gardella said. ''But right now, it's not like that.''
So far, he said, Rex Marine has filled about 30 of its 207 slips, and it could take as long as two to three years to reach capacity.
''If you want to build one of these it better be with a service or sales operation, because there's going to be competition and you need something to convince people to use yours,'' Mr. Gardella said. ''People who build one of these and expect people to flock in are going to be disappointed.''
Planners are also questioning whether developers are rushing into plans for boat valet services without consideration to protecting views of the waterfront.
Norman F. Cole, principal planner in Stamford, said a plan for a 250-space boat valet, along with 200 units of condominiums and 100 marina slips on the site of the Hoffman Fuel depot, has received mixed reviews.
''We liked the idea of boat rack storage in that it creates an opportunity for people with smaller boats,'' he said, and the city encourages diversity on the waterfront.
''But we also raised questions about whether it can really fit on this site,'' Mr. Cole said. He said with the condominiums the site was nearly covered, and the boat valet buildings would block views of the water.
Mr. Cole said he was also concerned about the proposal to have forklifts running boats back and forth through a residential area.
''I don't know of anyplace in Connecticut where one of these has been integrated with a condominium project,'' Mr. Cole said. ''Obviously, we've got a lot of questions that need to be answered during our review.''
Mr. Rothenberg said another problem is as the land near the waterfront gets used up, proposals for boat valets are coming in for property further and further removed from the water.
''We've got some proposals now where these boats would have to be hauled some pretty good distances on a fork lift just to get to the water,'' Mr. Rothenberg said.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

COUNTRY: UNITED STATES (94%);

HEADLINE: BOOK & BUSINESS;
DROPPING IN ON A DRAGON

BYLINE: By FRANK GIBNEY; Frank Gibney is the author of ''Japan: The Fragile Superpower'' and other books. He is the president of the Pacific Basin Institute.

 BODY:

THE FOUR LITTLE DRAGONS
By Brian Kelly and
Mark London.
432 pp. New York:
Simon & Schuster. $21.95.
The Four Little Dragons - or Little Tigers as they are more frequently called - are South Korea, Taiwan and the two city-states of Singapore and Hong Kong. Their postwar economic growth, founded on hard work, ingenuity, a kind of Confucian family solidarity and well-targeted export drives to the developed countries (the United States in particular), has created one of the great success stories of modern times. They started in the shadow of the Japanese ''miracle'' - and were undoubtedly influenced both by Japan's business strategies and bureaucratic planning. But their extraordinary economic growth figures have exceeded even the consistently rising growth rates of Japan itself. 
Business entrepreneurs in all four economies are sometimes called ''Confucian Capitalists'' (though the term is used advisedly). Taiwan, Singapore and Hong Kong are basically Chinese polities. Their people are products of a Confucian heritage that stresses loyalty to the group, an almost fanatical devotion to education and family and the general acceptance of strong, patriarchal Government authority. South Korea, too, has a heavy Confucian heritage; and even more than the others, it is the very model of what some American economists have called the ''capitalist developmental state,'' whose aggressive economic expansionism has given the phrase ''free enterprise'' a new and often curious meaning.
The talent and industry of the Four Little Dragons, although often demonstrated in quite a different way from American preconceptions, have much to teach us. All in all, this is a subject that cries out for a good book.
Unfortunately, ''The Four Little Dragons'' is far from that. In fact, Brian Kelly and Mark London's hop-skip-and-jump travelogue through the four states (plus Thailand, thrown in at the end for no extra cost) may be the most carelessly written book about Asia - or almost anyplace else - that this reviewer has ever read. Full of cliches, unsupported generalizations, half-truths and factual errors, the serious publication of this work suggests the gulf between the realities of the dynamic Asia-Pacific world and the insular perceptions of Manhattan publishers.
Apparently fresh from the steaming jungles of the Amazon (the scene of their last book), Mr. Kelly, a business magazine editor, and Mr. London, a Washington lawyer, decided to charge into the urban jungles of Southeast Asia: ''Here was another frontier that invited exploration,'' Mr. Kelly writes in the introduction. ''For all either of us knew about them, the people of these countries might have been Indians from the remotest rain forest. Yet more than the Amazon, the Four Little Dragons were beginning to have a profound effect on the United States. From the trade deficit figures to the unemployed steelworkers to the almond-eyed math geniuses at MIT, it was apparent that the world no longer belonged to the Caucasian race. What we wanted to know was 'who are those guys?' ''
With this premise, and an oversupply of breathless prose, our two travelers set out for Dragonland. Their passage through each destination seems to have followed a pattern. First they obtained the services of local government public relations officials, whom they would use as foils for various quips and pleasantries about the country involved. Then, obviously too shrewd to be taken in by mere propaganda, they found some knowing friends or acquaintances who would tell them what was really going on. These volunteer Sherpas ranged from successful local businessmen with American college educations to fellow drinkers the authors ran into in the evidently innumerable local bars, nightclubs and hostess spas on their tour. This on-the-spot reporting is then buttressed with copious quotations from various authorities like James Clavell, Anthony Burgess, Robert Elegant, John le Carre, Theodore H. White and ''The World of Suzie Wong.''
Mr. Kelly and Mr. London's sweeping generalizations are made the more distasteful by an air of condescension bordering on racism. About South Korea, for example, they declare: ''As was only hinted in our first plunge into Seoul nightlife, alcohol is the great stimulant of the Korean economy. It numbs the pain of the workingman so he can make it through another 10-hour shift of tedium. But it also binds the office workers, from stock boy to director - each drinking on his own stratum, of course, in a modern tribal ritual that is not so far removed from the tribe.''
Or here they are visiting a Government office in Taipei: ''We were escorted into a waiting room where we watched a procession of young men dressed in blue suits darting in and out of several doors, waving telexes and newspapers and shouting to one another. . . . After 15 minutes of watching this the phrase Chinese fire drill came to mind.''
The authors laugh uproariously between themselves over the Chinese mispronunciation of ''cherder,'' which as every Washingtonian knows is pronounced ''chowder,'' and just could not understand how Koreans could mispronounce the name of their LeMans (''Re-mans'') car. They even resort to the old sahib act: ''As flight time drew closer . . . we panicked and shamefully involved [sic] White Man's Privilege, with Kelly jabbering at an airline clerk that we were important businessmen about to miss a connection.''
The continual Rover Boys tone is all the more unfortunate because the authors - obviously bright people - have included much good and interesting material in their account. They correctly point out the continuing political and social unrest that lies behind the extraordinary South Korean economic success story, as well as the inevitable climb of the low wages on which so much of the country's economic progress has been based. They were certainly not deceived by Lee Kuan Yew's velvet-gloved dictatorship in Singapore. They rightly make a point of Taiwan's extraordinary congeries of huge cash surpluses and small business, with direct tie-ins to merchants and wholesale buyers in the United States. They give us a sense of the frenetic beat of Hong Kong, the city that keeps grinding out its products and making its financial deals in the shadow of ultimate takeover by Deng Xiaoping's China. They also perform a service to American readers by going through the details of the huge Carrian Investments scandal that rocked Hong Kong some years back.
Still, this useful information is mixed indiscriminately with errors of fact. For example, Yoido Island, the site of the National Assembly and a forest of new high-rise office buildings in Seoul, is referred to as ''Cheju Island,'' which happens to be about 300 miles south of the city. In discussing the Korean War, the authors reappoint the Secretary of State, Dean Acheson, to the office of Secretary of War, and suggest a truce two years and almost 100,000 lost lives before the actual armistice was declared. And this is the first time I learned that Taiwan's land reform occurred because ''Chiang [Kai Shek] wanted to end landlord abuse.'' (It was forced on his Government mainly through American pressure.) Of course readers can enjoy vicariously the authors' on-the-spot investigation along the nightclub circuit. It remains a pity that they couldn't have taken some of their bar time and socked away a week or two in the library instead - or better still, spent a little more time in the countries they write about.

HEADLINE: IN SHORT: BOOKS & BUSINESS

BYLINE: By MARY GRACE BUTLER

 BODY:

WHEN GIANTS LEARN TO DANCE: Mastering the Challenges of Strategy, Management, and Careers in the 1990s. By Rosabeth Moss Kanter. (Simon & Schuster, $21.95.) This could have been a deadly academic treatment, full of charts and graphs, footnotes and tables. Instead, Rosabeth Moss Kanter, a professor of business administration at the Harvard Business School, has written a relaxed, readable account of the hows and whys of change in American corporations. In tomorrow's corporate Olympics, the prizes will go to the businesses and managers who have met the challenge of ''the ultimate corporate balancing act'': organizational and structural changes that will require, simultaneously, cutting back and growing, doing more with less. It is a complex world, Ms. Kanter says, and Americans are up against tough competition. Business is in transition because the world economy is changing, and the author peppers her pages with examples. While older corporations, like Eastman Kodak, learn to update their approaches, newer ones, like Apple Computer, are evolving from entrepreneurial start-ups to more mature, settled organizations. Change is the key: becoming lean without becoming mean, restructuring for maximum ''entrepreneurial thrust,'' developing and using synergies. (Once an upstart buzzword, ''synergy'' is now an accepted academic term meaning a ''whole that multiplies the value of the parts.'') Synergies involve getting more for less; hence the streamlining, bureaucracy-cutting, decentralizing that are necessary in today's postentrepreneurial corporate world. For all the change, however, and the uncharted waters ahead, Ms. Kanter makes it clear that people are the dominant factor and the most important resource in a successful business. The demands on them are multiple and conflicting; restructuring can disempower them, but they are the key to success or failure.

HEADLINE: In Oakland After the Series, Joy With an Edge of Sadness

BYLINE: By ROBERT REINHOLD, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: OAKLAND, Calif., Oct. 29

 BODY:
Oaklanders had waited years for this moment, to beat San Francisco in the World Series, to show the world they had something better than their snooty neighbor across the bay.
But while their Athletics drubbed the Giants in an impressive four-game sweep, the celebrations were decidedly muted today in this city where 40 died and 2,500 lost their homes in an earthquake 12 days ago.
Green and yellow balloons festooned the Athletics' locker room last night, but there was no spraying of champagne, and organizers said today that they had scaled back plans for the official victory rally scheduled for 11 o'clock Monday morning in Jack London Square on the waterfront.
 
Minute of Silence
The team will still arrive and depart by ferry to the tunes of the Oakland Municipal Jazz Band, but fireworks and a parade have been scratched, in part because such enthusiasm was regared as unseemly and partly because so many streets are still blocked by quake damage. The parade would have been very crooked. 
''We've scaled back dramatically,'' said a spokeswoman for the Celebrate Oakland Committee, Cassie Arnold, who added that the city would forgo its plan to give each player a gift. A moment of silence for the dead is planned for the one-hour ceremony, and fans will be encouraged to donate to the Northern California Earthquake Relief Fund.
The delayed Series victory came as a needed lift after so many stressful days. About 900 people spontaneously gathered for a noisy celebration at the square last night; fans danced and sang in the streets downtown, and carloads of Oaklanders with pennants, banners and signs cruised up and down Broadway, the main street, much of the night.
At Ricky's Sports Lounge and Restaurant, where a boisterous crowd of about 250 people erupted into dance and song at the last out, Rich Kapferer, a patron, said: ''Oakland needed this. It's such a lift. It's going to put everything back on its feet again.''
Even Margaret Currey, who spent this morning trying to salvage a few possessions from what had been her home in the historic Madison Park Apartments at Ninth and Oak Streets, was ecstatic. ''A sweep!'' she exclaimed. ''We knew the A's were going to win.'' And nearby, at a Red Cross shelter at Laney College, some of the displaced gathered around a television set Saturday night to cheer the team.
 
Hard Realities to Face
But once the cheering stopped, there remained some hard realities for this East Bay city of 356,000. Oakland had expected to reap $100 million in economic benefit from the American League playoffs and World Series. While some of that certainly came in, it paled before the devastation left by the 15-second temblor. Damage has been estimated at $1.2 billion, and that does not include the Nimitz Freeway, whose collapse killed 39 people.
The quake, which killed and displaced far more people here than it did in San Francisco, aggravated Oakland's chronic problems of poverty, homelessness and drug abuse. It damaged or destroyed hundreds of homes and businesses, shut City Hall and 11 other municipal buildings and forced dozens of stores to close.
Though the cleanup and reconstruction will bring an influx of Federal and state relief funds, officials here say those efforts will not begin to make up for the damage. Some business leaders add, however, that the quake will not delay the city's $250 million downtown revival plan; businesses displaced in other counties may even want to relocate in Oakland, where there are many vacant offices built to modern standards for quake resistance.
While diehard fans were glued to their televisions, the Series clearly did not attract the normal interest. Baseball could scarcely match the earthquake and its aftermath for tension and high drama.
With a brisk breeze and crystal blue skies, Jack London Square was gay and festive today, but not because of baseball. The usual Sunday farmers' market, with pumpkins and shiitake mushrooms piled high, was supplemented by a fall harvest festival that included a pie-eating contest. Nearby, a rowing regatta brought scores of crews from around the state.
There were plenty of A's fans in the crowd, including Ben and Enid Witharm. ''Things had to start going again,'' said Mr. Witharm, a retired sheet metal contractor, who was wearing a green A's cap. ''You cannot sit around and mope.'' His wife added, ''We live with tragedy.''
The team's most loyal fan may be Louise Jones, the harbor master for the pleasure boats that dock here. Dressed in Athletics green, she said she had been to every A's home game in 12 years but one, the day her son was married. For her, at least, the games provided validation that Oakland was better than San Francisco. ''We're the class side of the bay,'' she said. ''We always were. It's just that the rest of the country didn't know.''
 
'It's a Healing Game'
But at De Lauer's newsstand on Broadway, Charles Fortson picked up a Sunday paper and said he thought too much festivity was inappropriate. ''I think we should keep a low profile,'' said Mr. Fortson, an accountant for the Navy here. He is a former Brooklynite who still roots for the Mets.
The fans who gathered last night at Ricky's, with its six giant television sets and 40 smaller ones, had not forgotten the earthquake. ''There's still an underlying sense of empathy for people hurt in the earthquake, but tonight was baseball,'' said Morgan Colebrook. ''It's a healing game.''
