HEADLINE: LEARNING TO SAY NO: SCHOOLS AND THE DRUG WAR - A SPECIAL REPORT:
Judgment Replaces Fear in Drug Lessons

BYLINE: By JOSEPH BERGER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: KANSAS CITY, Kan.

 BODY:
Once confined to a class session or two reciting horror stories and statistics, drug education in America is undergoing radical changes as the crack epidemic touches the lives of younger children across the country.
Rather than frightening students, as teachers often found themselves trying to do following the drug curriculum of the past, schools are now seeking to help students develop personal traits that make them resist drugs: strengthening their ability to make sound judgments, to handle the stressful times of life, to resist pressure from friends and to resolve confusing signals at home and in the community.
Visits to classrooms from the heart of Brooklyn to the heart of America here indicated that drug classes are now being introduced a great deal earlier than ever before and they are laced through a child's school career.
 
Need for Studies Is Cited
Preliminary indications are that the newer courses may have a beneficial effect on the students who take them. But critics of drug education programs, old and new, contend that far too little scientific evaluation has been done to know for certain. And they say the Bush Administration's new anti-drug policy does not provide enough money for such research. 
In the schools in this area, where stores stock dolls of Dorothy of Kansas innocently skipping through Oz, teachers now give 15 lessons a year coaching sixth, seventh and eighth graders on how to refuse drugs. A skit illustrates how.
In the improvisation by eighth graders, Monica Navarro warned Danita Conway that she would tell their friends that Danita is a wimp for declining marijauna. Danita, using the ploy of ''reverse pressure'' she has just learned, snapped back that she will tell their friends ''your momma still tucks you in at night.''
 
Lessons Conveyed Simply
Or, in the crack-ravaged Bushwick neighborhood of Brooklyn, Sharon Fleishman may never mention the drug to her kindergarten pupils, but she helps the 5-year-olds understand the importance of caring for their health. In a 20-minute class about prescription drugs that she enlivens with cartoons of an intoxicated raccoon, she tries to convey a simple lifelong lesson: ''Only sick people should be taking drugs.''
The scare tactics implicit in earlier programs, particularly those of the 60's and early 70's, were based on the notion that stark facts and figures about the intoxicating effects and health perils of drugs would speak for themselves and send the message. But the thinking now is that the presentation of simple facts without helping a child deal with them has sometimes had the opposite effect. Particularly among children of poor neighborhoods, the facts often seemed to make drugs more enticing.
''Children don't learn by scare tactics,'' said Anne Garfinkel, a drug education teacher in the Gowanus section of Brooklyn. Even experts who say such tactics can be effective for some children acknowledge that other approaches are needed in inner cities.
Paul J. Brounstein, senior research associate at the Urban Institute, said these tactics work best with people who have something to lose. But, he added, ''if you're dealing with older, inner-city kids, kids with an experience of failure, with few perceived opportunities, you've got to overcome a major hurdle, which says drugs are an alternative to economic success.''
The fact is that most students already know a good deal about the legal and health perils of crack and other drugs. What they often do not know, particularly if they come from chaotic or broken homes, is how to make important personal decisions and how to defend their values, says Ginay Marks, the drug coordinator of School District 15 in southern Brooklyn, which has one of New York's most ambitious programs.
Teachers who lead anti-drug classes are also trying to get across the idea that when children feel hopeless, as almost everyone does from time to time, there are solutions other than drugs. Gauging the Success Positive Indications, But With Cautions One persuasive study of the effects of drug education, published this year, focused on the Kansas City metropolitan area's experimental Refusal Skills program, the one taken by Danita and Monica. Researchers found that a year after taking the class, 3 percent of the students reported they smoked cigarettes, 4 percent drank alcohol, and 3 percent used marijuana. Figures for the schools where the program was not taught were higher: 13 percent smoked tobacco, 9 percent drank and 7 percent used marijuana.
But Dr. Joel Moskowitz, a research psychologist at the University of California at Berkeley, is quick to caution that schools chosen for the Kansas City experiment were not, strictly speaking, randomly picked. They were selected because their schedules were most flexible. Nevertheless, it turned out that the students given the drug instruction and those who were not were roughly identical in economic and racial backgrounds.
Dr. Moskowitz, who reviews applications for Federal grants for drug programs, notes that other studies that seem to show favorable results are not fully conclusive. They are usually doneat well-functioning schools for middle-class children, he said. Even when they are conducted at schools with diverse populations, the reseachers often lose track of the most troubled students, and these are the ones most likely to use drugs eventually.
''Nationally and locally there are no well-evaluated effective models for 'what works' in prevention and education,'' said a June report by Interface, a private Manhattan research group.
Still, teachers say they must try something, even if it is based only on their hunches about what will work. ''We're the only agency that can make a difference on children,'' said Cathy L. Sillman, supervisor of drug education for the Kansas City, Kan., schools. Selecting a Program A Call for 25 Hours Of Class in a Year About 70 percent of the nation's schoolchildren get at least one class in drug education during their school years, said Zili Amsel, acting director of prevention research for the National Institute of Drug Abuse. But Robert M. Stutman, special agent in charge of the New York office of the Federal Drug Enforcement Administration, said more than 25 hours of classes a year that are led by teachers are needed to bring about ''attitudinal changes.'' Most programs, he said, offer six to eight hours a year, do not start until junior high school and may use outsiders unfamiliar with classic teaching techniques.
School systems battling complaints that students cannot read and write well enough are finding it difficult to pack 25 hours of drug education into a school year. Nevertheless, many have bolstered their programs. After complaints last year from Mayor Edward I. Koch that too few elementary school children were receiving drug instruction, Richard R. Green, then the New York City School Chancellor, mandated that every student receive at least eight hours. The city now spends $34.5 billion a year on drug education.
Increasingly, instruction is starting in kindergarten. Experts have persuaded many parents that because children begin using illegal drugs in elementary school, they need to be alerted early. The average user's initiation age, said Ginay Marks, is 12.6 years old.
Most school systems cannot afford the time to invent their own drug programs, so they have adopted programs tried other places. These programs, complete with tapes, models and manuals, bear catchy titles like ''Here's Looking at You, 2000,'' ''Growing Healthy'' and ''Project Star.'' Building self-worth and rehearsing strategies to resist pressure from others are part of all the programs, along with a focus on health habits and drug information. Reaching the Youngest Drugs' Effects As a Health Matter ''Growing Healthy,'' sponsored in part by the New York Academy of Medicine, has been adopted by schools in 41 states. It tries to subtly steer children in kindergarten through seventh grade away from drugs, alcohol and tobacco.
Children learn about nutritious foods, brushing their teeth and caring for their eyes. Only occasionally are drugs mentioned. In the fifth grade, students will dissect a calf's lung and inflate the air sacs with straws. This vivid illustration, teachers hope, will buttress lessons about the harms of smoking tobacco and marijuana.
Ms. Fleishman's kindergartners in Brooklyn get a ''Growing Healthy'' lesson three times a week. Showing cartoons from a book, Ms. Fleishman told them that only parents should be giving them drugs.
 
Walking a Fine Line
''If you see your brother and sister taking some medicine, what are you going to do?'' she asked. ''Call my mother,'' one boys shouted. ''Throw it in the toilet,'' another said.
''My cat was playing with it,'' said 6-year-old Jason Mungen, ''and I went to my mommy and she told my brother to put it back in the cabinet.''
Such lessons, teachers believe, are essential in a neighborhood like Bushwick where children with drug-addicted mothers are often being reared by grandmothers. Ms. Fleishman recalls that several years ago, when she first mentioned cocaine, a 5-year-old said: ''My mother takes that white stuff and puts it up her nose.''
''I have to walk a fine line between teaching children not to take drugs and not condemning their parents,'' said Ms. Fleishman. ''I try to explain that sometimes adults do things that aren't good for them.''
For Kansas City second graders, who receive 30 lessons a year from the ''Here's Looking at You'' program, the message is more overt. Seven children in Katie Mathews's class at the M. E. Pearson School arranged themselves like the organs of a human body by standing on chairs of varying heights.
 
In Exhaustion, a Lesson
Walter Dobbins played the brain, his fingers pecking away in the air like someone at a computer. Mark Reyes was the heart, pumping his arms like someone inflating a bicycle tire. Nicole Rodriguez and Camila Martinez played the lungs, taking deep breaths. Crystal Stafford and Linda Davis were the kidneys, making broomlike motions to sweep away poisons.
First, Mrs. Mathews had these organs go about their jobs at a easy rhythm, just as a healthy body would. Then she asked how they might respond if a drug were injected into this imaginary body. The actors speeded up and giggled. ''Don't stop, keep going,'' Mrs. Mathews urged. When they seemed really fatigued, she let them stop.
''Imagine what would happen to a human body if it never stopped and you just keep putting drugs in and the organs would keep going faster and faster and faster,'' she gently said. Middle School Approaches How 'Just Say No'
 
Can Be Practice
Children in more than 50 middle schools in Kansas City, Kan., and across the Missouri River in Kansas City, Mo., are learning from ''Project Star,'' a 15-lesson program that teaches ''resistance skills.'' It was begun by the local Ewing Marion Kauffman Foundation after disclosures of cocaine use by four Kansas City Royals baseball players.
''A lot of kids want to say no, but they don't know how,'' said Glenn Schoenfish, principal of the Argentine Middle School, on the Kansas side.
In Sally Welter's physical education class, children talked about ways their friends might entice, threaten or tease them to use drugs. Then, with prodding from Ms. Welter, they figured out ploys to combat the pressure. They decided on these methods: the Cold Shoulder, the Broken Record (constantly repeating refusals), the Good Excuse and Strength in Numbers (allying with friends who will not try drugs).
 
'O.K. to Be One of a Kind'
At Public School 32 in the drug-ridden Gowanus neighborhood of Brooklyn, Anne Garfinkel, known to her students as ''the drug lady,'' commands the classroom like a conductor, squeezing just the right shadings of meaning from students.
''I'm going to give you a $25 word,'' she told a sixth-grade class and wrote ''unique'' on the blackboard. ''What does it mean?''
After students ventured some definitions, she had them compose a three-column chart of how the class members were like all other people, like some other people and like no other people.
All people are alike, the students agreed, in needing food, clothing and shelter. Some are alike in tastes, opinions and talents. Nobody is alike in the way they look, their voices, even their fingerprints.
''What have you learned?'' Ms. Garfinkel asked.
''It's O.K. to be one of a kind,'' a boy in the front volunteered. Ms. Garfinkel smiled. Outcome Can Be Deadly In older grades, the drug question is addressed more explicitly. But individuality and clear thinking are discussed as well.
Mark Sherman told his class of ninth graders in Sunset Park, Brooklyn, the news story of a 16-year-old Long Island girl whose boyfriend, after drinking several beers, was killed trying to beat a train across the tracks.
''Those people who ran across the railroad track - did they think they were going to die?'' the teacher asked.
He wrote the word ''omnipotent'' on the board and suggested that the boyfriend might have been thinking: 'I'm quick and strong and I've got good reflexes.''
Leaving the class, Israel Guzman, a student, said: ''It makes you think. If I do this, then this is going to happen. If I don't do this, then this is going to happen.'' High School Challenges An Emphasis On Social Skills By high school, students are given much more detailed information, but the emphasis remains on social skills.
Gregory Faulkner, an instructor at Phoenix House, a Manhattan drug treatment organization, visits a health class at Washington Irving High School in the Gramercy Park area for a series of three lessons and informs them that the euphoria of crack lasts 20 to 40 minutes and is followed by a long depression. But his main focus is on getting students to talk about what they most value and how drugs may affect those values.
''Can a drug user really say he's valuing his health?'' he asked a class.
In an exercise, Reheim Moye, 17, acted the part of a senior class president who is being urged by the vice president, played by Jacqueline Moran, 17, to allow a keg of beer and marijuana on the annual class trip. The class evaluated Reheim's predicament.
''People will lose respect for him if he turns around and does the same thing she wants him to do,'' said one girl in the front row. But another added: ''If you don't do it, you could lose friends.''
For the most part, the students gave answers that adults would hope for. Reheim said he found the class valuable. ''It puts you in a situation where you have to deal with your emotions.''

CORRECTION-DATE: November 1, 1989, Wednesday, Late Edition - Final

The New York Times

PUB-DATE: October 30, 1989

SECTION: Section A; Page 1, Column 1; Financial Desk

HEADLINE: Accuracy in Short Supply In Flood of U.S. Statistics

BYLINE: By JONATHAN FUERBRINGER

 BODY:
The Government's system of gathering economic statistics, much like the nation's highway network, is badly in disrepair.
Statisticians and economists, both in and out of government, say that a combination of budget cuts and deregulation - much of it a legacy of the Reagan era - is eroding important yardsticks and undermining policy makers striving to guide the economy.
 Furthermore, despite an effort by the Bush Administration to reverse the trend, statistical agencies face more spending restraint this year. This could compound the damage, hurting some well-known reports, including the index of leading economic indicators, and reducing the frequency of data collection or eliminating some data altogether. Efforts to improve other gauges that professionals consider imprecise -notably those for retail sales and foreign trade - will also have to be set aside, officials said.
 
Everyone Is Affected
And lest anyone think this is a dusty debate for economists and bureaucrats, the truth is that these numbers affect the lives of all Americans. Social Security payments and some wages are tied to the official inflation rate, and the Government uses statistics to help evaluate welfare and other social programs. On a broader scale, bad numbers can mean bad policy and a recession instead of a recovery.
What is more, the financial markets increasingly jump up or down, making or losing millions for investors, with each new economic report - and with the revisions that follow.
For example, measured growth for the second quarter went from 1.7 percent in July, to 2.7 percent a month later, to a second revision of 2.5 percent in September, undermining confidence in the numbers and leading to wide confusion about the economy's direction. The 2.5 percent growth, after adjustment for inflation, reported last week for the third quarter could be subject to the same kind of revisions.
No one doubts that data gatherers face a difficult task: tracking precisely the nation's growing, shifting economy. But critics say they could do better.
 
A Lag in Technique
Critics see two problems: Current statistics, they say, are deteriorating because staffs and data collection have been cut and sampling techniques have not kept up with the economy.
They also maintain that budget cuts have forced statistics agencies to skimp on research needed to make data reflect broader changes in the way the economy functions. Economists are debating whether important statistics like productivity, savings and the G.N.P. really measure what is going on in the economy.
It will not be long, some say, before the Government will be trying to set economic policy with a statistical compass so inaccurate that it cannot find north.
In a poll taken at a recent meeting of the National Association of Business Economists, Walter J. Williams, president of American Business Econometrics Inc., said he found that 72 percent of his colleagues were unhappy with data quality, up from 61 percent in 1988. A rising number, 38 percent, said data quality was deteriorating. The figures on merchandise trade, retail sales and G.N.P. were rated the worst.
Jerry L. Jordan, a member of President Reagan's Council of Economic Advisers, said he shrugs when he sees many of the closely watched statistics spewed out monthly.
''I take the numbers with a big grain of salt,'' he said. ''There are enormous problems.''
Lyle Gramley, a former governor of the Federal Reserve Board, withholds judgment on monthly numbers ''subtly and unconsciously'' because of his concern about their quality.
''The worry,'' he added, ''would be that at a critical juncture the statistics would suggest a course of policy that we would come later to regret.''
Much of the erosion is a result of Reagan-era policies, including deregulation and a general de-emphasis of the data's importance. Budgets have also been held constant, at best, after adjustment for inflation.
Staffs have been cut in the Bureau of the Census, the Bureau of Economic Affairs, the Bureau of Labor Statistics and other agencies. At the Bureau of Economic Affairs, for example, the staff has been reduced from 453 in 1979 to 371 this year.
 
Key Revisions Delayed
The number of mathematicians at these agencies has been held constant, and there are fewer statisticians. The size of critical surveys, like the Current Population Survey, which is a base for employment reports, has been reduced. Key revisions in the calculation of other data, like the Consumer Price Index, have been delayed for several years.
In addition, research money needed to improve the data has been diverted just to insure adequate staffing and surveys for the core reports, like the G.N.P. and the Producer Price Index.
Changes begun before the Reagan era but continued under President Bush have also hurt. Deregulation of some industries, like airlines, and a cut in required paperwork for business reduced the amount and variety of data collected. Because of a changing attitude about government and the restraint on pay, there has also been a general decline in the quality of the people attracted to the statistical agencies.
In the budget process this year, the Bush Administration has lost its effort to make improvements. The $20 million extra the Administration asked for to increase quality has been rejected in Congress.
This loss will mean the setting aside of plans for the revision of the Current Population Survey used for employment data, and improvements in figures for manufacturers' orders, retail sales and trade.
''We're looking for core program cuts at the Bureau of Economic Affairs and for options for cutting the frequency with which we gather data or even eliminating some data,'' said Michael R. Darby, the Under Secretary of Commerce for economic affairs, who oversees two agencies.
 
Additional Budget Cuts
Paying for the $3.18 billion anti-drug and anti-crime bill now in Congress will require an additional 0.43 percent cut in military and domestic programs, including statistics.
And the across-the-board cuts under the budget-balancing law will force even more damaging restraint if they are not revoked. This will depend on Congress and the White House agreeing on their own deficit reduction package.
Michael J. Boskin, chairman of the Council of Economic Advisers, will release a review of the economic statistics system soon. He said improvements could be achieved without major new financing but acknowledged that the budget restraint hurts.
Mr. Boskin would not say directly that the quality of Government statistics had declined, but he agreed that ''improvements need to be made to give the same degree of accuracy in the more complex economy of today that we had in a much less complex economy years ago.''
The problem has been dramatized recently by sharp revisions in the reports for retail sales, non-farm employment and G.N.P.
Revisions, in themselves, are not bad; they are part of the system. Initial reports based on preliminary information are revised in later months as more data are gathered.
 
Dependability Questioned
Many professionals may well put too much weight on the monthly figures, although they are clearly warned that they will be revised. But recent wide swings call into question the dependability of the reports.
In retail sales, initial reports this summer gave some the picture of an economy slowing sharply, even heading for a recession. But later revisions showed a much stronger economy. The main reason for the G.N.P. change was the record revision in the retail figures for May, which went from an increase of one-tenth of 1 percent to a decline of one-tenth of 1 percent, and then to an increase of eight-tenths of 1 percent.
Mr. Darby of the Commerce Department said retail sales figures were based on a sample that was steadily shrinking in comparison with the number of retail establishments, helping cause sharp revisions.
As the initial figures were released, the Federal Reserve began to ease interest rates. But after the revisions changed the view of the economy, the decline was halted. ''Would policy makers have decided policy differently?'' Mr. Darby asked. ''I don't know, but they could have.'' (The Fed has eased rates since the stock market drop of 190 points on Oct. 13.) Is Problem Worsening?
Beyond revisions, the deep-seated problem is that the quality of the data could well be getting worse. The G.N.P., for example, is slowly losing its relevance. It is better designed to measure the output of goods and services in the 1950's, when manufacturing was king. The service sector -areas like banking, retailing, insurance and legal services - now makes up 75 percent of output. But much of the service economy is small, and new businesses are often missed. And many businesses that used to provide data voluntarily have stopped as a way to reduce costs.
One problem with the G.N.P., as noted in a recent report by the Office of Technology Assessment, is in measuring price changes and quality improvements, especially of computers and other high-technology products. The measures affect the calculation of input and therefore change the total measured output.
Mr. Darby said that for the current G.N.P. report just using computer prices for 1988, instead of the 1982 prices now used, would lower this year's first-half growth by half a percentage point.
''It is easy to conclude that the quality has slipped as the service sector has grown,'' said Ben E. Laden, a Washington consultant who worked on a report on statistics by the National Association of Business Economists. ''But whether the G.N.P. growth is higher or lower one really doesn't know. But I would think that we underestimate the economic activity over time.''
 
Other Measures Criticized
Problems plague other data, too. Productivity, which is crucial to future standard of living, and savings, which is important for investment, are both poorly measured, economists say.
Despite the advent of computers, automatic teller machines and other changes in the last decade, there has been no measured increase in productivity in financial services. There are no measures for the value of a college education or the training paid for by an employer, both of which should affect productivity and, therefore, the measure of workers' output.
Data considered less troubled, like unemployment, could also be affected just by the change in living situations. The growth of two-income families and other extended unrelated groupings could make gathering accurate data more difficult.
Janet L. Norwood, the commissioner of the Bureau of Labor Statistics, said the Consumer Price Index needs, but does not have, an adequate measure of medical costs, which now make up 12 percent of the G.N.P.
''We have to have the resources to keep up with the changes,'' she said. ''Because these are tight times we don't. And that's what is scary.''

HEADLINE: Houston Candidates Court Business

BYLINE: By ROBERTO SURO, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: HOUSTON, Oct. 29

 BODY:
Although business leaders can no longer anoint mayors as they did decades ago, the campaign now under way shows that good business is still good politics in Houston.
Both major candidates entered politics as reformers, fighting the kingmakers with the help of minority voters. That was in the boom years of the 1970's. Now with the city painfully recovering from its bust, they eagerly portray themselves as champions of economic development and defenders of Houston's fabled ''good business climate.'' 
Mayor Kathryn J. Whitmire, who is seeking re-election to a fifth two-year term, speaks out in favor of contracting out city services, and she coolly dismisses opposition from organized labor. ''It is no secret that the unions are mad at me,'' she said proudly. ''They have reason to be mad at me.'' Fred Hofheinz, who is trying to regain the office he held from 1974 to 1977, accuses the incumbent of letting Dallas take the lead in luring corporations, the equivalent of a New York City mayor letting New Jersey take the Statue of Liberty.
 
Understanding How to Sell
Challenging Mrs. Whitmire in a recent debate, he said, ''I think Houston needs someone who really understands the importance of entrepreneurial activity, who really knows how to sell something.''
Just as heat and humidity mark the weather here, low taxes and minimal city planning are the traditional elements of Houston's business climate. Both candidates have vowed not to raise taxes or to disturb Houston's place as the largest American city with no zoning ordinances. Houston is the nation's fourth largest city, with about 1.7 million residents.
And the emphasis on business extends to other issues. Parks, education, transportation and even law enforcement are routinely discussed by the candidates as ''amenities'' necessary to attract new companies to the city.
Legend has it that the city's business elite used to meet in SSuite 8F of the Lamar Hotel to make major political decisions, including who should be mayor. The men who dominated the city from 1930's through the 1960's have left their names on monuments, but they have passed from the scene and their favorite hotel was torn down a few years ago.
But business has remained politically powerful because there is no limit on the size of personal campaign contributions to local campaigns and because municipal politics is nonpartisan.
''Houston remains the extreme case among Sun Belt cities where business elites hold sway,'' said Joe R. Feagin, a University of Texas sociologist. ''Politics is very different in older cities like Chicago or New York where political parties, organized labor, immigrant groups, and, more recently, minority groups make it more of a negotiation among equals.''
 
New Cry: Diversification
But now the city's business leadership is far too large and heterogeneous to fit in a single hotel suite, and diversification has replaced oil as the corporate byword. Instead of demanding that government leave them alone, proponents of economic development now speak of ''public-private partnership.''
After six years of traumatic recession, which began with the plunge of oil prices in 1982, Houston has begun a slow economic recovery that homeowners and workers as well as business leaders considere as fragile and sacrosanct as a newborn child. Under these circumstances, business interests are certain to get careful treatment even in a campaign between two people who were once proponents of change.
While both Mr. Hofheinz and Mrs. Whitmire have always been fiscal conservatives, they both once fought to reduce cronyism in City Hall and the influence of socially conservative business leaders. Each has also fought for homosexual and minority rights. Both remain in favor of abortion rights.
 
Liberal and Conservative
In the current campaign Mr. Hofheinz has occasionally articulated his liberal views on social issues, and he has accused Mrs. Whitmire of ''running the city like a corporation rather than a community.'' But he has emphasized a need for a police crackdown on drug pushers.
''Mayor Whitmire began as an outsider but she has become very much an insider over time,'' said Richard Murray, a professor of political science at the University of Houston.
A conservative tilt may have been assured by the fact that this is a campaign between two candidates who have previously shown strength among black and moderate white voters. In an interview Mrs. Whitmire said she considered the city's West Side to be the crucial battleground in this election. In that area of affluent, overwhelmingly white subdivisions, deed restrictions, private police forces, privately contracted garbage pickup and private schools make up for weak public services.
When the campaign began in early summer, public opinion surveys showed Mrs. Whitmire in trouble. It was a remarkable show of vulnerability for an incumbent with a solid record of success at the polls.
Mr. Hofheinz then suffered the loss of a crucial supporter when Representative Mickey Leland, Democrat of Texas, died in an airplane crash in August. Mr. Leland, the city's most prominent black politician and one of many community leaders the Mayor has alienated during her tenure, had made the defeat of Mrs. Whitmire a personal crusade.
Mrs. Whitmire has since skillfully set the agenda for the campaign. She has portrayed herself as the leader who guided Houston through the dark days of the bust and on to recovery. The hard times serve her as ready explanations for tax increases, an understaffed police department and streets that flood in a modest rain.
In all her campaigns Mrs. Whitmire, an accountant, has insisted that choosing a mayor is a matter of picking the most competent manager, and recent polls indicate this approach seems to be working. While Mr. Hofheinz has been prone to vague pronouncements on ''the need for a change'' and ''leadership that unites,'' Mrs. Whitmire clearly relishes the details of governance.
When she was asked in a debate about solid-waste disposal and garbage collection fees, the Mayor responded happily, ''Thanks for raising two of my favorite subjects.''

PUB-DATE: October 30, 1989

SECTION: Section A; Page 18, Column 1; Editorial Desk

LENGTH: 470 words

HEADLINE: On Moscow: The President Is Missing

 BODY:
There is an iron law of bureaucratic politics in Washington: Until a President takes a firm public position on an issue, even his closest aides will push and pull in different directions. And there's an obvious corollary: Without a united administration, coherent action is impossible.
That's why it was comforting when Secretary of State James Baker seemed, in two important speeches, to put a stop to the Administration's extended hand-wringing over policy toward the Soviet Union. He declared unequivocally that the United States wants Mikhail Gorbachev's reform efforts to succeed. 
Now, distressingly, the Administration seems to have stumbled into disarray again. On Oct. 17, only a day after Mr. Baker pledged the Administration's help in changing the Soviet economy, Vice President Quayle had another idea. In a little-noticed speech, Mr. Quayle said, ''Let them reform themselves.''
Last week, an even more questionable challenge to policy unity was under way in the White House basement. Robert Gates, the deputy national security adviser, drafted a speech saying Mr. Gorbachev's prospects for success are very slim indeed, and implying that Washington should invest little in the Soviet leader's future. Fortunately, Mr. Baker squelched the Gates speech, though not the story, which was uncovered by The Times's Thomas Friedman.
President Bush's role in all this is unclear, as it is in many other matters. Perhaps he savors the idea of placating contending constituencies with the Quayle and Gates speeches for the hard-liners and the Baker speeches for liberals and moderates. That might make everybody happy and leave the President riding 70 percent approval ratings.
But surely Mr. Bush must see the dangers in all this confusion. For starters, disarray feeds the growing impression that he has no convictions and that he's straddling most important issues. He might also reflect on the fact that his political support, while broad, isn't very deep. He'll need a record of accomplishment to consolidate his strength.
Soviet-American relations are the best place to make his mark. Americans want glasnost and perestroika to succeed because these policies are bringing the changes the U.S. has wanted for 40 years. Mr. Baker is as pessimistic as the next official about Mr. Gorbachev's prospects. But he understands that's all the more reason to lock in agreements now, like treaties to cut arms that Mr. Gorbachev's successors would find difficult to reverse.
Unless the President puts his public stamp on the Baker line and grasps the historic opportunities before him, he will pay dearly. His advisers will fight each other over every comma of an arms treaty and stymie any effort to give economic help to Moscow. The moment for accomplishment will pass and Americans will know whom to blame.

HEADLINE: James Florio for New Jersey

 BODY:
For the most part, Tom Kean's eight years as Governor have been good ones for New Jersey. The economy has been robust, job growth strong and the state has shucked its image as a backwater to New York City and Philadelphia.
The last few years, however, have been full of troubling portents. The economy has slowed, tax revenues have fallen short of expectations and the problem of high auto insurance rates has festered. 
When New Jersey voters pick Mr. Kean's successor on Nov. 7, they will choose between candidates of sharply different philosophies: Representative James Florio, a Democratic advocate of activist government, and Representative Jim Courter, a Republican who favors market solutions to most problems. Mr. Florio seems the better choice.
Mr. Florio lost by a hair in 1981 to the man he now hopes to succeed. He has represented the Camden area in Congress for 15 years. Among his most notable accomplishments have been the environmental Superfund and legislation to speed the removal of asbestos from schools. He calls for more sensible state regulation of the auto insurance business, a flat ban on sales of assault rifles and more drug treatment and education as a means of fighting the AIDS epidemic. He refuses to be specific about how he would cope with the next governor's biggest problem: a revenue shortfall that could reach $600 million next year. That's not a satisfying stance, but it's probably a shrewd one. He wants to do a complete audit of the $12 billion budget - the first in 20 years - to identify where cuts can be made. He cautiously says he foresees no need for new taxes, but avoids a no-tax pledge.
Mr. Courter pledges no new taxes for at least four years. That's unwise and unrealistic. Next year's budget gap is just the start. For example, the State Supreme Court may require the redress of funding inequities between rich and poor school districts and that would require more revenue.
More fundamentally, New Jersey's sacrosanct tradition of municipal home rule has become an obstacle to solving big problems like solid waste disposal and efficient transportation. And while Mr. Courter is gregarious, his minimalist approach would do little to remove that stumbling block.
Neither campaign has been distinguished. Like last year's New Jersey Senate race, this one has seen too much mudslinging. Nevertheless, both men have communicated their messages about how to govern - and Mr. Florio's sounds more sensible.

HEADLINE: Campaign Matters;
Trying to Fool All of the People All of the Time

BYLINE: By FRANK LYNN

 BODY:
''Candidates see success as the ability to be all things to all people,'' said Frank J. Macchiarola, who has the unusual perspective of an academic, a former New York City Schools Chancellor and a losing candidate for city comptroller. ''They promise $2 worth of services for the $1 we have.''
Lee Miringoff, the poll taker for the Marist Institute, said simplistic television commercials and candidates who tailor their views to polls also tend to ''trivialize'' campaigns to the point where debates, when there are any, are more concerned with the candidates' ties, makeup and one-liners than issues.
John H. Mollenkopf, a professor of political science at the Wagner Institute in the Graduate Center of the City University of New York, argued that ''ideologies and strong positions on issues make trouble in elections.'' 
Finally, there is the view that even a knee on the chest of a candidate is not likely to produce strong and realistic opinions on how to solve the crime, drug, education, housing and fiscal issues that cast a pall over New York City.
Maybe some problems are beyond anything but Band-Aid solutions. More likely, special interests may not like one solution or another.
That certainly was the case in a series of interviews with mayoral candidates at The New York Times in the primary and general election campaigns.
The idea was to give the candidates the opportunity to discuss their plans at length in the calm of a conference room and to allow follow-up questions. No audience, no cameras, hopefully no wind-bagging or posturing.
 
What did we get at
The Times? Pat speeches. Tap dancing. Pirouettes. Mush. So much so that it was hard to tell the difference between David N. Dinkins, the liberal Democrat, and Rudolph W. Giuliani, the moderate Republican.
They didn't even have Mayor Edward I. Koch to kick around - as most candidates did in the primary - because Mr. Dinkins and Mr. Giuliani hope to inherit the substantial number of Koch primary supporters. At one point Mr. Giuliani even compared himself to the Mayor at the start of his first term, trying to rejuvenate a city coming out of a fiscal crisis.
Clearly Mr. Koch has contributed to this blandness by his cries of fiscal gloom and doom. No talk of major initiatives. Can't afford it. Somewhat like the last Presidential election.
So what's the difference which candidate gets elected?
Obviously there is a personnel difference. A Giuliani election would bring in a whole new cast of characters, including neophytes whose lack of political experience nearly sank the Giuliani campaign: lawyers, businessmen, yuppies, Republicans and maybe a few Liberals that are left.
Even a dyed-in-the-wool Democrat like Richard C. Wade, the urban historian, acknowledged that Mr. Giuliani ''would come into office with fewer obligations than any mayor for years.''
A Dinkins administration? There would be some old and new black officials. There would be liberal Democrats, organization Democrats, union officials, Koch administration holdovers and hangers-on. Some would bring governmental expertise, which is important. Others would bring less desirable baggage. There are already signs of lawyer-lobbyists who manage to change administrations like shirts. They like winners.
''Giuliani hasn't enough friends; Dinkins has too many friends,'' Mr. Macchiarola said.
There would also be a difference in priorities. Instinctively Mr. Dinkins would lean toward conciliation and social welfare issues, Mr. Giuliani toward crime issues and budget management. It could be a classic ideological confrontation, except that the candidates have blurred any distinction because they don't want to turn off any voters.
Mr. Giuliani, too, would have to reach out to a black community that has had its expectations of a black mayor raised more than ever before. Conversely, if Mr. Dinkins is elected, the race issue is likely to be muted in future elections, as it has in other cities like Chicago and Cleveland, which elected black mayors and followed them with white mayors. The point was made.
There would probably be fewer demands on Mr. Giuliani because his coalition is more diffuse and economically better off. Mr. Dinkins's initial base - minorities, the poor and municipal unions - would guarantee strong demands on him.
''High expectations, low cash,'' Mr. Mollenkopf said. He added that Mr. Giuliani would be ''not unlike Koch, emphasizing fiscal restraint.''
So, there are some differences. Even if the candidates try to hide them behind a lot of smoke and semantics.

HEADLINE: Would Unions' Backing Cost Dinkins as Mayor?

BYLINE: By SAM ROBERTS

 BODY:
If David N. Dinkins is elected mayor of New York City next week, his pledge to share the goals of the many municipal unions that were instrumental in his nomination and his longstanding commitment to help uplift the poor will be tested almost immediately.
Mr. Dinkins has won nearly unanimous support from leaders of organized labor, which contributed money and volunteers to his campaign and votes in the primary election.
Having raised expectations, what, his Republican opponent and other critics wonder, would a Mayor Dinkins deliver in return?
The financial community, comfortable with Mayor Edward I. Koch after almost 12 years, appears to be jittery about the prospect of any new mayor.
 
Panel of Economic Advisers
But with the city facing projected deficits and what analysts say is a cooling economy, some members of the business community have expressed concern that Mr. Dinkins, by temperament and ideology, may deviate from the fiscal conservatism that generally marked the Koch administration's successful efforts to restore the city's credit in the securities markets. 
That he briefly considered tinkering with the state law barring strikes by public employees and joined demonstrations by private hospital workers pressing their contract demands deepened those concerns.
Mr. Dinkins, the Democratic nominee, says the concerns are unjustified. To reassure skeptics, he has said he would ask the state Financial Control Board to estimate how much money is available in the city budget for collective bargaining.
He has already appointed a panel of eminent economic advisers. He has named a former Koch deputy as chairman of his transition team. And as an example of his independence, he cites his public support for proposed limits on tenure for principals at their schools, despite the proposal's initial lukewarm reception from the principals union, which has endorsed him.
 
Early Labor Friends
A number of state fiscal monitors say any concerns about Mr. Dinkins should be tempered by existing legal safeguards and by additional reviews under a proposed city charter. Some say that Mr. Dinkins, as an ally of labor, may be better able to gain its cooperation in negotiations next year - as another friend of labor, former Mayor Abraham D. Beame, did in the 1970's when the unions made concessions in the city's interest and their own.
Addressing potential Wall Street contributors last week, Mr. Dinkins said as much, noting that looming budget gaps make it unlikely the next mayor will have much to give away.
''So it may well be that I'll have to tell some of my friends they cannot have the things they want,'' he said. ''But they'll take it from me.'' Among those friends is Barry Feinstein, president of Local 237 of the teamsters' union, whose early endorsement of Mr. Dinkins appeared to be pivotal at the time. All he wanted in return, Mr. Feinstein said, was access. Combative and vocal, Mr. Feinstein, who presides over a relatively small union, has filled a void among labor leaders since the retirement of Victor Gotbaum as head of the largest municipal employees union. Mr. Feinstein would be one of the first to confront Mr. Dinkins at the bargaining table.
 
Credit Rating Warning
''The reality is everything has to fit into a financial plan,'' Mr. Feinstein said. ''The next mayor, like the present one, will be much more conservative than we believe he ought to be. We did better with Koch than we can hope to do with Dinkins. We took every nickel there was to take. With Dinkins, you don't have the same adversarial relationship. You're not going to have someone on the bridge yelling, 'Break the strike.'
''That doesn't mean,'' Mr. Feinstein added, ''that the unions are going to say, 'Whatever you want, David, we'll do for you.' ''
Last week, Moody's Investors Service delivered a warning that the city's credit rating would be a function of ''the new administration's ability to maintain fiscal responsibility and realistically balanced budgets, without sacrificing its infrastructure-rebuilding program.''
The warning was not aimed solely at Mr. Dinkins. Rudolph W. Giuliani, the Republican-Liberal candidate and a former Federal prosecutor in Manhattan, is also viewed warily by some members of the financial community because of his inexperience in municipal government and his refusal, like Mr. Dinkins's, to rule out a tax increase. Both describe it as a last resort.
A decline in city bond prices this month was blamed by Mr. Giuliani on concerns raised in an article in Dow Jones Capital Markets Report that Mr. Dinkins ''would spend too freely.'' In endorsing Mr. Giuliani last week, Crain's New York Business cited its ''deep philosophical differences'' with Mr. Dinkins.
 
It's Not Just 'Trust Me'
Any new mayor would be constrained by a budget gap estimated at more than $1 billion during the rest of this fiscal year and next, and by outside overseers, like the Financial Control Board and the Municipal Assistance Corporation - vestiges of the city's brush with insolvency in the 1970's.
As the fiscal crisis receded, some contraints were loosened. The State Legislature deleted the city's ability to pay for labor settlements as a criterion in arbitration. The state monitors' influence is now largely limited to moral suasion, though the Financial Control Board can reclaim its veto power if the budget appears to be severely unbalanced.
''You just can't say 'trust me,' '' the board's executive director, Philip R. Michael, said. ''Compared to 15 years ago, it's night and day.''
Alair A. Townsend, the publisher of Crain's and Mayor Edward I. Koch's former deputy mayor for economic development, asked rhetorically, ''Can any mayor be free-spending, full-stop?
''No, because the F.C.B. and state law say the budget has to be balanced, whatever it takes,'' she said. ''Can any mayor be a relatively 'free-spending friend of labor?' That's a different question. The institutional forces don't constrain labor choices. They just say you have to pay for whatever you give.''
 
Delivering City Services
The city's financial plan assumes only a 1.5 percent wage increase. Since Mr. Koch took office in 1978, wages have risen slightly more than the inflation rate for uniformed city workers and slightly less for civilian employees, said Robert W. Linn, Mr. Koch's director of labor relations. The projected inflation rate for the coming year is about 5 percent.
''It's hard to give less than the Consumer Price Index,'' Stanley Brezenoff, the First Deputy Mayor, said.
Just keeping pace with inflation would cost $385 million, including pension contributions, beyond what the city has budgeted for wage increases next year.
''It's fair to say that rather minor swings in percentage have a major impact on your ability to deliver city services at the margins,'' Mr. Linn said.
Mr. Dinkins's repeated calls for a ''fair'' settlement for workers in private hospitals, who won wage increases of 7 1/2, 7 1/2 and 5 percent over three years, could haunt him.
''The teachers were quoted as saying this is the time for them to get more,'' Mr. Linn said. ''It will be hard for city hospital workers to get less than 7 1/2 percent. If the teachers prevail, if the hospital workers prevail, who's going to say to the cops or the teamsters, 'you should have a lower standard.' ''
 
Fiscally Moderate Advisers
Willingness to come to grips with looming deficits early, as Mr. Koch has, can avert a crisis later. When Mr. Koch unveiled his austerity plan last week, Mr. Giuliani embraced it and chided Mr. Dinkins for being noncommittal.
Mr. Dinkins's defenders recall, though, that, as a Congressman, Mr. Koch, too, was regarded as profligate, but was transformed by the epiphany of fiscal reality early in his first term. Moreover, while Mr. Dinkins, as Manhattan Borough President, often lobbied successfully for social welfare programs in budget negotiations, his additions did not represent ''astronomical sums,'' Mr. Brezenoff said.
Besides naming Nathan Leventhal, a former deputy mayor in the Koch administration, to smooth the transition between administrations, Mr. Dinkins has sought to wrap himself in the protective garb of fiscally moderate economic advisers, like Felix G. Rohatyn, chairman of the Municipal Assistance Corporation, to help him get elected and then to govern.
''The key to the acceptability of the labor settlement for the city economy and the credit markets,'' Mr. Rohatyn said, ''is that the amount of the increase be austere, that it be arrived at without confrontation, and that it be financed by real productivity, which means, in many cases, personnel reductions, and not by taxes.''
Yet, Mr. Rohatyn, a Dinkins supporter, said, ''I would argue the city's labor leaders are more likely to accommodate David Dinkins in trying to make him a success.''
Sandra Feldman, president of the United Federation of Teachers, agreed. ''If teachers felt they were more valued,'' she said, ''you'd get a lot more - you should pardon the expression -productivity.''
Mr. Gotbaum, former head of District Council 37 of the American Federation of State, County and Municipal Employees, recalled that former Mayor Beame ''supposedly was a captive of the unions and we gave him givebacks.'' With Mr. Koch, ''who was supposed to be tough on the unions,'' he said, ''I got my contracts ratified by 85 to 90 percent.''
Earlier this month, Mr. Dinkins told Local 3 of the International Brotherhood of Electrical Workers, ''Quite simply, you can't bargain away what you don't have.'' Describing himself as ''a firm and fair negotiator,'' he said that he would press for productivity and that he would ''strike a reasonable, fair, prudent agreement'' with municipal unions.
Jack Bigel, a municipal union consultant, said, ''I don't believe labor supported Dinkins because he's an easy mark.''
And Mr. Gotbaum said, ''They're not going to make David look bad.''

HEADLINE: Robert Van Fossan, 63, Chairman Of Mutual Benefit Life Insurance

BYLINE: By PETER B. FLINT

 BODY:
Robert V. Van Fossan, board chairman and chief executive officer of the Mutual Benefit Life Insurance Company and a longtime New Jersey civic leader, died of cancer yesterday at Morristown (N.J.) Memorial Hospital. He was 63 years old and lived in Mendham, N.J.
Mr. Van Fossan had been chief executive officer of Mutual Benefit, of Newark, since 1972. He was president of the company from 1972 until 1978, when he became chairman. 
He was or had been an officer of more than a dozen civic organizations. He was a spokesman for New Jersey businesses and a strong advocate of cooperation for social progress and reforms among business, government and volunteer groups.
Mr. Van Fossan was the chairman of Renaissance Newark Inc., a public-private group; the chairman of the Newark Performing Arts Corporation, and a trustee of the Newark Museum and of the Community Foundation of New Jersey, which aids nonprofit groups. He was the primary founder and former chairman of the Partnership for New Jersey, a group of business and community leaders that works to solve social and economic problems.
He was a former chairman of the New Jersey Supreme Court Committee on efficiency in the courts, of the executive committee of northeastern governors, of the state's panel of the Regional Plan Association and a member of the executive committee of the state's National Conference of Christians and Jews.
Mr. Van Fossan was born in Breckenridge, Minn., raised in Devils Lake, N.D., and served as a corporal in the Marines in the South Pacific in World War II. After earning a high school diploma, he won successively higher posts in the Northwestern National Life Insurance Company over 24 years.
Surviving are his wife, Mary Jane; a daughter, Deborah Greer of Eagan, Minn.; two sons, Robert, of Wayzata, Minn., and Steven, of Chatham, N.J.; his mother, Marie, of Missoula, Mont., and two grandchildren.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

 
 
The Economy
The U.S. system of gathering economic statistics is in disrepair, undermining policy makers' attempts to guide the economy, statisticians and economists say. The numbers at issue affect the lives of all Americans, since Social Security payments and some wages are tied to the official inflation rate, and the Government uses statistics to help evaluate welfare and other social programs. Bad numbers could also mean bad economic policy. [Page A1.] 
A national advisory committee will recommend that the Government establish a multibillion-dollar venture capital operation to resurrect the American consumer electronics industry. [D1.]
Machine tool orders climbed 33.4 percent in September, reaching the highest monthly total this year. Orders for the first nine months were down 19 percent from the comparable period of 1988, consistent with a decline predicted by industry analysts. [D1.]
Like it or not, the Federal Government is becoming committed to emergency measures to limit damage from the periodic plunges in stock prices. [D1.]
 
International
Eager to increase competition in the airline industry, European Community officials have decided that change is not coming fast enough and that it is time for tougher deregulation measures. But they face a huge fight from many governments and airlines. [D1.]
Prime Minister Thatcher expressed skepticism about whether other European Community countries would fulfill Britain's conditions for tying the pound more closely to their currencies, a prerequisite for full European economic union. [D1.]
Vitro, Mexico's biggest glass maker, has just completed the first successful hostile takeover of an American concern by a Mexican company. [D14.]
Air India is shedding its ethnic image for a sleeker, made-in-America look. After relying hevily on Indians traveling or living abroad, the carrier hopes to make its first- and business-class sections more attractive to international travelers. [D14.]
 
 
 
Companies
B. Altman's seven department stores have had losses of $4 million a month since September, the retailer's parent, L. J. Hooker, says. The drain, a result of a merchandise shortage, is expected to continue through the end of the year. [D2.]
Unisys reported a third-quarter loss of $648.2 million, reflecting a reorganization and losses on military contracts. [D5.]
 
The Media Business
Book publishers are smarting from stagnant summer sales. Particularly hard hit was best-selling hardcover fiction, with sales down some 16 percent from a year earlier. [D12.]
The Boy Scouts are seeking members with their first paid national television ad campaign. The MTV-style commercials, sponsored by American Airlines and Phillips Petroleum, seek to dispel scouting's old-fashioned image. [D12.]
Some fresh faces attracted new attention at the American Magazine Conference in Naples, Fla. [D12.]
The networks have cut back on their artillery for the sweep month of November, because of costs and a drastically changed television environment. Television. [D12.]
Toyota will keep the ''jump'' at the end of each commercial, after a fruitless search for alternatives. Advertising. [D13.]
 
 
 
Today's Columns
Wall Street's on-again, off-again debate on index arbitrage demonstrates how hard it is for investment firms to curtail a profitable business. Market Place. [D10.]
Credit market participants say they are tired of the political maneuvering over raising the debt ceiling. Credit Markets. [D11.]

HEADLINE: Government Spreading Net To Break Market Free Falls

BYLINE: By LOUIS UCHITELLE

 BODY:
Prodded by the likelihood of periodic plunges in stock market prices, the Federal Government, like it or not, is becoming committed to emergency measures to limit the damage from these frightening episodes.
That emerging safety net for the market showed itself in the Government's actions immediately after the 190-point plunge in the Dow Jones industrial average on Friday, Oct. 13. In the two weeks since then, various new damage-control measures have been proposed and debated.
But a containment procedure patched together by the Government could encourage speculation by creating ''the false sense that there isn't going to be too much downside risk in stock prices without the Government stepping in,'' said David R. Jones, chief economist at Aubrey G. Lanston, a Wall Street firm.
 
Commitment From Fed
The Federal Reserve Board has made the most obvious bailout commitment, hurrying the word out after the Oct. 13 plunge that it would provide adequate credit to buy stocks when the market reopened on Oct. 16. Such offers of easy credit, however, can sometimes bring down intesest rates and be inflationary. 
Less publicly, the Securities and Exchange Commission also stepped in that weekend, with staff members making dozens of telephone calls to major traders. The calls tended to discourage further selling, the traders said.
''The simple fact is that the Government held the market's hand and the investor's hand in a way that we have never seen before,'' Mr. Jones said.
Since then new proposals have surfaced, all reflecting the gowing concern over the prospect of repeated stock market plunges. None of them have been accepted or rejected, but all of them represent a growing discussion of ways to prevent future crashes or limit their damage.
H. Robert Heller, who resigned recently as a Federal Reserve Board governor, proposed in a speech that the Fed intervene during stock market sell-offs and buy stocks in quantity to halt slides - just as the Fed now buys and sells dollars to control the dollar's value.
And Richard C. Breeden, the S.E.C.'s new chairman, asked Congress to give his agency more power to monitor stock trading, particularly big trades that often cause stock market volatility. In addition, Treasury Secretary Nicholas F. Brady said the Bush Administration was studying ways to time the releases of economic statistics so that they do not roil stock prices.
Even without such new measures, the actions of the S.E.C. and the Federal Reserve over the Oct. 14-15 weekend undoubtedly helped stocks rebound the following Monday. That day, the Dow Jones industrial average rose 88.12 points. To some analysts, the Government's developing role in limiting stock market plunges invites comparisons to its commitment to maintain a smoothly functioning banking system.
 
Continental Bank Bailout
Over the last 15 years - to avert collapse of major institutions and the disruption of the nation's financial system - the Government has responded to bank crises by guaranteeing deposits even beyond the requirements of Federal deposit insurance. The Government's de facto commitment to banking was clearly established with the 1984 bailout of Continental Illinois National Bank and Trust Company in Chicago.
''The Government moved in to prevent banks from collapsing, and in doing so acknowledged a powerful and longstanding responsibility for the well-being of the economy,'' said Albert T. Sommers, a senior economist at the Conference Board, a business organization. ''Now they are eager to be supportive of the stock market because the shock waves from a crash can be damaging later on.''
But so far the Government's relationship with the stock market is in an early, evolutionary stage. The Federal Reserve's reassurances, for example, amounted to offering credit without the requirement of putting up stocks as collateral. The Fed did this by indicating that banks would be able to draw enough reserves from it to lend to brokerage houses and other big investors on easy terms.
A similar move was made two years ago, but not until the morning after the crash of Oct. 19, 1987 - and then only after banks had pulled back on loans to brokerage houses and other traders, aggravating the situation.
''The Fed's anticipatory action this time was a very positive signal and one that was sensitive to our concerns; it encouraged people not to panic sell on Monday,'' said Donald B. Marron, chairman and chief executive of the PaineWebber Group Inc.
 
Raising Expectations
But the Fed's readiness to help the markets with loans also raised expectations. Albert Wojnilower, senior economist at the First Boston Corporation, said, ''Once the Fed has come forward, it is really committed to keep on doing so.''
Similarly, the S.E.C. in its weekend telephone calls asked many of the nation's biggest traders what they thought would happen after the stock markets opened on Monday, Oct. 16 -the sort of question that has gone out in previous periods of unusual trading, but not on so wide a scale or with such energy. ''They stayed in touch with the system better than they ever had before,'' said Stanley Shopkorn, vice chairman of Salomon Brothers, in charge of trading operations.
What is more, the discussions carried the S.E.C. onto ground it does not usually tread. In discussing the market's prospects, the S.E.C. learned of trading plans. Some Wall Street executives said the discussion itself was quiet pressure to buy on Oct. 16, not sell.
The S.E.C. also called the big mutual funds, like Fidelity Investment Inc., which was asked to report on Saturday, Oct. 14, and again on Sunday, how many customers had placed weekend orders to sell their shares in stock funds.
 
Fueling the 1987 Crash
Relatively few had, in sharp contrast to October 1987, when a flood of redemptions forced Fidelity to sell huge quantities of stock to raise cash to pay the customers. Those sales helped fuel the crash of Oct. 19, when the Dow Jones average fell 508 points, or 22.6 percent.
''We get requests about redemptions and our cash positions whenever the market is volatile,'' said Robert Pozen, Fidelity's general counsel and a managing director. ''This time the requests came much quicker and they wanted immediate responses, not two weeks later.''
The Federal Reserve's open lending policy meant that brokerage firms would have funds to lend to clients for stock purchases on Monday. In addition, the firms would not be under pressure to sell off stock purchased on margin or credit, with the stock itself as collateral.
The Dow Jones average did rebound, so the Fed in the end did not have to follow through on its promise. And the S.E.C.'s calls, intended to restrain selling, were not put to the test, this time.
 
Two Unsettling Messages
The Government's emerging routine for market bailouts - one that Government officials speak of only off the record - carries with it two unsettling messages, economists and Wall Street executives say.
One is that the Government is being forced to get more deeply involved because big plunges in stock prices are no longer once-in-a-generation events. The Dow has dropped by more than 3.5 percent in a single day only three times since World War II, but all three of those days have occurred in the last two years. The first two came in October 1987, and the third was 18 days ago, when the 190-point plunge, in just 90 minutes, erased 6.9 percent of the Dow's value.
''This sort of volatility will continue to be a hallmark of the American financial markets,'' said Henry Kaufman, an economist and consultant. ''There will be other Oct. 13's and there will sometimes be other Oct. 19's.''
Some market experts contend that volatile price swings result inevitably from such developments of the 1980's as computer-aided trading; the rising influence of foreign financial markets, particularly Japan's, and the power of portfolio managers.
The other message concerns the economy. While the Government, true to its free market principles, is not concerning itself with whether the Dow is at 2,700 or, say, 2,500, it is serving notice that it will take steps to limit a one-day plunge that threatens economic stability.
 
Handful of Safety Measures
In addition to this month's actions of the Fed and the S.E.C., the emerging intervention process includes a handful of safety measures adopted since the 1987 crash. Among them are ''circuit breakers,'' which halt trading temporarily, and restrictions on the various computer-aided trading procedures that can feed a selling panic.
But the growing commitment to stock market containment could perhaps be inflationary. The Fed's easy credit commitment might put downward pressure on interest rates. That was not an issue this month, when the economy was weakening and interest rates were declining anyway.
But Mr. Kaufman said that if stock prices plunged during a period of economic strength, the Fed might have to offer easy credit just when monetary policy was on an opposite tack -one of holding back on loan money and pushing up interest rates to fight inflation.
''If the Fed tries in these circumstances to bail out the market,'' he said, ''that could destabilize prices.''

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL REPORT;
Thatcher Skeptical on Europe Money Ties

BYLINE: By CRAIG R. WHITNEY, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LONDON, Oct. 29

 BODY:
Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher expressed skepticism today about whether other European Community countries would fulfill Britain's conditions for tying the pound more closely to their currencies, an essential prerequisite for full European economic union.
France and Italy would have to get rid of foreign exchange controls and permit free movement of capital, as Britain had done, she insisted in a television interview. ''Then we'll see whether the exchange rate can hold under those circumstances; I hope it does,'' she said in a tone that implied that it might not.
With her remarks, Mrs. Thatcher thus rebuffed calls from several leading members of her own Conservative Party for a clear British commitment to the European Community's seven-currency exchange rate mechanism. Her former Chancellor of the Exchequer, Nigel Lawson, resigned from the Cabinet on Thursday after months of friction between him and Mrs. Thatcher over the issue. 
 
Direct Answers Avoided
Mrs. Thatcher avoided direct answers to questions by Brian Walden of London Weekend Television about what led Mr. Lawson to leave. He said in his resignation letter that he could not continue as long as Sir Alan Walters, who has described the exchange rate system as half-baked, served as Mrs. Thatcher's economic adviser.
New reports of the growing friction weakened the pound on the international exchange markets in recent weeks, and Mr. Lawson raised basic lending rates in Britain to 15 percent earlier this month to prop it up. Sir Alan also resigned on Thursday, after Mr. Lawson's departure.
''Strong leadership will continue,'' the Prime Minister said today, giving little evidence of contrition and dismissing talk about disagreement within the Government as ''tittle-tattle.''
 
'Reason and Emotion'
''I'm staying my own sweet, reasonable self, founded on very strong convictions which were a combination of reason and emotion,'' she said.
The European exchange rate mechanism, the first step of a process that many European leaders say they want to lead to a common currency, sets limits within which seven currencies, including the West German mark and the French franc but not the pound, may fluctuate against one another. It does not tie their value either to the United States dollar or the Japanese yen.
Mrs. Thatcher, at the last European summit meeting in Madrid at the end of June, went along with the other leaders on letting preparations proceed for an intergovernmental conference next year to prepare the way for a common currency and full economic union of the 12 member countries. But she also made clear she disapproved of the idea.
 
Parliament Reaction Cited
''I think there's no need for a single currency in Europe,'' she said then. ''It'll be the biggest transfer of national sovereignty we've ever had, and I don't think it will be at all acceptable to the British Parliament.'' She was reportedly angry with Mr. Lawson and her Foreign Secretary at the time, Sir Geoffrey Howe, for urging her to compromise, and eased Sir Geoffrey out of the Cabinet in July.
Today, she said the pound would not join the exchange rate mechanism unless all the other leading European economies played by the same rules as did Britain's.
''We shall join the exchange rate system when there are no foreign exchange controls, when there's freedom of movement of capital, when their insurance and pension funds are run as openly and freely as ours are and when the subsidies are gone,'' she added. ''You can't have a currency like sterling playing under that higgledy-piggledy set of rules.''
 
Differences Emphasized
Mrs. Thatcher said that France planned to eliminate foreign exchange controls by July, but that Italy might require longer, and that some countries barred their government pension funds from investing funds in other countries and some subsidized state-run industries.
''We believe in an open economy, but they have artificial and cultural barriers which are going to be very difficult to get down,'' she said. ''I really can't have Britain worsted by other people having a different set of rules from us. Of course I fight for Britain and of course I'm combative; I shall go on doing it. But they simply must be fair.''
''I like a strong pound,'' she said, but she would not say whether her new Chancellor, John Major, would raise British interest rates further if the pound fell again next week. It declined to 2.885 German marks on Friday, after Mr. Lawson's resignation, and at one point dipped below Thursday's close in New York of $1.575 before stabilizing after support by the Bank of England.
 
Continuance of Policies Seen
''I'm very sad that he's gone,'' she said. ''The same policies will continue. It was quite clear that he had made up his mind and that there was nothing I could do to dissuade him.'' She repeatedly described Mr. Lawson's standing within her Cabinet as ''unassailable.'' When Mr. Walden asked if Mr. Lawson would have stayed in the Cabinet if she had dismissed Sir Alan, she answered: ''I don't know. I don't know.''
Neil Kinnock, leader of the opposition Labor Party, accused Mrs. Thatcher of ''confusion, division and malice'' today. Labor ran an unchanged 10 percentage points ahead of Mrs. Thatcher's Conservatives in a Sunday Times telephone poll of 711 people taken after Mr. Lawson's resignation.

HEADLINE: Machine Tool Orders Rise To '89 High

BYLINE: By JONATHAN P. HICKS

 BODY:
Bolstered by higher capital spending in a number of industries, machine tool orders climbed 33.4 percent in September from the previous month, reaching the highest monthly total this year.
According to a report to be released today by the Association for Manufacturing Technology, machine tool orders rose to $302.9 million, from $227.1 million in August. Analysts said the rise was a reflection of plant modernization in a variety of areas. 
''Orders in September came from general machinery companies,'' said James J. Paper, an analyst with Kirkpatrick, Pettis, Smith, Polian Inc. in Omaha. ''It's not coming from any one particular area. It's coming from a wide range of industries, with a number of different companies increasing their capital spending.''
 
Orders for This Year Down 19%
Machine tools, which are power-driven devices that cut or shape metal parts, are used in the manufacture of everything from appliances to vehicles. Economists consider their sales and orders important indicators of capital spending patterns by makers of large products like automobiles and aircraft.
Although the level of orders was significantly higher in September than in August, orders for the first nine months of the year were down 19 percent from the comparable period of 1988. The level of new orders was also down 7.7 percent from September of last year.
Shipments of machine tools were up 24.5 percent from August, to $281.2 million. And shipments for the first nine months were 37.5 percent higher, at $2.25 billion. Shipments last month were 23.6 percent higher than in September of last year.
 
'Optimism and Caution'
Albert W. Moore, president of the association, based in McLean, Va., said the level of new orders for the year has been consistent with the 20 percent decline for 1989 that had been widely predicted by industry analysts. He added that 1988 had been a particularly strong year.
''The 1980's have been a period of transition for the United States machine tool industry,'' Mr. Moore said. ''As the decade draws to a close we look to the 1990's with both optimism and caution. Optimism, because we know that the United States machine tool industry can regain lost ground and grow. Caution, because we know there is much to be done to spur that growth.''
 
Foreign Orders Off 26.8%
The level of foreign orders for American-made machine tools dropped 26.8 percent in September from August, largely because the dollar had strengthened, analysts said. In the first nine months of the year, foreign orders were down 27.7 percent. Meanwhile, domestic orders for makers of machine tools were up 44.7 percent in September from August, but were 17.6 percent lower for the first nine months of the year.
Orders for metal-cutting tools, which include boring mills and lathes, were up 23.4 percent, to $192.8 million, from the August level. That category typically accounts for three-fourths of the industry. Orders for metal-forming tools were up 55.4 percent in September, the association said.
The backlog of machine tool orders stood at $2.15 billion in September, up from $2.13 billion in August.
