HEADLINE: U.S. Aid Sought for Electronics

BYLINE: By ANDREW POLLACK, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 29

 BODY:
In a report that will be delivered to the President this week, a national advisory committee on semiconductors will recommend that the Government establish a multibillion-dollar venture capital operation intended to resurrect the American consumer electronics industry.
The report could give new impetus to flagging efforts aimed at forming a Government-industry initiative in high-definition television. The advanced video product has become the focus of efforts to bring American companies back into the consumer electronics business, which they have all but abandoned to Japanese and European companies.
The Bush Administration is divided on that issue, and it has recently backed away from the idea of offering support for any particular industry. But members of Congress and electronics industry representatives say the new report could help swing momentum their way. 
 
'Serious Consideration'
''I think it's a report that will get serious consideration,'' said Representative Mel Levine, Democrat of California and a leading proponent of a national policy on high-definition television. ''Hopefully, something like this will move the debate, both within the Administration and beyond it.''
Mr. Levine said he expected to introduce a bill soon that would create a Technology Corporation of America, which would be similar to the semiconductor committee's proposed investment company. The major difference, he said, is that his proposed corporation would get direct Federal financing while the semiconductor committee's proposed company apparently would not.
The semiconductor committee consists of semiconductor and computer industry leaders and high-level Government officials. Its proposal calls for an investment company that would be known as the Consumer Electronics Capital Corporation, which would be privately managed and run for a profit and would serve as a source of ''low-cost, very patient capital'' for companies wishing to enter the consumer electronics business.
The Government would provide loan guarantees that would enable the corporation to borrow money at low interest rates and invest in new consumer electronics technologies and companies.
The group issuing the report, known as the National Advisory Committee on Semiconductors, was created by last year's trade act to come up with policies to maintain a competitive American computer chip industry.
The panel recommends that the investment company would get initial equity funding from industry sources, private and institutional investors, and state and local governments. The corporation would raise billions of dollars in commercial debt, using Federal, state and local government loan guarantees to insure a low interest rate.
Such an investment corporation would counteract a key advantage the Japanese have in their access to low-cost capital. Many American companies have said they cannot afford the heavy long-term investments needed to get into the manufacture of televisions, videocassette recorders and other consumer products while still showing a profit for their shareholders.
 
Financing for Sematech
The report, which has not yet been released, also recommends that financing for Sematech, the Government-backed semiconductor research consortium, be immediately increased to $300 million a year from its current level of $200 million, and by $800 million over the next three years.
In his cover letter to the President, the committee's chairman, Ian M. Ross, the president of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company's Bell Laboratories, acknowledges that the recommendations may be controversial.
''We have not shied away from controversy,'' Dr. Ross says. ''In this report we present necessary first steps toward a national semiconductor strategy. We believe that the country needs bold and innovative action.''
The report never mentions high-definition television, preferring to focus on all of consumer electronics and avoid the criticisms from those who say the importance of high-definition television has been overblown.
The report documents a decline in the competitiveness of the American semiconductor industry, which makes the silicon chips that are the heart of everything from computers and telephones to robots and weapons. The report finds an equally serious decline in the American industry that produces the sophisticated machinery and raw materials used to make chips.
The 29-page report also calls for the Government to play a stronger role in insuring that American companies can participate in consumer electronics. For instance, it asks the Government to consider requiring products sold in the United States to use a certain number of United States components. It also calls for the Government to help American companies license the technology they need from foreign companies that now control many of the key patents in consumer electronics.
 
Tax Breaks
The report also recommends numerous steps to lower capital costs by making the research and development tax credit permanent, reinstating the investment tax credit, reducing taxes on capital gains and facilitating the formation of industry consortiums. It also recommends steps to improve education, protect American patents and copyrights, and promote access to foreign markets.
Members of the advisory committee from industry were John A. Armstrong, vice president for science and technology at I.B.M.; Norman Augustine, chairman and chief executive of Martin Marietta; Robert W. Galvin, chairman of Motorola; Jerry R. Junkins, chairman, president and chief executive of Texas Instruments; James C. Morgan, chairman and chief executive of Applied Materials; Charles E. Sporck, president and chief executive of National Semiconductor, and James G. Treybig, president and chief executive of Tandem Computers.
Government members were: John A. Betti, Under Secretary of Defense for Acquisition; Erich Bloch, director of the National Science Foundation; D. Allan Bromley, the President's science adviser; Robert O. Hunter Jr., director of the Office of Energy Research at the Department of Energy; and Thomas J. Murrin, Deputy Secretary of Commerce. Executive director of the committee was William R. Bandy, a program manager for the Defense Advanced Research Projects Agency.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS PEOPLE;
Four New Trophies For a Top Headhunter

BYLINE: By DANIEL F. CUFF

 BODY:
Gerard R. Roche, who is regarded as a top executive headhunter, has four new trophies to display.
Mr. Roche, who is in the business of snaring top executives for big corporations, has within the last month been involved in the placement of four visible leaders in disparate fields: Paul J. Tagliabue as the new commissioner of the National Football League, James R. Jones as chairman of the American Stock Exchange, Hugh Southern as general manager of the Metropolitan Opera and Jerry J. Jasinowski as president of the National Association of Manufacturers.
''The common denominator here,'' Mr. Roche said last week, ''is that for a guy who has spent most of his time working for the Bill Paleys of the world, in all these cases we were working for committees.'' 
Mr. Roche is chairman of Heidrick & Struggles, an old-line executive search firm in New York.
Finding the candidates, or the ''tall timber,'' as Mr. Roche calls them, is not the hardest part. Mr. Tagliabue, as legal counsel to the N.F.L. for 20 years, was in a strong position to move up, as was Mr. Jasinowski, who was the chief economist of the manufacturers association.
Executive searchers are hired, Mr. Roche said, not only to produce candidates but to ''manage the process, conduct the meetings, do the reference checking and coordinate the various constituencies, and finally, to get the tall timber to accept the position.'' He is quick to point out that he did not do all four assignments alone, but had help from his partners at Heidrick & Struggles.
Mr. Roche, who is 58 years old, grew up in Scranton, Pa., working in his father's grocery store. He is a graduate of the University of Scranton and received an M.B.A. degree from New York University.
He was working as marketing vice president for the Cordite Company when he was recruited for a post at Philip Morris. He did not take the job, but the encounter piqued his interest in the recruiting business and he went to work for Heidrick & Struggles. That was 26 years ago. Some of the executive placements he is most proud of are John Sculley at Apple Computer, Richard Voell at the Rockefeller Group and Stephen M. Wolf at UAL.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Focus Is on Raising the Debt Limit

BYLINE: By KENNETH N. GILPIN

 BODY:
For much of the 1980's, official Washington has chosen a dubious milestone - a necessary increase in the nation's debt ceiling - as the appropriate moment to call a political scrimmage.
The tactic has grown tiresome to credit market participants, who warn that the latest upshot could be disarray, and possibly higher interest rates, over the next few weeks.
As a way of trying to make political points, Democrats in Congress have in the past delayed passage of a rise in the debt ceiling as a way of reminding voters that the huge increase in the national debt this decade has taken place with Republicans in the White House.
 
New Twist in Battle
The partisan battle took on a new twist last week, when Republicans made it plain that they intend to attach a rider to cut the capital-gains tax to legislation that raises the debt ceiling, now at $2.87 trillion. 
The gambit has been abetted by the Treasury Department, which on Friday said it would increase the size of its weekly bill auctions and supplement them with a $2 billion cash management bill sale so it can pay Social Security benefits after midnight tomorrow, when the current debt ceiling is scheduled to drop to $2.8 trillion. The additional cash will give the Government enough money to operate until Nov. 9, market participants said.
But continued gamesmanship over the debt-ceiling increase is almost certain to delay the Treasury's quarterly refunding auctions, which had been expected to take place in the first full week of November.
''The debt limit process has often been politicized by Congress, but never by the Treasury,'' said Richard M. Kelly, president of Aubrey G. Lanston & Company, primary dealers in Government securities.
Mr. Kelly, who was a Treasury official during the Carter Administration, added: ''This is a sad, unprecedented development, one that in my judgment has hurt Treasury's credibility. And in the end, the financial markets will quite likely suffer as a result.''
One bond trader, who asked not to be identified, said: ''The market is really getting sick of all this political posturing. It makes a mockery of the whole system.''
The Treasury's decision was not greeted with universal derision, however.
''I am not sure there would have been a timely vote on the debt ceiling even without the capital gains provision,'' said Lawrence A. Kudlow, chief economist at Bear, Stearns & Company, who was chief economist at the Office of Management and Budget during the first Reagan Administration.
''Treasury's step was somewhat unusual, but it seems prudent,'' Mr. Kudlow said.
 
Short-Term Rates Up
Short-term interest rates rose sharply on Friday once details of the Treasury's plan were fully disseminated in the market.
The increase in short-term financings poses no problem, but market participants fear that a further delay by Congress in raising the debt ceiling will jeopardize the efficient sale of $30 billion or more of securities at the coming refunding auctions.
''If the debt ceiling is not raised until Nov. 8, for example, there will be quite limited when-issued trading in these issues,'' Mr. Kelly said. A delay of that nature ''will compact the sale of an awful lot of debt into a very short period of time.''
Aside from watching Congress wrangle over the debt ceiling, this week market participants will receive important data on how the economy performed in October.
The reports include the monthly survey from the nation's purchasing managers, due Wednesday. More important, though, are the employment data due from the Labor Department on Friday.
Analysts are not expecting the October figures to be as weak as September's, but most anticipate that the numbers will provide further evidence of a slowdown in the economy.
Alan Levenson and Richard Berner, economists at Salomon Brothers, are forecasting that non-farm payroll employment rose by 180,000 in October, up from a strike-adjusted increase of 133,000 in September.
While the overall number is important, economists and Federal Reserve Board governors are likely to focus intently on how employment conditions in the manufacturing sector fared last month. In September, manufacturing employment fell by a surprisingly large 103,000 jobs.
An indication of investor sentiment about New York City, which faces a cloudy economic future, could come today in the tax-exempt municipal bond market.
As part of a plan to refinance part of its roughly $13 billion in outstanding debt, the city is expected to offer to investors more than $786 million worth of general obligation bonds. The refinancing will save New York $162 million in interest payments in the current fiscal year, and an additional $100 million in 1991.
After reviewing modifications to the city's financial plan, Moody's Investors Service and the Standard & Poor's Corporation, the two top rating agencies, reaffirmed their A ratings on the city's bonds. But questions remain.
 
'It Is Very Hard to Predict'
''We are really looking to see what the next mayor does,'' said Colleen Woodell, a vice president at Moody's. ''He somehow has to maintain a balanced budget, and unless he comes up with additional cuts, he has to do something to enhance revenues. It is very hard to predict how that will be accomplished without some increase in taxes.''
The refinancing package is part of a series of steps the outgoing Koch Administration is taking to help close a projected $528 million budget gap for fiscal 1990.
Late last week participants in the municipal bond market said that preliminary price talk about the New York City issue put coupons as high as 7.85 percent on long-term bonds.

HEADLINE: Trade View Of U.S. Dim

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 29

 BODY:
In a pessimistic assessment of trade prospects, the Bush Administration said Friday that it was unclear that the trade deficit could be shrunk further and warned that it might grow next year.
The current-account deficit, the broadest gauge of American trade, which measures investment flows as well as payments for goods and services, narrowed sharply in 1988, to $126.6 billion, down from a record $143.7 billion in 1987. But progress has stalled this year, with the gap running at only a slightly better $122.8 billion annual rate from January through June.
The Administration, in a report prepared by the Treasury Department, warned that the current-account deficit might start widening again unless the United States and its economic allies do a better job of coordinating economic policies, including currency exchange rates.
The report, the Treasury's semiannual report to Congress, was prepared under a provision of the Trade Act of 1988 that requires the Administration to look for cases of currency manipulation by American competitors in world trade and to negotiate to halt such practices.
Under the law, the Administration has singled out South Korea and Taiwan. The report expressed approval of the effort by Taiwan to raise the value of its currency and lower its trade surplus, but it sharply criticized South Korea.

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL REPORT;
Air India Tries a New Look For International Travelers

BYLINE: By BARBARA CROSSETTE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: NEW DELHI, Oct. 29

 BODY:
Falling behind its regional competitors in Asia's burgeoning air travel market, Air India is shedding its ethnic image for a sleeker, made-in-America look.
When the airline, India's international flag carrier, introduced its first redecorated Boeing 747 in Bombay earlier this month, gone were the red Rajasthani arches that once framed the windows. The plane had also lost its fussy red stripes. 
The new look, an all-white plane with a single red band and gold sun painted on its tail, was designed by Landor Associates of San Francisco, which also remodeled the images of Singapore Airlines and the Indonesian flag carrier, Garuda.
Interior changes are also being made by Air India, which wants to make its first- and business-class sections more attractive to international travelers.
 
Relying on the Ethnic Market
The airline has been relying heavily on what business analysts here call the economy-class ethnic market: Indians traveling or living abroad. But other Asian airlines, among them Thai International, Singapore and the Malaysian Airlines System, have been capturing growing shares of long-haul passengers because of their high standards of service and comfort.
The new look for Air India is part of a general shake-up at the airline under its 39-year-old director, Rajan Jetley. He said his aim is to create a ''high-yield contemporary airline.''
India, like many Asian nations, is now a nonstop flight from most European cities, and one stop away from the United States, where Kennedy International Airport is Air India's only stop. International carriers, once limited mostly to Bombay and New Delhi, are beginning to schedule more flights from Calcutta and Madras in return for greater access for Air India in Europe.
Ten years ago, Air India, which says it now flies to 40 cities on five continents, was rated among the world's 10 worst airlines by a European passenger association. Indian passengers also complained of slovenly conditions on planes and in airport terminals and of indifferent and surly service.
 
Complaints Are Down
Over the last two years, however, better airport operations and more convenient schedules have helped reduce complaints and raise profits for the Government-owned airline. India also has two nationalized domestic carriers, Indian Airlines and Vayudoot, both plagued by problems with service and equipment.
Air India reported a profit of $26 million in its 1988-89 fiscal year, though some industry analysts said they thought the profit was helped by the Government's cutting the price of fuel to the airline. But there is no debate that the airline's loss was almost that much in the 1987-88 fiscal year, so whatever the real profit, it was a turnaround.
The cost of Air India's revamped corporate image, down to menu cards, baggage tags and stationery, will be about $35 million. The new image is not winning much applause at home, however. The plane's design has been criticized as too bland to make an impact and too international to be identified with India.
Air India promises at least not to ditch its little Maharajah. The mascot will remain, though not on the planes.

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL REPORT;
Raid Across the Mexican Border

BYLINE: By LARRY ROHTER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MONTERREY, Mexico, Oct. 24

 BODY:
In his office at the headquarters of Vitro S.A. here, Ernesto Martens keeps a supply of customized baseball caps emblazoned with labels like ''creative'' or ''optimistic'' or ''emotional.'' At the moment, his choice would probably be a cap marked ''bold.''
As president and chief executive of Mexico's biggest maker of glass products, Mr. Martens - along with the company's chairman, Adrian Sada - has just presided over the first successful hostile takeover of an American concern by a Mexican company.
In a deal that was begun Aug. 9 and is expected to be formalized soon, Vitro is acquiring the Anchor Glass Container Corporation, the second-largest glass container manufacturer in the United States. The cost of Vitro's American foray is estimated at more than $900 million, including $460 million in Anchor debt, the purchase of the Latchford Glass Company of Huntington Park, Calif., for $48 million and the installation of Latchford's management at Anchor. 
 
'We Had to Expand'
''We had to expand our base,'' Mr. Martens said when asked why Vitro had decided to make acquisitions in the United States. Mr. Martens, a 56-year-old chemical engineer, was chief executive at Union Carbide de Mexico before he joined Vitro in 1977.
''If we want to continue to be a glass company, as we have been for 80 years, we can no longer be satisfied having a strong domestic base and some export activity,'' he continued. ''With a more open Mexican economy, our strategy has had to change.''
The watershed transaction comes at a time when the United States and Mexico are making big efforts to scale down barriers that have slowed the growth of trade between them. During a state visit to Washington by President Carlos Salinas de Gortari earlier this month, officials of the two countries signed an agreement that promises to reduce tariffs and open investment opportunities in important industrial sectors like automobiles, steel, telecommunications, petrochemicals, computers, textiles and processed foods.
Analysts here and in Mexico City said they would not be surprised to see other Mexican companies, faced with the prospect of increased competition here, move into the American market through the takeover route.
 
Shopping for Banks
Cementos Mexicanos recently bought several concrete plants in the Southwest, for example, and some of Mexico's state-owned banks are known to be shopping for savings and loan associations and small banks in Texas and California.
But the biggest impact of Vitro's acquisition of Anchor is likely to be felt among Monterrey's other industrial giants, like the Alfa, Visa and Cydsa conglomerates, whose activities include steel, paper cartons, plastics, beer and chemicals. Until the death of Eugenio Garza Sada in 1973, all four companies were run as divisions of the Monterrey Group, and even today they remain closely linked by blood ties and a common outlook.
''These guys are all first cousins, so you can be sure they are talking to each other,'' another American analyst here said. ''All of them also happen to be cash-flush, with money coming out of their ears, so now that the first step has been taken by Vitro, the odds are that we will see it happen again.''
That Vitro, which last year recorded income of $152 million on revenues of $1.1 billion at recent exchange rates, turned out to be the first Mexican company to move north across the border by the takeover route has surprised few here.
 
Entrepreneurial Spirit
The business community in this industrial center of three million people less than 100 miles south of the Rio Grande is renowned throughout Mexico for its entrepreneurial spirit, and Vitro, which was founded in 1909 to make glass bottles for beer, is regarded as one of the best-run businesses in Monterrey.
''In Vitro we have observed a management that has been very aggressive, in the sense of diversification and expansion, and capable of achieving growth in spite of the economic crisis from which the country has been suffering since 1982,'' said Jorge Placido Evangelista, an analyst at Operadora de Bolsa, a large brokerage house in Mexico City. ''It's also in the vanguard of technology, much of which it has developed itself and has been exporting.''
Nevertheless, Vitro's acquisition of Anchor comes after a decade of great change and retrenchment for the publicly held conglomerate, dominated since its earliest days by members of the Sada and Garza families. Like many Mexican companies, Vitro borrowed heavily during the oil boom of the late 1970's, to find itself reeling from twin blows in 1982, when oil prices collapsed and the Mexican Government nationalized a bank owned by the company.
 
Astute Negotiators
By 1983, Vitro's debt to foreign banks had risen to $758 million. But the company was never forced to declare a loss, and it showed unusual skill and astuteness in talks with its bank creditors, with the result that indebtedness had been reduced to $15 million in August.
''Vitro showed a capacity to negotiate with the banks,'' Mr. Placido said. ''They took firm positions and held to them.''
In the mid-1980's, additional pressure came from the Government's decision to open up Mexico's closed domestic market to foreign imports and competition, which was followed by Mexico's entry into the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade in 1986.
''If we had done nothing, we would have ended up with a strong domestic market position, but with everybody outside shooting at us,'' Mr. Martens said.
Faced with recession at home, Vitro also embarked on an effort to raise its profile in overseas markets. Exports, which totaled $108 million in 1984, had grown to more than $250 million by 1988, including items ranging from delicate crystalware sold at Neiman-Marcus and soft-drink bottles made for Coca-Cola and Pepsico to sophisticated glass-making machinery for American clients and windshields and windows for Ford automobiles.
 
Appeal to the Middle Class
In Mexico, Vitro has also diversified into product lines that appeal to middle-class Mexican consumers who hope the worst of the economic crisis has passed. In one of its 12 joint ventures, the company makes Samsonite luggage, mostly for the domestic market, while a joint venture with Whirlpool, to make refrigerators and stoves, was begun in 1985.
Mr. Martens said Vitro planned to use its advanced glass-making technology to help restore the competitive position of Anchor, which has recorded net losses of nearly $26 million over the last four quarters. That strong technological position, market analysts said, should help Vitro recover a large chunk of the $400 million the company has said it plans to invest in Anchor over the next five years.
''This is the most brilliant move that any company in Monterrey has made,'' an American economist here said. ''Vitro has opened a huge window into the United States, and I would suspect we are going to see them benefit from a lot of cross-fertilization and cross-trafficking.''
 
In American Hands
Mr. Martens said Vitro planned to shut three of Anchor's existing United States plants and would name Federico Sada, the 40-year-old head of Vitro's container division, as Anchor's vice-chairman. But Vitro executives said day-to-day management would remain in American hands.
''Anchor is to be an independent subsidiary, not a part of the Vitro container division,'' said Mr. Sada, who studied at Washington University in St. Louis and at Harvard. ''My role will be indirect, at the board level.''
While some Wall Street analysts viewed the $21.25-a-share price paid by Vitro for Anchor as overly generous, Vitro's senior management said the purchase was worth the price, especially in view of the company's desire to gain a foothold in the United States and become a worldwide force in the glass industry. ''We're buying 26 percent of the biggest market in the world,'' Mr. Martens said.

HEADLINE: Shun 'Backwater of Oppression,' Nixon Tells China

BYLINE: By SHERYL WuDUNN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BEIJING, Oct. 30

 BODY:
Former President Richard M. Nixon urged China today not to sink into a ''backwater of oppression and stagnation'' and called on both the United States and China to strive for cooperation to overcome the present bitterness in their relationship.
Parts of his remarks, delivered at a banquet tonight given by Prime Minister Li Peng, are likely to embarrass the Chinese. Mr. Nixon referred twice to the events surrounding the violent crackdown on demonstrators on June 2-4 as a ''tragedy'' that has soured Chinese-American relations.
''The cultural, political, and ideological differences between us, Mr. Premier - you a Chinese Communist who believes in Leninist rule, I, an American conservative who believes in capitalism and democracy - are too great to permit a common understanding of this tragedy,'' Mr. Nixon said.
''But let us not become mired in endless and fruitless recriminations over the seeming impasse that has now developed between our two countries,'' he said. 
 
Continued World Role Urged
Mr. Nixon, who arrived on Saturday and is expected to stay until at least Thursday, also called on China to help maintain stability in the Pacific region and to continue to take part in the global economy and balance of power.
The visit was billed as a fact-finding trip rather than a mission to accomplish major breakthroughs in tense relations between the United States and China. Diplomatic relations have been strained since the military crackdown on the democracy movement in June and since the American Embassy decided to grant refuge to a dissident couple, Fang Lizhi and Li Shuxian.
Mr. Nixon made a landmark trip to China in 1972, helping prepare for establishment of diplomatic relations seven years later.
He is the most prominent American to visit China since the June crackdown. The United States has suspended all high-level trips to China, and he is visiting as a private citizen, although he is to brief President Bush upon his return home.
Earlier today, Mr. Nixon met with Li Ruihuan, who was named to the six-member Politburo standing committee in June, but the substance of the talks was not made public by either side.
Separately, the Government announced tonight that it would withdraw martial-law troops from Tiananmen Square in Beijing and from major intersections throughout the city. The troops will be replaced by armed policemen, in what appears to be another step toward easing of martial law in the capital.
The Government added that a small number of troops would remain in the city to carry out martial law, which was imposed in major areas of Beijing on May 20. ----U.S. Charges Harassment BEIJING, Oct. 30 (AP) - The United States Embassy has filed three protests in three days with the Chinese Government, asserting that diplomats and their families are being harassed by the Chinese authorities, an embassy official said today.
The reported harassment, including incidents of slashed tires and policemen pointing rifles at diplomats' children, comes as the Chinese have increased surveillance of the American Embassy's compounds.
The increased surveillance is in addition to the police officers with automatic rifles and helmets who have surrounded the embassy and the Ambassador's residence since the crackdown in June, when the dissidents Mr. Fang and Miss Li took refuge in one of the compounds.
The official said he saw no connection between the harassment and Mr. Nixon's visit.
In the last week, the official said, one embassy staff member found a tire on his car flat on two mornings, each time after he had entertained Chinese guests. Two other staff members found their car lights had been turned on during the night, draining the batteries, and one car's fan belt was stolen.
Twice in the last week, policemen outside the embassy pointed unloaded automatic rifles at children of American diplomats and pulled the triggers, the official said.

HEADLINE: As Oratory Fades, Obstacles to Chemical Arms Pact Multiply

BYLINE: By MICHAEL R. GORDON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 30

 BODY:
One month after President Bush proposed from a United Nations podium that the United States and Soviet Union begin to slash their stockpiles of poison gas, his initiative has run into political and technological obstacles.
In the Soviet Union, the only plant equipped to destroy poison gas has been shut down by a newly powerful environmental movement, Soviet officials say. Experts believe it will be years before new Soviet sites for destroying chemical weapons are built and operating.
''We do have difficulties in destruction,'' said Sergei B. Batsanov, a top Soviet chemical arms negotiator who began a weeklong meeting today with American negotiators in New York. 
Bush Administration officials are still struggling to turn the President's remarks into a workable plan. For example, they are still debating whether the President's initiative should include highly intrusive verification measures to guard against the possibility of covert stocks of poison gas.
An insistence on stringent monitoring could frustrate Mr. Bush's hope for an early accord that would lend impetus to the worldwide effort to ban poison gas, officials said. But they acknowledged that without far-reaching monitoring measures, it would be impossible to verify fully Mr. Bush's proposal that the two sides reduce their chemical arsenals to equal levels.
 
'Not Got It All Together'
Nor have Bush Administration officials decided whether a Soviet-American agreement to reduce chemical arms would require Congressional approval.
''We have not got it all together yet,'' an official said. ''But once these remaining issues are resolved, we hope to have a workable plan ready to discuss with the Soviets.''
The idea of destroying chemical weapons gained high visibility in January when the Soviet Foreign Minister, Eduard A. Shevardnadze, announced in Paris that Moscow would begin to eliminate its poison gas stocks in advance of a global treaty banning chemical weapons. Washington responded that the United States already was destroying chemical arms.
At that time, the Moscow authorities appeared to assume that their new chemical weapons destruction plant at Chapayevsk on the Volga River would soon be ready to operate. After Mr. Shevardnadze's address, however, local residents raised objections to the Chapayevsk facility on environmental grounds. In early September, the Government dropped its plan to destroy chemical weapons at Chapayevsk, Soviet officials have said.
President Bush sought to seize the initiative in his Sept. 25 address by proposing that the two sides cut their chemical weapons stocks to an equal level that would be about 80 percent below current American stocks.
But political problems in the Soviet Union, among other factors, may delay Mr. Bush's efforts, according to Administration specialists and experts outside Government.
 
Moscow Lacks the Means
One major obstacle is that the recent decision by Moscow has left it without the ability to destroy significant quantities of chemical weapons.
Mr. Batsanov, the Soviet chemical arms negotiator, confirmed that the Chapayevsk plant would be used only for training purposes, with water substituted for chemicals.
He said the Government would decide later this year what additional chemical destruction plants to build.
He did not say how long it would take to build the new plants. But American officials estimate that it will take about three years to build new American installations for destroying chemical weapons.
In contrast to the Soviet Union, the United States has already built a new chemical weapons destruction plant on Johnston Island, south of Hawaii, that they hope will be fully operational in July 1991.
The Government also plans to break ground Tuesday on a destruction plant in Utah, one of eight to be built in the continental United States.
The Johnston Island site is months behind schedule. But Pentagon officials say that they will be able to meet a Congressional requirement to destroy old chemical weapons by 1997 if no unforeseen challenges arise.
Aside from these problems, Moscow and Washington still disagree over whether a pact reducing American and Soviet chemical weapons should be accompanied by a ban on new production.
The Soviet Union has proposed such a ban. But the Bush Administration has strongly opposed it, arguing that it needs to manufacture advanced new ''binary'' weapons, in which two types of otherwise harmless chemicals are mixed to produce a lethal gas.
On verification, the Soviet Union appears to have an accommodating stance. Mr. Batsanov said Moscow would be willing to accept far-reaching monitoring as part of a American-Soviet accord, including impromptu ''challenge'' inspections in search of covert stocks.
Bush Administration officials argue that the President's initiative should be pursued despite political and practical problems.
An Administration specialist said that the two sides could share destruction technology. A pact could also take account of ''the problems and dilemmas facing the Soviets'' in constructing plants to destroy chemical stocks.
Such assurances might be helpful, the interview with Mr. Batsanov suggested.
The negotiator said that some officials in Moscow were concerned that Washington would take advantage of the Soviets' problems to score public relations points. He argued that the United States was in a much better position to destroy chemical weapons.
He said that some Soviet officials questioned the timing of Mr. Bush's address, which could be linked to the problems at the Chapayevsk facility.
''The magnitude of effort'' to destroy chemical weapons, ''political, economic and so forth, is not equal,'' Mr. Batsanov asserted.

HEADLINE: U.S. Birth Level Nears 4 Million Mark

BYLINE: By FELICITY BARRINGER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 30

 BODY:
The number of babies born in the United States every year is edging toward four million, a level not reached since the baby boom in the 1950's. Until recently, demographers thought that level would be out of reach until well into the 21st century.
A decade ago some demographers, confronted with record low birth figures, estimated that as many as 25 percent of American women born in the 1950's would remain childless, thus reducing the total number of births for decades to come. Others argued that these women were merely deferring births. 
Figures being compiled now show that the second view is generally correct and that the rate of childlessness for women born in the baby boom will be only about 15 percent.
Other questions remain about how the next group of women, those born in the late 60's and early 70's, will balance motherhood and careers.
 
Impact in Baby Boom
And some experts, like Ben J. Wattenberg, author of ''The Birth Dearth,'' say the current surge in the fertility rate is like the baby boom itself, an aberration in a steady, 200-year decline in fertility in the United States.
At the peak of the baby boom, when births exceeded four million from 1954 to 1964, women were having slightly more than three children each. Their daughters, now 25 to 42, are all in their childbearing years, and although they are having, on average, slightly fewer than two children each, their sheer numbers are fueling the current surge.
''During 1989, it looks like we'll just touch 4 million,'' said Martin O'Connell, a Census Bureau demographer, ''That number I see peaking at between 4.0 and 4.1 million and trailing off toward the end of the decade to 3.8 and 3.6 million.''
''People would have said 10 years ago that we weren't going to get back'' to 4 million births, said Suzanne Bianchi of the Census Bureau.
 
Crowded Classrooms Foreseen
The number of births in the United States fell in 1986, but rose sharply in 1987 and 1988. In 1988, the National Center for Health Statistics recorded 3.91 million births and the figures have been going up steadily.
For two years, Ms. Bianchi said, the number of births has been significantly higher than the Census Bureau projected in 1984 and 1985, a discrepancy that could cause unexpectedly crowded classrooms in elementary schools in the early 1990's.
Ms. Bianchi and other experts agree that delayedin childbirth is the main factor in the current surge. Predictions of high rates of childlessness have not proved out.
 
Rising Average Age
A decade ago demographers predicted that 1 in 5 or even 1 in 4 women born in the baby boom would have no children, but, Mr. O'Connell said, the rate of childlessness is expected to be only 14 percent for women born in the late 1940's. For women born in the 1950's, he said, the rate is 16 percent.
While the average age of first-time mothers rose from 21.8 years in the early 1960's to 23.7 years in 1988, more than 70 percent of all babies are still born to women in their 20's.
Some experts argue that in the near future American women will return to a pattern of slightly earlier childbearing. A complete return to the patterns of the early 1950's is not expected.
Richard Easterlin, an economist at the University of Southern California who says a family's financial wellbeing is crucial in the decision to have a child, expects that women in their late teens or early 20's will achieve financial security faster than baby-boomers because they will face a less competitive labor market.
The result, he said, should be earlier childbearing among these women. ''My expectation would be to see the upswing in the 25- to 29-year-old age group,'' he said, adding that he expected this to become evident ''five years down the road.''
 
Income and Fertility Rate
William Butz, the Census Bureau's associate director for demographic programs, questions whether the fertility rate for younger women could increase as long as their educational and career opportunities increase.
''In an economy that is holding women in jobs, women's time becomes more expensive,'' said Mr. Butz.
When men were the sole or predominant family wage earners, he said, couples tended to have more children in good times and fewer in bad times.
As the labor market opened to women, he continued, a new variable entered the equation: Did a couple want to forgo the woman's income for a period of time so they could have a child?
This change, he said, led to a reversal of normal patterns. Economic downturns became occasions for increased fertility, at least among younger couples.
Mr. Butz said these assumptions tested well for the recessions of 1970 and 1973-74, but he has not examined them in light of later recessions.

HEADLINE: ON MY MIND;
Gag That Man!

BYLINE: By A. M. Rosenthal

 BODY:
Some of those people in Washington really have their nerve.
Take what happened last week. The deputy director of the National Security Council had the gall to propose saying a few public words about how Mikhail Gorbachev was having some very serious economic and nationality problems and how it was not a foregone conclusion that perestroika would work.
Bush Administration people have said something like that before. But that was in the old days - a few weeks ago. 
Since then, the Bush Administration and the Baker State Department have become hugely enthusiastic about the American commitment to perestroika - reforming and preserving Soviet Communism through Soviet Communism and Western help.
Now they see political gain in get-ting on the Gorbachev bandwagon and none in raising pesky questions.
So you can understand how irritated Secretary of State James Baker was when he heard that Robert M. Gates had had the impertinence to propose making a little speech that might dampen the euphoria about the perestroika the Administration is promoting.
Then, as Tom Friedman of The New York Times reported en route to his 12th Pulitzer Prize, Mr. Baker made the right call; no more speech.
It does not take long for a top bureaucrat to try to put a mental fence marked ''no trespassing'' around his department.
Also, Gorbachev zealots in the United States keep telling President Bush and Mr. Baker they better hurry up and build an American ''consensus'' about foreign policy in support of the Soviet leader, his present and his future. Otherwise, they say, watch out - we will call you a wimp again.
Like most top bureaucrats - political, governmental, business and even, Heaven help us, journalistic - Mr. Baker seems to think ''consensus'' is another way to say yes, sir!
Russian bureaucrats even have a proverb for it: Every little vegetable has its season. In translation: Shut your mouth.
So silencing Mr. Gates may be within Mr. Baker's bureaucratic clout-prerogative. But the rest of us are not bureaucrats. What is best for Mr. Baker's blood pressure may not be best for what we laughingly call the intellectual climate of the country.
But what is disappointing is not so much Mr. Baker's automatic reaction - silence, small vegetable - but the acquiescence and even praise with which it has been received in the intellectual community.
One of my favorite editorial writing friends, versed in government ways, is even suggesting that to win more political strength at home President Bush should jump right in to help shut off the ''confusion'' of dissenting voices.
The argument is also used that if Bush-Baker do not whip everybody into line, some Administration officials may even argue about the terms of arms treaties or economic assistance to the Soviet Union.
Isn't that part of what they are getting paid to do? Remember whistle blowers? When Mr. Gates wants to sound a little peep, the reaction of Administration bureaucrats, and ex-bureaucrats, is: Gag that man.
But let's not the rest of us think as bureaucrats or former bureaucrats. Few things are more important to debate now than American policy toward the future of the Soviet Union.
Is Mr. Gorbachev the issue? Or is it how we can help the Soviet Union achieve a future free of the restraints and powers of the Soviet system, which he still holds in his hand?
It is even possible Mr. Gorbachev may be part of that future; it is difficult to predict the limits of his flexibility.
But even to suggest real discussion brings floods of denunciation: You want to destroy Gorbachev and bring on Russian Fascism.
If Mr. Gorbachev can be destroyed by some honest discussion in the United States, the man is a gone goose.
Another argument that must give him a good chuckle: If anybody in the Administration raises public questions about bandwagoning, Mr. Gorbachev will not sign the arms control agreements he wants to sign. That is not only an insult to the Administration's political sophistication but to Mr. Gorbachev's, which he has already demonstrated is much higher.
The issue of the moment is not perestroika. It is the right of a responsible public official like Mr. Gates to discuss it candidly. It is a pity that a man as intelligent as Mr. Baker chose to exercise his ability to shut Mr. Gates up.
Anyway, with a nod of appreciation for Mr. Gates's attempt, let's be happy that you and I do not grow in any Government garden, and never have.

HEADLINE: IN THE NATION;
Bush's Acid Test

BYLINE: By Tom Wicker

 BODY:
President Bush's much-ballyhooed clean air proposals took a beating in a House committee but he still can push his innovative acid-rain program through Congress - if he throws the full weight of his Administration and his own prestige behind it.
If not, his growing reputation for ''waffling'' will be furthered and his early credits as an environmentalist will be lost. Already, Mr. Bush has failed to call the White House environmental conference for this year that he promised in his campaign, and he seems reluctant to join the industrialized world in moving against global warming - perhaps because John Sununu, his chief of staff, is reported to believe the problem does not yet require action.
Mr. Sununu also was ingloriously involved in one of the Administration's most embarrassing setbacks -when that House committee threw out Mr. Bush's plan requiring the automobile industry to build and sell, in the nation's nine most polluted cities, one million alternative-fuel cars by 1997. It was not just that the committee surrendered to the industry, merely requiring it to certify its capacity to build the cars; Mr. Sununu was reported to have undercut the Bush proposal, while William Reilly, the director of the Environmental Protection Agency, was supporting it. 
That produced charges that the Administration was ''all over the lot'' while George Bush was nowhere. Then the committee gave him the back of its hand again, stiffening far beyond his desires the proposals he had sent up for reducing pol-lutants emitted from automobile tailpipes.
Mr. Bush's acid-rain plan is still on the table, however, though it faces stiff opposition in both houses. Environmental sources believe it still can be approved, if the President and the Senate majority leader, George Mitchell, join forces in supporting it. Mr. Mitchell has every reason to do so, since his home state, Maine, is a major sufferer from acid rain and he is trying to overcome the Democrats' reputation as big spenders.
The Bush plan sets a tough and permanent cap on pollutants that cause acid rain, emitted from 107 plants in 18 states. The plan requires a reduction of 10 million tons of sulfur dioxide (about half the total now spewed into the air) and two million tons of oxides of nitrogen over the next 10 years -far greater emission cuts than the affected industries wanted.
They could achieve specified reductions in pollutants by any of several methods - installing smokestack scrubbers, switching to low-sulfur coal, encouraging consumer conservation of electricity, adopting new technologies, or any combination of the above. The Administration and the Environmental Defense Fund -which helped devise the plan - contend that this would be less costly than requiring the plants to install scrubbers, with Government subsidizing the expense.
Costs could be further reduced by a daring ''market approach.'' If one plant cut its pollutants more than required, it could sell its overage to another plant that had not sufficiently reduced its emissions. The buying plant then could subtract that amount of pollutants from the reductions it otherwise would have to achieve. The costs to both would be lowered - to the selling plant by the proceeds of the sale, to the buyer in the reduced costs of reaching a smaller quota.
That is not ''selling pollution rights,'' as some critics have called it, since the total required reduction of sulfur dioxide and oxides of nitrogen still would have to be achieved. Nor is the whole program ''anti-growth,'' as critics also allege. To reduce the emission of pollutants is not necessarily to restrain the capacity for economic growth or plant expansion. When the benefits of an end to acid rain - which kills lakes, rivers, animal and plant life, and even damages structures - are included, the cost-benefit ratio heavily supports Mr. Bush's program.
But will Congress support it? That may depend on the Senate, where action on acid rain is expected first and might well influence the House. The former majority leader, Senator Robert Byrd of West Virginia, a high-sulfur-coal state, leads the formidable opposition of other such states and of the Midwestern utilities most affected.
That only gives George Bush the opportunity to prove two things now in doubt: his commitment to environmentalism and his resolution as a political leader.

HEADLINE: U.S.-Soviet Citizen Forum: Fewer Rifts Now

BYLINE: By ROBERT PEAR, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: PITTSBURGH, Oct. 30

 BODY:
Soviet and American citizens celebrated the improvement in relations between their two nations today as they met here for their fifth annual exercise in people-to-people diplomacy. But the occasion was marred by American concern about a Soviet editor who was not allowed to attend.
Officials from the two countries, speaking at the conference sponsored by the University of Pittsburgh and the Chautauqua Institution, said they hoped that they could reach significant agreements to reduce both conventional and nuclear weapons before the summit meeting tentatively planned for late spring or early summer of 1990.
Vladimir F. Petrovsky, a Soviet Deputy Foreign Minister, said such agreements, including one to reduce strategic offensive arms by 50 percent, were possible if ''both sides make vigorous efforts.'' Such a timetable is highly optimistic and would require spectacularly rapid progress by arms negotiators. 
The Chautauqua conferences, which began a few months after Mikhail S. Gorbachev took power in 1985, have become a barometer of Soviet-American relations, marked in the past by fierce debates and ideological fireworks. But there are fewer points of contention this year, and the conference has become a forum for charting cooperation on economic matters.
 
Pittsburgh's Perestroika
Senator John Heinz, Republican of Pennsylvania, and Wesley W. Posvar, president of the University of Pittsburgh, said the Soviets could learn many lessons about perestroika from Pittsburgh, which has restructured its economy in the last decade, with the demise of big steel plants and the rise of high-technology industries.
Vladislav A. Starkov, chief editor of the weekly tabloid Argumenty i Fakty, had been scheduled to attend the conference, but he is not here. A senior member of the staff of the Central Committee of the Soviet Communist Party, Leonid N. Dobrokhotov, said Mr. Starkov had been ''advised'' to remain in Moscow.
''It was not punishment,'' the party official said. ''He is a Communist. We have the right to advise members of the party to do something or not to do something. He agreed with it.''
Mr. Starkov published a reader survey that cast doubt on President Gorbachev's popularity and glorified his more radical critics.
Vladimir V. Pozner, the Soviet television commentator who is serving as a moderator for some of the sessions here, expressed ''sympathy and support'' for his journalistic colleague. He deplored the effort to remove Mr. Starkov, who he said was ''fighting back.''
American delegates said the exclusion of Mr. Starkov was inconsistent with the spirit of Chautauqua, an intellectual, ecumenical retreat in western New York that promotes cultural exchanges and uncensored debate on political issues.
 
Wide Range of Topics
Among the topics to be discussed by Soviet and American experts in open sessions at the six-day conference this week are trade and economics, arms control, human rights, the role of ''women in contemporary society,'' regional conflicts, drug abuse, the exploration of outer space and environmental issues like acid rain and global warming.
At the insistence of Soviet officials, the program also includes discussions of ''religious pluralism'' and ethnic diversity in the Soviet Union and the United States.
Seventy-nine families in the Pittsburgh area have opened their homes to members of the Soviet delegation, who are sampling American supermarkets, pizza parlors, and sports events.
The United States Government strongly supports this type of citizen diplomacy, and the United States Information Agency helps with the arrangements.
Surveying Soviet-American relations, Curtis W. Kamman, a Deputy Assistant Secretary of State, said the two nations were no longer just adversaries, but ''cooperative partners in certain respects.''
''A key difference is the fact that the ideological component of U.S.-Soviet relations has diminished,'' he said. ''This has allowed both countries to move away from an ideological prism and thus find a more realistic and pragmatic way of tackling problems.''
 
Nicaragua Issue Raised
Mr. Kamman called on the Soviet Union to make sure that the Government of Nicaragua did not resume combat operations against guerrilla forces backed by the United States. President Daniel Ortega Saavedra of Nicaragua has threatened to break the 19-month truce because of renewed attacks by the contras. Mr. Kamman complained that the continued shipment of arms to Nicaragua from Soviet bloc countries ''makes it much more difficult'' to have free elections of the type promised for February 1990.
Mr. Petrovsky said the Soviet Union had agreed to ''desist from shipping arms to Nicaragua'' as part of an effort to promote a political settlement there.
More generally, Mr. Petrovsky said that Moscow wanted to ''become an equal and predictable member of the civilized community of nations.''

HEADLINE: Kean's Popularity Is Little Help to Courter

BYLINE: By PETER KERR

DATELINE: TRENTON, Oct. 30

 BODY:
The popularity of New Jersey's best-known Republican, Gov. Thomas H. Kean, has been of little help this fall to his own party and its candidate for governor, Representative Jim Courter.
One reason, both Republican and Democratic leaders say, is Mr. Kean's aloof style of leadership, which has often separated the Governor from controversies over his two terms and now has kept him at arm's length from the struggling Courter campaign.
In addition, Mr. Kean's liberal positions set him apart from the national party and from Mr. Courter, and he has made little effort to conceal his differences.
Mr. Kean has publicly differed with Mr. Courter on the death penalty, automobile insurance, abortion, whether gay teachers should be allowed to teach children, whether AIDS-infected students should be admitted to classrooms with other children, and Mr. Courter's pledge not to raise taxes. 
The Governor also criticized Mr. Courter, along with his Democratic opponent, Representative James J. Florio, for their negative television commercials and the assaultive tone of the second television debate between the candidates, on Oct. 11.
 
Kean Rejects Television Script
Recently Mr. Kean rejected the script for a Courter commercial that would have had the Governor make a tough attack on the Democrat.
In recent weeks leaders of the Courter campaign and top members of the party have said that they believe Mr. Kean could have campaigned harder for Mr. Courter in the summer and early fall. ''The feeling is that sometime this summer Tom or his advisers decided not to give this thing their all,'' said one prominent Republican member of the Legislature.
''After looking at what Kean has been saying over the years and some of the statements by Courter this summer, it's a position that makes some sense,'' the lawmaker concluded.
Recent polls show that just four years after Mr. Kean won re-election with 70 percent of the vote, Mr. Courter is failing to attract the independents and Democrats who voted for Mr. Kean, Ronald Reagan and George Bush throughout the 1980's.
But aides to the Governor say Mr. Kean has done whatever the Courter campaign has asked. After criticism by members of the Courter campaign and other Republicans appeared last week in The Washington Times, Mr. Kean immediately began making daily campaign appearances with the Republican nominee.
In contrast to his usual policy of freely responding to the press, Mr. Kean repeatedly declined to be interviewed on the subject of his relations with the Courter campaign.
Carl Golden, the Governor's press secretary, said that even before that criticism became public, Mr. Kean had made 14 appearances with Mr. Courter. The problems that Mr. Courter experienced, he said, were beyond the Governor's control.
''Tom Kean has done everything he can to help Jim Courter,'' Mr. Golden said. '' The people who are attempting to lay the blame on Tom Kean are doing so for self-serving reasons.''
In any case, Mr. Florio has played off of the differences between the two Republicans, arguing that he is more likely than Mr. Courter to continue Governor Kean's initiatives. He points to votes in Congress on the environment and transportation where Mr. Florio voted for the positions endorsed by Mr. Kean and Mr. Courter did not.
This weekend, for example, the Florio campaign quoted an editorial endorsement by The Atlantic City Press, which said Mr. Florio was more likely than Mr. Courter to continue the policies of Mr. Kean.
''On a lot of issues where it comes down to what are your values, it is a fact that Governor Kean and Congressman Florio have been closer to each other than either have been to Congressman Courter,'' said Jon Shure, Mr. Florio's press secretary.
 
A Patrician's Diction
Over the past eight years Governor Kean practiced an eclectic politics that many politicians say has resonated almost perfectly with the sentiments of the era. Though he championed free-market economics, he also spoke out forcefully on environmental issues and on behalf of minorities, and maintained a quiet liberal line on social issues like abortion and homosexual rights.
Brandishing a buoyant smile and a patrician's diction, Mr. Kean often appeared to be not just a partisan advocate, but a personification of New Jersey in resurgence. Under what he called the ''politics of inclusion,'' he helped attract large numbers of white Democrats in 1985, along with a majority of black voters.
While voters in 1980 and 1981 favored the Democratic Party by 31 percent to 22 percent, voter preferences are nearly equal today, according to studies by the Eagleton Institute of politics at Rutgers University.
But critics of Mr. Kean charge that he exercised a kind of removed leadership, and often refused to spend his political capital on controversial issues. Democrats have charged that Mr. Kean's successor will immediately have to face the problems Mr. Kean failed to solve, including a disastrously-managed automobile insurance system, rising property taxes and widespread overdevelopment.
 
Swinging at Easy Balls
''You don't get into the record books by only swinging at the easy balls,'' said Assemblyman Alan J. Karcher, a Democrat who was one of Mr. Kean's major foes in his first term.
In recent weeks, criticism of Mr. Kean's distant style has come from Republicans who have watched mishaps plague Mr. Courter's campaign. Last year, the Governor promised to endorse a candidate to succeed him this year, a choice which many party leaders hoped would avoid a bitter battle for the nomination.
Mr. Kean, however, never did endorse a candidate for the nomination and Republicans fought an expensive and tiring race. Meanwhile, Mr. Florio, who faced only minor opposition in the Democratic primary, concentrated on organizing his fall campaign.
In the summer the Governor, aides say, was upset by Mr. Courter's remarks on abortion and his advocacy of a ban on homosexual teachers. During those weeks, Mr. Courter made few indications he would continue Mr. Kean's policies and appeared far to the right of the incumbent.
 
Pushes for Courter Staff Change
In mid-September, said people familiar with the meeting, Mr. Kean and his top aides told Mr. Courter that he was under the influence of conservative Republicans from Washington who did not understand the state. They pressed to replace his campaign manager, Kenneth Connolly, with Roger Bodman, a Republican consultant who had managed Mr. Kean's campaigns. Mr. Courter agreed, but Mr. Bodman changed his mind the next morning and refused to take the job.
Mr. Connolly has remained in charge, together with Roger Ailes, President Bush's media adviser.
''The perception that Kean is not actively helping him has hurt Courter,'' said Stephen Salmore, a professor at the Eagleton Institute of Politics at Rutgers, who is advising the Republican Party.
''Whether that perception is reality is not clear,'' Mr. Salmore added. ''The Courter campaign has not tried to focus on continuity with the Kean administration. And that has made it difficult for Kean to do much. Kean truly does not believe in arm-twisting. That is not his style.''

HEADLINE: The Mayoral Candidates' Basic Speeches: Laments Followed by Proposals;
Dinkins: I Intend to be Toughest Mayor on Crime This City Has Ever Seen

 BODY:
The New York City mayoral candidates give dozens of speeches. Sometimes they address a particular issue or audience in a particular way. More often they use a ''basic speech'' that varies little from one occasion to the next. These are the basic speeches of Rudolph W. Giuliani, the Republican-Liberal candidate, and David N. Dinkins, the Democratic candidate:
Let me take a couple of minutes to tell you my view, my vision of what it means to be a Democrat in New York in 1989. We Democrats believe that government should be an agent for change, that government can't afford to stand on the sidelines and that it belongs on the side of communities fighting back against crime and drugs.
It belongs on the side of activists and builders working to create affordable housing, on the side of people with AIDS, on the side of parents, teachers, principals and students who are struggling to make our schools drug-free zones, where our kids learn more about reading and math and less about cocaine and crack. 
Let me say it as plainly as I can: I hate drugs and what they're doing to our children and our neighborhoods. This greatest of urban centers, this city that we care about, is a city under siege. Whole neighborhoods are fast becoming free-fire zones. Some of our housing projects have become base camps for drug dealers, and, too often, we hear of roving gangs' terrorizing our subways, our streets and our parks.
My first term as mayor I will double the number of community-patrol police officers on the beat term. And I will guarantee that there will be a cop on every subway train every night in the year. And I intend to fund community anti-crime groups in every borough, and I'll re-dedicate our criminal-justice system to a very basic proposition.
 
'Learn to Respect'
Every crime must be punished. I don't care if it's your first offense. I don't care if you just stole a car for the night or if you just took a few dollars from a kid on the street. If you commit a crime and are caught, you'll learn to respect the law and the system.
You will because you will punished, no excuses, no apologies. This is one marine who believes in the value of discipline and respect. And I'm going to make sure that some young guys get a whole lot of it early on, when they still have a chance to turn their lives around.
In the next four years, we're going to fight back against crime and drugs. I intend to be the toughest mayor on crime this city has ever seen. You know, I have a wife, I have children, a little boy and a little girl, ages 35 and 32 - they used to be little. But I have a grandson, and he really is little. He's only 3 years old, and my daughter is going to bring me another grandchild. I hope a daughter. And I care about them, and I want to make sure they're safe. And I want your children and your grandchildren to be safe.
So, with your help, I intend to be a mayor who draws on the strength of each of us to lead New York into the future. Together, we will protect our neighborhoods and preserve our environment. We will build up our economy and tear down barriers and secure social justice, from job care to health care to affordable housing. Most of all, I will reach out to all the family of New York. I will fight for you and speak for you.
 
Plea to Unions
I will not pretend that leading this city into the 90's will be easy. Our economy is slowing. Challenges are mounting. And with this year's budget gap now estimated at $500 million, it's clear that the next mayor will have to make some tough choices.
But I'm prepared to do that. And I'm already hard at work, quietly and diligently, to assist in solving the city's current fiscal situation.
I know that the trade-union movement understands the challenges of governing New York during lean times. For it was the labor movement that pitched into help during the fiscal crisis, to restore this city to solvency and fiscal balance. People tend to forget that, you know. I'm going to remind them.
While we don't face that kind of crisis today, the next mayor will have to start from a basic proposition. Quite simply, you can't bargain away what you don't have, and the city will be hard pressed to meet all of the many challenges we face in the coming years. . . .
My friends in labor, like my friends in business and my friends in government, know that I'm a firm and fair negotiator. They know I will bargain hard to increase the productivity and efficiency of the city work force. And I'm confident that we'll be able to sit down and strike a reasonable, fair, prudent agreement on the next round of municipal contracts.
 
Three Costly Challenges
This city faces many costly challenges - drugs, housing and AIDS -just to name three. And my highest priority will be to see that we invest in our $26.6 billion budget wisely, so as to meet the challenges of the 90's.
But working together, all together, we will be able to make this city livable and workable and create a future of opportunity and prosperity for all New Yorkers. And together we will re-establish and reaffirm the progressive values that are New York's best heritage and hope. ...
So let us come together now as New Yorkers in a great coalition stands for progessive principles, that appeals to what is best in our people and that seeks to expand the frontiers of justice and opportunity. Let us give new life to the values given to each of us in our time by John Kennedy and Robert Kennedy and Martin Luther King Jr. For too long from the center of power in this nation, we have heard only a summons to selfishness. Meanwhile, our national government is evading the emergency of urban America. We have seen the wealthiest prosper at the expense of the poor and the middle class. We watched bombs increase while hope declines. . . .
It's time in this city to determine the next mayor to open a new path to progress. I hope you will walk that path with me. And victory in November is only the beginning of the journey. We won't finish it overnight. But we will renew our hopes and our aspirations. We will be activists and strong and determined. We will make this city work. We will make it safe, and we will bring New York together.
In closing, let me recall and adapt the words of President John Kennedy in the last speech he ever made in our city, because his thoughts apply in this moment in our history. ''It is essential,'' John Kennedy said, ''that the word go forth to all who are concerned about the future of the family of New York that we are not weary in well doing. And I am confident, if we maintain the pace, that we shall in due season reap the kind of city we deserve and deserve the kind of city we will have.''

COMPANIES

HEADLINE: Sales Dip Deflates Hyundai Bubble

BYLINE: By RICHARD W. STEVENSON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES, Oct. 30

 BODY:
Just three years after engineering one of the most successful imported-car introductions in the United States, the Hyundai Group has hit a rough patch.
Sales of the South Korean company's subcompact Excel model have dropped sharply this year as its price has risen, as domestic and foreign competitors have grown more aggressive in a weak auto-sales market, and as buyers have tired of the Excel's three-year-old styling.
Hyundai's relations with its 310 dealers in the United States have become strained, and in the last few months the company has lost three of its top American managers.
But analysts and Hyundai executives and dealers say that the company's problems are not irreversible and that it is not unusual for importers to suffer growing pains as they move beyond the introduction of their first car. But they say Hyundai's woes clearly reflect its biggest strategic misstep - a slowness to bring on new models - as well as the perils of competition in a weak market for auto sales. 
With an initial base price of $4,995 and styling drawn heavily from pricier Japanese competitors, the Excel quickly became a hit with first-time buyers and others seeking affordable ''cars that make sense,'' as the company's advertising slogan put it. Within a year, Hyundai trailed only Toyota, Nissan and Honda among all foreign car makers in import sales in the United States.
 
'Ran Out of Customers'
''They sold 700,000-plus of the Excel model over several years without changing it, and they just ran out of customers to buy it,'' said J. David Power of J. D. Power & Associates, an automotive consulting firm in Westlake Village, Calif. ''They didn't get the next generation of styling on stream fast enough, and the market changed very rapidly on them.''
Through the first nine months of this year, Hyundai sold 146,042 cars in the United States, down 30 percent from the corresponding period of last year. For all of 1989, Hyundai Motor America, the company's sales and marketing arm in the United States has already slashed its sales projection to 200,000 cars, from 300,000, and some analysts think Hyundai will fall short of the lower figure. In 1988, Hyundai sold 264,282 cars in the United States, up slightly from 1987.
''We started with such a bang that the manufacturer didn't think there was much urgency to bring on new models,'' said Bob Brest, a Hyundai dealer in Lynn, Mass. ''They probably got a little complacent, and when things turned down, they turned down very quickly.''
 
Another Executive Quits
Earlier this month, Hyundai Motor America said it was eliminating 50 of the 600 jobs at its headquarters in Garden Grove, Calif., south of Los Angeles. At the same time, it announced the resignation of W. Greg Warner, the only remaining executive of three Americans who had led Hyundai's introduction into the United States.
The company attributed Mr. Warner's departure to ''differences regarding business direction'' with executives of the South Korean parent company, and analysts said there had long been strains between the Korean and American managers. Mr. Warner did not return telephone calls.
The company is now searching for a new chief operating officer to serve as second in command to H. W. Baik, the Korean president of Hyundai Motor America.
Hyundai Group, one of South Korea's largest companies, is engaged in shipbuilding and shipping, steelmaking, electronics, construction and other businesses in addition to automobiles. Its sales last year are estimated at $18 billion.
While the domestic South Korean auto market remains very important to Hyundai, the company's investment in North America is growing. In January, the company opened a $325 million assembly plant in Quebec to serve the United States and Canada, and is now building a $100 million metal-stamping plant on an adjacent site to make components.
Hyundai executives say their product line remains strong, with few quality complaints, and they will be able to re-establish themselves as a maker of cars that rival the Japanese in looks, options and reliability, but at a significantly lower price.
''We see this as a temporary setback,'' said Debbie Douglas, a spokeswoman for Hyundai Motor America. ''We have a lot of new and exciting products for 1990.''
 
Bigger Car, but Poor Sales
Hyundai faces a formidable task. After three years of selling only the original Excel model, Hyundai last winter introduced the Sonata, a four-door sedan with a base price of $9,999 that is intended to compete with larger cars like the Toyota Camry and the Honda Accord, both of which generally sell for several thousand dollars more.
Sales of the Sonata have been disappointing. Cynthia Certo, director of forecasting for Integrated Automotive Resources, a consulting firm, said Hyundai had projected in January that it would sell 80,000 Sonatas this year. Through September, only 26,115 had been sold.
While the car has received generally good performance reviews, it was introduced in a weak market that has forced all manufacturers - even those like Honda that had previously avoided widespread rebates and other promotions - to become intensely competitive, especially in the market for midsized cars. Even with a price advantage, the Sonata suffers from Hyundai's relatively low volume of advertising and lack of a clear image in this country, analysts said.
''Somehow, they've got to get that car on the buyer's consideration list, and so far they haven't done that,'' said Dennis Keene of the Keene Consulting Group, an automotive consulting firm.
Hyundai is now bringing out a more powerful Sonata with a V-6 engine, and it plans to introduce a sporty coupe within months. But the company is by no means abandoning the subcompact market. It is introducing a version of the Excel with more power, a roomier interior and new styling. It has a base price of $5,899.
 
More Competition for Excel
But the low end of the market has also become increasingly competitive since the original Excel made its initial splash. Appreciation of South Korea's currency, the won, and wage increases in Korea have diminished Hyundai's price advantage over both imported and domestic competitors, like General Motors' Geo Prizm, the Toyota Tercel and the Nissan Sentra. The Excel's rivals in this country now include two Korean-made cars, the Pontiac LeMans, built by the Daewoo Motor Company, and the Ford Festiva, built by Kia.
Moreover, competitors have been aggressive in offering rebates and financing deals on slightly bigger compact cars, prompting many buyers to pay a little more for a larger car.
''The larger the incentives you have on those attractive larger cars, the worse it gets for 'econoboxes' like the Excel,'' Ms. Certo said. ''The small-car market is going to shrink dramatically over the next several years, and it's doubtful that the Excel will ever reach the sales levels it did in prior years.''
Hyundai was also hurt by the poor creditworthiness of many buyers, a problem for other makers of entry-level cars. As defaults mounted among low-income and first-time purchasers, Hyundai dealers found it more difficult to help other buyers obtain financing. Hyundai is trying to solve that problem by setting up its own financing company.
 
Big Dealer Investments
Dealers have been increasingly worried about whether the large investments in showrooms required by Hyundai will pay off now that sales have slipped. Hyundai had required stand-alone dealerships, and even asked franchisees to buy showroom furniture from the company. Since sales have dropped, however, some dealers have started selling Hyundais alongside other makes with the manufacturer's grudging permission.
The company is also planning a big advertising push for the 1990 cars in the next few weeks and plans to increase advertising spending for the coming year, apparently responding to dealer criticism that its marketing has not been aggressive enough.
For all their gripes about the company's performance in the last year, dealers say they remain convinced that the Korean company will do whatever it takes to turn around the situation. ''They told us, 'We are in the States for good,' '' said Richard Kim, a dealer in Los Angeles who recently traveled to South Korea to meet with Hyundai executives.
