LENGTH: 953 words

HEADLINE: Dollar Takes Its Cue From Stocks

BYLINE: By JONATHAN FUERBRINGER

 BODY:
Something different is happening in the foreign exchange market. In a reversal of the recent pattern, the dollar is being led around by the stock market.
The change came with the 190-point drop in the Dow Jones industrial average on Oct. 13. In the uncertain days since, the stock market has taken over from the foreign exchange market as the barometer for the financial markets. 
Currency traders' eyes remain on the Dow as stock trading begins in New York at 9:30 A.M. and throughout the day. It seems that even a little move in the stock market, especially down, causes the dollar to twitch.
 
Lower Rates, Lower Dollar
True, the dollar has not tracked the stock market exactly in the last two weeks. And traders acknowledge that part of the impact on the dollar is not the stock market directly but that the sudden stock market plunges have forced the Federal Reserve to ease interest rates already and may force further moves in the future. Lower rates will push the dollar lower.
But it is clear, traders said, that the stock market is sending out its own tremors. And because foreign exchange traders, like moths, are attracted to a simple signal to guide their dealing, these tremors are no longer being ignored.
''For the first time in a while we are following the stock market,'' said Liliana Nealon, vice president at Union Bank of Switzerland in New York.
''The foreign exchange market sometimes gets myopic; it focuses on one thing,'' said Frank Watson, vice president of the Swiss Bank Corporation in New York. ''And in the last couple of weeks that has been the stock market. The one clear signal to sell dollars is when the Dow goes down.''
Before October, the dollar had been setting the pace. For a year or more, the dollar, rising or falling, had generally led the stock, bond and other markets. This is because the foreign exchange market has been the arena where opinions, especially from abroad, have been expressed most quickly about the health and attractiveness of the American economy.
The foreign exchange market has also been where the United States and its economic allies have best been able to express their policy intentions through dollar selling, economic communiques and the movement of interest rates.
And it is likely that the foreign exchange market will return to this leading role when the outlook for the stock market and the economy improves.
For now, economists and foreign exchange traders said the switch means that the dollar is headed downward, although many argue that the dollar is not headed for a sharp plunge unless something much worse happens to stocks.
It is a change that should please the United States and its economic allies, which have fought all summer to end a persistent dollar rally that pushed it well above the ceilings believed to have been set for it - 1.90 marks and 140 yen. Since Oct. 13, when the dollar stood at 1.9075 marks and 144.15 yen, it has fallen sharply, closing yesterday at 1.8340 marks and 141.85 yen.
 
Roles Are Reversed
With the roles now reversed, a strong dollar rally on Friday was crushed as the stock market, as measured by the Dow average fell 32 points. Even when the market rallied late in the day, the dollar had lost its steam and ended down for the day against most currencies.
On Thursday, another rally was squelched as the stock market slumped, wiping out most, but not all, of the gains for the day. And last Tuesday, when the market fell more than 80 points in the morning before recovering, the dollar dutifully followed, declining and then rallying a little on the rebound.
Yesterday, the dollar rose a little as the Dow Jones industrial average posted its first gain in five trading days.
There are two reasons for the role reversal, which has quickly dulled the bullish attitude that had helped push the dollar above 2 marks and 150 yen this spring and allowed it to remain strong despite coordinated central bank intervention and interest-rate increases in Europe and Japan.
The plunge in the market, some analysts argued, woke up traders to the negative statistics on the economy and the dollar that they had been ignoring. This news included the employment report for September, the rise of interest rates by one percentage point in most of Europe and the increase of the discount rate in Japan. At the time of the announcements the dollar pretty much shrugged off the impact.
''I think there have been a lot of negatives for the dollar recently,'' said Geoffrey Dennis, chief international economist at James Capel Inc. in New York. ''But it took the stock market to make traders pay attention.''
 
Ease in Rates Unexpected
The second reason is that the plunge in the stock market has forced the Federal Reserve to ease interest rates slightly, a move that was not expected this soon.
When the United States and its allies in the Group of Seven announced in September that the dollar was too high, they aggressively sold the currency and interest rates rose in Europe and Japan. But analysts said it would take a lowering of interest rates in the United States to close the policy loop and really bring the dollar down. Now this is happening.
If there are any more sharp plunges in the stock market, traders are likely to assume that the Fed may have to ease rates further in an effort to make sure the market has the liquidity it needs to function normally.
This would put more downward pressure on the dollar. When interest rates fall here and rise abroad, the differential narrows, making investing in dollar-denominated securities less attractive to foreign investors.
''Every bout of weakness,'' one top bank trader said, ''means the Fed has to be on its toes.''

HEADLINE: Mitsubishi Estate a Force In Japanese Real Estate

BYLINE: By JAMES STERNGOLD, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TOKYO, Tuesday, Oct. 31

 BODY:
When the brokers and investment bankers representing the Rockefeller Group went looking for a buyer with the cachet to match that of their prestigious client, they did not have to look far.
''Just about our first call went to Mitsubishi Estate,'' said a professional involved in the deal.
In fact, when Mitsubishi Estate was approached in the late summer, it agreed almost immediately to make a pre-emptive bid, ending any further discussions with other Japanese companies approached. Those included Mitsui Real Estate Development and Sumitomo Realty. 
Mitsubishi Estate is regarded as Japan's most prestigious real estate owner and developer. It developed and owns most of the buildings in one of Tokyo's premier commercial centers, the Marunouchi district, which borders the Imperial Gardens in the center of the city. Mitsubishi Estate is also pursuing a number of other large-scale development projects that are likely to keep it at the top of the Japanese real estate industry.
Still, even if the investment bankers were pleased with the quality of Mitsubishi Estate's image, there were political concerns driving the deal, some of those involved said. Mitsubishi Estate will acquire 51 percent of Rockefeller Group at first. Over the next two to three years, it will increase that holding to 80 percent, according to those involved.
The whole point of this complicated process was to avoid criticism in the United States. Many politicians and others in the United States have reacted negatively to huge Japanese acquisitions in the United States and in this instance the dealmakers wanted to soften the blow of yet another purchase of a highly visible American asset.
Mitsubishi Estate is a member of the Mitsubishi group of industrial and financial companies, a successor to one of the most powerful pre-war zaibatsu's, which had previously dominated the Japanese economy. Mitsubishi Trust and Mitsubishi Bank together own 11.4 percent of the real estate company, and other members of the group own more shares.
As of the end of the fiscal year that ended March 31, Mitsubishi Estate had assets of $7.6 billion, at current exchange rates. It had net profits of $250 million and sales of $1.93 billion. Slightly more than half of its sales came from leasing.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Treasury Securities Inch Higher

BYLINE: By KENNETH N. GILPIN

 BODY:
Prices of Treasury securities inched higher in very slow trading yesterday, as dealers awaited reports on economic activity in October.
Market participants said the survey due tomorrow from the nation's purchasing managers and a report on employment conditions scheduled for release on Friday will be focal points for trading.
Treasury market participants centered their attention yesterday on auctions of $2 billion worth of 51-day cash management bills and $15.6 billion of three- and six-month bills.
The short-term offerings were announced by the Treasury last week in order to raise cash to pay Social Security beneficiaries before the nation's debt ceiling of $2.87 trillion expires at midnight. 
Proceeds from the auctions will raise enough revenue for the Government so that it will remain solvent until Nov. 9. By then, Congress must enact legislation to raise the debt ceiling.
 
Short-Term Offerings
At the auctions, the three-month bills were offered at an average discount rate of 7.78 percent, up sharply from the 7.52 percent average rate at last week's auction.
Meanwhile, the six-month bills were sold at an average rate of 7.62 percent, up from an average rate of 7.50 percent a week earlier.
The 51-day cash management bills were sold at a discounted rate of 7.87 percent.
The short-term issues are merely a prelude to next month's quarterly refunding auctions, when around $30 billion worth of notes and bonds are expected to be sold.
''With all the supply coming, it is somewhat surprising the market did as well as it did,'' said Maury N. Harris, chief economist at Paine Webber Group Inc.
In late trading, the Treasury's 8 1/8 percent bonds of 2019 were offered at a price of 102 10/32, up 1/8 of a point, to yield 7.92 percent.
 
Secondary Note Trading
Among secondary Treasury note issues, the 8 percent 10-year notes were offered at 100 5/8, up 5/32, to yield 7.90 percent. And the 7 5/8 percent two-year notes were offered at 99 5/8, up 1/ 32, to yield 7.83 percent.
In other developments, the municipal bond market was encouraged as a $786.9 million offering of New York City general obligation bonds was snapped up by investors.
The issue, the second from New York in the past few weeks, comes at a time when doubts about the city's economic and political prospects have been rising.
''The deal apparently went very well,'' one municipal bond trader said. ''And the successful pricing helped the rest of the secondary market do better.''
Late yesterday, investment bankers at Goldman, Sachs & Company, the firm acting as lead manager for the underwriting, said the issue had sold out.
 
Broad Appeal
The officials said that a broad spectrum of individual investors, money managers and institutions - some of whom had not previously bought New York City bonds - bought the issue.
''Right now yields on all municipal securities, not just those issued by New York City, are at very attractive levels compared to Treasuries,'' one investment banker involved in the financing said. ''As a result, we saw a good bit of cross-over buying by accounts that were getting out of other securities and into municipals.''
For the second time this year, the New York City issue included an offering of taxable bonds.
Yields on the $55.9 million worth of taxable bonds range from 9 1/8 percent on issues that mature in 1994 to 9.90 percent on bonds maturing in 2010.
Yields on the $757.44 million of tax-exempt serial bonds sold yesterday range from 6.50 percent on bonds that mature Aug. 1, 1990, to 7.78 percent on bonds that mature in 2008.
The issue, which carries an A rating from Moody's Investors Service and an expected rating of A-minus from the Standard & Poor's Corporation, is to refinance bonds that mature over the next several years. The prospectus states that many of the issues to be refinanced mature in 1990 and 1991.
 
Budget Savings Claimed
City officials claim the refinancing will result in savings of $162 million in interest payments during the 1990 fiscal year and an additional $100 million in 1991.
After examining the contents of the refinancing package, however, some critics claimed yesterday that the savings would be far smaller than that.
''There is a modicum of real 'refunding' going on that may save the City $1 million or $2 million,'' said Robert C. Apfel, president of Robert C. Apfel & Company Inc., a capital markets consulting firm. ''All they are really doing is rolling debt that would mature over the next 12 months to 18 months over into the next 20 to 30 years.''
Steven J. Matthews, New York's assistant comptroller, said the issue ''is a restructuring of debt that produces both present value savings and budgetary savings and will allow the City to more accurately reflect the life of the asset that is being financed. This is not fiscal gimmickry.'' The successful New York City offering helped to push prices of outstanding City issues up by half a point, dealers said. Many City issues have been under pressure in recent sessions.
Participants in the secondary market for municipal bonds said prices of most other issues rose by 1/4 of a point to 3/8 of a point yesterday.
Acitivity in the secondary market for investment-grade corporate bonds was very sluggish, dealers said, with little or no change in prices.
The following are the results of yesterday's auction of three-month and six-month Treasury bills:

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
British Pound Makes Gains; Some Traders Are Cautious

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar was mixed against leading foreign currencies yesterday while the pound advanced for the first time since London was shaken last week by the departure of Nigel Lawson, the Chancellor of the Exchequer.
Gold prices slipped in domestic trading after rising overseas.
Analysts said investors spent the day squaring their positions after the pound declined sharply late last week. Mr. Lawson resigned on Thursday, spurring questions on whether British policy might change. 
Robert Ryan, an analyst with the Bank of New York, said the rise of the pound reflected short-covering, the buying of dollars to fulfill previous agreements to sell them.
The pound rose to $1.5825 in New York, up from $1.5795 late Friday, after closing earlier in London at $1.5785, up from $1.5750 on Friday.
Some dealers warned, however, that sentiment remained pessimistic toward the pound.
''You're bucking the trend if you try to take the pound higher right now,'' said a corporate dealer at an American bank in London. ''I'm not convinced the pound's fall has stopped.''
Overseas dealers said trading was lackluster as dealers waited for fresh economic news later in the week.
Late dollar rates in New York, compared with those of late Friday, included: 1.8340 West German marks, up from 1.8295; 1.6050 Swiss francs, up from 1.6005; 6.2265 French francs, up from 6.2150; 1,346.00 Italian lire, down from 1,348.00, and 1.1735 Canadian dollars, down from 1.1747.
The dollar rose to 141.85 yen in New York, from 141.75 late Friday.
Gold edged lower in New York after gains in foreign trading. Republic National Bank of New York quoted a late bid of $376.65 an ounce, down from $377.25 late Friday. Earlier, gold fell 50 cents to close at $377.80 on the Commodity Exchange in New York.
Silver prices also were mixed. An ounce of silver fell 3.8 cents, to $5.243, on the Comex.
